column2: LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Sam Oolie of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janis Lisbeth Oolie to Peter Marshall Berk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan S. Berk of Greenwich, Conn., and Stockbridge, Mass. A November wedding is planned.
LEAD: THEY say colds are all around us. I don't happen to have one at the moment but I must confess that there have been times in my life when I wished I did.

LEAD: AT the trial of John Gotti on assault and conspiracy charges in the shooting of a union official, the prosecution produced an incriminating witness and several incriminating tape recordings. But there were hitches.
LEAD: ''Mr. de Klerk, he is trying to start a new South Africa. At least he has got that direction.'' - Godfrey Qolweni, a 30-year-old dairy worker, in Khayelitsha, South Africa. [16:4.]

LEAD: Alfredo Kraus joined the cast of ''La Traviata'' at the Metropolitan Opera last week as his namesake Alfredo. This might seem like no particularly big deal; Mr. Kraus has sung four romantic tenor leads at the Met in the last two seasons, including Hoffmann this past December.
LEAD: Abercrombie & Kent/Continental Waterways, 1420 Kensington Road, Oak Brook, Ill. 60521 (708-954-2944; 800-323-7308 outside Illinois).
LEAD: Battle of Britain Anniversary

LEAD: For some 18 years, John Walker Jr. sold top military secrets to the Soviet Union, managing in the process to recruit his son, brother and best friend to help him. It's been estimated by some intelligence experts that Mr. Walker provided enough code-data information to alter significantly the balance of power between Russia and the United States.

LEAD: A wave of nostalgia for the 1950's and 60's is flowing through the fashion world. It can evoke a feeling of deja vu in women over the age of 40, but for the younger crowd it hails a sexy new way of dressing.

LEAD: EARLY WINTERS RESORT, a development company based in Bellevue, Wash., has disclosed plans for a $1 billion ski and summer resort five miles northeast of this northeastern Washington village. It would be the largest recreation development in the state.

LEAD: Not every pop-jazz singer matures as gracefully as Marilyn Maye, who is appearing at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street) through Feb. 17. It was nearly 30 years ago that Steve Allen discovered the singer in a Kansas City nightclub and made her a regular guest on his television show. She went on to record seven albums for RCA, to have the first successful recording of the title song from ''Cabaret'' and to win the praise of Ella

LEAD: The schedule left plenty of time for golf when the Tobacco Institute, the cigarette lobby, played host recently to about 35 members of Congress and their spouses at a Palm Springs resort. Anyone who thought the newly enacted Congressional ethics package barred lawmakers from accepting such freebies should look again.

LEAD: April wedding plans for Kathleen Hull Kelly and Keith Lambert Oberg have been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Luther Kelly of Norfolk, Va. Mr. Oberg is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Raymond Oberg of West Hartford, Conn.
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roger Perry of Rye, N.Y., have made known the June wedding plans of their daughter Amy Perry and Joshua Thomas Basseches, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Basseches of Washington.

LEAD: Milanese, or Milan-style, means that there will be parmigiano reggiano in the dish along with bread crumbs and eggs. Veal Milanese, rice Milanese and chicken Milanese all sound reasonably familiar. But salmon Milanese?
LEAD: The rate of unemployment soared nearly 600 percent last month after the Solidarity-led Government imposed a host of market-oriented economic changes.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT has pulled out more stops than usual for Black History Month; in Hartford alone, half a dozen or more shows are scheduled. Current attractions include a retrospective by the photographer Gordon Parks, at the State Legislative Office Building; a juried show by local black artists, at the Pump House Gallery in Bushnell Park, and ''Free Man,'' a documentary about the successful rebellion of a group of Africans on board the Spanish slave ship Amistad and the American antislavery movement, at the Connecticut Historical Society.

LEAD: Four attacks on students in France in the last two and a half years have prompted the University of Vermont to end its 23-year relationship with the University of Nice through the Vermont Overseas Study Program.
LEAD: EVOLUTION OF THE BRAIN Creation of the Self. By John C. Eccles. 282 pp. New York: Routledge. $29.95.
LEAD: ECLIPSE By Rene Belletto. Translated by Jeremy Leggatt. 312 pp. San Francisco: Mercury House. $20.95.

LEAD: Shaquille O'Neal had 20 points, 24 rebounds and a school-record 12 blocked shots and Louisiana State took advantage of Loyola Marymount's bad long-range shooting today and won, 148-141, in overtime.
LEAD: Frank Walker scored 22 points and Hofstra beat Delaware by 79-64 today in an East Coast Conference game.

LEAD: Deirdre Olivia Schaus is to be married in July to Christopher Enfield Painter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitfield Painter Jr. of Concord, Mass. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Farmington, Conn.

LEAD: Jerry Oster goes too far and pretty much gets away with it in INTERNAL AFFAIRS (Bantam, $16.95), a gritty, if implausible, New York City procedural in which the hero cop, Sgt. Joe Cullen of the internal affairs unit, never seems to visit his precinct house or turn in a work report.

LEAD: THE cruise industry, responding to the drastic political changes in Eastern Europe, is adding calls to rarely visited ports in Poland, Rumania, Bulgaria and the Soviet Union to its spring and summer itineraries. They include Memel in Lithuania, Constanta in Rumania and Batum in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: IT is hard for most of the world to focus these days on anything other than Europe, as events there tumble forward, pell-mell, and last week President Bush proved to be no exception. Not only did he propose, in his first State of the Union address, radical new cuts in Soviet and American combat forces, but he also gave Mikhail S.

LEAD: We were talking the other night about technology and inventions and automobiles. As usual in such discourse, there were few revelations, but one of the guys digressed into a story he had heard, and the simplicity of the idea blew us away.

LEAD: Having successfully petitioned New York City for landmark status for the Seagram Building on Park Avenue, the landlord is suing city officials for having extended the landmark designation to the Four Seasons restaurant at the skyscraper's base.

LEAD: Harsh U.S. Report on China Painting a harsher picture than that offered by the White House, a confidential State Department report speaks of pervasive and severe human rights violations. Page 26. The Help Flows Both Ways In an innovative education program in the Los Angeles suburb of Bellflower, juvenile delinquents act as teachers' assistants at a school for disabled children.

LEAD: The United States clinched a first-round Davis Cup victory over Mexico today as Rick Leach and Jim Pugh made a successful debut in Davis Cup play by beating Jorge Lozano and Leonardo Lavalle in doubles, 6-4, 6-7, 7-5.

LEAD: Thank you for the article on Carol Gilligan's work with adolescent girls. I understand that it is a moral study, but I am surprised that there is no mention of the fierce female biological change that takes place at about 12 years of age.
LEAD: BROWSERS' BOUTIQUES

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Harold Brooks of New York have made known the May wedding plans of their daughter, Suzette Margaret Brooks, and Seth James Masters, a son of Judith Bush of Sharon, Vt., and Dr. Roger D. Masters of South Woodstock, Vt.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Managers at most companies are required to give performance evaluations to their workers on a regular basis, usually at least once a year. While some executives say they enjoy the opportunity to provide thoughtful, constructive feedback that will help the worker meet clearly defined performance objectives, others - the majority, perhaps - would rather go to the dentist.

LEAD: Richard Wilson, the Oglala Sioux tribal president who was a principal target of dissident Indians who occupied Wounded Knee, S.D., for 71 days in 1973, died of complications from an enlarged heart and kidney failure Thursday at a hospital in Rapid City. He was 55 years old. The occupation of Wounded Knee, the historic village within the Pine Ridge Reservation, resulted in gunfights between the dissidents and Federal forces, with dozens of injuries and two Indians' deaths.

LEAD: The Jan. 14 reply by David Carey [''Costs of Cable: False Comparisons''] director of public affairs for Cablevision, to the Dec. 17 article [''Cable TV vs. Consumers: Battleground Emerges''] continues to distort the truth about Cablevision. Mr. Carey replies that on a cost-per-channel basis, we are paying less in 1989 than we did in 1986.

LEAD: Congratulations on a superb article; Trip Gabriel's ''Cliffhanger'' (Dec. 31) just makes it for the end of a decade. What fun to have the experience of climbing with Lynn Hill. Her arrival in New Paltz marks a definite upswing for women climbers. It's wonderful to be older and to have a younger woman as a role model.

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 7 2 THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes and consequences of his behavior. 2 6 3 VINELAND, by Thomas Pynchon.
LEAD: PALACE WALK By Naguib Mahfouz. Translated by William M. Hutchins and Olive E. Kenny. 498 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.95.

LEAD: ''Hey creepos i'm talking to you,'' Siouxsie Sioux sings, buttonholing her listeners in the first moments of the Creatures' album, ''Boomerang'' (Geffen 24275; LP, cassette and CD). ''You've got a problem.'' Actually, it's more than a problem - it's a chronic condition of ''self-hate and loathing,'' of pessimism, cynicism, despair and the willingness to broadcast every grim moment of it.
LEAD: A single building, a solid five-story structure from the days of the last Kaiser, houses more political groupings today than this capital has known since Hitler came to power 57 years ago.

LEAD: A delay of almost four weeks in the scheduled launching of the Hubble Space Telescope has forced the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to shuffle its 1990 space shuttle timetable, shifting one science mission from June to November and deferring a military flight until 1992.

LEAD: SILVER STALLION. By Ahn Junghyo. (Soho, $19.95.) After almost four decades, the Korean War has become a forgotten war. As the Korean journalist and translator Ahn Junghyo makes clear in his second novel to appear in English, what is even more forgotten, at least for Americans, is the impact that conflict had on the Koreans themselves.

LEAD: Next Wednesday, for the fifth time in a decade, New York City will try to sell an old public school at 51st Street and First Avenue that refuses to stay sold. The red-brick, Romanesque building, which opened as Public School 135 in 1892, then became the first home of the United Nations School in the 1940's, is now a shelter for homeless women.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A SAFE PLACE Laying the Groundwork of Psychotherapy. By Leston Havens. 162 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.50.

LEAD: In reference to your call for opinions on National Football League drug testing policies: the men playing the games today are big boys. They all know the risks and dangers of using and abusing drugs. I think the league should butt out and leave the individual teams to decide their own policies. Those teams with weak policies will end up out of the game because of weak, debilitated and jailed players.
LEAD: This was in the closing weeks of the 1985 season, while the Mets were running out of time. They had played a day game in Montreal on Saturday, and now they had a doubleheader on Sunday.
LEAD: ''I GOT news for you; your Prince Charming has come,'' declares an ardent, insistent short-order cook (Johnny) to a defensive, disbelieving waitress (Frankie).

LEAD: ENCLOSING a bathtub to give it the appearance of being set into a raised platform can transform a drab bathroom into a lavish one. The project involves building a framework around the tub by using ordinary 2-by-4 or 2-by-6 lumber, sheathing it with plywood and applying finish material like wood paneling or ceramic tile.

LEAD: Erich Leinsdorf - now in town for concerts with the New York Philharmonic - has reversed the usual career cycle of wandering youth followed by sedentary maturity. With a long history of music directorships behind him, Mr. Leinsdorf has forsaken permanence for guest conducting.

LEAD: The well-written article on the Chatham Fish and Game Protective Association (''From a Fish and Game Agency to a Friendly Social Center,'' Jan. 7) captured much of the flavor of the club, its past and present. The text must be corrected, however, in regard to the dues structure.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 WEB OF DREAMS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) The origin of a curse that has haunted a family of orphans in five previous novels. 2 15 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King.

LEAD: A bakery is alive and atonal in David Ives's ''Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread'' as two women, Philip Glass and a baker rap their way through a devastating send-up of this idiosyncratic composer. The play is the first of four in the Manhattan Punch Line's sixth annual festival of one-act comedies.

LEAD: Discounting the recommendations of the University of Wisconsin faculty, the chief executives of the 13-campus University of Wisconsin system and the campus here urged the Board of Regents last week to continue its affiliation with the Reserve Officers Training Corps.

LEAD: Even the most conscientious cartographers could not find Park Slope South on any map of Brooklyn. But it exists in the minds of real estate brokers, according to William J. Kane, a Brooklyn developer, and who knows, it may catch on as the new more-marketable name for the area west of Greenwood Cemetery and east of Gowanus Bay that up to now has been called Sunset Park.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Emma Willard School is a boarding school. As a close-knit community where adolescents away from home must look to community members for support and guidance, the boarding-school environment itself may be responsible, in part, for the morality of care voiced by the girls there. BONNIE A. BARSAMIAN

LEAD: IT seems only fitting that as we begin to celebrate the 20th anniversary of Earth Day, when we as a nation suddenly had an awareness of the importance of our environment, that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo rekindles this spirit with an environmental initiative that seeks to protect the natural and cultural beauty of New

LEAD: Q. Our master bedroom has six Thermopane windows. When the temperature outside drops below freezing, condensation forms on the inside of these windows and the water runs onto the sill. This room is the only one exposed to the outside on three sides and the only one with this problem. Our heat is set at 60 degrees during the night.

LEAD: The marriage of Patricia Anne Mahoney, a daughter of James J. Mahoney of Norwich, N.Y., and the late Mary McKenna Mahoney, to Richard Patrick Dempsey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Dempsey of Kennebunk, Me., took place yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich Village. The Rev.

LEAD: A credit line in the Arts and Leisure section on Jan. 21 with a picture of Dylan Thomas misidentified the photographer, and a correction today on page 32 of the section refers to her incorrectly. She is Rollie McKenna.

LEAD: Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said today that 195,000 is the minimum number of troops that the United States needs to keep in central Europe if a new East-West agreement is reached on cutting conventional forces in Europe.

LEAD: Doug Elkins is a product of his time if ever there was one, a choreographer who creates dance bytes and skillfully chains them into a fast-paced flow of visual information that is almost as overwhelming as the aural information offered by his collage-style scores.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BARCELONA is a city of innate theatricality. It is a theatricality that springs, in large part, from the vivid contrasts that make Barcelona so engaging. Laundry hangs from lines draped across apartment houses on some of the most cosmospolitan of streets. A city plaza that bursts with Saturday night street-fair festivities, complete with the skulking ladrones and murmuring gitanos - petty thieves and gypsies - that tourists are warned about, is taken over by elderly men selling stamps and antique postcards on the sunny Sunday morning that follows.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 WEB OF DREAMS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) The origin of a family curse. 2 15 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in "The Gunslinger." 3 2 MUTATION, by Robin Cook.

LEAD: The West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, today rejected a Soviet proposal for an international referendum on German unity and said his Government expected Moscow to help ease the process of German reunification.

LEAD: Gloriously colored, intricately patterned silks and embroideries enriched the interiors of tents and palaces throughout the Islamic world from the 7th to the 19th centuries. The wealth of imagery and techniques developed in many lands during this period is seen in part in ''Islamic Textiles: A Sampler From Muslim Lands,'' an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, through

LEAD: When the University Students Cooperative Association voted to close Barrington Hall last November, the 166 University of California students who lived there were given until Jan. 20 to move out. The residence has a history of drug-dealing, poor maintenance and bad community relations, officials say.
LEAD: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won a second term in a primary today, capturing well over the 50 percent of votes he needed to avoid a runoff against his challenger, Donald Mintz.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Gardner Hood of Peach's Point, Marblehead, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Samantha Emmart Hood, to Neal Hilton Stephens Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephens Sr. of Warwick, Bermuda. A June wedding is planned. Miss Hood graduated from the Tower School, the Stoneleigh-Burnham School and expects to graduate in May from Endicott College.
LEAD: Yes. It should be downgraded to a tropical storm.

LEAD: The definitions of a romantic dinner vary as much as the people who are asked to define it. To some it may be a snug and serene dining room twinkling with candlelight. To others it might be dressing up in evening clothes and gliding across the dance floor at Maxim's, or maybe living out your Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers fantasy at the Rainbow Room, complete with a chilled bottle of

LEAD: The engagement of Denise E. McBride to Gregory P. Kelly, a son of Elizabeth Hallinan of Cumberland, Md., and the late William E. Kelly, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. McBride of Morristown, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: WALL-TO-WALL ducks set the stage at the Duck Pond Inn in Bay Shore. The ducky decor begins outdoors with a family of fowl on the maroon marquee and a handsome carved duck sign marking the restaurant.
LEAD: The Right to Stabilization
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-26

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Gallatin of New York and Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Buchanan Gallatin, to Clay Edward Stobaugh, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Stobaugh of Belmont, Mass., and Goudarques, France.

LEAD: MONDAY: The Senate Finance Committee holds hearings on Senator Moynihan's proposed Social Security tax cut. TUESDAY: The Fed's Open Market Committee meets. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and O.M.B. director Richard G. Darman are scheduled to testify before the House Ways and Means Committee on the nation's economy and the President's budget.
LEAD: When Donna Shalala left Hunter College in 1988 to become chancellor at the University of Wisconsin, she received a piece of advice that she has not forgotten.
LEAD: Luxury cars, gleaming tributes to this country's economic success, are lined up outside the garage where Jorge Arturo Jimenez sometimes finds menial work.

LEAD: America's policy triumph in Afghanistan a year ago has turned sour. Washington expected a swift rebel victory when the Soviet Union ended a decade of occupation last Feb. 15. It didn't happen. Now the onus for fueling a murderous war falls on the U.S. and Pakistan, the main supporters of a quarrelsome rebel coalition.

LEAD: Regina Steuart Green, the daughter of Mrs. Frederick J. Green Jr. of Baltimore and the late Mr. Green, was married yesterday to Richard Paul Rule, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques F. Rule of Sarasota, Fla. Msgr. E. Melville Taylor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Sacred Heart in

LEAD: Barbara Klaus's ''1990'' column in the Jan. 14 issue was one of the best she has written, and her columns are always intelligent and enjoyable. She is really a prize writer, and my family enjoys her regularly.

LEAD: THE two Mount Laurel decisions by the Supreme Court and the subsequent passage of the Fair Housing Act have brought nationwide attention to New Jersey. The state's housing policy has also fueled intense local debate and continued litigation.

LEAD: Ashley Louise Richards, an associate in the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, and Jonathan Thomas More Reckford, a senior analyst in the corporate strategy department of the Marriott Corporation in Bethesda, Md., plan a June wedding.

LEAD: I was born in Ellenville, N.Y., in the shadow of the Shawangunk Mountains. This is the first time I've ever heard them referred to as the ''Gunks.'' Yuppies must have coined the phrase without ever having listened to the proper pronunciation, which is SHON-gum, not Sha-wan-GUNK. Don't ask me why, but they're our mountains, and that's what we call 'em.
LEAD: LAST year, Textron Lycoming in Stratford was predicting a secure future: It had orders to produce 1,000 Army tank engines a year through 1996.

LEAD: Given the times, it is tempting to look for political undertones in even the musical doings of Central Europeans. But perhaps it would stretch interpretation a bit far to attach much extra-musical significance to the Warsaw Philharmonic's choice of music at Carnegie Hall on Friday night.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: While I am not familiar with the policies of the N.F.L. on drug testing, I feel that athletes should win or lose based on their ability.

LEAD: It is always good to be disabused of one's misapprehensions, and that is what has been happening to me with regard to the singing of Elisabeth Schwarzkopf. Ms. Schwarzkopf was the high priestess of the lieder recital from sometime around the early 1950's, when her collaboration with her husband and record producer Walter Legge entered its most fruitful phase, until her gradual retirement in the later 1970's.
LEAD: THE ROCKETS' RED GLARE When America Goes to War: The Presidents and the People. By Richard J. Barnet. 476 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.
LEAD: China's aging rulers are engaged in intense jockeying over national policy and a possible shuffling of Communist Party and Government posts, Chinese officials say.

LEAD: On the morning after the San Francisco 49ers won their second consecutive Super Bowl game, George Seifert was reminded that nobody has ever won three in a row. True to his personality, the 49er coach responded with a soft smile.
LEAD: Isiah Thomas, playing with five fouls, scored 7 of Detroit's final 9 points today as the Pistons beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 105-100, for their sixth consecutive victory.

LEAD: Buttons were not especially voguish five years ago when Beverly Adler, sifting through a jumble of flea market jewelry, came upon a whimsical bracelet of mismatched buttons. She later learned that young Appalachian women crocheted such bracelets during the 1930's, raiding their grandmothers' sewing boxes to create Depression-era jewels.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Hatzenbuhler of Verona, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristine Smith Hatzenbuhler, to Michael John O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. O'Connor, also of Verona. A September wedding is planned. Miss Hatzenbuhler, who expects to receive a J.D. from Seton Hall School of Law in June, graduated from Wheaton College.
LEAD: As a writer and an armchair ''climber,'' I enjoyed Trip Gabriel's vivid reporting of the rock climber Lynn Hill, and vicariously enjoyed the thrills of the sport.

LEAD: AT AN OFFICIAL SOVIET diplomatic reception for summiteers in Moscow, guests came up to me on the way out to express their gratitude at having been invited. In Russian-accented English, I replied that it was good of them to come.

LEAD: The N.F.L. Players Association is no longer a certified bargaining agent, but its president, Gene Upshaw, said the organization would help any player who wanted to go to court to challenge the National Football League's year-old modified free-agent system.

LEAD: The Albany police are used to occasional complaints from residents about noisy parties in the homes of student neighbors. But since September, the police say, those complaints - about revelers urinating on private property, destroying shrubs and arguing loudly in the streets late at night - have gotten out of hand.

LEAD: THE artistic directors of Chamber Music Plus, Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann, often program contemporary works, but take care to nestle them alongside masterworks of the Baroque, Classical or Romantic eras. On the other hand, when the cellist and pianist joined with the violist Lois Martin to form the Fidelio

LEAD: Dana Irene Spector and Scott Lauren Kimmel, both lawyers in New York, plan to marry in July. Miss Spector is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Spector of Kings Point, L.I. Mr. Kimmel is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kimmel of Buffalo.

LEAD: The Soprano Margaret Price, who is ill, has cancelled the recital she was to give at Avery Fisher Hall on Feb. 11 It will not be rescheduled. Refunds may be obtained in person or by writing to: Avery Fisher Hall Box Office, Broadwat at 65th Street, New York, N.Y. 10023. Information: 874-2424
LEAD: The A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am reverted today to its usual brutal self, which is just the way Mark O'Meara likes it.
LEAD: Jef Wis waye kul. Hiz kwan-tro adz, c'est mutch stile.

LEAD: The engagement of Diana Gail Thall to Craig Levin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Levin of Wynnewood, Pa., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Richard S. Thall of Locust Valley, L.I. A March wedding is planned.
LEAD: EVERY town should have a restaurant like Pasta Vera, an informal place that serves freshly made food at reasonable prices.

LEAD: The routine was a familiar sight to any hockey fan: a steal of the puck in front of the player's own goal, a swift skate to center ice and a sudden slap shot into the opponent's net for another Gretzky goal.
LEAD: Your publication of the article about Kevin Kearney [''Lobbying for Nudists' Rights,'' Dec. 24] showed remarkable naivete on a matter that is not without considerable controversy.

LEAD: Mrs. Paul T. Gorman of New Vernon, N.J., has made known the June wedding plans of her daughter, Nancy Gorman, to James Edward Dougherty 3d, a son of Mrs. Timothy J. Mahoney of Las Vegas, Nev., and the late Mr. Dougherty. Miss Gorman, also the daughter of the late Mr. Gorman, is a candidate for a master's degree in architecture at Columbia University.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has endorsed proposals to end the Communist Party's monopoly on power and to accept rival parties and private property, party members familiar with the documents said today.

LEAD: President Bush knows good politics and knows how to be a world leader. He showed that when he abandoned his reluctance to support Mikhail Gorbachev and reached out dramatically to end the cold war. He could now act with equal force at home if only he would seize the opportunity to transform the emerging peace with Moscow into a peace dividend for
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Howard 3d of Haverford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Brooke Howard, to Howard Bock Cromey Courtemanche, a son of Mrs. Edwin Cromey of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. Miss Howard, 24 years old, graduated from the Agnes Irwin School and Bowdoin College.
LEAD: A CHOICE OF INHERITANCE Self and Community From Edmund Burke to Robert Frost. By David Bromwich. 317 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.50.

LEAD: THE toothpaste tubes should have sent up a signal. When I began dating my husband, his friends chided him about being forthright and honest. I wondered what deep, dark secrets he was hiding. Did he have a criminal record? Was he suffering from some dreaded disease? As it turned out, his affliction was, and is, obsessive collecting.

LEAD: THE old adage ''can't see the forest for the trees'' might never have been more appropriate than on the day the Long Island Pine Barrens Society hurled a massive lawsuit at the people of Long Island.

LEAD: AT Nardin Fine Arts, ''Works on Paper'' covers the last 187 years and all of the available wall space. One cross-section of this miscellany might go from the on-the-spot sketches of Robert Henri (lots of them) to the large, squared-up drawing for the mural ''Leisure and Architecture'' by Thomas Hart Benton; another might take in John Marin's impressionistic watercolor of the Seine, Edward Hopper's study of a steamship with sail rigging, a perfect pen and ink that must date from the artist's youth in

LEAD: Investors would have done well to have dabbled in the stock market the first and last trading days of January, but to have taken to the ski slopes in between. The gains of 56.95 and 47.30 points, respectively, on those two days formed handsome bookends around what was otherwise a discouraging trounce.
LEAD: Robert Figlerski's essay (''Encouraging a Healthy Life Style,'' Jan. 14) advocates group calisthenics as a way of lowering medical insturance expenditures.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: An article last Sunday about the Connecticut Film Commission misstated its address. It is at 865 Brook Street, Rocky Hill, Conn. 06067-3405. The telephone number is 258-4301.

LEAD: This is the time of year when camera makers proudly trot out their newest models. Why? Because the annual Photo Marketing Association convention is soon to happen in Las Vegas. Every manufacturer wants to have something new to generate foot traffic at its booth.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The drug-testing policy of the N.F.L. should not be under scrutiny here, but rather the journalistic ethics of WJLA radio in its irresponsible attempt for sensationalistic headlines during Super Bowl week. (Is it a coincidence that this radio station cast a shadow over the most prominent player in the Super Bowl, Joe Montana, when it said that three white quarterbacks were ''guilty''?) The N.F.L.

LEAD: On Thursday night, with yesterday's start of the 24 Hours of Daytona sports car endurance race just a couple of days away, it seemed only natural that Al Unser Jr., his cousin, Robby Unser, and Raul Boesel of Brazil, all members of the Dauer racing team, would try to get in a little practice.
LEAD: You read your Emily Dickinson And I my Robert Frost And we note our place with bookmarkers That measure what we've lost

LEAD: To commemorate the birth of the 34th President, the United States Mint has issued a coin celebrating Gen.Dwight David Eisenhower. The coin, called the Eisenhower Centennial Silver Dollar, can now be ordered from the United States Mint.

LEAD: Their bout in Tokyo is less than a week away, and if they don't get sharper in a hurry, it could prove to be a distinctly lackluster affair. That's because the heavyweight champion Mike Tyson and his challenger, James (Buster) Douglas, both appeared sluggish yesterday in abbreviated public sparring sessions.

LEAD: The Times today adopts the country name Romania, spelled with an o, in place of Rumania. The o form is preferred by many Romanians as a reflection of their Roman origins and has been favored in recent years by most English-language publications.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security tax and Richard G. Darman's counterproposal to shield the pensioners' nest egg from the hungry gaze of Congress have so far generated more shock than debate.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Eric Bogosian, the monologuist, writer, actor, is at a crossroads. His new show, ''Sex, Drugs, Rock-and-Roll,'' which opens Off Broadway at the Orpheum Theater Thursday, will, he says, be his last solo performance. For Mr. Bogosian, the show is a culmination, the final synthesis of the characters, attitude and energy he has created that has made him one of the shooting stars of the downtown performance art world.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Dorsey Weber of Guilford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Dorsey Weber, to Karl-Erik Leopoldo Gude, a son of the late Helena Borda de Gude and the late Erik Anker Gude. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: IN many of New York City's prime residential co-operatives there is a semiprivate elevator landing on each floor - a miniature common area, often no larger than a walk-in closet, shared by only two apartments whose tenant-shareholders are normally given the right to furnish and decorate the landing.

LEAD: IT is a morning deep in February and the village dock on the Great South Bay is deserted except for seagulls. Children are in school; adults are working. The few baymen left are far out on the icy water. They stand in flat wooden boats clawing at the bottom ooze with long, heavy tongs. Silhouetted against the pale gray of sky and bay, their shoulders rock back and forth, back and forth, like men davening at the Western

LEAD: Rival Christian forces fought with tanks and gunboats for a fifth day today, violating a Vatican-brokered truce after just three hours. Shellfire reportedly killed 25 people and trapped 500,000 in shelters.

LEAD: University of Maryland athletic officials have acknowledged to the N.C.A.A. that a coach's scheme to scalp tickets for players in 1988 was not an isolated incident, Jeff Adkins, a former Maryland assistant basketball coach, said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: I search through the endless newspaper columns about the German wave rolling toward unification, but I cannot find any of the words I am looking for.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joel I. Banker of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have made known the June wedding plans of their daughter, Caroline Patrice Banker, and Jeffrey Lawrence Schneider, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schneider of New York and Longboat Key, Fla.

LEAD: EVEN as travelers streak from place to place in jets, many are drawn back to the days of journeys by sailing ship, of crashing storms and even mutinies. On the island of Mauritius, about 530 miles east of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean, this fascination is created and sated by the island's popular craft of building model ships.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A LEFT HAND LIKE GOD: A History of Boogie-Woogie Piano. By Peter J. Silvester. (Da Capo, Paper, $12.95.) Of all the subspecies of jazz, none has caught the public imagination quite so acutely as boogie-woogie, a blues-derived piano style characterized by repeated left-hand figures set against percussive right-hand riffs.

LEAD: ''We used to play this little game in language class, where the teacher would give us a famous line or clue from an opera, and we'd have to identify the opera and the act. I lost every time. I didn't know anything about the traditional repertory.''

LEAD: MARTIN AMIS IS probably fiction's angriest writer. In Britain, with its long and decorous literary tradition, his voice stands out discordantly from the rest like a boom box at a harpsichord recital. His urban satires have provoked extreme reactions in Britain, none more so than his latest, most ambitious novel, ''London Fields.
LEAD: The Superintendent of Schools, Jack Bobroff, has reinstated a teacher and librarian who were suspended after high school students were shown the R-rated film ''Catch-22.''
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: POTENTIALLY one of the most prosperous agricultural spots in Africa, the Sudan is facing yet another famine, this time caused not by weather but by war.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stan Weinstein of Hollywood, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter Marcy Eden Weinstein to Jeffrey Harris Schneider, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Schneider of Roslyn, L.I. A December wedding is planned. Miss Weinstein and her fiance are 23 years old and are graduates of the University of Pennsylvania.

LEAD: Separatist leaders of several republics in the Soviet Union succeeded today in circumventing the Kremlin and negotiating a cease-fire in the explosive border violence between Armenia and Azerbaijan.

LEAD: The flight to safety is on. Investors, worried about skittish stock and ''junk bond'' markets and lured by high interest rates, are shifting their cash to money-market funds. And fund experts say that investor nervousness shows no sign of clearing.
LEAD: There was a surprising omission in the lead article on North Haven [''Tiny Oasis Braces for Influx of Wealthy,'' Jan. 14] .

LEAD: China's population increased by 15.77 million people last year, bringing the total population to 1.112 billion, according to the State Statistical Bureau. The bureau's figures, reported today by People's Daily, said the natural population increase for the year was 14.33 per 1,000 people, up slightly from 14.2 per 1,000 in 1988.

LEAD: On some evenings, William A. Schreyer, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, takes a helicopter to his home in Princeton, N.J., from Manhattan. This weekend, the brokerage firm, the nation's largest, is hosting an elaborate ''junk bond'' conference, trying to outdo the decadent ball held by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

LEAD: HOW many passenger jets will crash this year? This is not a popular question with the airlines, which are extraordinarily sensitive to public doubts about safety. But an attempt to answer it illuminates both successes and gaps in aviation's safety record.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. A. Neal Geller of Ithaca, N.Y., have made known the September wedding plans of their daughter Bonnie Dara Geller and Laurence Ira Arnold, the son of Alvin L. Arnold of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Nancy Arnold.

LEAD: As Francine Prose suggested in her article, the key to restoring women's sound psychological development may lie in recovering the physical confidence of an 11-year-old running on the beach, playing tag. If I had my way, I would require girls to complete a carpentry or mechanics course and run a mile in under 10 minutes before they receive their high-school diplomas.
LEAD: January 1990, in every other instance a mean season, was made memorable by the arrival of two movies by which all other films that open this year may at some point be compared.

LEAD: WHEN fancy took flight after the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in 1986 it was suggested that redevelopment would soon follow in the broad mixed-use area separating its 11th Avenue location in the West 30's from the central business district to the east.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S new health commissioner will not get the usual honeymoon period. Instead, the tenure of Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. is going to be something akin to instant marriage counseling as he seeks reconciliation with the advocates for AIDS services who are bitterly divided over his selection.
LEAD: To the Editor:

Last April, almost exactly a year after the report was issued, the company's president stood accused of attempting to bribe a member of

LEAD: As the father of a 16-year-old daughter, I read with interest your article on the work being done by Carol Gilligan. Perhaps the confidence of 11-year-olds is the confidence of the blind horse. Most 16-year-old girls have acquired some knowledge of the constraints that all adults must live with. How did Ms.

LEAD: THERE I was, trying to spread an intractable pat of butter across a rapidly disintegrating slice of toast when my wife suddenly asked across the breakfast table: ''Does the universe go on forever?'' Just like that, no warning, no preparation - metaphysics at 8:15 in the morning, and I hadn't even had my juice yet.

LEAD: FOR some ensembles, rehearsals are a necessary evil on the way to a performance. But the Hudson Valley Wind Symphony exists more for the joy of reading through the remarkably rich repertoire for symphonic band than for the occasional local concerts it has presented since it formed in 1988.

LEAD: THERE is no denying that the published prices of most cruises are higher this year than last, but that does not mean that most travelers are paying more. Competition for passengers remains fierce among cruise lines, resulting in widespread discounting.

But that was 45 years ago. LEAD: In a market-based economy that recognizes the rights of private property, the only social responsibility of business is to create shareholder value and to do so legally and with integrity. Yet we do have important unresolved social challenges - from drug abuse to education and the environment - that require collective action.

LEAD: The modest budget increases requested by President Bush for the arts and humanities in fiscal 1991 are regarded by top members of Congress as significant because while they do not keep pace with inflation they reverse a nine-year trend of declining or flat budgets in these areas.

LEAD: Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, on Friday urged a crowd of more than 16,000 to ''stop the killing,'' a reference to both the recent shooting death of a Black Muslim and the continuing violence among street gangs.

LEAD: Brenda Lebowitz Stoller, a registered nurse and the clinical educator of orthopedics at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, and Dr. Lewis West Marshall Jr., the assistant director of emergency medicine at Jamaica Hospital in Queens, are planning a March wedding. Ms. Stoller, a daughter of the late Dr.

LEAD: The Milwaukee Brewers announced yesterday that they had reached a contract agreement with their catcher, B. J. Surhoff, and thereby averted an arbitration hearing scheduled for tomorrow. The contract is for one year, but no other details were announced.

LEAD: WHEN President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the first farm subsidy law on May 12, 1933, he promised it was a temporary measure. At a time when people were hungry, he remarked, the Government had no business propping up prices by paying farmers to hold back their harvests. Now, nearly 60 years later, the payments are as much a part of

LEAD: New Jersey should continue to ban self-service at the gasoline stations because in the dozen or more states where I have visited the gasoline price has not gone down. Besides, women in New Jersey do not want to fill their own tanks and smell of gasoline.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: George Reiger's book ''The Wildfowler's Quest'' (Nick Lyons Books, $24.95) is an exuberant, perceptive and sensitive excursion into a venerable tradition that each year moves many hunters to set forth with delight on bitter, stormy days when most men choose to remain beside the hearth.

LEAD: It has a reputation for business aplomb, but Textron Inc., the Providence, R.I., conglomerate, is also a company that's found itself on the crest of trends. Back in the early 1950's, when single-mindedness was American corporate gospel, Textron's founder, Royal Little, decided he needed a strategy to protect his cyclical textile business, so he invented the modern conglomerate.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Kinberg of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Jill Moral Kinberg and John Joseph Hubbard, the son of Mrs. Kent E. Drown of Salt Lake City and John D. Hubbard of Grass Lake, Mich.

LEAD: CHEESEMAKING once knew quite a reputation in Scotland. A painting of Sir Walter Scott by Wilkie shows his wife and daughters outfitted for sheep-milking.

LEAD: INITIATING what he clearly intended to be a major assualt on Westchester's homeless problem, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week that he was moving from ''the think-tank stage to the let's-do-something stage.''
LEAD: WHAT is 36 1/2 feet long, 8 feet wide and 12 feet high, weighs 20,000 pounds and moves on wheels? It is ORCA, the latest addition to Hoboken's police force.

LEAD: The authorities have decided not to cut off the limbs of 12 prisoners condemned to that punishment under Islamic law, and similar cases are under review.
LEAD: The oil workers' union has reached a tentative agreement with the Amoco Corporation that is expected to set a pattern for negotiations with the oil industry nationwide.

LEAD: IN recent weeks, the cry has been raised wherever blacks have gathered to protest apartheid: ''Madiba! Madiba! Madiba!''

LEAD: Bill Shoemaker, the greatest jockey in racing history, brought the horseplayers to their feet one last time today in an emotion-charged race at Santa Anita Park that marked the 58-year-old rider's retirement from racing.

LEAD: I was raised in a traditional 1950's home, where I was taught that to be feminine was to be caring . . . as well as to be coy, deferring and, frankly, dishonest. Women had to get by in life by being seductive or subtly manipulative. Too seductive, however, and you were ''loose,'' too manipulative and you were a nag.

LEAD: A $9 million program to assist the opposition in Nicaragua's presidential election has encountered so many delays and bureaucratic obstacles that a Nicaraguan Government agency has received more money than the coalition of opposition parties supported by the United States, American officials say.

LEAD: DAVID N. DINKINS, who once was dismissed by a critic as ''Mr. Smoothie with no position,'' proved last week what dividends such derision can bring. Presenting his first preliminary New York City budget as Mayor, he won praise partly for taking an unpopular stand.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Mogford Carpenter of Greenwich, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Carpenter, to Mark Randall Hill, a son of Patricia Ann Hill of Waukegan, Ill., and Joe Robert Hill of Pittsburgh. A June wedding is planned. Miss Carpenter, who is 27 years old, expects to receive an M.B.A.

LEAD: Anita Brett Elkind, the general manager of Argus Computerized Exchange, a computer information service in Burlington, Mass., and Dr. Richard M. Pomerantz, a fellow in cardiology at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, are planning a May wedding. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Marilyn Elkind of Somers, N.Y., and Victor Elkind of La Jolla, Calif.

LEAD: I would like to thank the editor who brought us the funny story about the lawyers objecting to mandatory continuing education. These are the same people who object to ''pro bono'' legal assistance in offices or courts. These are the same people who have made it a requirement for other professionals to have continuing education so they can better serve the public.

LEAD: ''How do you deal with AIDS in pictures?'' asks Marvin Heiferman. ''Do you show those suffering from the disease, depress everyone, and let the audience gawk at a bunch of sick people? Or do you try to raise issues and hopes, even though that may seem too politically correct?''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AT THE HUMAN AND BEHAVIOR GENETICS Laboratory at Emory University, in Atlanta, a videotape recording shows a smiling 8-year-old girl peering from behind thick glasses at two clear plastic boxes topped by red bows, each containing a chocolate-chip cookie. The game, a psychologist explains, is to open both boxes and remove the cookies - and no eating until both cookies are out.
LEAD: AS the Iron Curtain rises, the stage is set for trade, and some of the players are already in place.

LEAD: A grand jury investigating what the authorities suspect was Charles Stuart's scheme to kill his pregnant wife heard testimony this week from one of his brothers, his closest friend and several other people who might shed light on the case.

Mr. Cromwell is the son of Joan Van Pelt Cromwell of New York and Roger J. K. Cromwell of Cheshire, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE poster that hung in a Washington classroom, ''Great Kings and Queens of Africa,'' was a work of pride. All the figures were in heroic poses and all were black. Like Queen Nandi of the Zulus, the Egyptian pharaoh Akhenaton and even Cleopatra had the broad features and dark skin tints indicating origins in Central Africa.
LEAD: AS the end of World War II neared, there was talk among Allied leaders that American soldiers need not remain in Europe for much longer than two years.
LEAD: I find it comical, if not ludicrous, to read that safety is one of the factors in prohibiting self-service gas stations in New Jersey (''Debate on Self-Service Gas Lives On,'' Dec. 31).

LEAD: ABOVE High Street on the Yale campus, Harkness Tower soars in neo-Gothic grandeur, as if seeking divine inspiration for a community of scholars. After six months of silence, the tower's bells have rung again with the music of Mozart, Handel and Bach.

LEAD: COMPANIES A New, More Subdued, Mood at Shearson Lehman An era of daring and deal-making at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. undoubtedly ended Tuesday night with the resignation of Peter A. Cohen as chairman and chief executive. His replacement, Howard L. Clark Jr., has been chief financial officer at the American Express Company, Shearson's corporate parent.

G. W. Biddle of Great Falls, Va.

The value of art, unlike that of stocks or bonds or barrels of crude oil, is determined largely by psychology, and the factors that make one van

LEAD: AS the Soviet Union strives to modernize its economy and match the performance of countries with free markets, it begins with an energy industry that missed the important events of the last 20 years. The Soviets are the world's largest producers of oil, but they were never driven to the productivity advances required in the West by years of competition and the price collapse of 1986.

LEAD: ''I GOT news for you; your Prince Charming has come,'' declares an ardent, insistent short-order cook (Johnny) to a defensive, disbelieving waitress (Frankie).

Carroll of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday at the Clinton Inn in Tenafly, N.J., to Steven Rudinsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rudinsky of New York. Judge John F. Keenan of the United States Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York officiated.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Murray Kaplan of Bayside, Queens, have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Lisa Kaplan, and Cary M. Hirshon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hirshon of Rego Park, Queens. Ms. Kaplan, 28 years old, graduated from Queens College and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University.

LEAD: THE smile on the Mona Lisa at 704 Traction Avenue is all lit up. Two delicate bands of neon - a squiggle for the upper lip and a small curve for the lower - are like brush strokes of light. This Mona Lisa, with a dramatic yellow zig-zag above the left eyebrow, a chin outlined in uranium blue and strands of hot pink, yellow and blue hair cascading in a fireworks finish, positively glows.

LEAD: For This Week: Keep up with seed and nursery catalogue study; don't delay to mail orders. Plan to grow one of more unusual plants this year to learn the challenges of their culture. Be sure to keep seedlings indoors in light, but not too strong sunlight, which could burn young leaves. Questions/Answers

LEAD: Anyone who thinks the popular no-makeup look is an artless product of luck and lipgloss has probably never wielded a blush brush. Bobbi Brown, a freelance makeup artist, is the master of the natural look.

LEAD: In 1921 the photographer Paul Strand said of John Marin that he was ''one of the few whose work is the supreme proof of the actuality of an American painter, of the possibility of American painting.''
LEAD: THE MIRROR MAKER Stories & Essays. By Primo Levi. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 176 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $16.95.

LEAD: Bo Jackson is one player who could have benefited from the threatened lockout if only he had been able to plan for it. No, Bo doesn't need the extra rest between football and baseball seasons. Had he known he might have more time before spring training, he could have planned for more school work.
LEAD: Blacks and whites in South Africa are caught in a tide of relief and hope that after decades of tightening confrontation, the corner has been turned toward reconciliation.

''It says, 'America: one out of every four people can't read this word.' '' The writer adds: ''It's impactful, it's true and it's a tragedy.''

LEAD: YOUNG MAN started his career as a makeup artist at a cosmetics company. He worked his way up and, with $80,000 from the sale of his house, moved to California to invent his own line. He ordered $500,000 worth of makeup and other products from an Italian concern that supplies the leading cosmetics companies, but when they arrived, the lipstick cases were smashed and the foundation bottles were shattered.

LEAD: The new Indian Government has moved to curb the influence of a former resident of Chicago who returned to India to give a push to the nation's modernization drive and who is now chief of India's telecommunications network.
LEAD: THE Hudson River Quilt, created by 30 Westchester-area women two decades ago and known as ''the first group quilt for a cause,'' was sold for $23,100 last weekend by Sotheby's in Manhattan.

LEAD: Primal, a local hero who fires his best shot every time he goes to the post, collared Ole Atocha in the stretch and drew away to a strong one-length victory today in the $100,000 Broward Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

LEAD: A handmade sign attached to an iron fence at a school in East Harlem said the soup kitchen there would be closed yesterday because of a ''death in our family, Robert Cole, age 13.''
LEAD: Donating money to a charity can be like sending a bottle with a message into the open seas. The ultimate recipient of the gift is unknown to the giver.

LEAD: Tournament bridge is in general a democratic game with almost everyone permitted to play subject to occasional restrictions based on gender, age or, more frequently, past performance measured by some standard such as master points.

LEAD: The yen lost its punch this week, falling back to its level of 145 against the dollar. As for the West German mark, it continued strong, but the dollar only moved down a little against it. Suggestions from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that there was less chance of a recession seemed to have little impact.
LEAD: Syphilis has risen to its highest rate in 40 years and young people's education about sexually transmitted diseases is lacking, Federal health researchers say.

LEAD: ''One of our giant redwoods has fallen, and left a space we cannot fill by any quick plantation of lesser trees,'' Lewis Mumford wrote of Frank Lloyd Wright after Wright's death in 1959, and today we might use these words to speak of Lewis Mumford himself. His death a few days ago at the age of 94 brings to a close a life of extraordinary breadth, sweep, ambition and passion.
LEAD: Two years ago Paul Hecht and his wife, Lynn Vogt, built a log cabin in the Muskoka Lake region north of Toronto. Theoretically, that is. Actually, Ms. Vogt built it with the help of her father.

LEAD: There seems a good possibility that for years to come some top officials at the Ford Motor Company will think about Robert W. Kearns (below) every time it rains. In a closely watched patent-infringement suit, a jury in Detroit ruled last week that Mr. Kearns had invented the intermittent windshield wiper used in Ford products and that he was entitled to seek royalties.
LEAD: WHAT happens when the sponsor of a cooperative or condominium conversion falls behind in his maintenance payments?

LEAD: CRUISES are not part of the core curriculum at American colleges and universities; no Caribbean Islands 101 here. But they are part of higher education's agenda for winning friends and influencing alumni.

LEAD: A memorandum prepared by the Cambodian Defense Ministry says the two non-Communist factions opposing the Phnom Penh Government are increasingly cooperating on the battlefield with their dominant ally, the Communist Khmer Rouge.

LEAD: Graeme Townshend, the rookie forward who is only the third black to play for the Boston Bruins, sat at his locker after today's 2-1 loss to the Rangers, dressing quickly, speaking curtly, deflecting as best he could the controversy that had engulfed him in only his second National Hockey League game.
LEAD: The 13th stamp in the Black Heritage series is a 25-cent issue to honor Ida B. Wells, journalist, suffragette and a founder of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

LEAD: Some student editors at the University of Texas are protesting a longstanding school policy limiting newspaper and magazine distribution at the college - a regulation they describe as censorship.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 21 about what shapes a new apartment house misidentified the status of the Severn, at 170 West 73d Street, and the Van Dyck, at 175 West 72d Street. The apartment houses are rentals, not co-ops.

LEAD: She was tall and tan and stylish, expansive and difficult, playful and brilliant. She began her career as an anthropologist in the late 1920's and made her mark as a novelist during the Depression years. Almost 30 years later she died, nearly forgotten, in a Florida welfare home, and lay buried in an unmarked grave for more than a decade.

LEAD: Perhaps the most telling comment on the resignation last week of Peter A. Cohen (above) as chief executive of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. came from the marketplace: Shearson's stock went up. The 43-year-old Mr. Cohen, a Wall Street wunderkind who exemplified the hotshots of the 1980's, rode to glory on a market heated by the takeover boom and was ridden out of Shearson at least in part because a couple of his own takeover moves went sour.

LEAD: Only a decade ago, there were so few cable services that marketing merely meant telling the American public that cable existed. Today there are 54 advertiser-supported networks, which get their revenues both from commercials and from fees paid by cable operators. ESPN, the sports network, and CNN, the Cable News Network, are by far the largest, seen in virtually all 55 million cable households.

LEAD: The Grand Prix given each year to outstanding stereo components may seem like a case of the audio industry vigorously patting itself on the back. While there is some of that - what with the awards being sponsored by Audio/Video International, a prominent trade publication -these accolades also reflect valid judgments.

LEAD: With chants of ''asesino'' and ''murderer'' and banners denouncing police brutality, more than 150 people gathered in front of the 83d Precinct station house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday, to protest the killings of two teen-agers by police officers.
LEAD: WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION A Political Life in the Reagan Era. By Peggy Noonan. 353 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

LEAD: When Alfred M., a gang member and convicted felon, shows up each morning at a school for disabled children, a small freckled boy with cerebral palsy pulls himself laboriously across the classroom floor to greet him.

LEAD: WHY would the Reichmann family of Toronto, developers of such enormous projects as the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan and Canary Wharf in London, go to all the bother of rebuilding a mediocre, 29-year-old tower on Park Avenue, particularly when the cost may equal that of new construction?

LEAD: Except for a few rallies in black townships like this, the legalization of the African National Congress prompted little political activity today beyond a proliferation of T-shirts with slogans that had been illegal.

LEAD: Eamonn Coghlan may be 37 years old and he may soon be moving back to his native Ireland and he may be cutting back on a running career that has made him the fastest and perhaps the most popular indoor miler ever.
LEAD: Not since Wilbur Mills took a nocturnal dip in the Tidal Basin back in 1974 has the nation's capital had a story as juicy as the Marion Barry saga.

LEAD: When New York's highest court upheld a judgment of $1.57 million in damages to a Manhattan restaurant from the cooperative apartment house that leases it space, and much of the amount was paid, it seemed that the unusual suit had been largely resolved. It hasn't. The eight-year-old case now has spawned at least two more suits.

LEAD: Arnold Gumowitz's suggestion for specialized service from the Long Island Railroad (''L.I.R.R. Should Recognize Long Beach's Ties to New York'' (Opinion, Jan. 14) is an interesting one and one that the L.I.R.R. desperately needs to explore, especially with the lack of capital improvement to many towns.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Birnbaum of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Greer Birnbaum to Andrew David Heath, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard G. Heath of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and New York. The wedding is planned for next year.

LEAD: IT had long been the common wisdom that East Germany could have no separate identity if stripped of Communism. What nobody seemed to realize until recently, however, was just how true this was - how rapidly the ''first state of workers and peasants on German soil'' would disintegrate once freed of the Muscovite mold, how swiftly its citizens would reach out to the other Germany.

Technology, Politics, and the Strategic Defense Initiative: How the Reagan Administration Set Out to Make Nuclear Weapons ''Impotent and Obsolete'' and Succumbed to the Fallacy of the Last Move. By Sanford Lakoff and Herbert F. York. 409 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press.

LEAD: Residents of downtown Brooklyn are being treated this weekend to a phenomenon both rare and dear to the hearts of serious sidewalk superintendents - the inching of three historic houses along the streets to new locations. The 150-year-old structures, which had occupied sites at 106, 108 and 110 Johnson Street, are being towed as a unit eastward on Johnson, then south onto Duffield Street and then to their final site on newly built foundations on Duffield between Myrtle Avenue and Willoughby
LEAD: Frederick S. Leinbach, former president of the Riegel Paper Corporation, died of a heart attack on Friday at his home in Ocean City, N.J. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: In a world where air passengers hurtle around the globe in less than two days, people who take 135 days to do it set themselves, well, apart. Which is precisely why Ethel Warner and her husband boarded a cargo vessel for their last world cruise.

LEAD: THE COPPER SCULPTURES IN THE background of the photograph above are among 10 that will be installed at the Opera and Ballet Theater in Vilnius, Lithuania, on Feb. 16. They are the work of artists who belong to Skulpturos Kooperatyvas, an independent enterprise that separated from the state two years ago, among the first steps toward privatization in Lithuania during the Gorbachev era of perestroika.

LEAD: The Soviet Jews now flooding into Israel say that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost gave them new freedom to practice their faith, but that it also gave new voice to anti-Semitic expression in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: WHEN Avianca Flight 52 crashed into a hillside in Cove Neck, most reporters spent hours trekking through dark woods and heavy rain to reach the isolated, barricaded and, by then, traffic-clogged disaster site.

LEAD: A violent windstorm gusting up to 104 miles an hour battered northern France today, killing at least 18 people and damaging scores of buildings, among them Chartres Cathedral, one of the world's most celebrated Gothic cathedrals.

LEAD: Jim Wright's wheeling and dealing explained his success as Speaker of the House and, eventually, his fall. Driven to resign by the embarrassing findings of House ethics investigators, he went home to Fort Worth, where they still love him. Well they should.
LEAD: John B. Griffin, a lawyer in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died of a heart attack on Thursday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Dance, the most sheerly physical of all the performing arts, has long seemed to offer an inherent though changeable commentary on gender and sexuality. With its wordless metaphoric power, dance is capable of suggesting as much if not more than the relationship of two people sharing a stage in an aria or as characters who talk of their love.

LEAD: A TWO-YEAR, $30 million rehabilitation project now under way in the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel will be the ultimate test of a high-tech communications command center recently installed in the tunnel's administration building here, officials say.

LEAD: CROOKED HEARTS, by Robert Boswell. (Laurel/Dell, $9.95.) For the members of the Warren family of Yuma, Ariz., disappointment is such an expected part of life that they throw parties to celebrate their latest failures. This novel is ''rich and vivid, an intriguingly busy view of the human adventure, the impossible family of man,'' Sharon Sheehe Stark said here in 1987.

LEAD: Spend a night cruising the streets of the city in a patrol car, eyeing the crackheads and the hustlers, stopping for domestic disputes and suspicious characters, and by the time the sun comes up, there'll be one clear thought in your head: I'm glad I don't have this job.

LEAD: There were only three games to go for Jan Timman and, with a two-point lead in his KRO Exhibition Match in Hilversum, the Netherlands, against the British grandmaster Nigel Short, he could not close it out. The Dutch grandmaster lost two of the remaining games and drew the last one to finish in a 3-3 tie.

LEAD: I read with great sadness the article ''Lawyers' Courses Draw Fire'' (Jan. 14). What a great hardship and tragedy it must be to require lawyers to attend 12 hours of continuing legal education a year.

LEAD: Toni Kasander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kasander of New York, was married last evening to Kermit Prill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Prill of Lincoln Park, Mich. Rabbi Harold Loss officiated at the Sheraton Oaks Hotel in Novi, Mich. The bride, who will keep her name, graduated summa cum laude from Ohio University and received a master's degree in education from the University of Detroit.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 31 about a proposed landfill in Hunterdon County misidentified the site to which the county ships ash from incinerated trash. The ash is sent to the Grand Central Sanitary Landfill in Plainfield Township, Pa., not to a landfill in Tullytown, Pa.

LEAD: The best way to deal with workers who lose their jobs when industry shrinks, Washington has thought for years, is to teach them to do something else. But retraining is more talked about than done, and in this blue-collar city on the Arkansas-Oklahoma border, it is off to an uncommonly rocky start.

LEAD: Thousands of Jews, most elderly and some bearing concentration-camp numbers inscribed on their wrists, thronged today to a Holocaust memorial dedicated to what Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel called ''suffering that transcended suffering.''
LEAD: Closing a chapter of its most tumultuous year, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. reported yesterday that it lost about $40 million in 1989 on gross revenues of about $4.1 billion.

LEAD: In midsummer, 21 young people at six youth shelters in five states talked with reporter about how they came to be there. Counselors in the shelters either veirified the accounts or said they were consistent with the lives and personalities of the young people. The stories of seven of the young people from four states are summarized here, and recent checks determined what had happened to them since the interviews.

LEAD: SKIERS are renting equipment in greater numbers than ever before. In addition, many skiers test different ski models before buying; others find it more convenient to rent equipment than to bring their own for ski vacations.

LEAD: The chairman of the House panel investigating abuses in the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that he was canceling an appearance at a hearing Monday by a former top housing official who has been cooperating with investigators.

LEAD: In an effort to avoid losses, many insurance carriers have quietly blacklisted dozens of types of small businesses and professions. A wide variety of occupations, from bartender and gas-station attendant to oil driller and dentist, have been declared ineligible for health insurance.

LEAD: Two victims of the recent Avianca crash in New York were found to have sealed up quantities of cocaine inside condoms and swallowed them to conceal them from Customs inspectors. How can America ever hope to win a war against drugs when the demand drives people to such degrading, inventive lengths?

LEAD: In ''La Source,'' George Balanchine paid overt tribute to France's ballet tradition. Judith Fugate and Ib Andersen of the New York City Ballet suggested in their poetic performance on Saturday afternoon that the choreography needed no outside reference, that it could be sublime on its own terms.

LEAD: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy won re-election to a second four-year term here on Saturday, making a comeback after polls last fall showed that he had lost the confidence of the voters.

On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.45 percent this week, up from 8.41 percent the week before.

LEAD: Today when summations are completed at John Gotti's trial in Manhattan, everyone will go home except the jury. For three weeks the freedom of 12 jurors and four alternates has been severely restricted as the evidence unfolded against Mr. Gotti.
LEAD: Battered and bruised, the docudrama has a disconcerting habit of bouncing back impressively.

LEAD: DR. THOMAS Q. MORRIS has resigned quietly as president of the Presbyterian Hospital, New York City's largest hospital. The hospital's acting president is HARRY J. BOLWELL, who is 64 years old. A search is under way for a successor to Dr. Morris.

LEAD: The stretch run up the rail that won Dancing Spree the $1 million Breeders' Cup Sprint three months ago didn't quite work in the $50,000 Gulfstream Park Sprint Championship Handicap today, but the stewards made him the winner anyway.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Many health insurers have quietly blacklisted dozens of types of small businesses and professions. While some insurance companies have been accused of denying coverage to people in cities and occupations where the insurers contend the AIDS virus is most prevalent, the exclusions extend well beyond these groups.

LEAD: SAVE for a few quarts of tomatoes, rhubarb and green beans, my freezer is nearly filled with venison, ducks and Canada geese, which will be consumed by the end of May to make room for bluefish and striped bass.
LEAD: The experiment has not been without its exasperation. Darren Turcotte, a center converted to winger, has often found himself baffled on the ice and disappointed afterward.
LEAD: The New York City government, which has signs banning everything from U-turns on streets to smoking in buildings, now has a sign banning weddings.
LEAD: Harold G. Warner, who rose from a job installing parts at the General Motors Corporation to become a member of the automaker's board, died of cancer Friday. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: Antonetta Ferraro, the mother of Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Representative and Vice-Presidential candidate, died of emphysema and heart disease on Friday at the home of her daughter in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 84 years old.
LEAD: The Census Bureau is looking for people across the nation to track down hard-to-count Americans in a job that can pay as much as $8 an hour.

LEAD: The North American premiere of the Association of Tennis Professionals Tour will have a West Coast setting, and like any good western, the event will feature a couple of hired guns to round out its cast of 32 players.

LEAD: At 1 in the morning, in his black robe and buckskin shoes, Hector Camacho headed out of the Convention Center followed by friends, family and, in a strange sight for boxing's leading rogue, a number of well-wishers.
LEAD: Harold Reynolds, the Gold Glove second baseman, reached agreement today with the Seattle Mariners on a three-year, $5 million contract.

LEAD: A Soviet official announced in Tunis this weekend that the Soviet Union would not allow direct flights from Moscow to Tel Aviv for Soviet immigrants to Israel, despite a commercial agreement between the two nations to begin the flights in January.

LEAD: Business executives and the anti-apartheid protestors who are pushing them to sever economic ties with Pretoria do not expect the changes announced by President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa to stimulate new foreign investments.

LEAD: Officials in Calfornia are seeking to determine if Jerry Jones, majority owner of the Dallas Cowboys, or a close associate improperly influenced a former executive of a large California public utility to obtain contracts for natural gas supplies, The Dallas Morning News said today.

LEAD: * Christie, Manson & Woods International Inc., New York, the United States branch of the London auction concern Christie's International P.L.C., named Doris P. Meister executive vice president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: Even with the sharp increase in interest rates since late December, some credit market analysts say bond yields may need to move higher still in order to attract buyers at the quarterly Treasury auctions that will be held this week.
LEAD: Carroll Vincent Newsom, the president of New York University from 1956 to 1961 and a leader in educational television, died Saturday at his home in Dublin, Ohio. He was 85 years old.

LEAD: In a move that could end a 150-year tradition at one of the nation's oldest military academies, the Justice Department has told the Virginia Military Institute in Lexington to include women in its cadet ranks or face court action.
LEAD: ''We need a new socialism with free politics. No one will give this to us. We have to do it ourselves.'' -Gavriil K. Popov, a dissident Soviet Communist Party member. [A8:3.]

LEAD: The Mexican Government and its foreign bank creditors signed a historic agreement today that will cut Mexico's foreign debt burden by as much as 20 percent. It also guarantees international bankers that the remainder of outstanding loans will be repaid.

LEAD: The Pennsylvania House of Representatives has passed a bill requiring ''parental warning'' labels on certain recordings before they can be sold, or offered for sale. Since the measure requires only the warning, and does not ban sales outright, the House legal counsel insists ''there's no question that our bill is constitutional; there's no censorship in the [label] approach.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins renewed his call yesterday for a state law specifically banning violence motivated by prejudice. Measures to achieve this died in 1988 and 1989 because of opposition in the State Senate.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Assailants armed with rifles and grenades attacked a tour bus carrying a group of Israeli academics and their wives on a main highway east of Cairo today, killing 8 Israelis and wounding 17 others, Israeli and Egyptian officials said.
LEAD: Less than a month ago, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was facing the rebellious Lithuanians, and conspicuously failing to dampen their longing for independence from the Soviet empire.
LEAD: A VERY intriguing meeting took place in Atlanta last week, when two top officers of CBS quietly visited a man whose previous role in the CBS drama was playing the bogyman: Ted Turner.

LEAD: A woman who told the police she had a miscarriage two weeks ago was arrested yesterday as she walked down a Brooklyn street carrying a three-day-old boy whom the police said she kidnapped from a hospital nursery.

LEAD: Political figures frequently play social bridge, but few play very well, largely because their schedules are too crowded to develop expertise. One of the few exceptions, and perhaps the best bridge player worldwide among today's politicians, is John Marek, a British Member of Parliament.

LEAD: Robert Stallings, chief executive of the Western Savings and Loan Association, a Phoenix-based savings and loan seized by the Government, said on Friday that he planned to leave the institution this Friday to work with an investment group that wants to acquire Western.

LEAD: The author Salman Rushdie, in hiding for the past year because of death threats from Islamic leaders offended by his novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' appealed to Muslims today to understand the book not as an attack on their faith but as ''a secular man's reckoning with the religious spirit.''

LEAD: Kimberly Hardy, a 22-year-old Michigan woman, was ordered Thursday to stand trial on a charge routinely applied to drug dealers: delivering cocaine to a minor. But the minor was her newborn, and she was charged with delivering the drug in the minute or two before the umbilical cord was clamped.

LEAD: Mark O'Meara's victory today at the A.T. & T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am tournament was as devoid of drama as this year's Super Bowl, but like the San Francisco 49ers, he'll be going for three in a row next year.

LEAD: NOW that the Centers for Disease Control have labeled the flu outbreak a full-fledged epidemic in 35 states, it should come as no great surprise that drugstores almost everywhere are experiencing a rush for dozens of remedies to fight coughs and colds.

LEAD: Silviu Brucan, a prominent figure of the Romanian revolution who became a chief target of opposition forces, resigned today from the leadership of the Council of National Salvation.

LEAD: On one point, the participants in ''Teaching, Testing and Treatment'' can agree: drugs are not good either for the individual or for society.
