LEAD: Curtiss E. Frank, a lawyer who was a mayor of Yonkers, a publishing executive and the president of Dun & Bradstreet, died of Alzheimer's disease on Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 85 years old. Mr. Frank was elected to the City Council of Yonkers in 1942, and became mayor in 1944. He resigned in 1949.

Wins: Keith Millard, a nose tackle for the Minnesota Vikings, scored on an 8-yard fumble return, and Jerry Gray, a cornerback for the Los Angeles Rams, added a touchdown on a 51-yard interception return yesterday as the National Football Conference beat the American Conference by 27-21 in a defense-dominated Pro Bowl in Honolulu.

LEAD: Boggs Bogged Down Q. Generally, if a minor league player has a decent season, he gets a shot at the major leagues. Wade Boggs played six years in the minors and hit over .300 five times before joining the Boston Red Sox. Why the delay? A. Blame it mostly on his glove and the bats ahead of him, as well as Boston's success with both during Boggs's minor league days.

LEAD: The number of people visiting New York City for business or pleasure declined slightly last year, but what really worries many in the local tourism industry is the prospect that the 1989 statistics may be the first sign of a long slide.
LEAD: Bo Kimble, the Division I scoring leader, got 50 points tonight as Loyola Marymount, ranked No. 20, completed a stretch of scoring 448 points in three games over four days.
LEAD: The New York Post has enlisted Kirshenbaum & Bond to help it fight the New York City tabloid war. The paper's previous agency, Ammirati & Puris, resigned the account in September.

LEAD: WHENEVER the shot is made, the referee raises both hands, the crowd buzzes a little louder, and 3 points are added to the scoreboard.

LEAD: The times have been few and far between when University of Texas fans could complain about a scarcity of tickets to a Longhorn basketball game. For that matter, it has been awhile since the Southwest Conference itself could generate much excitement in the sport.

LEAD: Softballs for amateur play will have a new look this spring. Spalding Sports Worldwide, an athletic equipment manufacturer based in Chicopee, Mass., has started to market a fluorescent yellow ball.
LEAD: Lech Walesa said today he probably would step down in April as leader of Solidarity, the union that he founded as a shipyard electrician and ultimately led into the halls of government.

LEAD: There is a Carnegie Deli here. There is a Saks Fifth Avenue. There are enough Mets fans to drown out the locals at Dodger Stadium. There is even going to be a subway. So perhaps it was inevitable that Los Angeles would one day get Donald J. Trump.
LEAD: Magic Johnson had 22 points and 13 assists and Byron Scott scored 22 points as the Los Angeles Lakers beat New Jersey, 121-105, tonight and extended the Nets' losing streak to nine.

LEAD: Cruising at 37,000 feet near the southern New Jersey coast, neither the crew of Avianca Flight 52 nor its passengers had any apparent reason at 7:40 P.M. on Jan. 25 to worry about reaching their destination safely.

LEAD: Melinda Lande and Lief D. Rosenblatt were married yesterday at the Plaza by Rabbi Harlan D. Wechsler.

LEAD: The American Federation of Musicians, which represents 185,000 musicians in the United States and Canada, reached a tentative agreement on Friday evening with representatives of the North American recording industry on a three-year contract.
LEAD: Take a long look ahead. Assume the Soviet military threat continues to recede, as grim necessity imposes a policy of contractionism.

LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a quarterly refunding that begins tomorrow.

LEAD: The Engelhard Corporation, a leading metals refiner, said it would sell those businesses to concentrate on chemical production. The Edison, N.J., concern will also cut 500 jobs from its work force of 8,100 and shut a number of plants. Engelhard's stock fell $1.125 on Friday, to $20.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: THE Exxon Valdez case is coming - ''one or two million pieces of paper,'' by one lawyer's estimate - and it is already testing the courts' ability to adjudicate for thousands of people at a time.

LEAD: The Federal Family Support Act, approved by Congress 16 months ago, has yet to support a single member of the family of New York.

LEAD: Jack Kemp was impatient. It was 6 P.M. one day last spring, and he wanted to mail a letter directing 3,300 public housing authorities to evict drug dealers. Unfortunately, the agency lawyer who was drafting the document had left for the day.

LEAD: In their second season in the National Basketball Association, the Miami Heat have won fewer games than any other team except the Charlotte Hornets. Miami is 19 1/2 games behind the Knicks and may be mathematically eliminated from the Atlantic Division race before the month is over.

LEAD: March 1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is named to succeed Konstantin U. Chernenko as Soviet leader and outlines an urgent agenda to improve the economy. At 54, he is the youngest man to take charge of the Soviet Union since Stalin, who was 45. April 1985: Presiding over the first full session of the Central Committee since the one that brought him to power, Gorbachev elevates three new members to the Politburo: Viktor M.

LEAD: A newly signed agreement between popular front leaders from Armenia and Azerbaijan was put to the test today when Armenian negotiators in the capital of Latvia complained of a fresh outbreak of strife and suspended further talks pending an investigation.

LEAD: Kate Simon, a writer of popular, literate and vivid travel guides and two memoirs that were hailed by reviewers as lucid, lively and humorous, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.
LEAD: The Central Committee of the Albanian Communist Party plans to introduce changes as part of a cautious move away from total control of society, the Albanian state press agency reported today.

LEAD: The hostile relationship between South Africa and other nations on the continent could be transformed into mutual co-operation, but only if negotiations for majority rule prevail, officials in black-ruled Africa countries say.

LEAD: TO some, the magazine publishing company Family Media Inc. is a model of efficiency, able to turn troubled magazines, like The Ladies' Home Journal and Discover, a monthly devoted to science, into profitable operations.

LEAD: Jack C. Zoeller has moved smartly through many careers, first in the Army, then on Wall Street and now in the banking industry. Mr. Zoeller, 40 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Comfed Savings Bank, based in Lowell, Mass.

LEAD: * Cliff Wilton will retire April 1 as vice chairman and executive creative director of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/ Pacific, San Francisco. The agency has named Mike Gold president and chief operating officer, Rob Ingalls executive vice president and creative director, Laura Dearborn executive vice president and media director, and Elizabeth Freeman senior vice president and management supervisor.

LEAD: A 6-year-old boy who was one of 36 children injured in a school bus accident last week died of severe head injuries today. The boy, Joseph Ribaudo of Monroe, was pronounced brain dead at 2:55 P.M., said Barry Bowman, director of public relations at the Westchester County Medical Center here. Joseph is the only child to die from the accident on Tuesday in the Orange County town of Monroe.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d is expected to propose to the Soviets this week an approach for ending the Afghan conflict that would allow President Najibullah to remain in power in Kabul for a transitional period before having to step down, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The wife of Nelson Mandela today repeated that obstacles remained to her husband's release, despite President F. W. de Klerk's assertion on Friday that it was imminent. But Mr. Mandela's wife, Winnie, would not say what the obstacles were.

LEAD: At the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I., yesterday, Carolyn Rand was married to Allan J. Berke. Cantor Harold Lerner officiated. Mrs. Berke, 29 years old, is a daughter of Phyllis Rand of De Witt, N.Y., and the late Dr. Milton Rand. A graduate of the State University of New York at Albany, she is an assistant corporate controller at Prime Motor Inns in Fairfield, N.J.
LEAD: Though not quite a celebration, there was a hesitant sense of victory here this weekend as human rights monitors from 16 countries gathered to discuss the changes in Eastern Europe.
LEAD: The programs of Fox Broadcasting may be moving up in the ratings, but the stock of its parent company, the News Corporation, is sagging.

LEAD: In what was probably its last important legislative act, the military Government has adopted a law granting patent protection to foreign pharmaceutical companies whose products are copied and sold in Chile.

LEAD: The agreement announced Friday in which a large Swiss drug company will buy a majority stake in the biotechnology pioneer Genentech Inc. could be the start of a wave of similar transactions, some industry analysts said this weekend.

LEAD: This year, the President and Congress have an extraordinary opportunity to speak for the poorest and most helpless of all Americans. Those Americans don't have the vote or any economic clout; they don't know how to read and write; and while they may fight among themselves, they can't possibly fight for themselves.

LEAD: The horrors of nuclear war are hard to exaggerate. That hasn't stopped proponents of the ''nuclear winter'' theory, who announced in 1983 that the soot from a large nuclear war would blot out sunlight and create weeks of icy darkness. The result could be ''global environmental changes sufficient to cause the extinction of a major fraction of the plant and animal species on the Earth,'' wrote a group of eminent biologists in Science magazine.

LEAD: The Rev. George A. Stallings Jr., who formed an independent African-American Catholic church last summer, said today that his congregation would encourage the ordination of women and allow birth control and abortion.

LEAD: No sooner does Cam Neely take up his position in the slot than his defenders begin their subtle retreat to positions across what has suddenly become a small, but significant demilitarized zone. The critical ground conceded Neely is done so out of a mixture of respect, fear and a kind of creeping defeatism.

LEAD: Books on audio cassettes are becoming such an important source of income for authors that audio rights are increasingly being treated as valuable literary properties.

LEAD: From the outside, the Microseal Corporation looks like any other small factory on the fringe of Chicago. But inside, there is an experiment under way that could well change the nature of the accounting profession.

LEAD: 1883: The first Russian Marxist group, ''Emancipation of Labor,'' is founded in Geneva, with G. V. Plekhanov at its head. 1898: The Russian Social Democratic Labor Party, a Marxist organization, is founded in Minsk; it is soon broken up by the police and and forced to meet in European exile. 1903: There is a split in the Russian Social Democratic Labor Party; the Bolsheviks, led by Lenin, organize as one wing of the party and pick a name meaning the party of the majority although they gained their majority at a congress by virtue of a protest walkout by others.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company will lay off more than 10 percent of its employees by Feb. 23 because of reduced military spending by the Government, the company's president, William P. Brown, announced. The move will involve about 400 workers each at the company's base plant here and at the California Manufacturing Center in Culver City, Calif.

LEAD: Some letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reveal a great deal about their authors, and some raise intriguing questions. For example, one letter this week said, ''Well, I'm unemployed, illegally sub-subletting a dump, and being looked for by the authorities.''

LEAD: Dave Meggett, the Giants' rookie kick returner and running back, was arrested in Baltimore yesterday on a charge of offering to pay an undercover female police officer for sex. The police said he was charged with lewdness and soliciting a prostitute.
LEAD: ''This,'' Ned O'Gorman said, hugging Kyle Baxter, ''is one of my best friends in the world.''

LEAD: Tugged by conflicting views from his advisers, President Bush gave a studiously tepid speech to the meeting in Washington this week on global climate change. The conflict represents a serious debate, within and outside the Administration, about the seriousness of the feared warming of the world's climate by pollutant gases.

LEAD: Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Trans World Airlines said they had completed their agreement to form a new company that will own and market a computer reservation system. LEAD: In a simple bidding style, a player whose partner opens one no-trump tends to settle in three no-trump if he can see values for game and can rule out a major-suit fit. This leads to an occasional disaster when there is extreme weakness in a major suit and the right contract is game in a minor. It is seldom right to play three no-trump when the partnership has a two-two, or worse, fit in a major.

LEAD: ''A CARAVAGGIO REDISCOVERED: The Lute Player,'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an exhibition modest only in size. It includes paintings of the first rank, paintings that have not been on view in years and paintings that have been unjustly ignored. It juxtaposes these works with related prints, musical scores and instruments to give a vivid sense of the cultural milieu of the late 16th century, in which Caravaggio was fortunate enough to find himself.

LEAD: Manhattan still awaits a great Thai restaurant. There are a dozen or so places around town that turn out a striking dish or two - and there are some solid family-run places in Brooklyn and Queens -yet no place has captured in a big way the delicacy and diversity of this underrated cuisine. If pressed to recommend Thai food, I usually mention the Los Angeles import Tommy Tang's on Greenwich Street.

LEAD: President Bush yesterday awarded the Flo Hyman Award for excellence in sports to Chris Evert, the recently retired tennis pro, calling her ''the role model for our nation's young women.''

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is prepared to accept President Bush's proposal for deeper troop cuts in Europe, but only if the plan leaves both countries with equal levels, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said this morning.

LEAD: * Colgate-Palmolive Co., the consumer products company, said it would form a joint venture in Portugal with the Unisol division of Quimigal, a state-owned Portuguese company that sells household products. Colgate will own 70 percent of the venture.

LEAD: E. Francis Bowditch, dean of students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1951 to 1956 and later headmaster of the New Lincoln School in Manhattan, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday in Boca Grande, Fla. He was 77 years old and had homes in Boca Grande and Madison, Conn.
LEAD: Mary Ground, an elder of the Blackfeet Indian tribe, died Wednesday. She was 107 years old.
LEAD: The people who staged the Vitalis/Meadowlands Invitational track meet tonight offered a total of $250,000 in bonuses for runners breaking world indoor records in three races.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: The soprano Shirley Verrett is to be the first guest in the spring series of Lincoln Center Offstage evenings, at 6 P.M. on Thursday at Paul Hall at the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street. The program consists of an hourlong discussion between a moderator and the performer. An informal wine-and-cheese reception follows.
LEAD: Dispirited Soviet consumers face a cutback in meat production because the country has run out of grain to feed its cattle, the Government's chief food official says in remarks published today.

LEAD: The United States and three South American countries have reached tentative agreement on a plan to cooperate in combating drug traffic throughout the hemisphere, Administration officials said tonight.

LEAD: While more and more air bags are being installed in new cars to enhance safety and to comply with Federal law, auto makers are scrambling to satisfy rising consumer demand for improved seat-belt design.

LEAD: SUSAN EISENHOWER and ROALD Z. SAGDEYEV cemented one aspect of American-Soviet relations yesterday when they were married in Moscow. The couple made their vows at a Protestant service at the residence of the United States Ambassador, JACK F. MATLOCK.

LEAD: When the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth-Harold Prince musical ''Merrily We Roll Along'' opened on Broadway in November 1981, it was blasted by the critics and closed after 16 performances. But the show has refused to die.

LEAD: Lord Maclean, the former chief official of Queen Elizabeth II's household and organizer of the 1981 wedding of the Prince of Wales, died on Thursday, his family announced today. He was 73 years old.
LEAD: A rift has emerged between the Palestine Liberation Organization and Egypt, one of the P.L.O.'s principal Arab sponsors, diplomats and Egyptian commentators say.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Prudential Strategic Income Fund (NYSE) As of Jan 26 1990 1989 Assets 548,983,969 605,987,795 Per share 7.91 8.87 Assets represented net assets and per share earnings are net asset value per share.

LEAD: Legislators and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis are backing a bill that would create a commission to investigate the way news organizations and the police coped with the events that began with the shooting death of Carol Stuart.

LEAD: A fire burned track ties on the West Side IRT line and delayed 10,000 people yesterday afternoon. The fire, at 72d Street and Broadway, was reported at 3:50 P.M., after debris on the southbound express track ignited, a spokesman for the Transit Authority, Termaine Garden, said. The No. 1, 3 and 9 lines halted for 35 minutes.

LEAD: Treasury securities prices soared yesterday as investors rushed to lock in yields, which have been tumbling since the conclusion of this week's refunding auctions. Dealers said the same high yields that led to the successful sale of $30 billion of Treasury notes and bonds attracted investors to the secondary market in these issues.
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a mini-van here today, the Previa, which features some unusual solutions to technical problems that have vexed such designers for more than a decade.

LEAD: After a furious fight and by a narrow margin, Congress sustained President Bush's veto of a bill giving Chinese students in America a statutory right to stay. Mr. Bush had warned Congress that if it insisted on the bill, Beijing would retaliate by cutting off future student exchanges.

LEAD: In Washington State, SENATOR JIM WEST struck a blow for romance after his proposal to make it illegal for couples under 18 to engage in ''heavy petting'' failed to make it out of committee last week. He succeeded in another proposal: during a State Senate session Mr. West, a Republican from Spokane, sent a note to GINGER MARSHALL, who was watching from the gallery.
LEAD: Final touches have been put on the new constitution. South-west Africa will become independent Namibia on March 21, the first day of spring, completing the formal decolonization of Africa.

LEAD: Romania and Repentance The head of the World Council of Churches has conceded that the group failed to take a public stand against Nicolae Ceausescu when he was the Romanian dictator.
LEAD: Dan Rather and Peter Jennings went to Moscow this week, but Tom Brokaw stayed home.
LEAD: Georg Arne Borgstrom, a scientist, geographer and ecologist who was an authority on hunger, died Wednesday in Goteborg, Sweden. He was 77 years old and had lived in Goteborg since 1988.

LEAD: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Buzzer Shot Gives Yale a Victory Casey Cammann scored on a pass from Ed Peterson as the buzzer sounded to give Yale a hard-fought 67-65 overtime victory last night over Cornell in an Ivy League game in New Haven. Cornell had forged a 35-27 halftime lead, in part because of 12 first-half points from Steve Johnson, a guard.
LEAD: An American man was found shot to death amid ancient stone ruins in the Andean city of Cuzco, Peru's tourism center and once the capital of the Incas, the police said today.
LEAD: The Lithuanian parliament has approved a resolution declaring Lithuania's 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union ''unlawful and invalid'' and seeking talks with Moscow on independence.

LEAD: The Boston Symphony concerts Wednesday and Thursday nights at Carnegie Hall were originally to have been conducted by Seiji Ozawa, and to have offered a rather more interesting program than usual -Haydn's ''London'' Symphony, Yo-Yo Ma in Shostakovich's Cello Concerto No. 2 and, at the very end, Rossini's ''Semiramide''
LEAD: The Devils rallied from a two-goal deficit in the third period tonight and defeated the Capitals, 5-3, here in a game with more stoppages than a busy city street during rush hour.

LEAD: Silliness and optimism became amiably subversive when the B-52's performed on Wednesday at Radio City Music Hall in the second of three sold-out concerts. The B-52's turn eccentricities and campy inside jokes into public revelry, sharing the possibility of pleasure in dangerous times. ''Do anything you want,'' Fred Schneider exhorted in ''Dance This Mess
LEAD: Peter J. Malatesta, a restaurateur and aide to former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, died of pancreatic cancer on Thursday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 57 years old.

LEAD: The stock market ended a strong week on a subdued but positive note yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up by 3.83 points, to 2,648.20, with advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange leading declining ones by 826 to 667.

LEAD: BARBARA BUSH is lending her home and her prestige to a cause close to her heart, the eradication of illiteracy in America. Tomorrow night she will be host to the National Literacy Honors, a program that recognizes reading tutors and their successful pupils.

LEAD: The ponds, palm trees and other oasis-like amenities of Orlando International Airport are under siege. Thousands of construction workers, hundreds of trucks with tons of dirt and concrete, and 45,000 passengers pour in and out of the airport every day.

LEAD: Operating in a business more ego-ridden than most, Richard Goode's collaboration with Dawn Upshaw on Wednesday night seemed an unusual event. This, after all, was the last of three concerts at the 92d Street Y entitled ''The Richard Goode Series''; yet the pianist seemed happy to share it - indeed, to give most of its time - to a young

LEAD: Almost a week after President F. W. de Klerk pledged to release him, Nelson Mandela remains imprisoned in South Africa. A visit by Jesse Jackson, the black American leader, has become the latest excuse for keeping the black South African leader in custody. When Mr. Jackson arrived Wednesday, a Government spokesman said it was unlikely Mr.
LEAD: The governing party and two opposition groups completed a merger today that gives them a huge majority in Parliament, and students responded with protests, firebombs and rocks.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation will close its Mount Sterling, Ky., dishwasher plant by March 1991 and lay off most of the factory's 650 workers. The appliance company said the plant's production would be shifted to its Findlay, Ohio, factory, which already makes dishwashers.
LEAD: The Government today announced plans to toughen its rules on the health claims that are made about food products.
LEAD: For the first time, a hospital will conduct random drug and alcohol tests on all doctors who deal directly with patients.

LEAD: Celebrating an occasion of personal joy seems to bring out the charitable instinct in many people. Births, engagements, weddings, significant birthdays and anniversaries have all been cited with gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, a theater review on Sunday about the Manhattan Punch Line's sixth annual festival of one-act comedies appeared with an incomplete paragraph. It should have read: ''Under the clockwork direction and choreography of Jason McConnell Buzas, the cast -Randy Danson, Liz Larsen, Ryan Hilliard and Chris Welles in the title role - turns 'Philip Glass Buys a Loaf of Bread' into a vintage skit worthy of a 'Forbidden Off Broadway.

LEAD: Del Shannon, who wrote and sang the hit, ''Runaway'' in 1961, was found dead in his home, apparently from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head, the authorities said today. He was 50 years old.

LEAD: When to employ a quarantine, the isolation or detention of individuals determined to be an infectious danger to others, is not a new dilemma in public health -especially not in the city of Typhoid Mary. Yet the recent media hullabaloo and protest circus over Mayor David Dinkins's appointment of Woodrow Myers as New York City Health Commissioner badly confused this issue.

LEAD: William Louther's Dance Theater Corporation will present ''Murder at the Town Hall'' today at 2 and 7 P.M. at the Kaufman Theater of the American Museum of Natural History. Mr. Louther, a former member of the companies of Martha Graham, Alvin Ailey and Donald McKayle, formed his own troupe in 1974 to enable actors, dancers and musicians to work together on projects.

LEAD: New Jersey's Education Commissioner, Dr. Saul Cooperman, leaves office at the end of June, content that changes he has engineered have eased the state's teacher shortage, toughened tests for basic skills and allowed the state to take over troubled districts to try to improve education in them.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's tentative proposal to shut or scale down dozens more military bases caused predictable howls in Congress. Some members warned of economic catastrophe. Others said Mr. Cheney was picking on Democrats. Nonsense, he replied, I'm just saving money. But he may also have been needling members who aim to cut weapons he wants to keep.

LEAD: Subsidiaries of the Chrysler Corporation and Philips N.V. of the Netherlands are negotiating a joint venture to make auto electronics products, the companies said. The Philips unit, Philips Car Stereo International G.m.b.H. of West Germany, would hold a majority interest in the venture with Chrysler's parts subsidiary, Acustar

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about an antitrust ruling against the American Medical Association for its boycott of chiropractors described the Federal appeals court's opinion incompletely in some copies. The opinion, by the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, said the A.M.A. had economic motives but was acting mostly out of concern about scientific methods in patient care.
LEAD: Unrepentant, the Israeli peace campaigner Abie Nathan was released from prison today. He vowed to continue the activities for which he was jailed four months ago.

LEAD: CBS was deluged with telephone calls yesterday, some from people supporting Andy Rooney, others praising the network's three-month suspension of the ''60 Minutes'' commentator. Network spokesmen would not say exactly how many calls had been received.

LEAD: The decision to own or to rent a home has traditionally been based on three elements: cost, personal preference and investment. But the recent decline in house and apartment prices has made a such an investment less of a sure thing and has helped to convert many potential buyers into renters, if only temporarily.
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company is giving theatergoers a bonus - no commercials with its movies. That may please some moviegoers, but cinema advertising executives and theater owners are unhappy.

LEAD: ATLANTA, Feb. 9 - Federal investigators today examined several boxes of materials and documents seized Thursday in the investigation of the Southern mail bomb attacks that killed two people in December.

LEAD: A former official of the Unisys Corporation was sentenced today to a year in prison for conspiring to make illegal campaign donations and obstructing the F.B.I.'s investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.21 percent, up from 10.17 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.46 percent this week, up from 8.45 percent the week before.

LEAD: A 48-year-old police commander, whose reputation as a management expert helped propel his rapid rise within the New York City Police Department in the last six years, was appointed as First Deputy Police Commissioner yesterday, the department's second highest post.

LEAD: In an unusual demonstration of official solidarity, Mayor David N. Dinkins and a half-dozen Brooklyn politicians met at City Hall yesterday to pledge their help to a black man whose newly purchased house in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn was set afire Thursday in what the authorities say was racially motivated arson.
LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers decided at their December meeting on a further easing of their high-interest-rate policies because of the sluggish economy, according to minutes released today.

LEAD: Douglas Long, chairman of The Sunday Correspondent, a British weekly newspaper, and co-founder of the daily Independent, died of liver cancer on Wednesday. He was 65 years old. Mr. Long was deputy managing director of the Mirror Group of newspapers, whose flagship is The Daily Mirror, and in 1980 was made deputy chief executive of the group.
LEAD: The players tied the owners, 3-3, yesterday when the Pittsburgh Pirate pitcher Bob Kipper won his salary arbitration case, which was heard Thursday in Chicago.

LEAD: A senior adviser to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that East Germany might become insolvent in a few days. But spokesmen for the Governments of East and West Germany rejected the statement, as did bankers and diplomats.

LEAD: Throwing up a new obstacle to the secession of Staten Island, state leaders said today that they had agreed on a bill that would give the Legislature the final say over whether the borough could pull away from the rest of New York City.

LEAD: Government troops have overrun a stronghold of minority rebels along the Thai border after 10 days of fighting in which at least 36 people were killed, a military spokesman said today.

LEAD: In ''Hard to Kill,'' Steven Seagal, the latest and suavest inheritor of the Charles Bronson-Chuck Norris-Bruce Lee action-film mantle, comes out of a seven-year coma looking a lot better than most people would look going in. The tanned, trim, very carefully groomed Mr. Seagal, who sports a sleek ponytail and favors starched white shirts even though they often wind up with bloodstains, is significantly more dapper than the Los Angeles police detective he is supposed to be.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Hundreds of workers in yellow slickers, carrying oversized paper towels, patrolled the beaches south of here today picking up shiny, coin-size gobs of oil. But the weather continued to hold the bulk of Wednesday's tanker spill a few miles offshore.
LEAD: Iran's supreme religious leader said today that a decree calling for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie, issued by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini a year ago, remained in force.

LEAD: The main rebel group fighting the Ethiopian Government began a long-expected military offensive on Thursday apparently aimed at forcing the Government out of the last piece of Eritrea that it still occupies.

LEAD: A Federal district judge yesterday morning ordered the arrest of Eddie Antar, the founder of Crazy Eddie Inc., after Mr. Antar failed to make a court appearance in a civil case and also disregarded an order to return $52 million that the Government contends is illegal profits.
LEAD: Elizabeth Bryan Patten, a Chattanooga philanthropist and civic leader, died Thursday at Memorial Hospital in Chattanooga. She was 82 years old.

LEAD: Struggling to adjust to events in Eastern Europe, Western Europe's leading Communist parties have seen themselves forced to applaud the crisis convulsing international Communism to preserve some credibility before their own democratic electorates.

LEAD: Mike Tyson weighed in at 220 pounds today for his heavyweight title defense against James (Buster) Douglas, who weighed 231 1/2.

LEAD: In another indication of the weakness in the market for ''junk bonds,'' RJR Nabisco Inc., whose $4 billion in securities dominate the high-yield market, has postponed a $1.25 billion junk bond offering.

Like all instant analyses, they made an outcome jurors wrestled over for four days seem all but inevitable.

LEAD: Reflecting December's exceptionally harsh weather, producer prices soared 1.8 percent in January, the biggest rise in more than 15 years, the Labor Department reported today.
LEAD: John H. Poelker, an accountant who served one term as Mayor after 10 years as comptroller, died today after a long struggle against cancer. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: The world's most prolific stamp designer never sold a design to any government. Rather, he created his own governments, dozens of them, in a wave of artistic wit in the early 1970's. His designs in watercolor have been circulated throughout the world and now hang in museums and galleries.

LEAD: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it. The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left. I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking.

LEAD: The Golden Triangle of Southeast Asia, whose flow of drugs the United States has been trying to control for 25 years, is once again the single-largest source of heroin coming into America, with production levels rising sharply.

LEAD: MICHAEL F. CATANIA, a former state official, says this decade will be a pivotal one for the environment. Improvements in environmental quality, he says, will have to come as much from individuals as from industry and will require people to make substantial changes in the ways they live.

LEAD: Chocolate is not an aphrodisiac. Chocolate is not addictive. But for millions, chocolate satisfies the mind and the heart.

LEAD: To the Editor: In his letter on Pavlovsk (Letters on Travel, Jan. 14), Lester Schulman observes that New York ''is rapidly surpassing Calcutta as a model of urban squalor and decay.''

LEAD: THE release of a long-awaited Federal review of the proposed $1 billion residential complex on David's Island, a deserted 78-acre site off the coast of New Rochelle, has renewed a bitter public debate and set the stage for a final state study that will determine whether the project can proceed.

LEAD: ONE of New Haven's many attractions is the ethnic diversity of its restaurant scene. In addition to Chinese, French, Indian, Italian, Mexican, Thai and Vietnamese retaurants, there are now three Japanese restaurants in town. Ashiya, named for a town in Japan, is the latest to appear.

LEAD: Later this week, we'll be so smitten with Valentine's Day chocolates, flowers and love that coins won't mean a thing. Years ago in the make-believe kingdom of love, coins were the currency of the realm.
LEAD: LENINISM, a doctrine with roots in the 19th century that was a scourge of most of the 20th, has finally begun to lose its hold over the Soviet Union on the eve of the 21st.

LEAD: The dollar lost more ground last week as the West German mark rose because of euphoria over the sudden acceleration of negotiations for a common currency for East and West Germany. The current wor ries about higher interest rates and a slumping bond market in West Germany should only weaken the mark temporarily.

LEAD: THE LEXICON OF fury needs constant updating. In describing a person in a state of extreme rage - your boss, for example, or a red-faced baby in a highchair - you show your age or tolerance for cliches with hit the ceiling, go through the roof, split a gut, blow his stack/cork/gasket, or fly off the handle.

LEAD: Ken Oberman, manager of Oppenheimer & Company's Global Fund, keeps several cartoons taped near the computer in his crowded New York City office. One depicts the late Andrei Sakharhov as a diminutive figure on one end of a seesaw upending a massive stone monument of Stalin. Another shows Lech Walesa and asks: How many Poles does it take to change the world?

LEAD: Four times a year, the Treasury Department sells billions of dollars in notes and bonds to raise money to finance the budget deficit. Before each auction, the cry goes out that the securities could be hard to sell because the Japanese may be reluctant buyers, either because they are annoyed with Americans or are attracted to better investments elsewhere.

LEAD: John Cobb, a pianist whose reputation rests largely on his recordings of contemporary music, devoted his program last Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall to works drawn mostly from the Romantic mainstream. The one exception, Clementi's Sonata in F-sharp minor, straddles the line between Classicism and Romanticism.

LEAD: ANY SPACECRAFT THAT inspires allusions to Alice of Wonderland cannot be meant for some ordinary excursion through the heavens. The Hubble Space Telescope is, indeed, not just any spacecraft. Scheduled for launching this spring, after five years of delays, the spacecraft and its exquisitely polished 94 1/2-inch-wide telescopic mirror should enable astronomers to see farther and 10 times more clearly than they have before, out tantalizingly close to the edge of the universe and toward the very beginning of time.
LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union appear to have agreed on virtually all major elements of a strategic-arms treaty that calls for deep reductions in long-range nuclear weapons.

LEAD: For nearly a decade, Case Western Reserve University has had a place for students to escape the pressures of classes, roommates, soul mates, parents and illness, but few students knew about it. Now the existence and virtues of the Refuge, as it is known, are being advertised on campus as the program has expanded.

LEAD: A factory at Nassau and Jay Streets in downtown Brooklyn that was used during World War II to make the Norden bombsight is being renovated into office and retailing space.

LEAD: Sometimes Sunday outings need not have a destination, but rather a direction - and let chance be your tour guide. A leisurely drive through parts of Westchester County offers a little of everything to the weekend rambler: history, antiques, scenery, shopping, and even some exceptionally fine dining.

LEAD: WHEN Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposed cutting the Social Security tax, some party consultants seized on the idea as a brilliant political weapon. Here was a Democratic tax cut for the 1990's that was fairer than the Republican tax cuts of the 1980's. At the same time, the proposal revealed two facts of Republican fiscal policy: that cuts in the progressive income tax had effectively been paid for by increases in the regressive payroll tax, and that the proceeds were being spent like any other revenues rather than being socked away.
LEAD: IT is time to dust off the heart-shaped cookie cutters and cake molds again. Valentine's Day is Wednesday.

LEAD: Of the nine computer companies that formed an alliance in 1988 to develop an ''extended industry standard architecture'' (EISA) for personal computers, Zenith Data Systems Inc. of Glenview, Ill., was the last to announce the details of its designs. But late last month Zenith became one of the first to bring such a machine to market.

LEAD: True tartans are the stuff of drama and legend, conjuring up swashbuckling tales of Scots wearing kilts woven in the plaid of their clan. Now, the tartan patterns are used on all sorts of fabrics to make dashing designs for women to wear in all seasons and at any time of day.

LEAD: AFTER a decade in which average incomes fell while foreign debt and inflation soared, Latin America remains in deep economic crisis. The future of its new democracies may well rest on the ability of civilian leaders to improve living standards in the 1990's as they try to modernize their economies in the face of enormous obstacles.

LEAD: A bitter dispute over control of this city's school system has provoked racial animosity just a month before a planned 25th-anniversary commemoration of the ''Bloody Sunday'' protest march that placed Selma indelibly on the map of civil rights battlegrounds.

LEAD: FORGET the cold and dreary days of winter; the Van Fleet Circus has come to Oceanville. Under the big top, clowns cavort, trapeze acrobats hang by their delicate toes and ferocious of the Noyes Museum here. lions glare out from their cages. A calliope and three separate bands seem to be playing a cacophony of oom-pah-pah music.

LEAD: Sarah Bloom, an associate in New York for the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, and Jamin Ben Raskin, the general counsel to the National Rainbow Coalition, a social-political organization in Washington, are planning an August wedding.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Magic Johnson of the Lakers has already racked up five National Basketball Association championships. Ewing, Jordan, Barkley, Karl Malone, Akeem Olajuwon and Dominique Wilkins as a group are still searching for their first.

LEAD: He has been drawing since he was 10 years old, when his parents would take him out to dinner and talk about politics. ''I was bored,'' John S. Winkleman recalled, so he covered the restaurant's paper placemats with line drawings of houses and buildings.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Cynthia Crane is a cabaret singer who develops her programs with unusually industrious and productive research. This research has enabled her to do programs on such relatively commonplace themes as songs of the 1920's, the 30's and the 40's, programs that have been brightened by unfamiliar songs - some funny, some romantic, some that reflect the mores of the times - along with tidbits of background information that add to the interest of what is sung.

LEAD: The John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital, once the finest in West Africa, recently announced on the radio that its morgue could no longer accept ''dead-on-arrival bodies'' until relatives claimed the ones that were already decomposing. The hospital said the morgue's refrigerator was broken. Hardly anyone here was surprised.

LEAD: The engagement of Mary Dombrowski to Joseph B. Rizzo, a son of Joan A. Rizzo of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dombrowski of Westfield, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''THERE'S nothing I enjoy more than a good go at a steak-and-kidney pudding in the open air,'' says a character in ''The Magic Pudding,'' Norman Lindsay's children's book that has been a best seller in Britain since it was first published in Australia in 1918. Whether outdoors or in, upstairs or down, new-fangled or old-fashioned, most

LEAD: DURING a dial-turning session one quiet evening, Paul Newman's face flashed onto my television screen. To my surprise he was talking to Barbara Walters. I'm not a fan of the ubiquitous Ms. Walters but I knew that Newman rarely submits to an interview. I paused to listen.

LEAD: At the opening volleys of his racketeering trial, Federal District Judge Robert P. Aguilar has been portrayed by the Government as an example of the American dream turned nightmare of public disgrace because of power brokering on behalf of a Federal fugitive, a casino owner and two convicted felons.

LEAD: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on Jan. 28 omitted an airline under the heading ''Discount Fare.'' The airline, B.W.I.A., matches the lowest fare, $249, available on the New York-Barbados route.

LEAD: The marriage of Susanne Goetz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Goetz of Piscataway, N.J., to Stephen William Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Miller of Bethesda, Md., and Canberra, Australia, took place yesterday at the Takoma Park (Md.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. George Taylor performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The recent article ''A New Breed of Volunteers Alters Ways of Helping Others'' captured the spirit of the ''new breed,'' people who work from 9 to 5 and still make time in their busy schedules to help others early in the morning, evenings and weekends, or during lunch hours, as well as retirees who are giving their time and expertise.
LEAD: The Has-Been: Larry Bird. Now: Michael Jordan. The Future: David Robinson. GEORGE HELLER Summit, N.J.

LEAD: Sarah Skaggs often depicted choreographic struggles in the program she offered on Thursday night for the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. There were also moments of virtuosic skill. But it was the struggles that held the attention.

LEAD: THE Board of Legislators seemed to solve one problem while compounding another last week when it approved the construction of an $18.9 million sludge-drying plant in the Ludlow Park section of Yonkers. The action came in time for the county to avoid Federal fines for ocean dumping of toxic wastes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Larry Bird is superb in virtually all aspects of the game, much like Oscar Robertson was. Michael Jordan has no peers in the talent department, as was the case with Wilt Chamberlain. Magic Johnson is comparable to Bird in his knowledge of the game as well as style of play.

LEAD: Working in a Spain that has thrown off austerity and solemnity in favor of being frivolous, irreverent, promiscuous, materialistic and just a touch superficial, Pedro Almodovar makes no claims to be making films for posterity.

LEAD: On the first page of THE WORLD BEYOND THE HILL: Science Fiction and the Quest for Transcendence (Jeremy P. Tarcher, $29.95), Alexei Panshin and Cory Panshin identify science fiction as ''the myth of the modern Western world.'' This is not offered as a thesis to be defended or a concept to be explored, but as an axiom that the reader must accept in order to make sense of the 685-page history of science fiction that follows.

LEAD: While Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has been out of town almost three weeks undergoing treatment behind closed doors in Florida, the grand jury investigating allegations of drug use by him has been working hard behind closed doors here. In fact, it has increased its labors. Federal prosecutors have refused to discuss details of the grand jury's work.

LEAD: Housebuster staggered home to a three-length victory over Yonder today in the $94,645 Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park as Rhythm, last year's 2-year-old champion, finished a dismal seventh in his first start as a 3-year-old.

LEAD: Even by the none-too-decorous standards of Israeli political discourse, the mudslinging leading into the Likud party showdown on Monday between Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and three antagonists led by Ariel Sharon seems to be reaching for new lows.

LEAD: Catherine Elizabeth Farley and David S. Elkind were married yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Avery C. Manchester, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. Margaret Patricia Farley, the bride's sister, was her maid of honor and P. Gregory Schwed was the best man.

LEAD: Camper Van Beethoven played a set like a shaggy-dog story on Tuesday night, opening a three-night engagement at CBGB (315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street). The band's singer, David Lowery, kept asking the audience, ''Are you tired yet?'' The music was unhurried, casual and digressive, with a deadpan ease that carried listeners toward mild punch lines.

LEAD: As things stood last week, the next 780 minutes of ''60 Minutes'' will include no minutes with Andy Rooney. Mr. Rooney, a commentator on the weekly show, was suspended for three months without pay after racist statements were attributed to him in The Advocate, a gay magazine. Mr. Rooney, whose comments have previously incurred the wrath of gay groups, immediately denied the quote and later said it had been made up as part of a campaign by homosexuals to discredit him.

LEAD: An effort to slip past a hostile committee a bill that would have restricted abortions for minors failed in the State Senate on Friday, apparently dooming any chance for such legislation in Virginia this year.

LEAD: FOR a time it seemed that the Iran-contra investigation might lead into the Oval Office and threaten the Presidency of Ronald Reagan. In any case, many hoped, the appointment of Lawrence E. Walsh as special prosecutor in the case would finally help affix responsibility for the secret actions that bedeviled Mr.
LEAD: There are many great players out there, but how many players can fly? Jordan can do it all. STU SALTZMAN Nanuet, N.Y.
LEAD: EDWARD TELLER Giant of the Golden Age of Physics. By Stanley A. Blumberg and Louis G. Panos. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

LEAD: CLASSICAL MUSIC lovers, hoping to be better informed when they take their seats at concerts, are flocking to lectures to gain insights about the music they will hear. Attendance at the lectures has surged, and in some instances, what is packing them in falls just short of theatrics.

LEAD: ''I don't want to hurt you/I just want to join in/ This is a kindly creamer/ A kindly crematorium,'' Tanita Tikaram sings in ''Thursday's Child,'' one of 10 cryptic ballads on her second album, ''The Sweet Keeper'' (Reprise 26091-2; all three formats).

LEAD: Danbury, Conn. $178,500 7 Craigmoor Terrace 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old raised ranch; h/w floors, screened, flagstoned porch, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,857. Norwalk, Conn. $284,000 5 Charcoal Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old colonial; sauna, skylights, raised-hearth fireplace, 0.33 acre; taxes $3,321.

LEAD: AT the age of 68 and with a resume that includes more than 25 athletic jobs, including coach of three professional and seven college footall teams, just about anybody would agree that Lou Saban could use a rest. Just about anybody, that is, but Lou Saban.
LEAD: An article last week about the California clothing company L.A. Gear misstated the length of time the chief financial officer's post had been vacant. It was two months.

LEAD: Q. Our house is more than 60 years old and has more than one roof on it. The last roof has been on about 20 years, and the last time a contractor checked it he said there were many more years of wear left. I am concerned about the weight of more than one roof on the house because there are some cracks in the foundation, and it appears to me as though the house may be sinking.

LEAD: Celebrities have to be cautious about what they endorse these days: somebody might buy it. Lloyd Bridges, the actor, last week became the latest celebrity endorser to be held personally responsible for the failure of a product he pitched. In an out-of-court settlement, Mr. Bridges paid an undisclosed sum to 11 people who lost hundreds of thousands of dollars they had invested with a Michigan real-estate outfit whose principals wound up in jail for fraud.

LEAD: Elizabeth M. Watson was confirmed as Police Chief on Wednesday, making Houston the largest city with a police department headed by a woman. She succeeds Lee P. Brown, who is now he Police Commissioner of New York City.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor: On a recent visit to Munich, I visited the German Museum of Hunting and Fishing on Neuhauser Strasse. I found the entire museum fascinating, but one exhibit particularly impressed me. On the second floor was a large, low table filled with stuffed animals. In addition to a written identification of these animals, a Braille plate beside each one bore its name.

LEAD: Five championship rings. Two-time Most Valuable Player. Ear-to-ear grin. Need I say more? SHAWN J. RUBEL Jersey City

LEAD: Although it has been 17 years since Long Island's Matejov family got word that 21-year-old Joseph had been killed in an Air Force mission over Laos, Mary Matejov says she knows that her son survived the crash and that the United States Government knowingly lied to her about his status.
LEAD: A study of Lyndon B. Johnson provides new evidence that the 36th President stole his first election to the United States Senate, in 1948.

LEAD: While the French may take their dogs out to dinner, some New Yorkers bring their dogs to the office. Typically, the work place is within walking distance of home, since dogs (other than seeing-eye dogs or small dogs in carriers) are not allowed on public transportation. And, too, these pet owners are often their own bosses, who can set their own rules.

LEAD: To the Editor: I had decided on an extended trip to Rome to study Italian, and your article appeared just one week before I left Ohio. Based on your listing, I selected the Torre di Bable Language Center at 74 Via Bixio. After four weeks of intensive Italian classes, I felt almost like a Roman!

LEAD: The recent ''New Jersey Q & A'' interview with Dr. Michiko Kosaka (''On the Trail of Automatic Translation'') may have unintentionally given the impression that translation by computer is still only at the stage of a research project.

LEAD: Lincoln's Brithday will be celebrated Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal and state open. City closed. Post Office: Regular service. Banks: Option to close. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No pick-up, recycling collection or street cleaning.

LEAD: The rift between the Rev. George A. Stallings Jr. and the Roman Catholic Church apparently is terminal. The Archdiocese of Washington announced last week that Father Stallings, a priest who founded a separate congregation for black Catholics last summer, had excommunicated himself from the faith through his public statements.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: An article on page 31 of Arts and Leisure about the conductor Bruno Weil misstates the date of one of his appearances at the 92d Street Y. He will conduct on Saturday at 8 P.M., as well as Sunday at 3, and not on Monday.

LEAD: At a time when a shaky ''junk bond'' market and a paucity of takeover deals have sent many Wall Street arbitragers to the sidelines, a few stalwarts are still hanging in. In fact, they contend that the current bloodbath in takeover stocks should not be cause for concern. Rather, they say, it should be seen as just another business opportunity.

LEAD: MY childhood was marred by what I considered an unforgivable deprivation: 16 years elapsed between my birth and my first flight on an airplane. When my parents finally relented and let me ascend into the heavens - an hourlong shuttle flight from La Guardia to Logan to accompany an older brother on a college interview in Boston - I got airsick.

LEAD: Hundreds of Bulgarians, chanting ''No money for Commies'' and ''Democracy U.S.A.'' in English, greeted Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on his arrival today. He stopped for 12 hours to press the new Government to conduct free and fair elections.

LEAD: Recently, Thai restaurants have sprung up like mushrooms after a spring rain. Yet, they are still uncommon on Long Island, and the opening of a new Thai outpost is cause for rejoicing among lovers of this intricate and intriguing cuisine.
LEAD: The four 50-year-old oaks and five magnolias alongside the football stadium at Louisiana State University still stand, saved from the saw by student and faculty protests.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article ''Treasure House of Gods of India'' by Olivier Bernier (Travel, Jan. 7) brought back memories of several visits to the Madras Government Museum which I made while living in that city.
LEAD: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Suzette M. Brooks and Seth J. Masters described the prospective bride's education incompletely. She graduated cum laude from Harvard Law School.

LEAD: A friend has been preoccupied of late with copying the pages of old magazines. He is not trying to make reproduction-grade images, just records of what appears on the printed pages. He is also worried that the camera he is using isn't right for the job.

LEAD: ''YOU KNOW WHAT MY FRUSTRATION IN ALL this is?'' Al Bianchi, general manager of the New York Knicks, was saying. ''That I knew, because I had the experience, what a chance we had to win the championship last year. You understand?''

LEAD: WHEN Michael DiScala and James Gardella bought the Lock Building near the waterfront of the South Norwalk neighborhood 17 years ago, they knew that the city was at its nadir. The partially rented, 125,000-square-foot factory was losing $60,000 a year and was surrounded by derelict industrial buildings in an area that attracted street people.

LEAD: In a letter carried here clandestinely, a Catholic bishop in the former Portuguese colony of East Timor has described the human rights situation there as intolerable and has criticized Portugal and the United Nations for failing to intervene on behalf of the Indonesian-occupied territory.

LEAD: ''A New Life Beckons Organ Recipients'' (Jan. 21) told the stories of four transplant recipients whose lives were turned around because they were able to receive an organ transplant. It was an article full of joy and hope. There are hundreds of others who have been given a second chance at life. The list grows daily.

LEAD: At times it seemed a futile exercise. But for weeks on end Mordechai Glick and a few other volunteers showed up outside the United States Embassy each morning at dawn and handed leaflets to Israelis waiting in long lines outside the visa office.
LEAD: It seems that there is always someone who wants to bring the House down, or at least shake it up.

LEAD: James (Buster) Douglas rebounded from a nearly devastating eighth-round knockdown today to pummel Mike Tyson into an overwhelming knockout 1:23 into the 10th round and take the world heavyweight title away from a boxer who had been declared all but unbeatable.

LEAD: EARLY on in the American Stage Company's new musical, ''A Fine and Private Place,'' a big bologna descends from on high, landing on the stage with a thump. Unless a show aspires to follow in the pratfalls of ''Sugar Babies'' or ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' it's not likely to live down a portentous moment like that.
LEAD: When large overcoats hide fashion, hats become a prime form of expression. This winter, it seems, every other hat wearer is an artist.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a veteran of six walking trips with three different organizations, I read Betsy Wade's article on walking vacations (Practical Traveler, Dec. 3) with great interest. In 1980 I went on my first English walking trip, conducted by Douglas Caldow of Country Walking Holidays, a 17-day trip in four different areas.

LEAD: Lisa Lynn Shrewsberry and Edgar Charles Ivory Greene were married yesterday at Simsbury House in Simsbury, Conn., by Mr. and Mrs. Webster T. Copp, justices of the peace from West Hartford, Conn.

LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk announced today that Nelson Mandela would be released from a prison outside Cape Town on Sunday afternoon, ending 27 and a half years of imprisonment for South Africa's most celebrated black leader.

LEAD: A decade ago, a dozen major tire manufacturers, half of them American, vied for world leadership. Today, just six giant companies, one in the process of formation, are dominant. The only one based in America is the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

LEAD: For the revolutionary executive, there is a Sandinista briefcase. For his wife, a Sandinista apron. And for the revolutionary child, there is everything from Sandinista lunchboxes to Sandinista building blocks.

LEAD: Brown's heralded 20-year experiment in student-guided undergraduate education was labeled a ''resounding success'' in an internal review published last week by the university. But its author said the program, free of stated requirements and featuring a pass/fail grade option, has not worked for ''a small minority'' who need a curriculum made of sterner stuff.
LEAD: The New York City Ballet featured some talented young male dancers in leading roles last Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.
LEAD: It's been six years since he has been on native soil, but now that things have loosened up a bit in his homeland, Ivan Lendl said he would pay a visit to Czechoslovkia early next month.

LEAD: Lisa Robyn Pepper, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Pepper of Valley Stream, L.I., was married last evening to David Murray Edelblum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Edelblum of Brooklyn. Rabbi Morris Friedman officiated at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I.
LEAD: In the dealt hand in last Sunday's bridge column, the clubs were misplaced. They are as follows: North: A J 8 6 2, East 5 4; South 10 3; West K Q 9 7.

LEAD: William E. Simon has a problem, and true to the former Treasury Secretary's reputation, he has a rather audacious solution.

LEAD: Instead of a self-help section, my local bookstore has a section called Recovery, right around the corner from the one called New Age. It's stocked with books about addiction, psychic healing and codependency - a popular new disease blamed for such diverse disorders as drug abuse, alcoholism, anorexia, child abuse, compulsive gambling, chronic lateness, fear of intimacy and low self-esteem.

LEAD: WHETHER the $7.2 billion budget that Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed last week is a masterwork of hard-nosed cost-cutting, as many Democrats contend, or a magician's trick full of trap doors, as the Republicans see it, one thing is almost certain as the debate over it goes on: aid to towns and cities, although up from last year, will not be enough.

LEAD: The citizens of central New York, at least the ones who insist they bleed Syracuse Orange, have grown to live for nights like this, when the words ''Sold Out'' are posted on the ticket windows of the Carrier Dome and a record crowd is stacked on three levels, all the way up to a Teflon sky.
LEAD: Brett Hull of the Blues displayed his scoring brilliance again tonight and showed why he is the league's leader in two important categories.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Budd Lowe Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Ann Lowe to Christopher Charles Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John James Burke Jr. of Chelmsford, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union had agreed that it was ''the right of the German people alone to decide whether to live together in one state.''

LEAD: Underwriters and lawyers agree that the Camden County Municipal Utility Authority bond issue now being marketed to investors across the country is one of the most unusual refinancing deals the tax-exempt market has seen in years.

LEAD: It's an uneasy time for New England's old Celtic fans. Larry Bird is back, but it's hard to say that the Celtics are. The question raises itself and will not disappear: are the Celtics the Celtics? Doubt moves over New England like a coastal fog.

LEAD: Arguing that they should take control of their school fees, a group of 200 University of California students is trying to replace administrators as managers of several buildings.

LEAD: To the Editor: The Oct. 29 Travel section contained two articles, ''How Safe Are Cruise Ships?'' and ''Under Full Sail From Monte Carlo to Italy's Coast'' on Windstar Sail Cruises' Wind Star. Surprisingly, the two articles could be linked. As a former ship's physician with years of experience on several noteworthy vessels, it became apparent to me that a ship's safety is not only related to the knowledge and experience of the crew in handling the physical hazards that may occur but also to the size and competence of the ship's medical staff.

LEAD: After holding their religious observances in the student union through the 1980's, Muslims at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill can look forward to a distinctive, permanent place of worship in the 90's. LEAD: THE BRONTES: Charlotte Bronte and Her Family, by Rebecca Fraser. (Fawcett Columbine, $12.95.) LEAD: It has been conventional wisdom that upping the number of digital bits in the decoder circuits of a CD player improves its sound. While CD players were originally designed for 16 bits, companies like Yamaha and Denon proclaimed the superiority of CD players using 18 or even 20 bits. Those extra bits did indeed offer advantages, even though it was rarely understood that the ebulliently advertised claims in this regard needed careful qualification.

LEAD: Norton, a 20-pound American alligator; Ramona, a boa constrictor; Bowie, an iguana; and Paki, Holli, Tusa and Oliver, four baby gorillas, were just a few of the animals mingling with 5,600 guests at Lincoln Center Monday night. They were at the 96th annual meeting of the New York Zoological Society, which included cocktails, films and a report by the society's president, Howard Phipps Jr.

LEAD: FOR years the old 32d Precinct station house was a delightful antique on upper Amsterdam Avenue, a proud, slightly sagging police station, but with its delicate roof cresting intact. Over the years the sag increased, especially after a new station house was built and the old one was sealed.

The neglected little areas for manicures in beauty salons took on more importance.

LEAD: William Honan thoughtfully explored the current debate concerning the Field Museum's new exhibit program. It is true that these islands are home to few of the Pacific's people, but ''Traveling the Pacific'' is about not only human cultures but natural history as well.

Administration officials estimated that the change, made last month, would enable 100,000 more moderate- and low-income families to get federally guaranteed private loans.

LEAD: As several critics note in PARIS 1889: American Artists at the Universal Exposition (Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts/Abrams, $49.50), the only way to identify the American pavilion there was by the sign over the door. LEAD: Tennis McEnroe Upset by Mayotte: Tim Mayotte joined Ivan Lendl in the final of the Milan indoor tournament in Italy by stunning John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-4, in their semifinal match last night. McEnroe struggled with an erratic serve and was unable to cope with Mayotte's aggressive play. After the match, McEnroe hinted that he had an injury to his left arm but declined to elaborate, saying he did not want to seem to be making an excuse for his defeat.

LEAD: The early 19th century was the epoch of untrammeled attacking play, the time for slugging it out with an opponent who was just as intent on slugging it out with you. But Wilhelm Steinitz spoiled all that - or almost all that. The man who dominated the chess world from 1866 to 1894 brought a sophisticated grasp to defensive play that had never been seen before.

LEAD: In lawmaking, as in any field, work expands to fill the time available. LEAD: Few fabrics carry with them as much folklore as the tartan. Scottish plaids have been used as coats of arms, articles of clothing and patterns that decorate everything from mugs to jewelry boxes.The earliest tartans were thought to have been woven by the Celts before the year 1000. Indeed, these plaids were so much a part of the Scottish culture that between 1746 and 1782, the British Parliament banned their wearing by anyone except the military, in an attempt to break up Scottish clans.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today became the first American Government official to testify before a committee of the Soviet Parliament. He told the legislators that he felt as though he was appearing ''before the Founding Fathers of a new Soviet Union.''
LEAD: American University students awoke to find anti-Semitic graffiti spray-painted on the main gate and a residence hall last Thursday morning.

LEAD: Love poems old and new are to be read by a number of writers and others in the arts, including Eric Bogosian, Ann Carlson, Lenny Kaye, Sally Silvers and Ishmael Houston-Jones, on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery, Second Avenue and 10th Street. Admission is $5. Information: 674-0910.

LEAD: In ''Some Americans Abroad,'' which opens tonight at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, a group of college English professors and their students go on a theater tour of England. The teachers sit at dinner, debating Shaw, capital punishment, the role of politics on the stage and who should pay for the wine.

LEAD: THE girl is young, the boy insistent. ''Come on, have a drink,'' he urges. Daisy hesitates, then gives in. ''You have the most sexy eyes,'' Mark murmers to her. ''I'd really like to know you much better.
LEAD: IT is a highly theatrical week in Connecticut, with opera and ballet, Broadway memories and parodies, even a performing troupe from Japan.

LEAD: If psychiatrists, rather than economists, were the specialists that Wall Street relied upon, they might have a simple explanation for the way the stock and bond markets have moved this year. ''Manic-depressive'' would be the diagnosis. One moment all is well; the next brings obvious and overwhelming reasons for fear.

LEAD: Sounding as if she had just had a halftime pep talk from a football coach, Leona Helmsley seemed eager to take the offensive last week as she prepared to defend herself against the next round of tax evasion charges. Mrs. Helmsley, who is appealing her Federal conviction, not only said she was innocent of those counts and the state charges she still faces, but also implied that she might be due a tax refund.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Campbell Jr. of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Witter Campbell to James Turner Denton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Denton Jr. of Allendale, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: We all wonder why there is so much violence in our society. The Stuart case here in Boston has refueled these feelings of helplessness. You treat David Lynch as a creative force in the movie industry, but in my view his vision is dark and feeds the ugliest fantasies of his audience. Call his work by its rightful name - pornography.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Gibbons of Mantoloking, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Ann E. Gibbons and Gregg P. Helbock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Helbock of Cold Spring, N.Y. Miss Gibbons, 32 years old, is a graduate of Rosemont College and an assistant vice president in the Weehawken, N.J., office of Paine Webber.

LEAD: IGNORED for years by the world's top airlines, Newark International Airport is finally drawing the crowds of international passengers it was designed to serve, airport and airline officials say.

LEAD: Language is reaffirming itself in the American theater, and the harbingers are Mac Wellman, Eric Overmyer and David Ives. In a reaction against the recent emphasis on performance art, they value words - the polysyllabic as well as colorful vernacular. In common, their dialogue has an imaginative intellectual base.
LEAD: PASSING ON By Penelope Lively. 210 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $17.95.

LEAD: Last month, two of the nation's largest pension funds took the unprecedented step of trying to confront the corporate lion in his den. Worried about the long decline in the fortunes of the General Motors Corporation, the heads of the California and New York public employees' pension funds wrote to G.M.
LEAD: INCIDENT AT HOWARD BEACH The Case for Murder. By Charles J. Hynes and Bob Drury. 305 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

LEAD: President Bush said last week he'd rather be ''cautious'' than ''reckless'' in how he builds bridges from the old cold war to the new international order and in how he cuts military spending. It's commendable to avoid mistakes, but caution alone can be wrong-minded and even reckless in other ways.
LEAD: FOR a man who prosecutors say bilked the University of New Mexico out of $25,000, John Koenig, the school's former atlhetic director, is getting off easy, but not necessarily that easy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There can be such a thing as a significant book that almost no one reads - Samuel Rich-ardson's ''Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded,'' springs to mind. Undergraduates, forced to ponder the birth of the English novel, are routinely steered toward it, but my own research indicates that only a handful of Ph.D.
LEAD: Poor people have started looting food stores as Brazil's monthly inflation rate soars.

LEAD: Mrs. David B. Findlay Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Holbrook Adams to Stephen P. Hodgkins, a son of Dorothy Hodgkins of Punta Gorda, Fla., and Richard B. Hodgkins of Wilton, Me. The prospective bride is also a daughter of the late Peter R. Adams. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: The unlikeliest regions for international yacht racing are showing up on the global map this winter for events in both sailing and powerboating.

LEAD: Cruise and resort swim wear in department stores now is dressy, with lots of old-fashioned detailing and high-fashion embellishment, more conducive to lolling than swimming laps. Their summer spinoffs, most of which will arrive in stores at the end of April, offer more of the same.

Any film that features a fictional rap group called ''The Say No Rappers,'' whose antidrug lyrics include the lines ''Big Sister is the white girl/ Her name is cocaine,'' can't begin to reach the teen-age audience it is aimed at. Kids are smarter and savvier than that, and it's hard to imagine they will find much truth in ''The White Girl.'' The film is so sincere, blunt and awkward it resembles a 94-minute-long public service message about the dangers of drugs. Written, directed, produced and distributed by Tony Brown, the host of ''Tony Brown's Journal'' on public television, it tells of a black college student named Kim, a judge's daughter, who battles a cocaine problem.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans faces a double challenge created by dwindling stocks of Atlantic cod and severely depleted spawning runs of Atlantic salmon in many of Newfoundland's rivers.

LEAD: A new human-rights monitoring group, Middle East Watch, assailed the Government of Iraq today for what the group termed ruthless suppression of dissent, apparently seeking to counter Baghdad's assertions that it has entered a period of liberalization in the aftermath of the Iran-Iraq war.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Hate Crime Statistics: Vote on an amendment to the Hate Crime Statistics Act that declared that ''the homosexual movement threatens the strength and the survival of the American family as the basic unit of society.'' Rejected 77 to 19, Feb.

LEAD: July wedding plans for Mary Alison Curtis and John Charles Ulin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Irwin Ulin of New York, have been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Allen James Curtis of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif.

LEAD: The events were distressingly familiar. A black New Yorker was the victim of a crime, described by the police as racially motivated, in the predominantly white rim of southern Brooklyn and Queens.

LEAD: IN predicting the future, much of what is proclaimed as science must ultimately be taken as a matter of faith. A problem that continues to confront the Bush Administration is how fervently it should believe in the dangers of the greenhouse effect - and how high a price the country should pay to forestall them.
LEAD: Time on Their Hands
LEAD: Cheap, fortified wine, street alcoholics' staple drink, is harder to find in some cities these days because of citizens' groups, government agencies and some companies that make it.

LEAD: I appreciated the Dec. 31 article reviewing New Jersey restaurants (''Critics' Choices: Memorable Meals''), but I feel one important item was entirely skipped - smoking. I don't care how delightful the decor, how friendly the service or how delectable the cuisine, if someone lights up next to me as I am about to savor a glorious evening out,

LEAD: On a cool, damp and somewhat misty December afternoon, two men walk across a meadow, rifles in hand and hunting dogs baying as they advance toward a cluster of pine trees in pursuit of their prey. The age difference between them is such that they could be father and son, and the easy familiarity they display toward each other suggests just that.

LEAD: Western relief officials said yesterday that areas of Afghanistan controlled by guerrillas face the threat of widespread famine despite improvements in transportation and communications that initially smoothed the delivery of food and medicine.

LEAD: Sound has been television's stepchild, and it has been treated badly. It has been battered and bruised in poor equipment and has long suffered neglect at the hands of video manufacturers who regarded sound as secondary.

LEAD: A fraternity at the University of California at Los Angeles has been placed on probation after a lesbian sorority said that fraternity members ridiculed and humiliated them at a school football game.

LEAD: The conflict at the Field Museum has not been simply over ''showmanship versus scholarship.'' I don't know a single curator here who wouldn't love to be a showman. LEAD: The New York City Human Resources Administration is investigating charges that an agency official who claimed to be a priest is not one and used false credentials.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Varley of Winnetka, Ill., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Burch Varley and Gregory Talcott Camp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Camp of New York.
LEAD: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.
