LEAD: Parenthood 1989. MCA. $89.95. Laser disk. $34.98. 2 hours 4 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Ron Howard's bittersweet adult comedy presents a survey of the everyday pains and anxieties of bringing up children. The story revolves around Gil Buckman (Steve Martin), a cheerful but harried businessman; his nearly perfect wife, Karen (Mary Steenburgen); their three children, and an extended family - all of whom live in close proximity.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The South African authorities have announced that Nelson Mandela will be freed today, giving him the opportunity to make his first statement in a public place in more than 25 years. His last such statement, on April 20, 1964, came from the dock at the Rivonia Trial, at which he was tried on charges of capital offenses and sentenced to life imprisonment.

LEAD: When the South African police arrested and jailed Nelson Mandela in August 1962, F. W. de Klerk was a young attorney in Transvaal, a fervent upholder of the apartheid doctrines of the governing National Party.

LEAD: At the first World Team Olympiad, in Turin, Italy, in 1960, hundreds of spectators clustered around the playing tables. At the eighth, which was held in Venice in October 1988, there were none. Spectators watched on a Bridgerama screen on which the progress of a selected match was displayed.

LEAD: Five years ago, the four-story house of the founder of Temple University was a hazard to the Sigma Pi brothers who lived next door. People repeatedly broke in, old mattresses were strewn about, and vagrants would start fires in the old house, said Donald Cox, alumni president of the fraternity chapter.

LEAD: THE greatest leaders are often, in reality, skillful followers. They do not control the flow of history, but by having the good sense not to stand in its way, they seem to. So it is with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who time and again dazzles the West by accepting reality.
LEAD: The top executive of the American Medical Association has resigned unexpectedly, 10 months earlier than scheduled, the Chicago-based organization said in a statement issued yesterday.

LEAD: An unexpected conversation on the subway led Martha D. Stevenson of Manhattan to write a check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and to think about how she chooses to give to charitable causes.

LEAD: Going to school, and particularly attending g m classes, used to be torture for Scott F. of Plainview, because classmates teased and mocked him about his height. Only 4 feet 9 inches tall, at age 14, he was so embarrassed about being small he would shy away from his peers.

LEAD: TWO young pianists who once lived in the county are returning for concerts this afternoon. Marija Stroke joins the violinist Mark Steinberg for a 2 o'clock program at the Emelin Theater and Susan Merdinger plays a solo recital an hour later at her alma mater, the Westchester Conservatory.

LEAD: THROUGH the roaring 1980's, as Connecticut caught up with and then surpassed Alaska as the richest state in the nation in personal income, it began to seem to many people both inside and outside the state that things here had somehow turned to gold. There was virtually no unemployment, taxes were more likely to go down than up, and growth outstripped the national average for years.

LEAD: In a loft with drab green walls at 12 West 21st Street, 72-year-old Lisa Dulken and her staff make beautiful silk flowers. The roses, carnations and anemones adorn dresses by Bill Blass, Adolfo and Carolyne Roehm.
LEAD: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about older musicians misstated Leontyne Price's age. She was 63 years old yesterday.

LEAD: Is it a coincidence that the stores these days are full of ''country''-inspired furniture (heavy maple tables, dry sinks and roll-top desks), that menus are heavy on grits and blackened everything, and that all the successful young lawyers seem to be wearing suspenders?

LEAD: As we move into the 1990'S, the increasingly familiar video screen has assumed many functions. Ammong these are playing back home movies recorded by the owner's video camera; presenting images of people acting filmed stories; and capturing real events in surveillance situations. The fine lines among these possibilities have been fascinating the Canadian director Atom Egoyan since be began making movies 10 years ago.

LEAD: Before anyone else says it:yes, most holidays have been turned into commercial bonanzas; yes, it's the sentiment that counts; yes, gifts given at odd moments during the year, for no reason at all, are the tops. Yes, yes and yes. But it's still nice to get a valentine and if that valentine takes a special form, wouldn't one have to be mad, mad as in crazy, to object?
LEAD: Hundreds of students shouting anti-Government and anti-American slogans fought the riot police today with firebombs and rocks to protest the creation of a new conservative governing coalition.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article ''Taking Chowder Personally'' (Travel, Nov. 12) by Malabar Hornblower solved a mystery for me. I've wondered for a long time why I've got similar feelings about chowder and ale.

LEAD: Robin Lori Fins, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Rabbi Jeffrey L. Salkin and Cantor Carla Boscoe-Reynolds officiated.
LEAD: Lisa Stawberry, wife of the Mets' outfielder, Darryl Strawberry, met with prosecutors Friday to discuss the domestic dispute that led to his arrest for on charges of threatening her with a gun.

LEAD: The Puerto Rican on the American mainland. Who is he? What does he want to be? Identity crisis, the perennial puzzlement of the newcomer in the city, is the issue poignantly and melodramatically at hand in Richard V. Irizarry's ''Ariano,'' now playing at the estimable Puerto Rican Traveling Theater.
LEAD: One small beleaguered corner of government where public services may actually improve during New York City's looming budget crisis is the Human Rights Commission.
LEAD: Like an advancing shadow, AIDS has touched the lives of nearly everyone in the fashion industry.
LEAD: Alcoholic beverages will have to carry health warning labels headed ''Government warning'' in bold capital letters under final Treasury Department regulations.

LEAD: I am not sure whether the most remarkable thing about the recent competition to find a building to complete the Federal Triangle was the design that won, the design that lost, or the fact that the competition was held at all. For this was like few architectural competitions in our time or any other: all entrants were required to produce a design in the spirit of the neo-classical architecture of the rest of the Federal Triangle, the vast complex of Federal offices between Pennsylvania Avenue, Constitution Avenue and 15th Street that was built in the late 1920's and early 1930's.
LEAD: RESURFACING a kitchen counter by adding a new plastic laminate counter top is not too difficult. It is one of the quickest ways to brighten a drab kitchen, and the results can be dramatic.

LEAD: For most of Dartmouth College's 4,000 undergraduates, a trip to the local barbershop or beauty salon is no big deal. But for about 300 black students, until recently, getting a haircut or hairdo to their liking often meant a two-hour trip to Boston.

LEAD: WHITNEY M. YOUNG, JR., AND THE STRUGGLE FOR CIVIL RIGHTS. By Nancy J. Weiss. (Princeton University, $24.95.) Nancy J. Weiss adequately chronicles the life of Whitney M. Young Jr., a consummate inside agitator who simultaneously fought and manipulated the corporate culture to expand opportunities for blacks.

LEAD: Out there in the video marts these days one sometimes gets the feeling that there are more movies for sale than for rent. Hot new titles - the just-released ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' say - are meant to be bought, or so it seems. Rentals, according to several surveys, appear to be shrinking.

LEAD: I am pleased that Walter McCarthy, in his article ''What the Retarded Need'' (Jan. 7), brought up the topic of social skills for the retarded. LEAD: Minh-Chau Luong and Willam Maxwell Crouch Jr. plan to marry in August, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Luong-Si Chuong of Cherry Hill, N.J., have announced. Mr. Crouch is a son of Dorothy M. Crouch of Bridgeport, Conn., and the late Mr. Crouch.

LEAD: I finished a tour of Epcot Center a couple of weeks ago feeling angry because the place turned out to be a carnival (''Say Goodbye to the Stuffed Elephants,'' by William H. Honan, Jan. 14). LEAD: THERE seems to be one in every suburban condominium development - the buyer who moves in full of promise and joy but who over the months begins to chafe under the restrictions imposed on owners. He may want a 30-foot flagpole on his 20-foot house, or he may assert a Constitutional right to paint his front door puce with polka dots.

LEAD: DONNA HENNINGSEN has not had to move often in her life, relocating only when she came to Westchester with her husband, Peter, and three children in l972. LEAD: There I was out to dinner with two heavyweight New Yorkers, extremely nice, literate people to whom I was wholeheartedly defending Shirley MacLaine. That's right, Shirley MacLaine. Mind you, I was making no defense of her claim to past lives; that far I can't go. But as to her benign, maybe even salutary emphasis on yoga and meditation, her jam-packed new-age seminars, her books and videos (yes, I've even rented one), in that I could certainly see no evil intent beyond a little spiritual hustling.

LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. reported today that its profits jumped 39 percent in its third quarter, partly because of traffic growth, lower pension contributions and aircraft sales. The carrier said earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled $78 million, compared with $56 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

LEAD: John Meehan, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, has been appointed artistic director of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet, Canada's oldest ballet company. Mr. Meehan succeeds the late Henny Jurriens as director.

LEAD: A history professor at the University of California at Berkeley has been identified by other scholars as a likely author of a pseudonymous article asserting that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will bring neither democracy nor a market economy to the Soviet Union.

LEAD: FOR coffee aficionados, the best if freshly made and piping hot. Le Petit Cafe is a pot and set of cups that sit on the stove top. When the cofee is ready, it pours directly into the cups, which are also warm.

LEAD: Relief supplies were sent today to East Beirut and tanker trucks began distributing water in the streets of the western part of the capital after two weeks of bitter clashes between Christian factions.
LEAD: Casimir J. F. Patrick, a retired bank executive and a lawyer in Manhattan for 40 years, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 83 years old.
LEAD: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death sentence on the author Salman Rushdie will be carried out.

LEAD: The share price of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation rose $2 today, to $64, after the company said in a Federal filing that it was already in the ''preliminary stages of negotiations with third parties'' to sell the company for more than $63 a share.

LEAD: Valborg Anderson, professor emeritus of the English department at Brooklyn College, died of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at a nursing home in Colton, Ore. She was 78 years old and moved to Colton from Manhattan two years ago.

LEAD: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney arrived in Asia today for 10 days of talks that allies of the United States see as a prelude to a major reduction of American forces in the Philippines and South Korea, and to renewed tensions with Japan over its contribution to the American military's huge presence here.

LEAD: When Ronald Reagan appears in a Federal courtroom on Friday, he is likely to be asked point-blank the fundamental questions about his role in the Iran-contra affair, which have gone unanswered for three years.

LEAD: An article on the Consumer's World page on Jan. 20 about finding a retirement home in Florida misstated Florida property tax rules. LEAD: ''So! Who has a song for us?'' Peter asks Heidi and her schoolgirl chums in a scene from ''Courage Mountain.'' ''We can't have a campfire without a song or a poem!'' Will anyone be surprised to find Charlie Sheen playing cheerleader here in the role of Heidi's stalwart swain? They should be. Both the actor and the film seem to have taken a step backward in time, back to the days when adventure films for young audiences did not involve dance competitions, video games or the kinds of personal triumphs that lead to unanticipated fame.

LEAD: The exhibition of 16 still lifes by Giorgio Morandi (1890-1964) at the Philippe Daverio Gallery comes at an ideal moment. Against the backdrop of a contemporary art scene in which money, bombast and irony have reigned for a decade, Morandi's example of abstemiousness and monklike dedication to the humblest of tasks is another reminder that art need not be big and brash to make its mark, nor must it be entirely made over from one season to the next, like the latest couture collections.

LEAD: Of all the things that can go wrong in a snapshot, few are more disconcerting than the phenomenon of red eye. It leaves friends and family looking like ghouls, their eyes glowing an unearthly shade of crimson. While over the last 10 years camera manufacturers have eliminated virtually all the other plagues that can ruin photographs, red eye has remained an all-too-common flaw.

LEAD: A mother and father died in a fire early yesterday morning in Brooklyn after the mother desperately squeezed their four children under a window gate that had been illegally wired shut, fire officials said.

LEAD: The nation's trade deficit narrowed sharply in December to $7.2 billion, the smallest gap in five years, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: Few players realize that there are considerable opportunities for effective deceptive plays in the trump suit. There is, for example, a whole family of doubleton tenaces: jack-nine, queen-ten, king-jack and ace-queen. In each case it is sometimes productive to play the higher honor unnecessarily, and lead the declarer down a tempting path.

LEAD: Four winners have been announced in the Boston International Choreography Competition sponsored by the Boston Ballet. Rick McCullough was awarded the gold medal and a cash prize of $3,000 for ''Others Because . . .,'' set to Prokofiev's first violin concerto. Bonnie Scheibman won the silver medal and $2,000 for ''Moon Roses,'' set to music by Bruce Novack.

LEAD: Executives at the General Motors Corporation are making plans to shift an undisclosed amount of the company's $35 billion in pension-fund assets into ''junk bonds,'' said people in the market who have been told about the move.

LEAD: The soul singer Ike Turner was sentenced today to four years in prison for a variety of cocaine possession offenses. Mr. Turner, 58-year-old former husband and musical partner of the rock star Tina Turner, was convicted in Superior Court here last month. In 1986, he acknowledged that he had been addicted to cocaine for 15 years.
LEAD: The indictment of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. on drug and perjury charges on Thursday has intensified pressure, from friends as well as enemies, for his resignation.
LEAD: The disappearance of a 23-month-old girl missing since Feb. 2 was solved on Thursday, after her mother, who had made a plea for her daughter's return, led the police to the child's body.

LEAD: Ross E. Mitchell, an inventor in Newtonville, Mass., obtained a patent this week for a watch to help travelers fight jet lag by making time fly. Mr. Mitchell noted that travelers arriving in a different time zone normally switched to the new time in an abrupt and disorienting way. His new watch is designed to smooth this transition by spreading the adjustment over the flight.

LEAD: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about Henry A. Kissinger's resignation from the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board described the board's activities incorrectly. It meets formally about every two months, and consultants and staff members meet at other times. The item also referred incorrectly to John Tower's nomination to the board.

LEAD: The director of the Yale University Concert Band, THOMAS DUFFY, thinks of the group as a serious orchestra and he normally rejects brassy oom-pah-pah. But it's not every day a band can play the American premiere of a work by John Philip Sousa.

LEAD: After three decades of sustained interfaith dialogue among America's Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews, the borders of most religious groups are largely undefended, and no one is massing troops along them. Compared with the bitter Catholic-Protestant conflicts of, say, the 1950's, today's occasional quarrels look more like customs disputes than full-scale belligerency.

LEAD: AFTER seeing a quilt spread over a waterbed in a television commercial, Francis Sheppard was inspired to stitch her own version and call it ''Who'd a Thought It.'' Mrs. Sheppard, who is nearly 100 years old, estimates that she has pieced at least 1,000 quilts since she started playing with small pieces of cloth at the age of 5.

LEAD: UMBRIA, the small, green, hilly, landlocked region of central Italy, is best known in the rest of the world for the Spoleto Festival, the cathedral of Orvieto and St. Francis of Assisi. In Italy it is loved for its natural beauty and quiet civility but most of all for being a good place to eat. Its fruity green olive oil is arguably the finest the country produces.

LEAD: THE struggle over the county's 1990 budget ended last week as the Board of Legislators averted eliminating more than 400 jobs while indicating that it would take a more assertive role in drawing up future budgets.

LEAD: THE SPRING OF 1990 holds the promise of momentous transformations as the nations of Eastern Europe hold elections in their quest for democracy, and as a disengaged Soviet Union strives to forge ahead with change amid an explosion of internal conflicts. Marc D. Charney and Anne Zusy of The Week in Review compiled a country-by-country look at where things stand in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

LEAD: The whole idea of a lockout is absurd. We faithful fans, numbed by winter, have been looking forward to the new season. And who's responsible for the high salaries, anyway? Certainly not the players. The owners have backed themselves into a corner and are now resorting to very unpleasant methods to get themselves out of it.

LEAD: Karl Marx must be cringing in his grave. The draft platform of the Soviet Union's Communist Party that was published last week contains an economic bombshell: approval of private ownership of private capital. This proposed surrender of the party's economic dictatorship is every bit as radical as the document's proposed surrender of the party's 70-year political dictatorship.

LEAD: IN THE TOWN OF GUANICA IN SOUTHWESTERN PUERTO Rico, a stone monument commemorates July 25, 1898, the day the village awakened to cannon blasts. That morning, people fled to the cane fields; among the few who remained to watch troops disembarking from the three battleships anchored in Guanica's turquoise bay was Agustin Berrenechea, the town commissioner.

LEAD: WELCOME news for the jaded palates of restaurant habitues has been the influx of Thai restaurants in Connecticut in recent years. Newest on the scene is Mhai Thai in Greenwich, which earns high marks for its looks as well as its cuisine.

LEAD: Despite the swift demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the ''junk bond'' market seems certain to survive, money managers, analysts and traders said. But the form that it will take is not clear, they said, and in the short term, as the Drexel network of lenders is dismantled, some highly leveraged companies will have to scramble to find new sources of financing.

LEAD: As everyone knows, the winter of 1989-90 has seen the birth in Central and Eastern Europe of a new collective noun - ''a toppling of tyrants.'' In earlier times, tyrants, if toppled at all, were toppled one by one. Others, of whom Stalin was the great and terrible exemplar, lived out long lifetimes as if set in marble.

LEAD: On Wednesday evening my grandson William called to give me an assignment. ''It's the 75th birthday of my school,'' he explained, ''and Mrs. Lyver would like the grandparents to tell what it was like when they were in the first grade. And I have to have it by the first day of next week.''

LEAD: IN ''Rumors in the Palace,'' Enid Rudd's two-character sendup of royal tradition, British style, the oversexed future king (Arthur) and his frigid teen-age princess (Vivian, or Vi) play, teasingly, with plastic water guns. Before long, their fun and games are aimed toward kinky sex. Years later, in a hot tub, where the prince is playing with his little boat, they have a spat over mutual infidelities, and Vi tosses fried chicken nuggets at Artie.

LEAD: The Corcoran Gallery of Art has announced the resignation of Bruce H. Yenawine, dean of the Corcoran School of Art. His resignation leaves the gallery with its top three senior positions unfilled.

LEAD: An unusually hard-fought election campaign ended in Japan, with most opinion surveys indicating that the governing Liberal Democratic Party would win a slim majority in the lower house of Parliament. Page 3.

LEAD: A QUONSET hut was transformed into a modern airline terminal, complete with escalators, observation deck and air-conditioning, as county legislators got their first look last week at architectural designs for the long-planned modernization of the County Airport.

LEAD: Susan Jane Kerr and Allan R. Dragone Jr. were married yesterday at St. James' Church in New York by the Rev. J. Seymour Flinn, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Julius Hamilton Sedlmayr of New York and Edmund Hugh Kerr of Greenwich, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: The Dance Theater Workshop opened its music series on Monday with a band led by the composer Steve Elson. Mr. Elson, a saxophonist, accordionist and composer, has worked with mainstream pop acts and new-music composers, and his music was full of references and stylistic approximations.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Mindy Gerber and Comdr. Charles Harry Barber 3d, U.S.N., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herman B. Gerber of Charlottesville, Va. Commander Barber is a son of Janet Forester Barber of West Chester, Pa., and the late Mr. Barber Jr. Miss Gerber, who attended Hamilton College, is an independent producer of television commercials, as was her father, who is retired.

LEAD: EVERYBODY had a soft spot for 16-year-old Sally Anders. Friends and family members described her as sweet and responsible, an average teen-ager who looked forward to school dances, sang in the church choir and auditioned for the school play. Why then, asked residents of her quiet Connecticut town, would someone want to murder her?

LEAD: THE corner of West Main and Spring Streets in Oyster Bay has been the location of three restaurants in the last three years. It was a giant leap from the casual California cuisine of Monterey Bay to the classic northern Italian fare of Casa Savoia. The recent grand opening of Sebastiano's represents an imperceptible change.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Cross & Brown Company, a New York real estate brokerage and property management concern, has agreed to sell its residential division to Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives, a Manhattan residential brokerage. Officials of both companies, who declined to disclose the purchase price, said one effect of the sale would be the transfer of 31 brokers from seller to buyer.

LEAD: Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Government offices: Closed. Post office: Express mail and special delivery only. Service at main post office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended Sanitation: No pick-up, recycling collection or street cleaning.

LEAD: Owners collude to hold free-agent costs down, or they engage in cutthroat bidding wars that lead to absurdly inflated contracts for journeymen players. Neither the owners nor the players seem to recognize any common interest with the fans. Get the fans to walk away, and one fine day the whole enterprise will collapse like a house of bubble-gum baseball cards.

LEAD: Europe in headlong change: Questions about how a single, powerful Germany might behave at home and abroad, and an up-to-the minute scorecard on changes in the east. The Week in Review, Section 4.

LEAD: SEVENTEEN years after abandoning its vision of a second Rockefeller Center east of Times Square, the Durst Organization has apparently given up trying to assemble one last major parcel on the Avenue of the Americas, and will content itself with building one-story shops.
