LEAD: A judge in Phoenix ruled last week that the cross atop Arizona State University's Danforth Chapel must be removed, but allowed Christian groups defending the symbol 30 days to appeal his decision.
LEAD: The engagement of Frances Lynn Taylor to Keith Nicholas Costa has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Patricia J. Kenney of New York. A July wedding is planned.
LEAD: ''If a reunited Germany is in NATO it is just a matter of time before all Soviet troops are back behind their borders.

LEAD: If Orlando had not existed before Walt Disney World, those who built the central Florida entertainment empire would probably have had to invent the city. With 32,000 workers and more than 23 million annual visitors, Disney World relies on Orlando and surrounding communities to house its employees and administer the airport that is the gateway to its three theme parks: the Magic Kingdom, Epcot Center and Disney-MGM

LEAD: AT the Little Professor Book Center in Niantic, fledgling writers meet to talk about writing, established authors give readings and children attend story hours. The activities represent what a bookstore should offer, said Robert Rue, who, with his wife, Connie, owns the store.

LEAD: Roger Keizerstein's warning that financially advantaged youngsters will have more difficulty establishing independent households because many will not be able to afford comparable lifestyles and will thus choose to remain in the comforts of the parental nest is based on a simplistic formulation of a complex problem.

LEAD: I realize tiat Danny Aiello's head must be swimming after playing supporting parts in such deathless masterpieces as ''Harlem Nights'' and ''Fort Apache, the Bronx,'' so it's no surprise he failed to mention that he played a leading role in my play ''Gemini.'' It's my recollection that he was with us for nearly three years, Off, and, eventually, on Broadway in the late 1970's.
LEAD: Dramatic changes in medical practice have shattered the profession, leaving many doctors deeply demoralized.

LEAD: RIGHT after Chancellor Helmut Kohl returned from Moscow last week, posters appeared on the streets of Bonn showing his picture with Mikhail S. Gorbachev over the legend, ''The way is clear! Now comes unity!''
LEAD: Art Over the Centuries

LEAD: Lonnie Smith of Atlanta lost his arbitration case yesterday but still gained the largest salary increase awarded in the 15-year history of salary arbitration. Terry Pendleton of St. Louis won his case and matched the second-largest salary ever awarded.

LEAD: The man who robbed the Westfarms Mall branch of the Farmington Savings Bank on Friday walked out with an estimated $3,900 in mixed bills and then hopped on a bus headed down New Britain Avenue for Hartford, the police said.

LEAD: I hope I'm not the only one who is rooting for the baseball players and owners to remain at an impasse forever, until the owners file for bankruptcy and the players go on welfare. Let us all hope that some nice protracted intransigence will tear the system down. WILLIAM BAKER Bloomfield, N.J.

LEAD: Supporters of the Democrats' leading campaign finance proposal say Senator Alan Cranston, the California Democrat whose fund-raising techniques are under the scrutiny of Federal law-enforcement authorities, is quietly maneuvering to dilute the measure.
LEAD: Here is some important legal and business information for Americans importing goods from China or investing in Chinese factories or mines:
LEAD: I read with interest Dr. William A. Dwyer's letter to the New Jersey editor entitled ''Fees for Disposing of Medical Waste'' (Jan. 21).

LEAD: Why did you have to do a cover story about the high-rolling tourists of Aspen? The Italians have an apt expression that fits them: faccia da schiaffi, which roughly translates as ''faces to slap.''

LEAD: One of the first things Barber B. Conable Jr. did when he became president of the World Bank nearly four years ago was to adorn his office with non-American objets d'art: a Waterford globe from Ireland, Cantonware serving plates from China, rugs from Mauritania and Morocco.

LEAD: In previous seasons, as Seton Hall was blossoming into a Big East power and Georgetown was making its annual push for conference supremacy, a meeting between the schools could always be counted on to tip the conference standing one way or another.
LEAD: COPLAND Since 1943. By Aaron Copland and Vivian Perlis. Illustrated. 463 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $29.95.
LEAD: Students at Chatham College, the oldest women's college in Pennsylvania, say they feel abandoned, betrayed and angry over a proposal to admit men to the 121-year-old school.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Senator and Mrs. Pete V. Domenici of Washington and Albuquerque, N.M., have made known the engagement of their daughter Nella Louise Domenici to Steven Brian Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Carl Powell of Augusta, Ga. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I love New York! I love show biz! I love Danny Aiello! I loved Michael Norman's article on Danny (''His Bus Came In,'' Jan. 21)!

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Louis E. Fierro of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Ann Fierro to Bryan Keven Hawkins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Blayne Hawkins of Cashiers, N.C. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: Lebanon's embattled Christian militia coalition, vowing to fight on despite losing main strongholds in East Beirut, mounted an attack today against an army base north of here where 500 troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun have been holding out.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Mutual Funds table last Sunday gave incorrect headings for two columns showing percentage change. One column was for January, not December, and the other was for 1990, not 1989.
LEAD: A freight train derailed near this small town early today, sparking a huge fireball and forcing the evacuation of several families, the authorities said.

LEAD: Time stills and then stops altogether for SAND CASTLES (Mysterious Press, $17.95), in which Nicolas Freeling unceremoniously restores to life his well-beloved Dutch detective, Commissaris Piet van der Valk, whom he killed off in ''Aupres de Ma Blonde'' almost two decades ago. Literal-minded readers might find some inconsistencies about this miraculous raising of the dead, but these fade in the considerable pleasure of accompanying the detective and his wife on a holiday tour of the northern
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The city's first black Superintendent of Schools has sued the white-majority school board, whose vote not to renew his contract has brought weeks of racial turmoil here.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I survived a Kenyan ambush in which a friend sitting beside me was killed and my husband was wounded by gunshot. It was gratifying to read in your article that the Kenyan Government at last is admitting it has serious problems.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: No one knows how much the peace dividend will be or when it will be on the books, but the debate over how to use it may dominate American politics for years to come.

LEAD: Long gone are the days when history, nationalism and mutual suspicion fed doubts that Britain and France would ever be linked by a tunnel under the English Channel. The doubts remain, but today the reason is money.
LEAD: BEATRICE LILLIE The Funniest Woman in the World. By Bruce Laffey. Illustrated. 296 pp. New York: Wynwood Press. $18.95.

LEAD: To the editor: My wife and I love snorkeling and skin diving but a series of hip replacement operations has made climbing ladders into dive boats a real struggle for her, especially in choppy water.

LEAD: Though spring is officially more than a month away, there is always something blooming at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Situated on 250 acres of hills, gardens, forest and streams, the garden offers an abundance of green growing things to winter-weary visitors.

LEAD: Those familiar with the famous Ritz chicken hash would hardly consider this a reasonable alternative. The original has lots of heavy cream and egg yolks. It is sinfully wonderful, but this chicken hash need make no apology.
LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is concerned that the American Bar Association will use a resolution endorsing abortion rights to produce a litmus test for screening judicial nominees.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Lloyd: Symphony No. 5 BBC Philharmonic conducted by George Lloyd. Albany TROY-022; CD and cassette. Much of George Lloyd's music is autobiographical, or at least reflective of world events during his lifetime. His Fifth Symphony (there are apparently 11 to date) was written in Switzerland while the composer was slowly recovering from serious wartime injuries.

LEAD: Words like Romanticism, Classicism and Serialism, the common coin of musical commentary, can become so worn from continual handling that they lose all value. They take on a mystical fogginess, emphasized by Germanic capitalization, that makes them impressively abstract but worthless as tools for thought.

LEAD: The Bush Administration's new housing initiative, announced with great ballyhoo by the President and Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, certainly has a ring to it. HOPE, it's called, the last word in inspirational acronyms: Homeownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere, a package filled with promising programs.
LEAD: Sergiu Comissiona has taken over conducting chores for the Vancouver Symphony as music director designate until September 1991. He will then become music director through the 1993-94 season.

LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about efforts to stop emigration from Israel characterized Mordechai Glick incorrectly. He is a member of the Organization to Stop Emigration From Israel but is not its head. The caption also misidentified the setting. It was Mr. Glick's home, not his office.

LEAD: There's no sonic boundary between the sacred and the profane. Melodies, rhythms and inflections have no allegiances; they're free agents, at the service of anyone with the technique to perform them. In Europe, popular songs were the foundations for medieval cantus firmus masses; in Latin America, the rhythms of

LEAD: A popular Greek cartoon shows American G.I.'s, a look of indifference on their faces, carrying out crates of personal belongings as they abandon their military bases in Greece. Taken away with the belongings is a Greek protester clutching a ''Yankee go home'' sign, a look of bewilderment betraying his confusion at being left without a cause.

LEAD: The engagement of Lauren Joy Bartner and Dr. Joseph Ascher Singer has been announced by the prospective bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Easton of Alpine, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla. Dr. Singer is the son of Hannah Singer of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Abraham Singer. An August wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 5 4 DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam Dalgitesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 2 1 4 THE BAD PLACE by Dean R. Koontz (Putnam, $10.95.) A troubled sleepwalker hires a detective team to discover the causes and consequences of his behavior.
LEAD: WE hear much of the economic decline of Long Island. The key to recovery is the creation of jobs in the service industries and the computer and communications technologies they depend upon.

LEAD: Oscar is doing it, and so is Calvin. So, in fact, are Geoffrey and Bill. What Oscar de la Renta, Calvin Klein, Geoffrey Beene and Bill Blass are doing is knocking themselves off in lower-priced lines that have the potential of reaching many more customers and ringing up millions of dollars more in sales.

LEAD: Speculum Musicae's evening at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday was called ''Music From the British Isles,'' and three of its four composers seemed to be asking, if not the same question, at least a very similar one: Is it the job of creators to tame chaos or do they find even more profit in exploiting it?
LEAD: Q. Inside the garage, my foundation wall has two hairline cracks oozing a steady stream of sand. What can be causing this?

LEAD: Fort Salonga $230,000 12 Timber Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,800. Islip $135,000 106 Beaver Dam Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33- year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room, basement; taxes $4,500.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned by Blaine Allyson Hammer and Allen Thomas Levenson, the prospective bride's parents, Martin L. Hammer of New York and Ronnie S. Hammer of Westport, Conn., have announced. Mr. Levenson is a son of Paul Levenson of Framingham, Mass., and the late Rose Levenson.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Alano of Shrewsbury, Mass., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Marie Alano and Brian Anthony McCarthy Jr., a son of Arlene McCarthy of Stamford, Conn., and Mr. McCarthy of New Canaan, Conn.

LEAD: It is impossible to feel sorry for either side, impossible to take seriously the question of whose shameless greed is slightly less unjustified. Clearly, there is more than enough money to go around. VICTOR LEVIN New York

LEAD: The headline on the Commercial Property column on page 13 of the Real Estate section today misstates the decision of the Durst Organization on a midtown project. As the column reports, Durst plans to build one-story retail buildings on the site.

LEAD: The president of Clemson University's student body, who recently reviewed and approved the school's toughened alcohol policy, was charged early Friday with driving under the influence of alcohol. William Astor Blackwood 3d, a 21-year-old senior, was arrested by a university police officer. This week, after a committee of students and faculty agreed on changes in the campus alcohol policy, their recommendations were approved by Mr.
LEAD: His friends call him Geoffrey, but to his employees he has always been Mr. Beene. And so it is that Mr. Beene, the collection, was named.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Barrack of Matawan, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Diane Karen Barrack and Kevin Andrew Milstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic M. Milstein of West Long Branch, N.J.

LEAD: Cristine Allen Mesch, the daughter of Mildred A Mesch of New York and Dr. John Mesch of Albany, and Jonathan Simonds Sapers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Sapers of Brookline, Mass., plan to marry in April, the prospective bride's parents have announced.

LEAD: A report in the Style Makers column on Feb. 4 about Jeff Weiss misidentified his role in the new advertising campaign for Cointreau. He was not the sole creator; Victor Levin was his collaborator.

LEAD: Elizabeth Anne Daly and Michael David de Verteuil were married yesterday at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Samuel B. Matarazzo performed the ceremony. Candace Daly Scottow, the bride's sister, was her matron of honor, and Carl Frederick de Verteuil, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Four weeks after its debacle with a cigarette aimed primarily toward blacks, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company may be heading for a new battle over a cigarette reportedly aimed at young, blue-collar white women.
LEAD: Having just read that upscale fish cakes would be popular in the 90's, I thought it seemed like a good idea to get a drop on the competition.

LEAD: Happily, among the faults of our beleaguered National Endowment for the Arts is not found a repertory requirement for touring chamber ensembles, as reported in the article about the Da Capo Chamber Players (''Not All Old and Not All New,'' Jan. 7).
LEAD: Elizabeth Sue London, an administrative aide to Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of New York, and David Lawrence Piaker, an architect, plan to marry in April.

LEAD: THOSE who feared the Wadsworth Atheneum was going to wrack and ruin when it showed the photographs of Robert Mapplethorpe may take heart from its eminently respectable ''Mannerism to Modernism.''

LEAD: Yes, great performances do always touch the heart and move the spirit. Proof, if any is needed, came again when Darci Kistler and Robert La Fosse offered an achingly tender love duet Thursday night in Jerome Robbins's ballet ''In G Major.''
LEAD: Wearing black armbands ''to mourn the death of affordable tuition at U.M.,'' students at the University of Miami held demonstrations last week to protest higher charges.

LEAD: The cruise directory on Feb. 4 omitted the European schedule of the Sun Viking of Royal Caribbean Cruise Line. The ship will begin a series of 12-night Mediterranean cruises from Lisbon on May 4. Also scheduled are a 12-night voyage from Lisbon to London on June 9 and a series of 12-night Baltic cruises from London, concluding on Aug.

LEAD: ''Ethnic Dance'' is the usual label affixed to any troupe that looks foreign and whose offerings are not in the realm of modern dance or ballet. The latest entrants would seem to be the Don Cossacks from the Soviet Union and the Jose Greco Company of Spanish Dancers, Singers and Musicians - two groups that are stirring up enthusiastic audiences this month.
LEAD: A STATE law effective with the new year that forbids the outlawing of mobile-home parks has enraged many municipal leaders who resent Augusta's dabbling in what they consider to be town issues.

LEAD: University of Connecticut students are showing rising enthusiasm for their basketball team, which ranks in the nation's top 10 for the first time. But the university has begun to try to calm down some of the fans.

LEAD: Bolstered by new auditing powers, Federal tax officials are investigating many American subsidiaries of Japanese companies on the suspicion that they have underpaid corporate income taxes by billions of dollars.

LEAD: AS Bloomingdale's and its parent, Federated Department Stores, seek to reorganize in the wake of bankruptcy proceedings, the store's unusual, low-rise home on a block site - 59th to 60th Streets, Lexington to Third Avenues - also is attracting notice. Any attempts to sell off the store itself would be affected by the split ownership of the property.

LEAD: Over the objections of the state, a sheriff, fed up with months of overcrowding at the county jail here, has commandeered a National Guard armory and says he will temporarily house prisoners there ''to keep the peace.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A service for Dr. Y. C. James Yen, founder of the International Institute of Rural Reconstruction, will be held at 4 P.M. on Wednesday in the chapel of the Interchurch Center at 475 Riverside Drive at 120th Street. Dr. Yen died on Jan. 17 at the age of 96.

LEAD: Dozens of supporters are planning to lie down across the road here in front of Ariel Sharon's northern Negev ranch early Sunday morning to stop him from driving to Jerusalem for the Cabinet meeting where he plans to resign.

LEAD: A Harlem grandmother who feared staying alone at night suffered a fatal heart attack early yesterday, minutes after she opened the door to two masked gunmen who ransacked the apartment and fled, the police said. Detectives investigating the robbery are treating it as a murder case.

LEAD: Laura Beth Kohn and John Briggs Parkinson Jr. are planning an October wedding, the prospective bride's parents, A. Eugene Kohn and Barbara Kohn, both of New York, have announced. Mr. Parkinson is a son of Mrs. Michael O'Sullivan of Somers, N.Y.
LEAD: The Fast Forward column last Sunday misidentified the winner of the 1941 Academy Award for best supporting actress. She was Mary Astor.

LEAD: Joanne Woodward has a toothache. Paul Newman would prefer to be home in bed. ''This is certainly an endurance record,'' said James Ivory, the director of ''Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' the movie in which the Newmans are starring.

LEAD: THE rocks where Indians held council over the centuries and a building where black girls and women attended school in the 1830's are among the Connecticut sites on the National Register of Historic Places. But most places around the state that reflect the history of women and minorities are not recognized, and the Connecticut Historical

LEAD: The Devils and the Maple Leafs used their heavyweight fighters tonight, perhaps as a result of the proceedings in prior meetings between the teams this season. The game was carefully monitored by the National Hockey League's disciplinarians, and boxing officials would have probably declared the fistfights a draw.

LEAD: Researchers have found a higher risk of leukemia in the offspring of men who worked at a nuclear plant on the northwest coast of England than among the children of men who worked at other jobs in the area.

LEAD: After reading Mathias B. Freese's article, ''Teachers Have No Chance to Give Their Best'' (Long Island Opinion, Jan. 21), I feel compelled to respond to the blatant cynicism expressed by the author.
LEAD: To the Editor: Here is a warning of entrapment at the Canadian border for all American tourists.

LEAD: The Essex House, at 160 Central Park South between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, is undergoing a renovation that includes redecorating it to bring it more in line with the Art Deco design it had when it opened in 1931. The $55 million project, scheduled to continue until early next year, will reduce the number of guest rooms from 690 to 580, making some larger and converting others into two-room suites.

LEAD: June wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Burton M. Siegel of Short Hills, N.J., for their daughter Lilli Siegel and Jonathan David Roth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Roth of Bellerose, L.I.

LEAD: Candice Calabro and Richard Martin, both of Philadelphia, were married there last night at the Four Seasons hotel by Judge Richard B. Klein of the Court of Common Pleas in Philadelphia. Mrs. Martin is the daughter of Mrs. John Felice of Rosemont, Pa., and the late Joseph C. Calabro. Her husband is a son of Ruth Martin of North Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Joseph J.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about a split within the Likud party in Israel misstated the birthplace of Foreign Minister Moshe Arens. He was born in Lithuania and emigrated to the United States as a child.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Jean Wallace, a screen actress who had feature parts in a dozen Hollywood productions and was married to two stars, Franchot Tone and Cornel Wilde, died of a gastrointestinal hemorrhage Wednesday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 66 years old.

LEAD: William Hamilton Hoge, an early manufacturer of television sets and the first large-screen projection TV sets, died of a heart attack on Friday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 83 years old and also had a residence in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A $16 MILLION, 70-unit condominium project - the first major new condominium proposed since the early 1980's - is being planned for a downtown site by the Hammond-Pacific Development Company.

LEAD: The engagement of Elizabeth Roos Ehrenfeld to Kenneth Mendez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Mendez of New York and Makati, the Philippines, has been made known by her parents, Mikki Ansin of Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. John Ehrenfeld of Lexington, Mass. An April wedding is planned.
LEAD: An essay by Jean-Claude Baker on Feb. 4 about Josephine Baker omitted credit for his collaborator. Mr. Baker wrote the article with Chris Chase.

LEAD: Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Cynthia Terry Lawrence and Alan Read Ziegler Jr. The Rev. Earle W. Pratt Jr. officiated, assisted by the Rev. Edyth Baker.
LEAD: An article on Jan. 28 about United States policy toward illegal immigrants from Central America misidentified a former Immigration Commissioner. He is Alan C. Nelson.

LEAD: The Museum of Modern Art celebrated its exhibit ''Photography Until Now'' with a cocktail party, dinner and preview on Wednesday night. The curator of this commemoration of 150 years of photography is John Szarkowski, director of the museum's photography department.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: JEREMIAH COLE sold his Chelsea co-op in a week by trimming his price and offering brokers 8 percent instead of the normal 6 percent commission.
LEAD: There is something about overtime that brings out the best in the Knicks.
LEAD: Students at Tufts University boycotted classes and rallied on Thursday to protest a freeze on financial aid that they say could leave some needy students without assistance.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having just read Steven Erlanger's piece on ''What's Doing in Singapore'' (Travel, Dec. 24), I have two comments. First, the article failed to mention one of the greatest pleasures of travel in Singapore - food.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The engagement of S. Dana Snyder and James F. Grant, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Grant of Chicago, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William L. Snyder of New York and Hillsdale, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Enis of Manalapan, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Stephanie Barri Enis, and Perry Alan Loesberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack P. Loesberg of Potomac, Md.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about consumers' reactions to the recall of Perrier mineral water misstated the position of the restaurant Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif. While Panisse is looking forward to eliminating imported bottle water, it has no definite plan to do so.
LEAD: An entry in the music column of the Connecticut Weekly today omits the time and date of a performance in Newtown by the Lydian String Quartet. It is 3:30 P.M. today.
LEAD: Rival Protestant and Roman Catholic soccer fans rioted at a match today, and the police said they fired plastic bullets into the stands to stop the disturbance.
LEAD: Among the fattest files to accumulate during the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is nearing its conclusion, is the one containing requests that donors not be identified.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: FOR THE SAKE OF ALL LIVING THINGS By John M. Del Vecchio. 790 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.
LEAD: Michel Drach, a director who along with Jean-Luc Godard and Francois Truffaut helped create the New Wave style of film making, died on Thursday. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about a royal appearance at the House of Lords in London referred incorrectly to the role of Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, and described the occasion incompletely. The Duke was present only in his role as husband of Queen Elizabeth II; he did not preside. The setting was the annual state opening of Parliament last November.

LEAD: THERE were 1,500 miles separating Joan K. Pompadur in Hartsdale from her grandmother and aunt in Florida. For years the Florida household had operated fairly smoothly, said Ms. Pompadur, who made periodic trips to Florida to check on her family.

LEAD: IN the mid-70's, when I was a college freshman and black studies was flourishing on college campuses across America, I took a black history course in which, as expected, there was a roomful of fellow blacks. What was unexpected was one white student among the bunch.

LEAD: Marvin W. Davis of New York and Southampton, L.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Marri H. Davis, to David W. Moffly, a son of William T. Moffly 3d of Fort Washington, Pa., and Louisa Peace Moffly of Oreland, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: ALL that money! All that sex! All that blond hair! Tout le monde dined out on Donald and Ivana Trump last week after the news broke that the brash billionaire intended to divest himself of Trump, The Mrs. Strangers in barrooms argued over how just much of Mr. Trump's many, many millions Mrs. Trump should get after 13 years and three children.

LEAD: After making the apology demanded by international auto-racing officials, Ayrton Senna of Brazil, a former world driving champion, was granted a license on Friday to drive on the Formula One circuit this year.

LEAD: FOR John Gotti it was a moment of triumph. Emerging from a Manhattan courthouse where he had just been acquitted on charges of assault and conspiracy, he was enveloped by a wave of cheers from a waiting throng. But that acclaim nine days ago could signal the last hurrah for America's Mafia or La Cosa

LEAD: Humphrey Borkum, a director of South Africa's largest brokerage house, wasn't surprised by what Nelson Mandela said when he was released last week from prison after more than 27 years. But other players in the South African stock market apparently were.

LEAD: It is the consensus in the boxing world that shortly after he demonstrated that he was the toughest man on the planet, James (Buster) Douglas was very nearly mugged in broad daylight. Douglas, a 29-year-old journeyman boxer, had in the minds of many fans gone as far as could be expected just by stepping into the same ring with Mike Tyson, the undefeated heavyweight champion.
LEAD: A picture caption in this section Feb. 4 accompanying a photograph of a golf tournament at Pebble Beach, Calif., misstated the name of the tournament. It was the A.T.&T. National Pro-Am.

LEAD: The announcement last week of a new line of powerful work stations by the International Business Machines Corporation has again focused attention on the microprocessor technology called RISC and the operating system called Unix. While they have been around for years, RISC chips and Unix are widely viewed as the next major steps in the evolution of high-performance business computers.
LEAD: Arab governments are resisting a call by King Hussein of Jordan for a summit meeting in the next few weeks to discuss the prospect of a huge influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, among other issues.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: HANGING wall cabinets, even an individual cabinet, can be a tricky task for amateurs. But by planning the job beforehand, using the proper tools and fasteners and having at least one helper, a good job can be done without too much trouble.

LEAD: In the last several years, the young saxophonist Greg Osby has emerged as a distinct, important figure on the alto saxophone, making appearances on his own moody, funk-influenced recordings as well as with the composers Andrew Hill and Steve Coleman and the drummers Cecil Brooks and Jack DeJohnette.

LEAD: Whether or not I attend any games or watch any on television, I'm going to have to pay for the monetary fiasco, just as I'm going to help pay for the savings and loan scandals. So I say ''a pox on all their houses'': players, owners, television (networks and stations), sponsors and all the rest.
LEAD: No doubt about it, it has been a spectacular few months for George Bush.

LEAD: Princeton University's 13 private eating clubs provide meals to about 75 percent of the upperclassmen and, until recently, alcohol to hundreds of underclassmen, many of them under age. But if last weekend's club initiation parties are a guide, new rules on alcohol use are turning these campus social centers into bastions of sobriety.

LEAD: The wedding of Harley Alison Farber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Farber of New York, and Robert Martin Raiff, a son of Frederic Raiff of New York and Elizabeth Haron of Greenwich, Conn., took place last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

LEAD: DIVORCING THE DICTATOR America's Bungled Affair With Noriega. By Frederick Kempe. 480 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95. OUR MAN IN PANAMA How General Noriega Used the United States - and Made Millions in Drugs and Arms. By John Dinges. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: Random House.

LEAD: THE old man who walked out of the prison farm near Cape Town a week ago was proof even to South Africa's critics that President F. W. de Klerk was serious about changing the universally despised system of apartheid. The unconditional release of Nelson Mandela, now 71 years old, was more than a concession to the world, for it set in motion a process that the Government hopes will produce a new constitution giving the black majority long overdue political rights without jeopardizing the interests of the white minority.

LEAD: AT a dollar a pound, which is what it is selling for in Chinatown these days, squid must be the cheapest seafood you can buy. It is also extremely nutritious, being low in fat and calories and high in protein.

LEAD: For some Chinese Communist Party members, the next few months will involve a flurry of meetings, self-analysis and the risk of being purged from the party if their outlook and behavior do not live up to the Communist ideal.
LEAD: ADULT ENTERTAINMENT By John Metcalf. 201 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95.

LEAD: MORE than a year of competition between Maryland and Delware has ended with this state's capturing a major research and development center proposed by Himont, an international chemical company based in Wilmington, Del.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: From luncheonettes to classrooms to rallies and marches, American blacks are voicing a euphoria and pride in Nelson Mandela of a kind many said has not been seen since the height of the civil rights movement two decades ago.

LEAD: In picking a recording tape, audio fans find themselves in the same situation as buyers of soap. Competing brands seem so alike that one is easily swayed by advertising, packaging or other irrelevancies.

LEAD: A regional Communist Party leader today denied reports of rioting in the republic of Uzbekistan, and another top official said the rumors were aimed at inflaming ethnic tensions in the neighboring republic of Tadzhikistan.

LEAD: Carlton Screen ran the show, the rest of the Providence Friars ran the floor and Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, nearly ran into the stands last night as St. John's lost to Providence, 77-74.

LEAD: I applaud Irving Kamil's article dealing with drivers who fail to use directional signals (''Turning Without Telling,'' Opinion page, Jan. 7). While our area is so much better than California in this regard, one can't help but be appalled by the lack of courtesy this shows.

LEAD: A picture caption on Dec. 15 with an article about Puerto Plata in the Dominican Republic misidentified an open corrugated-roofed structure. It was a souvenir stand, as a reader has written to point out; the Amber Museum is nearby. The correction was delayed through an editing error.

LEAD: Orchestral music in Japan has a history at least as old as jazz in America. Although the musical language of many Japanese composers remains rooted in an internationalist style (especially the ''color-field'' style so prevalent here and in Europe since the 60's, best exemplified by composers such as Witold Lutoslawski or Gyorgy Ligeti), it is being molded with confidence into a more typically ''Japanese'' character.

LEAD: When the Exxon Valdez left the port of Valdez one night last March, her crew included a timid helmsman, a second mate who may have had mental problems and a captain with a history of drinking, according to testimony at the trial here of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood.

LEAD: One of the preliminaries to today's Daytona 500 was a 200-mile race last Sunday sanctioned by the Automobile Racing Club of America as part of its Permatex Super Car series. The series is a training ground for Nascar's Winston Cup tour, the stock car major league.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Johannes Robert Krahmer of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Clemm Krahmer to David McNeill Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Aaron Cross of Chapel Hill, N.C. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: An unusually hard-fought election campaign ended today with most opinion surveys indicating that the Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu would win a slim majority of seats in the lower house of the Japanese Parliament.

LEAD: PERHAPS the biggest attraction for American skiers in the Alps is that generally the resorts there - unlike the Northeast and the Rockies - were not created for skiing. They are essentially villages that were always there, amid magnificent mountain terrain on which winter sports were easily grafted.

LEAD: Ronald Reagan said repeatedly during his testimony in a Federal court that he did not authorize John M. Poindexter to violate the law in the Iran-contra affair, a person familiar with the former President's deposition said today.
LEAD: Early in the second quarter tonight, the Nets were playing cohesively, they were leading by 12 points and the crowd at Byrne Meadowlands Arena was cheering enthusiastically.
LEAD: Times Beach has been a ghost town since dioxin was discovered in the soil seven years ago and the Federal Government bought up all 801 homes and businesses and moved the residents out.

LEAD: Armonk, N.Y. $350,000 479 Bedford Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 210-year-old farmhouse; country kitchen, darkroom, wet bar, porch, patio, tennis court, 2 acres; taxes $5,294. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $650,000 East Woods Road 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 18-year-old renovated contemporary; family room, 2 fireplaces, whirlpool, 4,513 square feet, 3 acres; taxes not yet assessed.

LEAD: Sandra Marie Pinnavaia, the daughter of Professor and Mrs. Thomas J. Pinnavaia of East Lansing, Mich., and Guy Moszkowski of Buenos Aires and Paris and the late Dr. Erica F. Moszkowski, plan to marry in September.

LEAD: April wedding plans for Dr. Joanne Bader and Jeffrey Mitchell, a son of Judge and Mrs. Jerry W. Mitchell of San Bruno, Calif., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bader of Belle Terre, L.I.

LEAD: If spring training had started on time the other day, if players were running around fields in bright sunshine in Arizona and Florida, some of them would be finding out just how far they have come back from serious injuries and, in many instances, surgery. More important to their teams, managers would be learning where the players are and how far they had to go before the season starts.

LEAD: When Dennis McIntyre died on Feb. 1 (of cancer, at the age of 47), obituaries were brief and, for many, his name was unfamiliar. Sadly, his death will not inspire Broadway eulogies, but his life says something revealing about the plight of the playwright. He was a fine playwright with the potential to be a major one, but more than many of his peers he had difficulty getting his work produced.

LEAD: The designer Bill Blass perks up when the subject comes up. A popular man about town wherever he is, Blass dreams of dining alone. ''In New York, it would be in bed; in the country, on a card table set in front of the fire,'' he muses. ''If it's diet, it would be Lean Cuisine. Indulgence?'' - a big smile here - ''Ben & Jerry's ice cream!

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Marshall N. Dudley of Guilford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Margaret Dudley, to Anthony P. Coles, a son of Dr. Roberta Goldring Coles of New York and Putnam Valley, N.Y., and the late Dr. Robert S. Coles. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Thank God for a brilliant, violent bruiser like Richard Leakey, who stands squarely on the side of the animals and fairness (''Can He Save the Elephants?'' by Jane Perlez, Jan. 7). I heard him speak at the Explorers Annual Dinner and at the Friends of Conservation fund-raising luncheon last year. His approach is so blunt and unforgiving and determined that he may serve as the catalyst for many who are anguished over the destruction of elephants and rhinos but feel helpless.

LEAD: April wedding plans for Dr. Michele Ann Hendler and Dr. Gregory Allen Beroza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton P. Beroza of Hempstead, L.I., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley B. Hendler of Hollis, Queens.

LEAD: THE name George Washington brings grimaces to the faces of many Fort Lee residents. But it's not the Father of the Country - who laid out a fort on the site in 1776 - they have a grudge against; it's the bridge named for him, the one that was opened in 1931 to connect New Jersey with Manhattan.

LEAD: THE PLUMBER The True Story of How One Good Man Helped Destroy the Entire Philadelphia Mafia. By Joseph Salerno and Stephen J. Rivele. Illustrated. 281 pp. New York: Knightsbridge Publishing Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Dr. Gayle P.Milton's engagement to Michael Clifford Zeller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Zeller of Great Neck, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Milton of Newton Centre, Mass. An August wedding is planned. Dr. Milton, 29 years old, is a pediatrician at South Shore Pediatrics in Oceanside, L.I., and Bele Harbor, Queens.
LEAD: His banishment from baseball doesn't apply to baseball broadcasts, so Pete Rose plans to keep his professional interest in the game alive and perhaps kicking this season as a radio commentator.

LEAD: In the Caribbean listings of Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, a one-night hotel stay was described incompletely. It applies only to passengers arriving from the West Coast. Fares for seven-night cruises of the Song of Norway were misstated; the range is $1,145 to $2,630.

LEAD: How I enjoyed Lesley Hazleton's article about her venture into the world of the internal combustion engine (Hers: ''Working on the Mechanics,'' Jan. 14). It reminded me of my own first, shy requests for initiation into the marvels of 10-wheelers, compaction trucks, backhoes and - my personal favorite - our landfill's 953 ''cat'' bulldozer.

LEAD: AS hundreds of residential buildings in the New York City area were converted from rental to co-op status in the last decade, the tenants, regarded as insiders, were offered their apartments at prices as much as 40 percent below those posted for outside buyers.

LEAD: Carla Ann Sputz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Sputz of Oakland, N.J., was married last evening to Robert Alan Fishbein, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Irwin H. Fishbein of Westfield, N.J. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.
LEAD: A review of ''Silver Stallion'' by the Korean novelist Ahn Junghyo on Feb. 4 rendered the author's family name incorrectly. The review should have referred to him as Mr. Ahn, not Mr. Junghyo.

LEAD: WHEN Neil Armstrong stepped on to the moon, an Indonesian illustrator commemorated the event with a cartoon that still has his countrymen laughing: ''Wonder if he'll find a Padang restaurant?'' one Indonesian was shown saying to another.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Tracy of New Canaan, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Megan Anne Tracy and Mark William Shea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer C. Shea of West Brighton, S.I.

LEAD: ''Culture and Commentary, an 80's Perspective,'' at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, is that rarity in the world of contemporary art, an ambitious and coherent theme show in which the work of every artist - even those as overexposed as Jenny Schnabel and Cindy Sherman - makes more sense than it did before.

LEAD: The inhabitants of Middle Earth, as described by J.R.Tolkien, are not recorded as having played bridge. But that was simply an oversight on the part of the chronicler, according to a recent report from Under Earth. Richard Hills, writing in the magazine, Australian Bridge, describes bidding in the Mithrandir Memorial

LEAD: HUNDREDS of tourists who make the somewhat bucolic two-hour rail trip from London to Rye each year have never heard of Lucia, Miss Mapp or E. F. Benson - and more's the pity. It isn't that the East Sussex town, one of the ''Cinque Ports and Two Ancient Towns'' forged as a unit in the 11th century, isn't worthwhile without this esoteric knowledge.

LEAD: THE battles over voting rights, school integration and public accommodations have long been more or less settled, but some blacks in the South say they now face subtler forms of discrimination. In education, they say, it shows up in public school ''tracking'' systems, and the issue was at the heart of black protests here last week.
LEAD: Someone to Watch Over Us

LEAD: People are in lines wrapped around the firehouse in this small borough 35 miles southwest of Philadelphia, but they aren't waiting for barbecued chicken dinners or free rides on the old fire engine.

LEAD: FROM the beginning, it was an idea almost no one liked: give clean needles to drug addicts. As a first step in studying whether that could slow the spread of AIDS, New York City began a program in 1988 to see if addicts would participate.

LEAD: Howell $168,400 49 Starlight Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; patio, c/a, family room, 2-car garage, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,786. Linden $166,000 227 Woodlawn Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 39-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, h/w floors, patio; taxes $2,535.

LEAD: AT first glance, Greg Grant would appear to have no business playing in the National Basketball Association. He is 5 feet 7 inches tall and weighs 145 pounds. Five years ago, he was a college dropout selling fish in his hometown. He then returned to school and became a standout player at Trenton State College, hardly a collegiate basketball power.

LEAD: A critical ruling in the Central Park rape case is expected this week when the presiding judge is scheduled to decide whether to admit as evidence the incriminating videotaped statements made by five of the six youthful defendants charged in the attack.

LEAD: Long plagued by well-organized gangs of kidnappers, Italy took its first steps this week toward a new hard-line policy against both the abductors and the families who are willing to negotiate with the kidnappers.
LEAD: Except for Poland, which is voting for local and regional governments, all countries are electing new parliaments. East Germany: March 18
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Grosvenor of New York and Newport, R.I., have made knbow the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Romaine Grosvenor, to R. Marcus Holloway, the son of Lynn K. Holloway of Wilington, Del., and W. Robert Holloway of Glen Cove, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: The marriage of Dorothea J. Lucarelli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Lucarelli of Rumson, N.J., to David W. Moffet, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Moffet of Toronto, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Stowe, Vt. The Rev. Lorenzo D'Agostino officiated.

LEAD: May the saints preserve us - not another television drama about the Kennedys! Irish or not, that's the way a good many people may feel about the prospect of devoting six hours to the ABC mini-series ''The Kennedys of Massachusetts'' (two-hour installments begin tonight at 9 and continue tomorrow, with the conclusion on Wednesday).

LEAD: IF you accept the idea that a bikini-clad woman who is all alone on her Westchester County estate would not sound the alarm when a weird stranger walks into her garden room and stares at her, then you might consider purchasing a large bridge that spans the East River.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: COLONIALISM AND CULTURE
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THREE distinct facets of the world of American glass, past and present, are on exhibit here at the Hudson River Museum. ''Persians,'' a series of sculptural blown-glass assemblages by Dale Chihuly, a leading artist in his field, is the dramatic centerpiece of three shows that will run through March 18.

LEAD: The marriage of Laura J. Pires and Melvyn F. Hester took place in New York yesterday at Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., the senior minister at the church, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Sam G. Hines.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump's marriage is not the only one of his important relationships that is not working out these days. His rapport with the ''junk bond'' market - whose contribution to his success arguably approaches that of his estranged wife, Ivana - has become equally rocky.

LEAD: For those who can't make it to New Orleans for Mardi Gras on Feb. 27, and for those who'll be wanting musical souvenirs, February brings an annual bounty of Louisiana music. From New Orleans proper comes rhythm-and-blues and street-parade music. And from the bayou country up the Gulf Coast comes bouncy, fiddle-topped

LEAD: IN a report issued in January by the office of the State Comptroller, New York City's assessors are likened to the mythological King Tantalus, who was condemned to stand chin deep in a pool of water in Hades.

LEAD: THE MAN WHO TRIED TO BURN NEW YORK, by Nat Brandt. (Berkley, $3.95.) In one of the more obscure incidents of the Civil War, a band of renegade Confederate soldiers tried to burn New York City in retaliation for what General Sherman did to Atlanta. In 1986 our reviewer, Patrick Clinton, said Nat Brandt's rendition of the trial of one of the conspirators ''is full of surprising perplexities, and the descriptions of his gradual descent into drunkenness and despair and of his death as the last Confederate to be hanged for spying are memorable reading.
LEAD: The Bush Administration is considering possible steps to improve relations with Nicaragua if the Sandinistas win free and fair elections on Feb. 25.

LEAD: Eberhard Diepgen, former Mayor of West Berlin and the leader of its Christian Democrats, promised a cheering crowd here today that a vote on March 18 for his party's candidates, combined with hard work and a rejection of all socialist experiments, would bring prosperity under a united Germany.

LEAD: THE Exumas are like beads off a broken necklace: just when you think you've collected them all, you step on another one. I've been picking them up on and off for almost 20 years, and am still looking. Starting about 35 miles below Nassau, this chain of 365 islands and cays curves southeast for some 150 miles in what many argue is the world's most beautiful water.

LEAD: If you heard a woof-woof here and a woof-woof there - here a woof, there a woof, everywhere a woof-woof - chances are you were at Madison Square Garden last week, where the 114th annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show was under way.

LEAD: The provisional Government's abrupt dismissal of Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru on Friday after days of protests by army officers is the latest step in its troubled quest for post-revolutionary credibility.

LEAD: Black African leaders have greeted the release of Nelson Mandela with caution, emphasizing that it is only a beginning. But they nevertheless see a parallel between the emerging situation in South Africa and the move from white colonial rule to black majority rule in several black African countries, particularly Kenya.

LEAD: An almost universal reaction to ''My Frame,'' which was conceived by Berdie Stein, is ''How come no one thought of it before?'' But no one did and that's why children's art was, until last year, usually stuck on refrigerator doors or taped on walls. And that's how the company ''My Art'' was born.

LEAD: THE KNEELING BUS. By Beverly Coyle. (Ticknor & Fields, $18.95.) Reading Beverly Coyle's first novel is like roaming through Disneyland as a child: you wander from image to image, discovery to discovery, and when you're finished you want to do it all over again. Through the perceptions and misperceptions of young Carrie Willis, the daughter of a liberal Methodist minister, Ms.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Weinstein of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Weinstein to Rabbi Leonid Feldman, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Moisey Feldman of Kishinev, U.S.S.R. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Christine Louise Dibble and Cameron Cohick, lawyers in Washington, plan to marry in May. Miss Dibble, 28 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon K. Dibble of Montgomery Village, Md. The prospective bridegroom, 32, is a son of Nancy Cohick of Raleigh, N.C., and Larry Cohick of Beaumont, Tex.

LEAD: After a decade of war, economic crisis and political polarization, Nicaraguans will vote in eight days in this country's first free and broadly contested democratic election. But because most voters, wary of such freedom, remain deeply reluctant to discuss their personal views, even the best-informed specialists say they are at a loss to predict who will win.

LEAD: Jan Alison Sigmon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Sigmon of Bethlehem, Pa., was married last evening to Andrew L. Dworkin, a son of Ruth Dworkin of New York and the late Bernard Dworkin. Rabbi Joseph Potasnik officiated at the Peninsula Hotel in New York.

LEAD: Richard Leakey faces a formidable task: balancing the demands of wildlife, tourists and a growing population. Having returned recently from a tour of Kenyan game reserves, I believe that making tourists more responsible is crucial to the effort. In the Masai Mara, tourists urge drivers to move closer to the animals.
LEAD: MAPLE SUGARING TIME

LEAD: The young soprano Angelina Reaux, like her obvious role model Teresa Stratas, is a singer with unusually strong dramatic instincts and the will to transcend the image of opera singer as a delicate hothouse flower.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Showing your pictures to someone is fraught with perils - especially if it's someone whose opinion you respect. But that doesn't seem to keep anyone's images in the closet.

LEAD: Mrs. William Barnes 3d of Decatur, Ill., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Julia Wells Barnes, to Herbert Arthur May 3d, the son of Mrs. May Jr. of Owings Mills, Md., and the late Mr. May. A June wedding is planned. Miss Barnes, 25 years old, graduated from Miss Porter's School and William Smith College.

LEAD: As the Soviet threat to Western Europe diminishes and the Warsaw Pact becomes a hollow alliance, the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is shifting and the alliance is emerging as a potential watchdog over a reunited Germany.

LEAD: FROM COOPER TO WAYNE TO Redford to Stallone, the stoic American movie idol has faced criticism for mechanical acting, for being more automaton than man. Now, to use the Hollywood lexicon, the tradition continues.

LEAD: COMPANIES Drexel: Driven From the Market It Created Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday amid ironies heaped as high as its clients' - and now its own -debts. The brokerage house has been driven from a ''junk bond'' market it created. A firm whose executives insisted they were investing in America, not just making quick profits, failed in part because they put too little money in the business and took too much out for themselves, bankruptcy filings indicate.

LEAD: The long search for synthetic blood for use in transfusions is becoming a neck-and-neck race between companies working on ''white bloods'' and those working on ''reds.'' The goal is to find a substance that is easy to use and free from contaminants like hepatitis or the AIDS virus.

LEAD: With the demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a collective sigh of relief is sweeping the board rooms of corporate America. The collapse of the Wall Street firm, which created the popular ''junk bond,'' is seen as the most convincing evidence yet that the financial fuel for corporate raiders and hostile takeovers is drying up.

LEAD: AT LAST IT HAPPENED. Four years of college, one more for good measure - all told a half-decade of great books and gregarious nights and green lawns and girls - and then one day some malignant force somewhere, some vile conspiracy of time and teachers and empty-pocketed parents had the nerve to hand me a diploma.

LEAD: Federal investigators have uncovered bribery schemes at three housing agencies in New Jersey and are investigating four other agencies for possible criminal wrongdoing, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, Samuel A. Alito Jr., said today.
LEAD: THE END OF THE AMERICAN CENTURY By Steven Schlossstein. 537 pp. New York: Congdon & Weed. $22.95.
LEAD: Optimism, a rare commodity in Brazil until recently, is back in fashion as a wide spectrum of Brazilians are pinning their hopes on the country's young President-elect, a new poll indicates.

LEAD: ''It hurts,'' said Morton Weir, the University of Illinois chancellor. ''I've been here for 30 years and I feel strongly about this place. It just eats away at me to see the kinds of things being said and written about us. I'm frustrated.''

LEAD: As executive editor of two food-industry magazines during the last decade, I have had occasion to cover various food-packaging issues, including chlorofluocarbons (CFC's) and the current controversy over banning plastic food packaging. It was therefore distressing to read County Legislator Paul Feiner's Jan.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Meyer 3d of Fair Haven, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lynn Meyer, to Thomas More Keating, a son of Mrs. Joseph M. White of Rumson, N.J., and James M. Keating Jr. of Shark River Hills, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

LEAD: Carol G. Brochin of Baltimore has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Hope Ann Brochin, to Joseph A. Horvath, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Horvath of Malvern, Pa. The couple plan to marry next year.
LEAD: Once recognized only by those who collected, studied or actually made or used them, fish decoys - lures without hooks - are swimming into public view.

LEAD: I hope that Mr. Freese feels better after his whining diatribe on the shortcomings of his students appeared in the Long Island section. Teachers like Mr. Freese indeed ''have no chance to give their best.'' His contempt for his students and their parents is evident.

LEAD: An answer to a Travel Trivia question in the Travel Watch column on Dec. 31 located the world's second-highest mountain incorrectly. Several readers have written to point out that the mountain, known usually as K2 and also as Godwin Austen, is in the Karakoram range of Pakistan, not in Nepal.
LEAD: YOUNG artists will be in the performing spotlight countywide next weekend, in concerts at four schools.

LEAD: To the Editor: I seriously question the propriety of featuring the article by Erik Sandberg-Diment (''Across the Sahara by Car,'' Dec. 31). As adults, the Sandberg-Diments have every right to risk their lives by traveling through that unpredictable and hostile environment. I am appalled, however, that they were accompanied by their children, especially a 7-year-old.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. B. William Basheer of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kelly Page Basheer, to Arthur Sellers Garrett 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garrett of McLean, Va., and Beach Haven, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: The cynicism of Bruce Wasserstein and those in his profession is no better illustrated than by his remark: ''Robert Campeau failed to do three things. . . . He did not float new junk-bond issues. . . . He did not mortgage his properties. . . . And he did not sell assets.'' (''Wall Street's Wonder Boys: Slightly Tarnished,'' by L.

LEAD: WHO would be the first to mention Tiananmen Square, I wondered as I embarked on a 12-day tour of China in December with 33 other Americans - one of the first large tourist groups back in China since the events of last June 4. The speculation was incredibly naive.

LEAD: ''Challenger,'' a TV film about the shuttle disaster that will be broadcast next Sunday evening at 8 on ABC, begins with an auspicious claim of factual authenticity. While most other docudramas merely give notice at the end of the credits that they are based on a book or two, this production offers a lengthy message that appears in white letters on a black screen.

LEAD: For This Week: Days are getting longer and growth is resuming on house plants. Repot those that need it and take cuttings of any that are overgrown and need trimming. Check plants outdoors for wind and winter injury; prune out any broken or dead limbs, but, in spite of recent mild weather, it is too early to carry out any major garden activities.

LEAD: From Feb. 1 to April 1, under so-called Plan B free agency, 490 National Football League players are free to sign with new teams without having the new teams compensate the old. This opens the door for higher salaries, but with almost a third of the signing period gone, business is slow.

LEAD: In his Carnegie Hall piano recital in December, Yefim Bronfman spent most of his time playing 19th-century Germanic music, with mixed results, but then scored a huge success with Stravinsky's Three Movements from ''Petrushka.''

LEAD: The Claremont Riding Academy, a fixture on the Upper West Side for nearly a century - it stables 100 horses and serves almost 50,000 riders a year - has been rescued from the knacker and will undergo an extensive rehabilitation with the help of the city's Industrial Development Agency.
LEAD: Georges Forest, Manitoba's most prominent champion of French-language rights, died on Wednesday night, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Mark A. Neymanof Andover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Neyman, to Michael Cary Silverman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Silverman of North Woodmere, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, a hard-line former member of the Soviet Communist Party Politburo and chief of the Ukrainian Communist Party for 17 years, died on Friday after a long illness, a day before his 72d birthday, the official press agency Tass reported today.

LEAD: Supporters of the Whitney Museum of American Art can only hope that when the institution's trustees meet early next month to discuss, among other things, the future of Thomas N. LEAD: A QUONSET hut was transformed into a modern airline terminal, complete with escalators, observation deck and air-conditioning, as county legislators got their first look last week at architectural designs for the long-planned modernization of the County Airport.

LEAD: The Prince of Wales, who has been sharply critical of some of the newer examples of modern architecture and urban planning in England, will share his ideas with 600 of this nation's leading architects on Thursday during a visit to Washington.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: OFFICIALS here, frustrated by months of stalled negotiations with the Bergen County Utilities Authority over the amount of money the township is entitled to for participating in the authority's solid-waste disposal operation, have decided to settle the dispute the old-fashioned way.

LEAD: Richard A. Bell runs the Integrity Life Insurance Company's Columbus, Ohio, office. His boss, Marianna Cimino, works in New York. Long-distance communications are rough even in the best of circumstances. And until recently, their circumstances were anything but the best.
LEAD: C. S. LEWIS A Biography. By A. N. Wilson. Illustrated. 334 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

LEAD: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT lawyers in New York City last week filed suit against six locals of a waterfront union that has been tarred with charges of violence and Mafia domination for more than three decades. Not far from the lower Manhattan courthouse where that case was filed, the elegantly suited men who ran the Wall Street house of Drexel Burnham
LEAD: Matt Steigenga scored 17 points and low-scoring Mark Montgomery hit 5 quick points today to stop a second-half Illinois run as Michigan State beat the Illini, 70-63.

LEAD: A makeshift shantytown that was raised on Feb. 6 in the shadow of the administration building at the University of California at Irvine is challenging a new policy that bars non-traditional couples, including homosexuals and lesbians, from living together in housing for married students.
LEAD: The Indian Government is barring foreign journalists from the Kashmir Valley, where a separatist movement has been growing for more than a year.
LEAD: The romance with all things Australian continues. The latest rage from Down Under is the outback coat.

LEAD: Mrs. Edward J. Sherman of Glens Falls, N.Y., and Bradenton, Fla., has announced April wedding plans for her daughter Mary Jo Sherman and Charles E. Stiver Jr., the son of Mr. Stiver of Cape Girardeau, Mo., and Lenore D. Stiver of San Diego. The bride-to-be is also a daughter of the late Mr. Sherman.

LEAD: For the better part of 25 years, I felt discontented with teaching in America. This is not a country that reads much, or believes that the little it is required to read has anything to do with the world of banks, cars and missile silos. We are practical to a fault, clean mental machines, so Thoreau, Whitman and Mark Twain go in one ear and pass out the other, frequently without impediment, loss of speed or any notable effect.

LEAD: Someday, Andrew Cuomo and Kerry Kennedy just could give new meaning to the term running mates. The son of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the daughter of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy will be married sometime this spring, Ms. Kennedy's mother, Ethel, announced last week. The prospective union of two clans whose family business is politics immediately gave rise to speculation.

LEAD: Olgivanna Lloyd Wright, the widow of Frank Lloyd Wright, died in March 1985, and for more than three years after that, her bedroom in the Wright residence at Taliesin West remained empty. There was no surprise to the fact that the room was left like a shrine: Taliesin, which is owned by the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation and functions as part tourist attraction, part architecture school, part Wright archive and part ongoing architectural practice, has always had an oddly worshipful, almost cultlike quality to it.

LEAD: For nearly two years now, Don King and Mike Tyson have emerged as the Siamese twins of boxing. Siamese twins joined at the money clip. One is seldom seen in public without the other. And last Tuesday, as King apologized meekly and weakly for having protested that James (Buster) Douglas didn't deserve to be the new heavyweight champion because of a long count, the promoter kept using the word ''we,'' meaning himself and the dethroned champion who was sitting nearby.
LEAD: Q. Inside the garage, my foundation wall has two hairline cracks oozing a steady stream of sand. What can be causing this?

LEAD: For all its glitz, the city of Aspen is pursuing a very unglamorous endeavor in outlawing the sale of fur coats in its local stores. It's a shame this was mentioned only briefly in your article. ANNE MULLIGAN MARCUS Cleveland Heights, Ohio

LEAD: PERHAPS the biggest attraction for American skiers in the Alps is that generally the resorts there - unlike the Northeast and the Rockies - were not created for skiing. They are essentially villages that were always there, amid magnificent mountain terrain on which winter sports were easily grafted.

LEAD: LEANING over four muffin pans filled with beads and charms, Ann Morgan worked in her design loft overlooking Five Mile River in Rowayton. She selected some silver fish and blue stones and strung them together in a combination she called Cousteau, creating a ponytail holder or braclet for her spring collection.

LEAD: AS President Bush set out for the inter-American conference on drug fighting last week, he spoke so much of the ''headway'' and ''success'' and ''cooperation'' already accomplished that it was not clear why he needed to go.

LEAD: ON Lincoln's Birthday last week, for the first time in years, there was no one at the New Haven Public Works Department to answer the phone in an emergency. This weekend, the street-sweeping trucks are not out as usual, as the city cuts overtime hours to save money.

LEAD: IT would be nice to say I became an anti-noise activist to make Larchmont a quieter place for everyone; but in fact it was to make Larchmont a quieter place for me. I got into the fight for peace and serenity more than nine years ago - and have been raising a ruckus about it ever since.

LEAD: Last September, the City Council of Aurora, Colo., approved a $1.25 million purchase of agricultural water rights in the South Platte river basin. Eager to secure more water for its rapidly growing population, this municipality east of Denver joined numerous others throughout the West by turning to what it sees as the only vast pool remaining: irrigation water.

LEAD: An article on the Fashion page on Jan. 28 about uniforms included an incorrect report from Scafati Inc. in Manhattan about outfits worn by the Rainbow Room staff. They were designed by Carrie Robbins, and they are not sold to the public.

The origin of a curse that has haunted a family of orphans in five previous novels. 2 4 MUTATION, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95.) A physician's attempt to create a superior child results in a prodigy that turns into a terror.

LEAD: You are looking for baseball - for some kind of sign that spring has arrived and that life goes on - so you come here. And in a time of lockouts and cold-hearted negotiating sessions, you are satisfied.

LEAD: Golf Forsman Takes Lead: Blustery winds were so severe that Dan Forsman needed only a par 72 to rally and take the third-round lead yesterday in the Shearson Lehman Hutton Open tournament at La Jolla, Calif. With winds gusting more than 40 miles and hour, and occasionally accompanied by a drizzly rain, Forsman outlasted other struggling contenders to establish a two-stroke margin at 203, 13 under par on the South course at Torrey Pines.
LEAD: English is America's common tongue, and ought to be. For their own benefit, all who choose to live here need to be fluent. But American freedoms include the freedom not to be.

LEAD: ''Teachers Have No Chance To Give Their Best'' is the lament of Mathias B. Freese's article, yet Freese keeps teaching English. A saving remnant, perhaps. I stopped teaching English more than 10 years ago on a beautiful springlike morning.

LEAD: IT IS MIDAFTERNOON IN A SLEEK ANNEX TO the Sony Corporation's headquarters in Tokyo, and Norio Ohga and Michael P. (Mickey) Schulhof are sitting in a plush screening room reserved for the company's top executives. For weeks, Sony's engineers have been trying to get this unlikely team - a former opera singer who is Sony's president and chief executive, and a former physicist who is vice chairman of the Sony Corporation of America - on the same continent at the same time.

LEAD: THE November sky cast a tombstone gray pall over Manhattan. The fictional private eye Mike Hammer always woke to this kind of morning in Mickey Spillane's mysteries, and I smiled at the appropriateness of it. I put on my trenchcoat, turned up the collar and went out to meet Mike's creator.

LEAD: It's been more than 50 years since plays dedicated to the glory of the labor movement flourished. Those were strident times that inspired strident playwriting, like Clifford Odets's ''Waiting for Lefty,'' the 1935 drama that became the symbol of the genre.

LEAD: THE Forum Theater Group may still be on the lookout for the lesser-known, perhaps esoteric or ''unsung'' musicals that have become the theater's trademark, more or less. For the moment, though, let's say that the theater's artistic credo has been amended by, or converted to, shows on Yiddish themes.

LEAD: The Classical Band, New York's first major attempt to create a period-instruments orchestra, is in the midst of its inaugural season. Wednesday evening's all-Beethoven concert at Carnegie Hall, the ensemble's first under a conductor other than its founder, Trevor Pinnock, had its palpable charms. But it also suggested that the orchestra is still very much feeling its way.

LEAD: Why should I care about Major League baseball? After eight years as a judge in criminal and juvenile court, why would I have special concerns about the 1990 season and the disputes between the players and owners?

LEAD: In 1929, Jimmy Doolittle flew blind - covering the cockpit of his biplane with a hood - to prove that a pilot could rely on flight instruments alone. Since then, cockpit electronics have become sophisticated enough to all but take the place of the pilot.

LEAD: TOM MORAN, the visual arts coordinator at the State Council on the Arts, oversees the implementation of the Arts Inclusion Act, which provides for the purchase of art for public spaces in state government buildings. Since joining the council in 1982, he has coordinated more than 50 projects that are enlivening the plazas, lobbies and grounds of new and renovated structures built by the state.

LEAD: THE vision of two adolescent boys silently playing in the spotlight and then peering at the audience just before the final curtain of ''An Enemy of the People,'' at the McCarter Theater through next Sunday, is calculated to stir us out of complacency, into agitation.

LEAD: THEY WERE MORE SANGUINE ABOUT Laura. She was, after all, in college and on the far side of growing up. They said she had loosened her tether to the family and was no longer hostage to the twists of their fate. They allowed that she would be shaken for a time by their divorce, but insisted that before long she would find her balance and regain her stride.
LEAD: The New Jersey Supreme Court was asked this week to decide whether a person's right of privacy extends to the garbage he places out for collection.

LEAD: Why would North Salem prefer to have paper cups litter their roads instead of polystyrene? Paper cups are not only more than twice the cost of foam cups, they are less functional, especially in insulation properties.

LEAD: When Don Skene was a boxing reporter for The New York Herald Tribune, his sense of perspective was so broad he never entered a fight club without saying, ''Things were never like this when we fought on barges.'' Unfortunately, the late Mr. Skene was wrong. Nothing ever changes in boxing. New faces populate the same old stories.

LEAD: Overheard in a Manhattan restaurant, one woman to another: ''He's a terrific father, but he's never home.''

LEAD: The marriage of Kathleen Marie Wilson to Scott Alan Katzmann took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I. Msgr. John J. Skelly officiated. Mary Jo Moore was the maid of honor and Brent Edward Katzmann, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.
