LEAD: Misha Dichter's Carnegie Hall recital on Thursday evening, the first of two celebrating the 30th anniversary of his stage debut, was a pleasant surprise. To begin with, the pianist constructed an excellent and demanding program of late Beethoven, late Schubert and late Brahms: repertory, as the advance publicity noted, ''with which he is not usually associated.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Pressure has been rising on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington to resign, but he appears determined to face at least one more set of voters - 12 of them. Mr. Barry, who entered a drug and alcohol clinic in Florida last month after his arrest on cocaine possession charges, was indicted last week on five misdemeanor drug charges and three felony counts of perjury.

LEAD: Elizabeth Lippincott Montaigne and Robert Russell Applegate were married yesterday at Old Swedes Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the ceremony. Katherine Montaigne, the bride's sister, was her matron of honor. Robert Hart Bolling 3d was the best man.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Lawrence of Concord and Nonquitt, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Marsh Lawrence, to John Fessenden Brooke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Brooke of Concord and North Pomfret, Vt. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE PARIS COUTURE IS THE OLYMPIAD of fashion design. In this biannual arena in which a chosen few compete, a couturier has free reign to create whatever vision he has in mind. Money is no object, and the most magnificent materials, accessories and artisans are at his fingertips. The news media of the world are there to cover the results, and, in turn, the publicity helps sell large quantities of more affordable products bearing the couturier's label.

LEAD: The phrase ''Do good, make good'' seems like a good motto to live by, but when found on a curious set of aluminum tokens, it's a reminder of a turbulent period of American prison reform. Prisoners at Auburn and Sing Sing prisons in New York used the tokens when morale and discipline were at an all-time high.

LEAD: Jimmy Brown has chubby cheeks and two new teeth, and this week he got his first vaccination. He knows how to shake his head ''no'' and wave goodbye, and he leaves sticky fingerprints on the television screen.

LEAD: One of the great privileges of wealth is that it provides the opportunity to travel anywhere, to discover unheard-of places; to meet people of diverse backgrounds; to grow intellectually; to achieve a most important aspect of human existence: new experience.

LEAD: IN a small rice-farming village south of Jogjakarta, Indonesia, a 19-year-old woman crouched in the doorway of her bamboo house, using the last rays of sunlight to see as she applied molten wax to a piece of cotton fabric. The woman, Miss Setyawati, was creating a work of batik, Indonesia's national handcraft.

LEAD: Government officials offered no further information today on the death of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko, whose partly burned body was found in the western part of the country under mysterious circumstances on Friday.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: PEOPLE don't need liquor to have a good time. That is the message of an alcohol-free dinner dance scheduled for March 3 in Shelton.

LEAD: LOMBOK. It sounds like a planet on ''Star Trek.'' The island is not really in outer space, but, as I showed my son on the globe, it was literally on the other side of the world, some 10,000 miles away in Indonesia.

LEAD: Witold Lutoslawski's uncanny color sense is usually the first aspect of his music to strike a listener. But the way he precisely and unconventionally manipulates a palate of stunning instrumental timbres into a language of intense expressive gestures is but one of the remarkable aspects of the Polish composer's music.

LEAD: Hey, I know these guys! There is Sandy Stevens, the driving instructor - I went through a course with him in Rutland, Vt., some years ago. And there is Sam Posey, the racer and television commentator. I followed Posey's pace car, a red Ferrari Boxer, around the track at Lime Rock, Conn., back when I was proving to everybody how truly fumble-thumbed I was at competition.

LEAD: There are any number of annoying, irritating, I'm-going-to-tear-my-hair-out sounds: chalk scratched along a blackboard, the slow drip of a leaking faucet, the sound emanating from the earphones halfway down the bus or subway car, the horn on the car parked outside your window that suddenly starts up at midnight and doesn't stop, doesn't stop, doesn't stop.
LEAD: Elmer Bennett hit a 3-pointer at the buzzer and Notre Dame ended Syracuse's home winning streak against nonconference teams at 37 games with a 66-65 victory today.

LEAD: Mstislav Rostropovich had his audience all but dancing in the aisles last week when he returned to the Soviet Union for the first time in 16 years and gave a concert of other Russians' greatest hits. Mr. Rostropovich, who was forced out of the Soviet Union in 1974 after his career hit a dead end over his support for Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, drew curtain call after curtain call on the conclusion of a program at the Moscow Conservatory that included symphonies by Tchaikovsky and Shostakovich.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Marvin J. Hoffman of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Yanes Hoffman to Mark Frederic Hirshorn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Hirshorn of Ambler, Pa., and Boca West, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Alan Bond, the entrepreneur and yachtsman, used to boast that his was the most recognized Australian name in the world. But these days, he is becoming better known as the head of an empire in slow-motion collapse -one that might become Australia's largest business failure.

LEAD: Florence Mamou, a student at New York University, was married yesterday in Paris to Jean Madar, the founder and president of Jean Philippe Fragrances, a cosmetics and perfume company in New York City. Rabbi Alan Goldman, the Chief Rabbi of Paris, performed the ceremony at Temple Rue de la Victoire.

LEAD: A Christian Scientist couple who tried to heal their ailing 15-month-old son through prayer instead of medical care, have been acquitted on charges of involuntary manslaughter and child endangerment.

LEAD: A party to celebrate the incorporation of this suburb of about 58,000 between Seattle and Tacoma will be held outside the municipal boundaries, embarrassed organizers have learned. Only after arranging the party for Feb. 28 at a bowling alley did planners learn it was not in the town as approved by voters a year ago.
LEAD: A private security guard at Columbia University was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape of a freshman in her off-campus dormitory room early Saturday, the police said.

LEAD: After the upheaval in Eastern Europe and the United States invasion of Panama, the Bush Administration is using a little-known Federal agency as a tool to achieve one of its main international policy goals - market-oriented economic reconstruction.

LEAD: Robert J. Collishaw, Chemical Bank's senior vice president for corporate affairs, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his vacation home in South Orleans, Mass. He was 55 years old and also lived in Mahwah, N.J.

LEAD: A throng of chanting, cheering demonstrators in the blue and white colors of the National Opposition Union surged into Managua's central plaza today in the largest anti-Sandinista rally ever held here.

LEAD: After two years of bad news about revenues, New York's financial problems appear to be growing increasingly dire. Financial analysts and even politicians are warning that dramatic steps will be needed to arrest the state's slide toward fiscal crisis.

LEAD: Derrike Cope got into stock-car racing when his baseball career ended with what he called a complete blowout of his right knee. Another blowout today, this one in Dale Earnhardt's right rear tire with about a mile to go, gave Cope the victory in the Daytona 500, the sport's biggest race.

LEAD: Roughly two out of three Poles are opposed to the reunification of Germany, but a majority of Russians and Hungarians feel positively about the idea, according to the results of a poll of political views in eight European countries published here today.

LEAD: A map accompanying an article yesterday on radiation exposure in airline flights omitted in some copies the number of cancer deaths over the national average that can be expected from flying routes 960 hours a year over 20 years. The national average is 22,000 cancer deaths for each 100,000 people.

LEAD: Like most other conductors, the young Austrian Bruno Weil appears to fancy showmanship, and he just received a lesson from a master. LEAD: Most American companies view the Soviet Union and the newly opening nations in Eastern Europe as potential markets for their products or as sources of low-cost manufacturing labor. And a growing number are expected to tap another resource they describe as plentiful and underused: brainpower.

LEAD: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission is scheduled to vote today on a proposed 12-story office building in the South Street Seaport Historic District in lower Manhattan. LEAD: The Drackett Company, a unit of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company that makes household products including Windex and Drano, has named Thomas L. Dahl, who made his marketing mark with Huggies diapers, to be its new president.

LEAD: Welcome to Byrne Meadowlands Arena, home of the Nets. See the empty seats. Endure the comatose atmosphere. Watch the Nets lose. LEAD: Sunrise, Sunset Q. How are the times of sunset and sunrise determined? A. Sunset and sunrise have exactly the same definition: the time when the apparent uppermost ray of the Sun is on the astronomical horizon. If it is the first ray, it is sunrise and if it is the last ray, it is sunset.

LEAD: ''No Father, No Mother, No Uncle Sam'' describes the children born of black American soldiers and white British mothers during World War II. When the soldiers, who found an unexpectedly warm welcome from British working-class women, were sent back to the United States, they left behind an uncounted number of babies and pregnant lovers.

LEAD: A 28-year-old Manhattan security guard arrested in the dormitory-room rape of a freshman over the weekend worked for Columbia University for months despite a police record including convictions for gambling and impersonating a police officer, the authorities said yesterday.
LEAD: A 10-YEAR, half-billion-dollar federally sponsored investigation is concluding that acid rain causes some significant environmental damage but far less than initially feared.

LEAD: William J. McDonald, a lawyer and former senior vice president of the Union Pacific Corporation who played a major role in the formation of Conrail, died of cancer yesterday at Greenwich, Conn., Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Rye.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Thirty-five million Americans report suffering from arthritis, but 6 million of them say they have not seen a doctor about it, Federal health officials say.
LEAD: * Atmos Energy Corp., Dallas, a distributor of natural gas, named Jerry D. Knierim executive vice president for corporate services.

LEAD: AFTER many vain attempts, a sample of what is believed to be the earth's oldest ocean floor has been extracted by drilling into the bottom of the Pacific beneath 18,652 feet of water south of Japan.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bulls Hold Off the Rockets Scottie Pippen's two free throws for the Bulls, after he was fouled with eight seconds left in the game, sealed a 107-102 victory over the Houston Rockets in Chicago yesterday. Houston had a chance to tie the score with a 3-point field goal with 14 seconds left, but Buck Johnson's shot went off the rim.(AP)

LEAD: William Reed Huntington, an architect and a former Quaker representative to the United Nations and director of the Quaker program there, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Norwich, Vt. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: Salary arbitration, the system that has resulted in an aggregate 98 percent raise for about one-quarter of all major league players, continued to keep baseball's club owners and players sufficiently apart yesterday to jeopardize the start of the exhibition schedule.

LEAD: It's been 15 weeks since David Dinkins knew he'd be Mayor of New York City, and seven weeks since he took the oath of office. Yet critical jobs in his administration remain unfilled. The vacancies are beginning to do damage, and not just in theory.

LEAD: Japan's worried business community expressed relief but little joy after the election victory Sunday of the pro-business Liberal Democratic Party. Some executives expressed concern over the economic problems that a divided Parliament faces in coming months.
LEAD: Twenty-five years after Malcolm X was assassinated, his voice is being heard again, his ideology is being re-examined and his face adorns T-shirts and buttons.

LEAD: From the Soviet Union to South Africa, societies are confronting their fundamental problems. Immobilism is giving way to change. There has never been a time in the world like this, we say to each other.

LEAD: Roger J. Gilmartin, a European textile consultant, will try his hand at running an American textile company, Opp and Micolas Mills Inc., which has mills in Alabama and offices in New York. One of his strategies will be to expand export markets in Europe.

LEAD: Challenging tax assessments often requires a lawyer's help. But some homeowners go it alone. The main vehicle is a challenge to the New York City Tax Commission. The forms used are available at the offices of the New York City Real Property Assessment Bureau in each borough. Challenges are considered in tax commission hearings.

LEAD: IN a surprise move, the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation has decided not to make its medical and scientific awards this year. The awards of $15,000 each are among the most prestigious American prizes in the field.
LEAD: Lewis Percy By Anita Brookner 261 pages. Pantheon Books. $18.95.

LEAD: The owners of cooperatives, condominiums and rental apartments in New York City, who have already seen their property values stung by the stumbling of the local economy, have been getting more bad news in the mail: tax increases now coming due based on the ascent of real-estate values in the mid-1980's.

LEAD: PERSONAL computers can offer independence, employment and information to millions of the estimated 37 million Americans with a physical or mental disability, helping them to lead richer, more fulfilling lives.
LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed by an auction of two-year notes tomorrow and a five-year note on Thursday.

LEAD: The game was over, but the televisions and tape machines in both locker rooms at Madison Square Garden were just beginning to roll. Back and forth the incident was replayed, at regular speed, in slow motion and finally frame by solitary frame.

LEAD: ''Crowbar,'' the newest site-specific project of Anne Hamburger's En Garde Arts company, is an act of reclamation and renewal. On Sunday, the Mac Wellman play reopened the Victory Theater on West 42d Street as a home for legitimate theater - unfortunately only through March 11.

LEAD: R. CROSBY KEMPER has given $6 million to the Kansas City (Mo.) Art Institute to establish a museum of contemporary art. The new Kemper Museum of Contemporary Art and Design will be built on the Art Institute's midtown campus.
LEAD: Doctor-patient relationships are becoming a distorted version of the rosy image so many Americans have long held dear.

LEAD: A Nepalese democracy movement, modeling itself on the campaigns for change that have shaken or toppled governments from Beijing to Bucharest, was born here over the weekend in a hail of broken bricks and stones.

LEAD: H. Chapman Rose, a Cleveland lawyer who became an Under Secretary of the Treasury in the Eisenhower Administration and later a personal adviser to President Richard M. LEAD: Awareness is spreading among the public that profound changes are racing through the world, and that they will make a big difference to the U.S. role.

LEAD: In his first month as Governor, Jim Florio has quickly attacked the independent centers of power in state government, drawing into his office more personal control of the sprawling bureaucracy here than any recent governor.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is considering the use of millions of caterpillars that feed on coca plants to destroy cocaine at its source in Peru and Bolivia, an official of the United States Department of Agriculture said today.

LEAD: The Blue Moon Tavern looks like a dump. Its weatherbeaten exterior, dating to the depths of the Great Depression, has been described as ''uniquely ordinary.'' A fern could never grow inside, nor would any of the tavern's regular patrons want it to.

LEAD: Three State Assembly seats were filled in special elections yesterday that will have little effect on the makeup of the Assembly but could be pivotal in overriding Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's death penalty veto. All three winners favor the death penalty.

Blacksmiths are represented by Local 5 of the International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers.

LEAD: Implacable critics of the Sandinista Government are crying foul about next Sunday's elections in Nicaragua. LEAD: The Rev. Dr. James Iley McCord, the former president of Princeton Theological Seminary and founder of its Center for Theological Inquiry, died of complications of Parkinson's disease on Monday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Princeton.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden said yesterday that his right shoulder felt ''100 percent better than it did last September,'' but he conceded that his comeback schedule would be disrupted if spring training were further delayed by labor trouble.
LEAD: When a fancy new wine store opened here recently, it struck some Pennsylvanians as an event on the magnitude of the dismantling of the Berlin Wall.

LEAD: THE enormous building at 120 Broadway that provoked protests 80 years ago and led to enactment of the first zoning laws in New York City - and indeed the nation - has been given a face lift that required seven years of intensive work. Among the tasks in the just-completed renovation were the cleaning of the 50,000-square-foot facade of the 40-story structure and the replacement of many of its eroded terra cotta details.

LEAD: College hockey's regular-season schedules end this weekend in three of the four Division I leagues, and the teams will be scrambling for final positions that determine playoff sites. Since home teams win two-thirds of the time in playoffs, there is reason to scramble.

LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said today that it would trim up to 1,000 jobs this year, or 12 percent of the payroll of its domestic exploration and production unit. The oil giant also said it would sell more than $700 million worth of its domestic properties in the next two years.
LEAD: David Kay, the son of the founder of the Kaypro Corporation, has resigned as the company's president, less than a month after taking the job.

LEAD: Since his presidential campaign sank in scandal in 1987, GARY HART has been quietly practicing law in Denver. Now he is writing a book about the Soviet Union, and he said yesterday he has had access to ''the entire leadership except Mr. Gorbachev.'' He leaves today for Moscow, where he has been traveling nearly every month, 10 days each trip, for a year.

LEAD: Principals who broke traditions and ''refused to let bureaucracy strangle innovation'' were able to build better schools, a nationwide study by a committee of the National Association of Secondary School Principals has found.

LEAD: Siro Vazquez, a retired senior vice president and director of the Exxon Corporation, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.
LEAD: New York State and City officials yesterday accused a major employment agency of discriminating against black applicants and people regarded as too old.

LEAD: Many circumstances lead people to donate to charity, from celebrating a birth to mourning a death, from continuing an old tradition to starting a new one.

LEAD: BLACK sea bass is one of my favorite local fishes. The plump little fellows with semifirm, mild-flavored white flesh usually range from 1 1/2 to 3 pounds but have been seen as big as 5 pounds. According to historical accounts, sea bass were so prolific around New York Harbor in the first half of the 19th century that commercial fishermen rarely had to venture beyond Sandy Hook, N.J., for their daily catch.

LEAD: After four recent visits to La Cote Basque, still one of New York City's most sumptuous dining spots, I came away with several lingering memories. One is of an awestruck young couple (my guess was high school prom age) trying to act so worldly as they struggled with the all-French menu and puzzled over the surfeit of silverware.
LEAD: Creditors of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group plan to file a motion today with the Federal judge overseeing its bankruptcy seeking the appointment of an official to examine Drexel's books.

LEAD: As music listening and performing have moved from the religious to the secular, the rituals surrounding the practice of music have grown increasingly distant from their roots in momentous ceremonies based on life and death or the changing seasons. It is that seriousness, that sense of organic connection with ancient ritual, that Kodo, the group of Japanese percussionists who played at City Center on Tuesday night, tried to convey.

LEAD: ''Odalisque,'' a group show of 41 primarily photographic works at the Jayne H. Baum Gallery in SoHo, has its intriguing moments. But it also brings to mind a recent card mailed out by the Conceptual artist and all-around subversive Les Levine urging the abolition of all group shows.

LEAD: The death of a 2-year-old girl whose disappearance prompted a lengthy manhunt appears to have been a homicide, according to a preliminary autopsy released today. LEAD: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to a stock deal between the Advanced Telecommunications Corporation and the Metromedia Company. Advanced has agreed to repurchase 1,954,500 shares of its common stock from Metromedia at $13 a share, for a total of $25.4 million.

LEAD: Failure has its gradations, just as success does. There are films that fail at doing nothing more elaborate than occupying their viewers' attention for an hour or two, and there are others that fail on a much higher plane. John Boorman's ''Where the Heart Is,'' incorporating elements of Shakespeare, Impressionist painting, magic, fashion and family psychology into a wildly imaginative, thoroughly incoherent mix, has an undeniable grandeur and nobility even in the midst of its broadest lapses of sense, taste and style.

LEAD: The Jamaica Tourist Board awarded its advertising account yesterday to FCB/Leber Katz Partners. The previous agency, Young & Rubicam, lost the account when the United States Government charged it with conspiring to bribe Jamaican officials to win the account, which bills about $6 million. Young & Rubicam has pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to bribe officials.

LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced an electronic film-editing system that is intended to take the place of the razor blade in professional photography labs. The system is the company's latest entry in the developing field of hybrid electronic photography. The Premier image enhancement system begins and ends with a regular film image.

LEAD: After nearly a year of negotiations, Eastern Airlines reached an agreement in principle yesterday with its unsecured creditors on a plan to bring the carrier out of bankruptcy within several months.

LEAD: Margaret Craske, a leading ballet teacher in England and the United States, died on Sunday at Grand Strand General Hospital in Myrtle Beach, S.C. She was 97 years old. A pupil of Enrico Cecchetti, the great Italian ballet pedagogue, Miss Craske danced for a short time with the Diaghilev Ballets Russes and toured with Ninette de Valois, founder of the Royal Ballet, in a small group that performed in English variety theaters during the 1920's.

LEAD: WHere are women in the world whose mascara never smudges. Their lipstick never blurs, their noses never shine, their hair never droops or sags. Or maybe it does, but we never see it. The point is this: They don't spend hours planted before the mirror, fussing, primping and retouching their makeup.

LEAD: Three men loitered on a dark street near Haizhu Bridge late one evening, whispering discreetly to young passers-by: ''Do you want to buy a Hong Kong video? Uh, about sex? Only 100 yuan.'' When the steep price, about $21, or more than a third of a worker's income here, was rejected, the men darted silently back into the darkness.
LEAD: Barbara Dill and Joseph B. Treaster were married yesterday in Coral Gables, Fla., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Volsky. Judge Seymour Gelber of Federal District Court in Miami officiated.

LEAD: The voice may resonate glowingly, but the name doesn't exactly ring a bell. Having spent most of her career in European concert halls and opera houses, the American soprano Arleen Auger has established a footing in the United States only within the last decade. ''I'm a late bloomer,'' says the California native, who has been singing professionally for 25 years.
LEAD: Q. I have some iodine spots on my bathroom sink that I cannot seem to remove. I've tried various cleansers, but nothing seems to help. What should I use?
LEAD: After a decade of revolution and war, Nicaraguans on all sides are counting on the national elections on Sunday to halt their country's long slide into fraternal strife.
LEAD: When ''Driving Miss Daisy'' led the list of Academy Award nominations, executives at Warner Brothers got a double dose of pleasure. The movie's nine nominations mean money and ego satisfaction.
LEAD: Aiming at The Majority

LEAD: The 14-member Governors' Task Force on Education endorsed the main thrust of President Bush's six national goals for education today, setting the stage for a vote by the full membership of the National Governors' Association as early as tomorrow.

LEAD: A TRIP over New Jersey's highways and byways could become much more interesting if the automobile passengers - especially families with young children - engage in a hypothesizing exercise about how certain places got their names.

LEAD: Television is not as simple as it looks. Not by a long shot. There are, for instance, two very different ways of approaching ''Challenger,'' the three-hour made-for-TV movie on ABC this evening at 8. From one perspec tive, it can be seen - thanks largely to a solid cast and Glenn Jordan's carefully measured direction - as a shrewdly constructed film that manages to draw inspiration, prime time's equivalent of mother's milk, from tragedy: the horrifying explosion of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan.
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany arrived here today for intensive talks with President Bush on the future of Europe and the accelerating pace of German unification.
LEAD: Not too long ago a woman sent a very nice and rather expensive flower arrangement to a male friend who was in the hospital. Days passed and she heard nothing. Had the flowers arrived?

LEAD: Jessica Joy Newman and Andrew M. Kronfeld were married last evening at the Hotel Atop the Bellevue in Philadelphia by Rabbi Seymour Rosenbloom. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Newman of Philadelphia. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey S. Kronfeld of Merion, Pa.

LEAD: August wedding plans for Christine Isabelle Rodeno and Lloyd Michael Bloom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bloom of New York, have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rodeno of Paris.

LEAD: BLAZING pink neon signs herald Cesar's Cafe in Great Neck. Also stopping traffic are the giant cacti seemingly flourishing in the ice of winter outside this Tex Mex-Southwestern restaurant. (Only after two or three touch tests does it become apparent that they are not real.) Cesar's interior is a match for its outside flash and dash.

LEAD: They were but faces in the crowd two years ago, among hundreds of young athletes trying to make the United States Olympic track and field team. And like so many whose forays ended too soon, they disappeared again into the background, left to ponder the what-ifs and train for future glories.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington, the other in Hollywood. 2 4 WEB OF DREAMS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) The origin of a curse that has haunted a family of orphans in five previous novels.

LEAD: Every few years there is an article on the topic of adult illiteracy that ''is causing alarm among government and education officials and corporate managers.'' Perhaps one contributory reason for widespread illiteracy, among even United States-born people who have some degree of schooling, is that editors and writers are, in general, ill paid and not respected.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Karen Ann Gallagher, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph L. Gallagher of Milton and Harwich Port, Mass., and Peter Lawson-Johnston Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawson-Johnston of Princeton, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Agatha Roman Catholic Church in Milton. The Rev. Francis X. Turke officiated.
LEAD: Four people were killed early today in a shooting at a nightclub in a neighborhood that is a frequent scene of drug-related violence. At least two people were wounded.

LEAD: LAWMAKERS and regulators in Trenton should alter New Jersey's system of public financing for gubernatorial candidates to reflect the realities of modern political life. The state's Election Law Enforcement Commission, which monitors all of New Jersey's campaign laws, held a day of hearings last week to consider such changes in the wake of the recent election.

LEAD: In an unusual set of maneuvers, a Georgia man has succeeded for now in barring the press and public from hearings in his lawsuit seeking to limit investigation into his possible role in the bombing deaths of a Federal judge and a civil right lawyer.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: No question, the Indian blanket has some miles on it. For years, its bright colors and sharp patterns have adorned bunk beds and the pages of mail-order catalogues, and there has never been a shortage of those who respond to its unpretentious lure of warmth and coziness.
LEAD: The Communist Party has agreed to remove its representatives from the work place and to postpone elections by a month, until June, the state press agency said.

LEAD: Thandabantu David Ntombela is the headman at Elandskop, a Zulu community 60 miles west of Durban. He says he is a good Methodist who deplores violence and trusts in the Lord. He also carries a .38-caliber revolver under his shirt.
LEAD: Right to Sublet in a Co-op

LEAD: A May wedding is planned by Sara McMakin and Paul Andrew Lynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Lynn of Southport, Conn., the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. McMakin of Hamilton, Ohio, have announced. Miss McMakin, 25 years old, graduated from Villanova University, as did Mr. Lynn.

LEAD: Dawn Leslie Parker and Michael Bruce Heifetz were married last evening at the Hilton in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Louis H. Frishman and Cantor Bruce Benson officiated. Michele Joan Parker, the bride's sister, was her maid of honor, and Scott Craig Heifetz, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

LEAD: At hand are the five newest major-label recordings of mainstream Verdi and Rossini operas, and there is no use in delaying the report that all five are unsatisfying. A grand old maestro with offbeat casting, dedicated restudying of scores through critical editions, a defiant stand in favor of ''traditional'' interpretation, superstar casting - nothing seems to work.

LEAD: The Vietnam War is the drawing card for the most popular course at the University of California at Santa Barbara. Hundreds of students are vying for the chance to learn about a conflict that was fought when they were babies.

LEAD: While I read with interest the article on ''Things of Value: Worker or Tools?'' I found myself at odds with the writer's theme. My experience as both a lumber-truck driver and a public-works crew driver, while different than the machinist, had certain parallels.

LEAD: Sam Lopata, a daring and innovative designer, helped make the restaurant scene sizzle in New York in the 1980's. He worked on places that helped define the style of the time. Among them were Cafe Seiyoken, one of the first noisy, grand cafes; Pig Heaven, a whimsical Chinese restaurant filled with pink pigs, and Batons, an austere environment with concrete floors and black and white light fixtures.

LEAD: In the most tangible sign so far that China is retreating from its decade-long commitment to sending students abroad, new restrictions will make it virtually impossible for most university graduates to study in other countries unless they work first for five years.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AS more and more rental buildings in Brooklyn and Queens are converted into cooperatives, New York City's Commission on Human Rights is gearing up to tackle one of the stickiest of housing discrimination issues - the broad powers of co-op boards to reject would-be buyers without explanation.

LEAD: RETREATING from encroaching bulldozers and chainsaws, some 45 enclaves of Indians survive in the depths of Brazil's Amazon basin, shunning contact with the 20th century. ''We don't know what language they speak, what their culture is,'' said Sidnei Possuelo, an official of Funai, Brazil's Indian protection service.

LEAD: BUCKING the tide, swimming upstream, is as much a part of the mission of social agencies today as is serving people in great need. To do only the latter quietly or in isolation, is to miss the opportunity of unveiling to the community the great triumphs of the human struggle that occur each day, in every community.
LEAD: The long-awaited return of Red Ransom will have to wait a little longer.
LEAD: Q. I have some iodine spots on my bathroom sink that I cannot seem to remove. I've tried various cleansers, but nothing seems to help. What should I use?

LEAD: A NEW volunteer organization called the Mianus River Watershed Council has been formed by Westchester and Connecticut residents who say the only way to stem pollution of the river is by fostering a regional, cooperative effort.

LEAD: ''Glory to the Soviet Union!'' proclaims a red banner slung across the gates to the Soviet command in Czechoslovakia, situated in this small town less than 20 miles northeast of Prague. But 21 years after the Soviet Army and other Warsaw Pact forces invaded Czechoslovakia to crush the reform movement of Alexander Dubcek, it is with an apology for that invasion and acceptance of defeat that the Soviet Army is scheduled to begin a slow withdrawal on Monday.
LEAD: BLACK SUN Depression and Melancholia. By Julia Kristeva. Translated by Leon S. Roudiez. 288 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $29.

LEAD: The engagement of Cindy Elizabeth Berenson to Mitchell David Bernstein, the son of Richard B. Bernstein of New City, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Bernstein, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Berenson of Kings Point, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Luella Wilson thought she could afford to lend her great-nephew money for a car in 1984, but it nearly cost her everything she owned. The great-nephew, Willard Stuart, driving without a license and with alcohol and drugs in his system, ran the car off a bridge in an accident that partially paralyzed a passenger, Mark Vince.

LEAD: First there was Vicki Baum's best-selling novel of 1929, then her play, then M-G-M's version, the original all-star Hollywood movie -Garbo, the Barrymore boys, Joan Crawford, Wallace Beery and Lewis Stone. Now, some 60 years after it all began, comes ''Grand Hotel'' the musical. Of course: the dashing staircase rippling with prestigious entrances!
LEAD: THE HOT JAZZ TRIO By William Kotzwinkle. Illustrated by Joe Servello. 153 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

LEAD: In October 1987 and again two years later, Wall Street started panics that spread around the world, only to be slowed and eventually halted in Tokyo. Each time, the Japanese stock market slipped a little but soon rallied, to the great relief of traders everywhere.

Morgan Roberts, the minister of Shadyside, and the Rev.

LEAD: Vincent Teresa, a colorful, obese New England crime figure of the 1950's and 60's who became a Federal informer and later was a co-author of two books about his underworld experiences, died of kidney failure Wednesday in Seattle, The Associated Press reported. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: An article on Feb. 10 about American visas for Soviet and Eastern European scientists referred incorrectly to an official of the National Science Foundation. He is Dr. Gerson Sher. A reference to an official of the National Academy of Sciences, Glenn Schweitzer, was also incorrect. He is Mr. Schweitzer, not Dr.
LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany met with President Bush at Camp David. They are to hold a news conference at 11 A.M. today. ABC News and CNN said they planned live coverage. Page 10.

LEAD: NEARLY 44 million gallons of petroleum products pass through the New York Harbor area every day in a network of tankers, barges, refineries and storage terminals, and hundreds of miles of surface and submerged pipeline.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Petersen of Haverford, Pa., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Amy de l'Orme Petersen, and Gardner Ritner Skene Walling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Campion Walling of Gladwyne, Pa.

LEAD: When Coreen Simpson, a photographer and jewelry designer, saw some cameos in a fashion magazine last year, she thought they were beautiful but said to herself, ''No black woman is going to wear this, especially someone who is really into her culture.''

LEAD: A $300 MILLION solid-waste incinerator being built in Essex County with fund provided by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is drawing criticism on environmental and financial grounds as the massive waste-to-energy plant nears completion.
LEAD: NIJINSKY Scenes From the Childhood of the Great Dancer. Written and illustrated by Catherine Brighton. Unpaged. New York: Doubleday. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

LEAD: Marian Barash Coppersmith and Justice Samuel G. Fredman of State Supreme Court in White Plains were married last evening in State College, Pa. Rabbi Jeffrey Eisenstat officiated at Congregation Brit Shalom. The couple were attended by the bride's son and four daughters and the bridegroom's two sons.

LEAD: Deirdre Mary Filan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James K. Filan of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday at St. Luke Roman Catholic Church to Francis Joseph Curtis 3d, the son of Nancy C. Duane of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Curtis Jr. The Rev. Thomas J. Driscoll officiated.

LEAD: TODAY is Millicent Fenwick's 80th birthday. The former diplomat and Republican Congresswoman from Bernardsville is battling her way into a new decade, fighting age and illness as tenaciously as she championed the political causes she espoused.
LEAD: Figures of speech are supposed to enhance understanding; sometimes they impede it. That's happening with the ''war on drugs.''
LEAD: United States officials are investigating the crashes of two United States Army helicopters in Panama that killed all 11 servicemen aboard, the Southern Command said.

LEAD: KOTOBUKI in Stamford, which opened to some acclaim five years ago, has become better and better. The sushi and sashimi offerings are just as sparklingly fresh, and the variety has expanded considerably. The owners, Hiei and Toshiko Ando, who keep adding new dishes and daily specials to the menu, are demonstrating the importance of hands-on management.

LEAD: Hundreds of students at Brandeis University ended a weeklong boycott of the Barnes & Noble campus bookstore on Wednesday after the company agreed to replace two managers accused of discriminating against black customers.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a caption with the Technology column on Feb. 4 about the neurotransmitter serotonin misstated the chemical's formula. It is C10H12N2O.
LEAD: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciencesis not, as it sometimes seems, a monolithic tyranny of middlebrow opinion. The 1989 Oscar nominations give the lie to all that.

LEAD: I didn't take swimming lessons because of my 40th birthday. I'd like to blame it on that, but it isn't true. I took them because of my 7-year-old daughter, Teal. I could see it in her eyes. She already hated the water as much as I did.
LEAD: Johnnie Ray, a singer whose emotionally uninhibited hit recordings in the early 1950's anticipated the rock-and-roll era, died of liver failure yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 63 years old.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: WONDER BOY Barry Minkow - The Kid Who Swindled Wall Street. By Daniel Akst. 280 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.
LEAD: Less than three minutes into last night's game between St. John's and DePaul, Robert Werdann, the St. John's center, was knocked to the floor at Madison Square Garden.

LEAD: May wedding plans for Elizabeth Hollister Adam and Charles Francis Smithers 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smithers Jr. of New Canaan and Niantic, Conn., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. Donald G. Adam of Pittsburgh and Nancy T. Adam of Nantucket, Mass.
LEAD: Young Einstein 1988. Warner. $89.95. Laser disk. $24.98. 1 hour 25 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.

LEAD: An off-duty police sergeant who was trying to break up a dispute outside a bar in Brooklyn early yesterday fatally shot a 37-year-old woman when his gun accidentally discharged as someone shoved him, the police said.

LEAD: The Art Dealers Association of America moved into the giant Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue Wednesday, filling the space with small galleries to display art works that span five centuries. The gala cocktail previews - there were three of them Wednesday night - benefited the Henry Street Settlement, which provides social services on the Lower East Side.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Cohn of West Orange, N.J., and Chilmark, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Priscilla Betsy Cohn to Daniel P. Karnovsky, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Manfred L. Karnovsky of Cambridge and Chilmark, Mass. An August wedding is planned.
LEAD: The Seattle Mariners have selected a moose as the team's first mascot, narrowly edging a sea monster.

LEAD: As Nicaragua prepares for national elections that all sides hope will draw a clear line between the country's past and its future, Nicaraguans on all sides are counting on the elections to halt their country's long slide into civil strife and economic ruin. Article, page 14.

LEAD: THE O'Leary family of Merrick jogs together. Now they are also learning to shoot together. Clara O'Leary was recently attacked, and she, her husband, Michael, and their daughter Michele MacKay are buying handguns.

LEAD: Gerald G. Conway, who was news director of WOR Radio when he retired in 1976 after 30 years with the station, died of leukemia on Thursday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 76 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: Expect more skirmishes this week in the so-far losing battle to boost the swooning yen. There was some hope last week that the yen would strengthen, given the victory on Sunday of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in Japan's national elections and the expectation that the Bank of Japan would soon raise its discount rate.
LEAD: Forty-one protesters at an abortion clinic here were arrested today on charges of defiant trespass and were released on their own recognizance, Deputy Chief James Galfy said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE JOURNALIST AND THE MURDERER By Janet Malcolm. 162 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: WHEN Stephen and Barbara Bishop bought their 1734 ''handyman special''on Taconic Road in Greenwich five years ago, they immediately began the gritty job of carefully restoring it into their dream house.
LEAD: I read with interest the article dealing with teen-agers and cults [''Westchester Q&A: Helping Parents to Understand Cults''] .

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Voute of Bronxville, N.Y., and Gulf Stream, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Patricia Voute to Kevin Lawrence Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Murphy of North Chelmsford, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: THREADING electrical cable behind walls to extend existing circuits or to add new ones is seldom easy. But stiff, tempered-steel tape called fish tape is the tool designed for the job and professional electricians rely on it. Fish tape is also used to route cable through conduit.
LEAD: WHALE MUSIC By Paul Quarrington. 226 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

LEAD: Nearing completion on the same site in Morningside Heights is a 200-seat chapel for the Seventh Church of Christ, Scientist, and a 71-unit condominium called Lionsgate. The plot, at 520 West 112th Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, is approximately 100 feet square and had, until three years ago, been the site of a brownstone owned by the church, as well as of the church building itself, which had fallen into disrepair.

LEAD: As Harvey Myerson tearfully tells it, not long ago he sat his two youngest daughters down in the living room of his apartment, high above Central Park, and placed before them a scrapbook chronicling his tumultuous legal career.

LEAD: Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, a World War II commander who went on to become a top Army administrator, a diplomat and a leading management consultant, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Friday at the Keswick Nursing Home in Baltimore. He was 82 years old and had homes in Wianno, Mass., and Winter Park,

LEAD: This season, display cases of hair ornaments reflect a trend toward nostalgia and romance. At Block Pharmacy (1282 Third Avenue, near 74th Street), more than 500,000 headbands, bows, combs, barrettes and snoods are on display, priced from $2 to $400. Block is one of a number of stores that have expanded their inventory beyond packs of covered rubber bands.

Adam Dalgitesh puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast. 2 2 5 THE BAD PLACE by Dean R. Koontz (Putnam, $10.95.) LEAD: Once upon a time, in an earlier life, wise men came to instruct me in the ways of something called Management Incentive Compensation, which was always pronounced reverentially, capital letters understood.

LEAD: Women sometimes go out in public clutching strange, sensuous objects. These can be little jeweled leather boxes, slinky lizard-skin envelopes, iridescent silk pouches or shiny sequinned metallic balls.

LEAD: Imagine this. A date takes you to a posh private club in the Wall Street area. The atmosphere's cozy: forest green leather love seats, beige carpeting, white oak-paneled walls that discreetly hide private lockers, cable television, and soothing contemporary music piped in from a compact disc player.
LEAD: A landlord was convicted yesterday by a Brooklyn jury on misdemeanor charges of failing to properly maintain two rental properties in the Flatbush section.

LEAD: President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan announced today that they would meet early next month amid signs that critical trade discussions between Japan and the United States are at a serious impasse.
LEAD: The biggest non-Olympic crowd ever to see a United States national soccer team play witnessed a vivid example today of how much ground the American squad must make up in the international race.

LEAD: Recalling a May Day crafts festival 14 years ago when she first saw glassblowers working in the dark, Ann Morhauser says she was ''hypnotized'' and knew she had to work in glass. Today her Annieglass Studio ships about 80,000 pieces of handmade glass tableware a year.

LEAD: Like many of the thousands of candidates campaigning for local office across the maddening new landscape of Soviet politics, Vladimir M. Rylyakov is a practicing Communist who is wondering what happened to Communism.

But after his team was held below 90 points and lost to the Pistons for a third straight time last week, Rony Seikaly blurted some words of wisdom.
LEAD: Peace is bringing deficits, not dividends, to Brazil's arms-exporting industry, until recently the third world's largest.
LEAD: A week of growing anti-Government protests turned violent today for the first time as fierce confrontations erupted between crowds of youths and heavily armed police officers and soldiers.

LEAD: A 17-year-old youth honored last summer as the nation's safest teen-age driver may have fallen asleep at the wheel before his car slammed into another car, killing him and another person, the police said today.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Milne of Ridge, L.I., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter, Evelyn Beth Milne, and Harold Gregory Moore 3d, a son of Lieut. Gen. Harold G. Moore, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Moore of Auburn, Ala.
LEAD: A United States Air Force captain who was the subject of a spy investigation was honorably discharged on Friday and the investigation was closed, the Air Force said.

LEAD: In boxing history, an upset victory in a world title fight has traditionally brought an automatic rematch. This fight will be demanded by the public, command the biggest payday for the new champion, and create the news media hype.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As the United States restructures its military forces and reduces military spending, it is imperative that it do so in a way that reduces the risk of nuclear war. But the first Bush defense budget moves us in the opposite direction - toward increased reliance on nuclear weapons and increased risk of a nuclear war that neither superpower wants.

LEAD: For Joseph F. Cullman 3d, the scenario had to be one of the oddest of his 77 years. In one court, his corporate accomplishments were drawing fire. In the other, his sports accomplishments were drawing praise. Like a tennis net, Cullman was straddling both courts.

LEAD: FINLAND is probably the only country in the world where the designers of mundane objects can achieve stardom. The Finnish custom of lionizing artists started in 1900 when a team of architects and designers headed by Eliel Saarinen astonished the world with their realization of the national pavilion at the Paris World's Fair, an elaborate, shingled building in the National Romantic style.

LEAD: Darryl Strawberry is expected to complete his 28-day program of treatment for alcohol abuse Friday and to leave the Smithers Center in Manhattan with a new determination to rejoin the Mets and salvage his marriage and career.

LEAD: As members of the Ossining Ministerial Association who have worked on the Affordable Housing Proposal for Ossining for more than two-and-a-half years, we appreciated the article ''Divergent Goals Collide at River Site Owned by State'' [Feb. 4] . While the need for affordable housing seems all too obvious to many of us, there are still some who question such initiatives, especially if it is in their neighborhood.

LEAD: While most people think of mutual funds and retirement accounts as something to invest in, the ''money management'' industry sees them as consumer products, like six-packs of beer or bottles of shampoo. And, heaven knows, money management has been a good business over the past 15 years, as household financial assets have grown sharply and the share of those assets under professional management has expanded as well.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Tighe of Darien, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Julie Anne Tighe and Joseph D. Carrabino Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Carrabino of Encino, Calif.

LEAD: CHILDREN evolve into independent travelers in progressive steps, and one of the most significant is the first stay at sleep-away camp. Parents who have focused on keeping children in seat belts, getting them to wear bicycle helmets and enforcing other travel safety precautions suddenly envision a world of hazards over which they have no control.

LEAD: For 18-year-old Pete Sampras, a draw that became progressively unkind to superstars and inspirational to newcomers allowed him to use a big serve and cool nerves to reach his first career final at the Ebel Pro Indoor tournament. Already the youngest player entered in the event, today he became the youngest finalist since the tournament's inception 29 years ago.

LEAD: An article on Feb. 11 about an outcry by Ringwood residents over a proposal to develop a portion of Sterling Forest misstated Jerome Wyckoff's role on the borough's Environmental Commission. He is a past chairman and a longtime member of the commission, not its founder.

LEAD: After failing a drug test and being suspended from the National Basketball Association for the rest of the season, Roy Marble, an Atlanta Hawk rookie from the University of Iowa, has entered an addiction treatment program in California. . . . Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club and the director of the New York City Marathon, will undergo a biopsy tomorrow to determine the extent of a tumor found on his brain during a series of tests at Mount Sinai Hospital last week.(

LEAD: Your question regarding a Tyson rematch was a bit ambiguous. Are you referring to a rematch with Robin Givens, Mitch Green, Barbara Walters, Don King or Buster Douglas? RICH SCHULHOFF Staten Island
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ever since personal computers became common in the late 1970's, users have wanted their computers to communicate. Modems answered their needs by allowing computers to exchange data over the telephone. During the 1980's, modems opened up a world of information, including electronic mail, computer data bases and services ranging from airline reservations to stock trading.

LEAD: IT still asks homeowners if they have indoor plumbing, and there are 232 communities in Mississippi that currently do not. It asks if the kitchen has a sink, range and refrigerator, and there are thousands of illegal apartments, including hundreds in Westchester, that do not.

LEAD: ''Overeducated, understimulated, overoptimistic, underprepared, overcomplicating, noncooperating, hyperventilating, scared'' goes the opening line of Richard Maltby Jr.'s lyric for ''The March of Time,'' from the Off Broadway revue ''Closer Than Ever.''

LEAD: There is a dividing line between cutting costs and cutting corners. Not all manufacturers recognize and respect this border, and that accounts for the difference between a good cheap product and a product that is merely cheap.
LEAD: There is one mail fraud that seems to persist despite a year-long effort by the United States Postal Service to halt it.

LEAD: A nice collection can begin and end with just one type of coin. A great coin to collect is the Franklin half dollar. Many dealers concur and feel that now is the time for purchasing Franklin half-dollars. Their reasoning is that there are only 35 varieties from 1948 to 1963 so a complete collection is not going to be a huge endeavor.

LEAD: ROOSEVELT AND MARSHALL: Partners in Politics and War. By Thomas Parrish. (Morrow, $25.) In 1943, as President Franklin D. Roosevelt was weighing the candidates for leading the invasion of Europe, he told General Dwight D. Eisenhower that he was giving most serious consideration to the Army's Chief of Staff, George Catlett Marshall, because otherwise ''fifty years from now practically nobody will know who George Marshall was.

LEAD: A 14-year-old drug dealer and his 16-year-old companion were charged yesterday with shooting a couple dead in a car in the Bronx last week, the police said.

LEAD: AS the Federal income-tax law eliminates deductions for interest charges and sales tax, automobile leasers in the county are hoping to attract a new type of customer. They say they are optimistic that more drivers will decide to lease a car for personal use instead of financing an automobile purchase.
LEAD: The American people are always down on someone, the pollster told the trade unionists here: big government, big business or big labor.

LEAD: You asked the wrong question.

LEAD: Paul MacCready is best known as the creator of the Gossamer Albatross, which flew across the English Channel under human power in 1979. It was followed by other flights of low-power, high-efficiency aircraft. The inventor even developed a flying dinosaur replica, one of many exploits that have inspired admiration for Dr.

LEAD: Today's election in Nicaragua may finally break the fever. For 10 years, successive Republican Administrations in Washington have relentlessly distorted diplomacy and even traduced the law, all in fear of a small and impoverished neighbor in Central America. This has been so consuming a preoccupation of the U.S.

LEAD: Nikon, the Japanese consumer products and high-technology company, will move its American headquarters this summer to a new structure in Melville, L.I., that is almost twice the size of the building it currently occupies 20 miles to the west, in Garden City, L.I.

LEAD: With all due respect and admiration for David A. Adler's work, I would like to make a correction to ''For Youth, Memories of the Holocaust'' (Jan. 28), where it states that ''We Remember the Holocaust'' by David Adler is believed to be the first publication about the Holocaust experience for children.
LEAD: THE growth in population has brought many new challenges to northern Westchester in recent years, among them concern about maintaining adequate police protection in some towns.

LEAD: HARDSCRUB. By Lionel G. Garcia. (Arte Publico, Paper, $9.) ''What makes you so sure that they're her children?'' asks a man on a bus as he scrutinizes the mother and sons who are the focus of ''Hardscrub.'' ''Why she hit 'em,'' is his wife's immediate response. That premise - the parent-child bond as defined by violence -is the focus of this bracing new novel by Lionel G.

LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke and the Board of Legislators, at odds for the last two months over a record-breaking 1990 county budget, have joined forces to seek Albany's approval for new legislation that they say would help relieve the burden on Westchester taxpayers.

LEAD: After tracing a major outbreak of Legionnaires' disease to a supermarket's vegetable-spraying machine, the Federal Centers for Disease Control have concluded that ''misting machines'' and home humidifiers do not appear to pose widespread risks to public health.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George Brainard Lucas Jr. of Watchung, N.J., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Ann Lucas and Garret Walker Vreeland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Walker Vreeland of Summit, N.J.

LEAD: In the five and a half years since Tom Clancy's nuclear-submarine thriller ''The Hunt for Red October'' became a best seller, the cold war, as every schoolchild knows, has lost much of its icy terror.

LEAD: For video people, the movie ''Lethal Weapon 2,'' a cop-buddy hit starring Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, is turning into a thriller off-screen as well as on. Warner released the film, which is rated R, on Feb. 8 at the price of $24.98, meaning that the studio thinks it should sell better than it rents.

LEAD: Walking through London's Eaton or Belgrave Squares, it seems as though life hasn't changed since these residential neighborhoods were orignally built in the early years of the 19th century. The rows of terraced houses look as they always have on the outside, but inside many of the buildings have been completely renovated to function efficiently in the 20th century.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Levine of Monsey, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Ellen M. Levine and Robert I. Altman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Altman of Marlboro, N.J. Ms. Levine, 28 years old, graduated from Pace University. She is a senior tax analyst with Young & Rubicam in New York.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: The Streetscapes column on Feb. 4 rendered the name of a historian and the organization he heads incorrectly. He is Wayne Drummond, president of the New Haven Railroad Historical and Technical Association.

LEAD: When I was a small child in Chicago, my mother began what became a repeated chant: we must return one day to gu xiang, ''the village of our ancestors.'' She became more urgent with time as she began to fear she would be too old to make the journey. And when China opened to travelers in 1978, my mother's determination grew.
LEAD: COUNTRY HOUSES

LEAD: Linda Fairstein - suburban born, classically educated, intelligent, impeccably dressed - spends her days thinking about vile and abominable acts. The longer one knows her, the stranger the paradox becomes.
LEAD: For two weeks this winter, the San Francisco supervisors were ousted from their dome-ceilinged chamber in City Hall, courtesy of legislation they themselves had authorized.

LEAD: A proposal to use surplus brood stock of Atlantic salmon to provide a put-and-take sport fishery for the species in a section of the Merrimack River in New Hampshire has distressed many of those who have for years been laboring to restore spawning runs of those highly prized food and game fish to the rivers of New England.

LEAD: MOST recent education reform has been a ''top down'' effort. The governors of several states and a handful of education commissioners have taken the lead in addressing problems in the schools. In Connecticut, both the Governor and the Commissioner of Education are acknowledged leaders in this area.

LEAD: AFTER 40 years in an alliance held together by the Soviet military threat, the United States and Western Europe have suddenly realized that things may never again be the same between them. When Cold War issues dominated, Western Europe never questioned Washington's leadership. Today, trans-Atlantic ties are being pulled in all directions.
LEAD: LOST IN SEOUL And Other Discoveries on the Korean Peninsula. By Michael Stephens. 238 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

LEAD: Whatever it is this season, it's easier. Whether it's the shape of the clothes themselves or the attitude about how and where you wear them, the lines are freer now. It is as if, as the 1990's roll in, fashion and women's approach to the subject have both relaxed.

LEAD: Wisps of choreographic ideas drifted through ''Dances in and Out of the Agora,'' the program Silvia Marinari, Christine Coppola and Almalyn Largey offered on Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. Some of their kinetic apparitions were mistily attractive. Others were totally insubstantial.

LEAD: One way to boost a car's mileage is to increase tire pressure, which reduces rolling resistance. But increased tire pressure means a harsher ride on uneven surfaces. Cornering ability suffers as well.

LEAD: The television commercial, set to ominous funeral music, showed Violeta Barrios de Chamorro smiling through a succession of bloody images - mutilated children, Nazi swastikas, raging fires and menacing rebels.

LEAD: In September 1987, as the bull market still raged and few guessed that a crash was but a month away, there was a huge waiting list for the investment banking course at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.

LEAD: SHIFTING the spending categories in the state budget will cost more in the long run, says Michael Levin, the vice president of the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council, which monitors government spending.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication.

LEAD: Katherine Lord Meyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Meyer Jr. of Centre Island, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Christopher James Merritt, a son of Mrs. Walter H. Merritt of Hudson, N.Y., and the late Mr. Merritt. The Rev. Guy P. Hawtin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: SIX years ago, David L. Gunn took charge of New York City's crumbling public transportation system, embarking on what he called a ''suicide mission'' to turn it around. On Wednesday, Mr. Gunn will step down as president of the Transit Authority, turning the job over to Alan F. Kiepper, a former general manager of Houston's transit system.

LEAD: The Seattle SuperSonics may have no better than a middling record in the National Basketball Association's Pacific Division, but the team has one consolation of sorts: its injured-reserve list may be the best in the league, and it's getting better.

LEAD: The Japanese stock market was in all but free fall last week, dropping 2,569.35 points, or 6.9 percent. One culprit was that old bugaboo - computerized program trading, one of the few unrestricted American imports into Japan. And most of the program trading is being done by American firms, Japanese analysts say.
LEAD: DARK OBSESSION A True Story of Incest and Justice. By Shelley Sessions with Peter Meyer. 316 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

LEAD: From the Cocaine Situation Room or some other place deep in the bowels of the Agriculture Department has come the Bush Administration's latest notion for the war on drugs. The Administration has proposed to quadruple the budget of the Agricultural Research Service - to $6.5 million - mainly to study eloria-noyesi, a coca-eating caterpillar, and the feasibility of dropping millions of the insects into the coca fields of Peru and Bolivia.

LEAD: Absolutely not. It is incumbent upon the champion to fight the No. 1 contender. While this may not be in Douglas's best monetary interest, he should preserve the integrity of the sport. Holyfield deserves the next shot. ADAM BERLIN New York
LEAD: Now that the Gillette Company has introduced Sensor, a lot more than a tough beard is riding on the razor's edge. Management's neck is, too.

LEAD: For This Week: When there are mild days to work outside, fertilizer can be applied to evergreens, young trees, fruit trees, perennials; the nutrients will be soaked in by spring rains. Lime lawns with a calibrated spreader; if the earth is wet and soggy, stay off. Last call to mail orders for nursery plants and seeds.

LEAD: Deborah Madison was the founding chef at Greens in San Francisco, generally agreed to be the best vegetarian restaurant in this country. Ms. Madison's latest cookbook, ''The Savory Way'' (Bantam Books, $24.95), is not due out until June, but one of the recipes is for eggplant and potatoes stewed with spices.

LEAD: ''It's quite wonderful and quite easy, isn't it? I rejoice in the fact that when the going gets rough, I don't have to put up with it. Spiritually I'm in a wonderful, calm place.'' - Jim Lee, who has AIDS and has made preparations for suicide. [1:2.]

LEAD: BERLIN, it now seems likely, is to become once more the capital of the Germans. In principle, that should make the city whole again, a megalopolis of three million people free to reclaim its place among the great centers of European culture and industry. But it is hard to imagine how the return of the capital will do more than add one more Berlin to the bewildering set already shaped by a tortuous history.
LEAD: Unions, in recent years, have initiated strikes that have been costly to them, but owners of baseball's 26 teams appear to be losing their own lockout.

LEAD: Gershon Mamlak, a slight intense man, talks about his past and present in impassioned bursts. He stabs the air with a finger to press a point and pulls letters out of manila folders to document others.

LEAD: Tyson is the best world champion boxing has had since Ali. He has been extremely generous in his willingness to defend his crown. He has fought as often as every other month to accommodate the long list of candidates. Mike clearly deserves an immediate rematch.

LEAD: The 1990 election campaign, which has so far generated little excitement despite a number of races with considerable significance, is approaching its first major event, the March 13 primaries in Texas.

LEAD: Some hot new processors still rely on Complex Instruction Set Computing. THE Series 6000 work stations introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation earlier this month clearly demonstrate the fundamental speed advantages of the technology called Reduced Instruction Set Computing. The RISC machines use a type of simplified processor chip that yields performance once found only among computers costing 10 to 100 times as much.

LEAD: On any given Friday, Saturday and Sunday, the U.S. No. 1 Flea Market and Antiques in New Brunswick, N.J., about 45 minutes down the turnpike from Manhattan, draws some 30,000 people. They push their way past sweatshirt vendors and bulletin boards announcing events like a Marvelettes concert at the local high school to get through the streaky glass doors.

LEAD: Whenever Jim Lee opens his refrigerator, his two carefully hoarded bottles of Seconal are there, reminding him that he is soon to die, and that like large numbers of people with AIDS, he is preparing when the time is right to take his own life.
LEAD: ''THE Education of Hyman Kaplan,'' at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst through March 17, is a musical about immigrants in New York City in the early part of the century.
LEAD: A spokesman for the Fish and Wildlife Service said that the agency would impose a ban on the harvesting of striped bass in New Jersey's coastal waters beginning Thursday.

LEAD: THE last time the warring factions in Cambodia sat down together at an international peace conference, in Paris last August, they seemed incapable even of holding a civil conversation. The world's diplomats concluded that the conference had been premature and that flexibility toward a solution, let alone its shape, would have to come after the warring sides had done some more fighting in the absence of Vietnamese troops.

LEAD: THEY look like classical performers, and they do take their music seriously, but members of the New World Consort play jazz, ragtime and ''jumps,'' and they sometimes stomp their feet and shout ''Ha-ha-ha!'' during concerts.

LEAD: THey are honest, romantic, sincere. Theyhave integrity. And they are sexy. Terms usually invoked to decribe friends, lovers, and sometimes, politicians, are the ones that crop up most when the topic turns to work clothes. Mention any one of those familiar and functional items, ranging from T-shirts to overalls to fishermen's caps, and the conversation takes on a high tone with a sentimental edge.
LEAD: Moved and still incredulous about the occasion, Petar Dartliev clutched copies of the newspaper that his party had just published for the first time in 41 years.

LEAD: Nelson Mandela may be viewed by much of the world as a man to be admired, but Jon Westling, the acting president of Boston University, begs to differ. When the superintendent of the Chelsea public schools, Diana Lam, cited Mr. Mandela as a crusader for human rights in a speech, Mr. Westling dashed off a letter sternly apprising her of his disapproval.

LEAD: It is not often that good luck comes disguised as a calamity. That, however, may be what is happening to the New York Philharmonic in its efforts to replace Zubin Mehta as music director. Having failed to induce Leonard Bernstein, its laureate conductor, to return to his old post with the orchestra and having lost out to the Berlin Philharmonic for the services of the next-best candidate, Claudio Abbado, Philharmonic officials have been flirting with a variety of more or less promising possibilities.

LEAD: ''HEY bud, that will be $5,'' said the bouncer at the Whispers Nightclub in the Smithtown Sheraton, grabbing the arm of a dark-haired boyish-looking man who had just walked past him.
LEAD: TO all the other environmental hazards connected with homeownership - radon, asbestos and foam insulation among them - must now be added underground oil tanks.

LEAD: A Greek passenger ferry that operates between the Mediterranean island of Cyprus and the Lebanese Christian region was hit by shellfire today from a gunboat 30 miles off the Lebanese coast. Security officials said 1 passenger was killed and 18 were wounded, some of them seriously.
LEAD: Elizabeth Ann Shollenberger and Timothy William James, lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the Ethical Culture Society in New York by Judge Stuart C. Cohen of City Civil Court.

LEAD: Erika Story Marshall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Marshall of New York and Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday to David James Gladwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Gladwell of London.

LEAD: Waving the black, red and gold banners of West Germany and the green and white of Saxony, enthusiastic crowds cheered Willy Brandt late Friday here and in Plauen and demonstrated impatience with the pace of reunification.

LEAD: After a hiatus of more than 30 years, the specter of abstraction once again haunts the art of photography. But today's version of abstract photography has little in common with the Abstract Expressionist style and high seriousness of work from the 1950's by Aaron Siskind, Minor White and others. Instead, it seems suffused with a sense of belatedness and loss, as well as an acute awareness that abstraction functions as a sign of the realm of the spiritual.

LEAD: In THE GOOD SPY by John Griffiths (Carroll & Graf, $17.95), the setting looks back a few years to the Brezhnev period. A Russian sleeper in the United States is called into service. Coincidentally, the head of an American intelligence agency learns that there is a mole in his department. There is a good deal of maneuvering before things are straightened out, to the satisfaction of all concerned.
LEAD: DREAM SONG The Life of John Berryman. By Paul Mariani. Illustrated. 519 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $29.95.

LEAD: IN the asphalt potluck called Hoboken, people like Angela Servello say that when the wind blows down from the river carrying the musky smell of coffee from the Maxwell House plant, it's going to rain for sure.

LEAD: Egyptomania in American decorative arts lingered longer than most revival styles, lasting from the Civil War until World War II. Temple-shaped clocks and sphinx-embellished coffee urns proliferated in the nation's parlors and dining rooms while children learned their A B C's with obelisks of alphabet blocks.

LEAD: ''Ah Scarlatti'' was the premiere by Eliot Feld Thursday night on his company's second program. The remaining three ballets were ''Theater,'' ''The Gods Amused'' and ''Danzon Cubano,'' all created by Mr. Feld in the 1970's and looking better than ever.
LEAD: ''Every Ballet,'' says Eliot Feld, ''deserves its own language. That sense of propriety, of the materials that are called for, is the quality that makes something beautiful.''

Instead, six personable, daredevil performers tumbled, dashed and teetered through a funny, often dramatic hourlong carnival of wild physical games.

He also paid tribute to ''the endless heroes of youth . . . You, the young lions have energized our entire struggle.'' Mr. Mandela has become the living symbol of the struggle for black liberation.

LEAD: An addendum to your article: I've been told that Russian emigres to Israel are reporting that, to gain admittance to Pamyat, prospective members must provide the organization with the names, addresses and phone numbers of several Jews. Those Jews are then harassed over the phone with death threats and orders to leave the country.

LEAD: During the 1980's, when inflation came under control and companies could get away with giving mediocre raises, they started tinkering with compensation packages. Instead of double-digit raises, they offered valuable employees stock grants, deferred bonuses and other potentially lucrative incentives if they attained higher profits, stock-price growth or other goals.

LEAD: After their greatest boom since World War II, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut face the prospect of years of slower economic growth.

LEAD: Almost as soon as Don King arrived in John Johnson's suite at the Mirage in Las Vegas on Wednesday to reaffirm his contractual options on the new world heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, the promoter phoned room service.

LEAD: RONALD REAGAN was on television again, unfazed but unable to remember. He had meant the Iran-contra operation to be covert but not illegal, he said in the videotaped deposition that John M. Poindexter, the next defendant to stand trial in the scandal, had sought for so long. Mr. Reagan could not recall conversations from his Presidency or even identify the Chairman of his Joint Chiefs of Staff.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Putting Yasir Arafat in an hourlong documentary film is like pinning down a ball of mercury: a heroic effort requiring patience, perseverence and a great deal of money.

LEAD: As the heat of ethics issues shifts from the House to the Senate, some members are seeking to tighten rules that permit Senate aides to augment their salaries unrestricted by limits that will soon apply to the rest of Congress.
LEAD: ''THE KING AND I'' at the Shubert in New Haven is a celebratory occasion and offers a sober perspective on a familiar musical.

LEAD: IN West Berlin, where only 45 years ago Allied soldiers could execute a man for being on the street without his I.D. card, the conundrum of identity - of who you are when you're not at home - has never quite been solved. It's the riddle at the heart of this schizophrenic city, yanked at from every quarter by contradicting tugs, and one that Berliners express in their choice of cafes.

LEAD: There exists in our world an unusual, partly savage tribe, ancient and widely distributed, yet until recently little studied by anthropologists or historians. All of us were at one time members of this tribe: we knew its customs, manners and rituals, its folklore and sacred texts. I refer, of course, to childhood.

LEAD: The mutual fund business recently rang in a record-breaking $1 trillion in assets, and that was good news for the industry. But it should also be good news for investors. Higher assets should translate into lower fees as costs are spread over a broader base.
