WEDNESDAY: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan testifies before the House Budget Committee.

LEAD: Court No. 2 of the somber Old Bailey Courthouse in London was packed to capacity last Oct. 19. Ranks of wigged lawyers squeezed into the jury box. A hundred reporters crowded the back benches; the public gallery was overflowing - but the courtroom was deathly silent. As the Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord Lane, finished his summing up, his voice, quiet and restrained, carried to the back of the courtroom: ''These appeals are allowed and the convictions are quashed.
LEAD: Anti-Semitic incidents continue to plague Middlesex County, N.J.

LEAD: Astronomers have discovered more than a dozen evenly distributed clumps of galaxies stretching across vast expanses of the heavens, suggesting a structure to the universe so regular and immense that it defies current theories of cosmic creation and evolution.

LEAD: Bill Keller's account of Russian nationalism brought to memory tales of the Russian past on which I was weaned (''Russian Nationalists: Yearning for an Iron Hand,'' Jan. 28). My Russian-born father would tell us about the events of the 1905 pogrom, when Cossacks broke into his home. My grandmother hid him in a wardrobe closet and covered him with blankets to save him from the drunken attackers, who beat her furiously, with cries of ''Kill the Yids and save Mother Russia.

LEAD: As long as there are children and hoops in this part of southern Indiana, people will remember the night Damon Bailey cried and more than a few in the customary adoring crowd of more than 6,300 wiped away their own tears.

LEAD: The decision by the University of Notre Dame to abandon the College Football Association's television plan and sign its own contract with NBC was a bad one, bad for college football and bad for intercollegiate athletics in general.
LEAD: The Devils jokingly call him Scary Terreri for the way Chris Terreri, their diminutive backup goaltender, flips and flops on the ice.

LEAD: Back in 1977, when Miss Margarida, the redoubtable schoolteacher, first strode onto a New York stage, it did not take the audience long to figure out that they were in the hands of a rather unusual tyrant.

LEAD: Though for some years past a refugee from the chocolate sundae topped with fudge and pecan, this critic still cannot see a lump of sugar without thinking with gratitude of Henry Tate, who in late Victorian times was England's Mr. Sugar.

LEAD: WALKING along the wintry shoreline of Seaside Park in Bridgeport, William Garrett paused to study the statue of the showman and entrepreneur P. T. Barnum, once the city's Mayor. The gaze of the imposing bronze likeness is fixed on the murky waters of Long Island Sound.

LEAD: NOBODY wants Johnny Pye, 11 years old and ''permanently orphaned.'' Made to think he's ''some kind of fool'' - ''a walking bad habit'' - the boy did see the Foolkiller when the dark, dreaded figure appeared to collect Johnny's father.
LEAD: The flight of the space shuttle Atlantis, delayed much of the week by weather and the illness of a crew member, was called off less than a minute before the scheduled launching early today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FIRST, one Roman Catholic bishop warned Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York that he was in serious danger of going to hell, and the Archbishop of New York didn't disagree. Now, the new bishop of Brooklyn has said that Mr. Cuomo had better watch what he says in his home borough.
LEAD: Baltimore's rejuvenated Inner Harbor celebrates its 10th anniversary this year in a season that also will see the National Aquarium open a $35 million marine mammal pavilion.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Horn of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Gila to Dr. Joel Gellman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gellman of Johannesburg. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mrs. Robert T. Sheehan of Brooklyn has made known the engagement of her daughter, Kerith Leah Sheehan, to Marvin Stanley Putnam Jr., a son of Janice Crawford Putnam of Bangor, Me., and Mr. Putnam of Portland, Me. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Sacuto of Charlottesville, Va., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Lisa Marie Sacuto and Jonathan Hodson-Walker, a son of John Hodson-Walker of Truro, West Cornwall, England, and the late June Elizabeth Hodson-Walker. Miss Sacuto, 25 years old, is a financial analyst with the Ford Motor Company in Louisville, Ky.

LEAD: COMPUTER viruses devised by high-technology vandals have crippled computer networks, damaged data and occasionally left personal computer users in a state of near hysteria. But some scientists are considering the possibility that these self-replicating programs might have constructive uses as well.

LEAD: In the final days of prosecution testimony against Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood, the state has revived the question whether he was drunk when his tanker, the Exxon Valdez, ran aground on a reef in Prince William Sound last March and began spewing almost 11 million gallons of crude oil.
LEAD: LIGHTS OUT IN THE REPTILE HOUSE By Jim Shepard. 285 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: The magnitude and urgency of the problem of functionally illiterate adults in New Jersey was well documented in the article ''Programs Combating Increase in Illiteracy'' (Jan. 14). But the generally upbeat tone of the report was somewhat belied by the statistics cited in its concluding paragraph.

LEAD: A NEW volunteer organization called the Mianus River Watershed Council has been formed by Westchester and Connecticut residents who say that the only way to stem pollution of the river is through a regional effort.

LEAD: THE repertoire for chamber orchestra is particularly rich, as composers rise to the challenge of writing pieces that approach the sonorities of a full symphonic ensemble, yet maintain the intimate precision we associate with string quartets and brass or wind quintets.

LEAD: Samite, A traditionalist musician from Uganda, passed on a traditional proverb to a recent New York audience: ''If you don't dance to music, it is wasted.'' By that standard, hardly a note went unused at some of the best concerts I've seen lately. In ascending order of capacity, the Meters at Tramps, the B-52's at Radio City Music Hall and Erasure at Madison Square

LEAD: Why has the number of student bridge players, once considerable in every college, dwindled to a trickle in the United States? Why has this not happened in other parts of the world where the game has grown steadily in popularity?

LEAD: These are heady days for the memory of Louis I. Kahn. The architect died 16 years ago next month, perhaps the most respected presence in his profession. And the intervening years seem only to have enriched Kahn's reputation still more, to the point where it is now no exaggeration to call him the most venerated figure in 20th-century American architecture after Frank Lloyd

LEAD: Hilary Foretich, the 7-year-old girl at the heart of the country's best-known custody battle, went on a 15,000-mile odyssey in 30 months in hiding with her grandparents, traveling from Washington to Plymouth in western England to Christchurch, New Zealand, where her father located her a few days ago.

LEAD: In its first public evaluation of the radar-evading Stealth bomber, the General Accounting Office has recommended that Congress slow the financing and production of the aircraft while it is tested further.

LEAD: Plymouth, Conn. $260,000 46 Richmond Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; 3-zoned heating, 3-car attached garage, formal dining room, 4.4 acres; taxes not available. Portland, Conn. $115,000 91 Marlborough Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 140-year-old colonial; country kitchen, w/b stove, deck, 1 acre; taxes $1,123.
LEAD: Tete-a-Tetes Vs. Derring-Do

LEAD: COLUMBUS AVENUE, which remakes itself every few years, is in the middle of another transformation, marked by a high number of vacancies, lower rents, frequent turnover and the loss of the very stores and restaurants that once epitomized the avenue.

LEAD: Malcolm Forbes, chairman and editor in chief of Forbes magazine and one of the country's most flamboyant multimillionaires whose enthusiastic pursuits included yachting, motorcycling and ballooning, died yesterday of a heart attack in his sleep at his home in Far Hills, N.J. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: EVER since the possibility of German reunification arose, the Bush Administration has chosen to talk about it in the most delicate and positive terms, almost as if Germany's division had been an act of nature and not war. This has been intentional, an effort not to antagonize the Germans and lose their cooperation at a moment when it is most needed to insure that Europe makes a peaceful transition to a post-Cold War order.
LEAD: In his first game as a San Antonio Spur, the former Knick Rod Strickland was a bit out of sync with his new teammates Friday night, but not so much that the Minnesota Timberwolves could notice.

LEAD: I was appalled to read the account of Russian nationalism. Not the least of the crimes for which Soviet Communism must answer is the creation of a populace so ignorant that the main alternative to Communism itself seems to be the vicious bigotry of groups like Pamyat and Fatherland. May Mikhail S.
LEAD: An article on Feb. 18 about Fort Lee, N.J., misstated the range of prices at the Westgate town-house complex. It is $159,990 to $214,990.

LEAD: The new hardiness zone map is out. It appears as end papers in the just-released book ''The National Arboretum Book of Outstanding Garden Plants'' by Jacqueline Heriteau with Dr. H. Marc Cathey, the arboretum's director. The 320-page book with 450 color photographs is available in bookstores ($39.95, Simon and Schuster).
LEAD: A group of conservative Republican members of Congress said today that the Nicaraguan Government had rejected their request to observe the national elections on Sunday.
LEAD: Yeats Unabated

LEAD: ''A Spinning Tale,'' a new musical at Playhouse 91, announces itself in its press release as ''targeted for an adult audience but guaranteed to entertain children.'' In reality it is targeted for a children's audience and not guaranteed to entertain adults.
LEAD: Italy and Spain have signed an agreement that could be the first step in the formation of a European basketball league.
LEAD: A lawyer representing a mother and daughter accused of defrauding customers of almost $250,000 says the women cannot be convicted unless the state proves that evil spirits do not exist.

LEAD: One day soon, a player's agent is going to stare across the negotiating table at the new assistant general manager of the Red Sox and suggest with a nuance or a smirk: ''Huh, a woman. What do you know about baseball?''
LEAD: Senior guerrilla officials say France has halted its arms supplies to a guerrilla group fighting Cambodia's Communist Government after the covert program was publicized.
LEAD: MARDI GRAS TIME
LEAD: BLUE TAXIS Stories About Africa. By Eileen Drew. Foreword by Rosellen Brown. Illustrated. 155 pp. Minneapolis: Milkweed Editions. Paper, $9.95.

LEAD: With the first round of the ''open skies'' talks between NATO and the Warsaw Pact in its final week in Ottawa, the Soviet Union's approach is puzzling Western diplomats, prompting speculation that Moscow might plan to break off negotiations for internal political reasons.

LEAD: The Alban Berg Quartet brought Alfred Schnittke's newest string quartet (his fourth) to Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. It is a piece that lives for its slow movements, of which there are three.

LEAD: Beth Ellen Cuda, an assistant vice president at Banque Nationale de Paris, and Todd McCord Baker, an associate at the Security Pacific Merchant Bank, both in New York, are planning an April wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Cuda of West Hartford, Conn., have announced.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY

Then, working with a colleague who specializes in clinical nutrition,
LEAD: Budapest And Vienna Plan an Expo

LEAD: Nearly a year after Washington University announced that it would close its sociology department, debate over the the move still divides faculty members, who are to vote on Friday on a resolution in support of the department.

LEAD: As a frequent driver on the New Jersey Turnpike and the parent of a Rutgers University student who has taken courses taught by Professors Gillespie and Rockland, I compliment them on their entertaining, informative book on the turnpike. But I must temper my compliments with criticism.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard K. Trambert have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Renee Stephanie Trambert and Edward Tyler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tyler of Oceanside, L.I. Miss Trambert, 25 years old, is a nurse at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, where her fiance, 31, is a pharmacist.

LEAD: Sonoma-Cutrer, a prominent California winery, uses one grape and makes only one wine from it: chardonnay. In this respect, Sonoma-Cutrer is unusual. Many wineries make only one wine, but they use a number of grapes to do it. For example, a Bordeaux chateau like Lafite-Rothschild makes only one wine, the world-famous red that bears its name, but it may use three, four or even five different grapes, in varying proportions.
LEAD: Q. I have some iodine spots on my bathroom sink that I cannot seem to remove. I've tried various cleansers, but nothing seems to help. What should I use?

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Howard N. Epstein of Washington Crossing, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Beth Epstein, to Dr. Mark Steven Gloger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gloger of Pikesville, Md. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: FANS of vocal music will have much to choose from over next weekend, according to the schedules of chamber and operatic ensembles.
LEAD: April wedding plans for Maureen Ann Kennedy and David Mortimer Hays have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Kennedy of Wilton, Conn.

LEAD: NOW that increased consumption of complex carbohydrates and fiber is recommended for a wholesome diet, lentils should be on the shopping list. These tiny members of the legume family are delicious, versatile and easy to prepare. Unlike most dried beans, they do not require presoaking.

LEAD: Harold Stover is the organist and choirmaster of Second Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, but he sometimes performs at other churches as well. Last Sunday afternoon he played a recital at St. Bartholomew's Church, on Park Avenue at 50th Street.

LEAD: WHY would Al Sharpton come to Yonkers? That's the first thought that came to my mind when I read that the black activist, who lives in Brooklyn, was coming here to protest the city's long opposition to building equally dispersed low-income housing to spur integration.
LEAD: MAO TSE-TUNG AND HIS CHINA By Albert Marrin. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)
LEAD: As freezing winds blew across Spruce Street, a sophomore at the University of Pennsylvania, John Steele, was on patrol trying to protect fellow students from crime and his hands from the cold.

LEAD: Some classic films have appeared on video in the past year, ranging from an unlikely, large-scale prospect such as LAWRENCE OF ARABIA (RCA/Columbia, $29.95) to THE WIZARD OF OZ (MGM/UA, $24.95), already so familiar from television that a video version scarcely seems to make a difference. But the classic least likely to survive the transition is GONE WITH THE WIND (MGM/UA, $89.95; two cassettes).
LEAD: Efforts by Mexico and the United States to halt drug trafficking across the border are being hampered by strong disagreements over how to go about it, Mexican and American officials say.

LEAD: Yevgeny Alekseyev was born after World War II, and like most Soviet children, he had drummed into him in his youth the pain and devastation that his country endured at the hands of the German enemy.

Happauge $165,000 35 Mackay Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old high ranch; new eat-in kitchen, den, dining room, gas heat, 2-car garage; taxes $3,500.

LEAD: I think it is very humorous when pro-development speakers invoke affordable housing to justify the latest development action. Who is kidding whom?

LEAD: The outcome of the trial, for or against, George Gardner is not the issue of my distaste for the story by David Margolick. It is the invasion, even in death, of the privacy of a very private person.
LEAD: The freshman Kenny Anderson matched his season high with 32 points, including 5 in overtime, as Georgia Tech held off Notre Dame, 88-80, today.

LEAD: Hilary Martin Lea and Matthew Lionel Bernard plan to marry in June, the prospective bride's parents, Avice S. Lea of Greenwich, Conn., and Charles L. Lea Jr. of New York, have announced. Mr. Bernard is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan H. Bernard of Greenwich.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Emily Kay Lyon and Dr. Bernard Jay Berger have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. Lyon of Greenwich, Conn. Dr. Berger is a son of Robert Berger and Carol Berger, both of Spring Valley, N.Y.

LEAD: NO one is talking anymore about a miracle in Atlantic City, about a phoenix by the sea rising from the rust of urban decay. The way some prominent state lawmakers assess the resort's flagging fortunes, what is needed now is a salvage operation.

LEAD: People up front at the 45th Street Theater during performances of Willy Holtzman's ''Bovver Boys'' must wonder when they will get a soccer ball or a foot in their faces as five of the eight characters kick and butt a ball around a raked stage that ends almost in the laps of front-row patrons. But their anxiety might be a blessing in this case.

LEAD: With Queens caught up in a flood of condominium and cooperative conversions, residents there may want to attend a seminar on owning and operating such apartments. It will be Tuesday at 6:45 P.M. at the Queens Borough Hall in Kew Gardens.

LEAD: THE Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry signed into law last summer was not just a simple matter of covering the depositors' losses. To recoup what it can, the Government is obliged to sell off billions of dollars in foreclosed property it inherited from hundreds of insolvent thrifts.

LEAD: The jury is now in on the 1989 debt restructuring agreement between Mexico and the international financial community. Unfortunately, the deal is a bad one for Mexico. The agreement, signed on Feb. 4, falls far short of the country's needs, has not and will not produce the desired effects, and leaves the nation in a woefully weak position for future negotiations.

LEAD: By a large margin, people who wish to memorialize those who have died make up the largest single category of donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. In letters that accompany their gifts, they recall parents, spouses, siblings, children, friends and associates and seek to honor them by helping others.

LEAD: Chris Smith scored 21 points and Nadav Henefeld sparked a 13-0 run to start the game as sixth-ranked Connecticut cruised to a 79-57 victory over Seton Hall tonight in a Big East Conference game.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a capsule listing of issues in medicine last Sunday, with a front-page article about doctors, misstated the percentage of black and Hispanic doctors for 1988. Black doctors made up 3.3 percent of the profession; Hispanic doctors made up 4.7 percent.

LEAD: The marriage of Jocelyn Keith Taylor and Henry Dickson McIntire took place yesterday at the Congregational Church in Peru, Vt. The Rev. Alice O'Donovan performed the ceremony. The bride's daughter and son, Ashley C. Taylor and Ashton K. Taylor, attended the couple.

LEAD: A PLAN to designate New Haven's affluent St. Ronan-Edgehill area as a historic district has divided its residents. Arguments about the proposal, and about historic districts in general, are flying across St. Ronan Street, Edgehill Road and other nearby streets - all lined with big, stately houses.
LEAD: Every other Friday evening, Jeanette Payne meets with her ''extended family'' in the community room of Concourse Village in the Bronx to share experiences and talk over coping strategies.

LEAD: Culturally speaking, it still has the ring of a contradiction in terms: a Los Angeles subway. Nonetheless, ground was broken for the city's Metro Rail system more than three years ago. And work on the first 4.4 miles - M.O.S. 1, or minimum operable segment - proceeds on schedule; Angelenos can anticipate underground travel beginning in the fall of 1993.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Murray of Skillman, N.J., and Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kelly Ann Murray to Michael Upjohn Kole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Kole of Clifton, Va. A June 1991 wedding is planned.

LEAD: The revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe are now tearing at North Korea's foreign policy, leading some diplomats to worry that the unpredictable North Korean leadership may react in dangerous ways.

LEAD: As if he hasn't had enough problems lately, Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State basketball coach, has a new potential scandal on his hands. The News and Observer of Raleigh reported that North Carolina State officials were investigating a report that Charles Shackleford, a former Wolfpack star who now plays for the Nets, accepted an illicit payment of $65,000 during the 1987-88 college season.

In a broader sense it is ascribed to anyone who appreciates good living and delights in gastronomic pleasures. LEAD: More than 500 Penn State University students spent 48 hours in a campus gym last weekend dancing for charity, and walked away with sore feet on Sunday night after raising $671,572 for children with cancer. Of the 536 students who began the 1990 Penn State Dance marathon, 511 finished it.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Six Torahs have been stolen this month from synagogues in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, and the authorities say they suspect that there is a ring specializing in religious objects.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
LEAD: I still can't believe Mike Tyson was knocked down by an unknown journeyman fighter from Columbus, Ohio. Was that Iron Mike there in the ring getting punched silly by this upstart?

LEAD: ''When my purpose tends to men, I always see burdened wretches, I have only the feeling of ridiculous objects. Never [so] in front of women, where I always find a way to isolate a few elements that satisfy the painter in me.'' So wrote Edouard Vuillard (1868-1940), a Parisian painter who never married, stayed home with maman and his sister and painted them repeatedly at their daily work as seamstresses.

LEAD: Seventeen years after it was launched and more than a decade after it became the first spacecraft to visit Saturn, Pioneer 11 flew beyond Neptune's orbit and out of the solar system Friday, the space agency and the company that built the probe reported.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: GETTING fired is an awful experience, way up there with other big losses. Even in this era of massive layoffs, being shown the door is humiliating. When it happened to me in 1987, I took it very personally. Over and over, I asked myself: what could I have done differently?

LEAD: The man who took television to new lows has reached one himself. Morton Downey Jr., whose syndicated Morton Downey Jr. Show was generally considered the prototype of ''shock television,'' filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition in Federal Court in New Jersey last week. Mr. Downey listed assets of more than $6.8 million and liabilities of about $2.4 million, but he apparently is having cash-flow problems.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet season was fairly unexciting, a phenomenon that would have once been gratefully regarded as stability -by those concerned about the company's survival in its early days and immediately after the death in 1983 of its co-founder, George Balanchine.

Mr. Mandela made the impassioned appeal in his first speech in Natal province.

LEAD: If Editions Gallimard was offered a novel about a family firm caught up in bitter feuding over money, power and honor, France's most prestigious publisher would probably reject it as too lowbrow to merit publication.

LEAD: The draft of a House subcommittee report criticizes the Food and Drug Administration and the maker of a mechanical heart valve for allowing the device to remain on the market after reports of malfunctions.

LEAD: Fire swept through a house early today, killing five members of a family, the authorities said. The cause of the blaze in this northeastern Florida town of 1,000 was not immediately known, said Capt. Richard Schauland of the sheriff's department. Three adults and two children, 4 years old and 7, were killed, he said.

LEAD: Next year, the people of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico may have a chance to vote themselves into the Union as America's 51st state. I am firmly convinced that statehood is not in the best interest of Puerto Rico or the United States. I believe that the present commonwealth relationship should be continued and enhanced.

LEAD: When the political leaders of the United States and Japan agreed last summer to begin talks over how the most fundamental characteristics of their national economies might change, bureaucrats on both sides said the effort would create frustration and ill will.

LEAD: Charles University in Prague was founded in 1348, but its chorus, which includes students and alumni, was established 600 years later. On Wednesday evening, the Charles University Chorus sang a concert of music from Czechoslovakia at St. Jean Baptiste Church.
LEAD: A 48-year-old Queens woman died in a fire of suspicious origin that caused extensive damage to her home in Springfield Gardens last night, the police said.

LEAD: The Bush Administration and an increasingly impatient Congress are intensifying pressure on Japan to slash import barriers and work down the nearly $400 billion of surpluses that Japan enjoyed in its trade with the United States over the last decade.

LEAD: Reflecting the continued downturn in the automotive industry, orders for American-made machine tools slipped 4.2 percent in January from December's level, according to a monthly report to be released today.

LEAD: In the baseball club owners' most recent proposals in their labor dispute with the players, they have included a somewhat unusual element. ''Sign off on memorandum of understanding so as to permit immediate contract production,'' article IX of their Feb. 21 proposal says.
LEAD: New York City's new Consumer Affairs Commissioner said yesterday that he was beginning a crackdown on unlicensed home-improvement contractors.

LEAD: Jazz repertory met mass transit when the MUNY - for Music Under New York - Big Band played Cal Massey's ''Liberation Suite'' on Friday afternoon in the main concourse of Grand Central Terminal. The 10-piece group was led by the tenor saxophonist Zane Massey, the late Cal Massey's son, 18 years and a day after the piece had its premiere in Brooklyn.
LEAD: A company called Pepsi Foods made its debut in India last week, selling cumin-flavored potato chips and an Indian version of Cheetos seasoned with fenugreek.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A soccer-tournament emblem depicting two horses that symbolize an old military setback for Saudi Arabia has caused a long-simmering feud between Saudis and Kuwaitis to explode.

LEAD: In the blackest hours before dawn, long before a morning downpour let up, Maria left her small wooden shack on the slopes of the mountains that ring this hamlet and began walking here to vote for the first time in her life.

LEAD: The republic of Lithuania received a rousing push toward independence today as the Soviet Communist Party, put to the test in the Soviet Union's first free multiparty election in seven decades, was overwhelmingly rebuffed by voters.

LEAD: David Goldfarb, the Soviet Jewish geneticist who in 1986 won a seven-year battle to emigrate, died of heart failure Saturday at Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox outfielder who had struggled to overcome a beaning that interrupted his career, died of kidney failure Saturday afternoon. He was 45 years old.
LEAD: Taxpayers save $4.40 for every public dollar spent to provide birth control to women who might otherwise not have access to contraceptives, a new study has found.
LEAD: State officials who want to inspect the site of a proposed nuclear-waste storage area here must first sneak by Margie Schlegel.

LEAD: ''Contra Pose'' is a remarkable new ballet by Eliot Feld, a contradictory outpouring of emotion and mathematical precision; it is splendidly performed by 18 dancers with a suitable mix of stamina and exactitude. Despite its name, ''Contra Pose'' is not about Nicaragua.

LEAD: With ''Burner's Frolic,'' the fourth in Charles Fuller's continuing cycle of plays about black Americans in the second half of the 19th century, one has a clearer picture of the playwright's ambitious intention. Through a series of episodes, seemingly tangential in the sweep of American history, the playwright is scrutinizing the economic entrapment of people forced to weigh their pragmatic needs against their desire for complete emancipation and integration.

LEAD: The rapid move toward the unification of the two Germanys is pushing the West German Government and the country's renowned central bank, the Bundesbank, to the center of the world's economic stage alongside the United States and Japan.
LEAD: Technicians at the Kennedy Space Center resolved the computer and engine problems that earlier today halted the flight of the space shuttle Atlantis seconds before it was to be launched.

LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Bank, believing that institutional investors are taking a global approach, has combined its domestic pension trust and global custody business and put Marshall N. Carter in charge.
LEAD: Phil Henderson's second-half scoring binge and key defensive play helped third-ranked Duke overcome No. 21 Arizona's inside strength and led the Blue Devils to a 78-76 victory today.

LEAD: Vincent Teresa, a colorful, obese New England crime figure of the 1950's and 60's who became a Federal informer and later was a co-author of two books about his underworld experiences, died of kidney failure Wednesday in Seattle, The Associated Press reported. He was 61 years old.

LEAD: A caravan of about 1,000 cars, many bearing Colombian flags and cardboard placards, drove through Kennedy International Airport yesterday to protest the January crash of Avianca Flight 52. Many said the crash of the flight from Medellin was a result of discrimination against Colombians.

LEAD: Efforts by President F. W. de Klerk have failed to still the controversy over allegations that death squads under military control have been killing opponents of apartheid. The continuing disclosures in South African newspapers appear to pose a growing embarrassment to Mr. de Klerk as he seeks a new political arrangement between whites and blacks.

LEAD: Barre L. Rorabaugh, who last worked for a health and fitness company, has been named president and chief executive of Everest & Jennings International Ltd., the nation's leading maker of wheelchairs.
LEAD: Jesse Jackson has told supporters he will not run for mayor here, associates say.

LEAD: He wrestles with a recalcitrant bureaucracy and a vast production system on the verge of collapse. Strapped for cash, he gambles that the promise of openness and restructuring will spark reform. But politicians in the outlying states of his empire are urging him to pull his people out and go home, and the half-patched new system seems to break down even more often than the old.

LEAD: When big bands lose their leaders but continue to work, they are usually labeled ghost bands by musicians. It is an apt title; the bands often become ephemeral and fade away. Based on a set the Mel Lewis Orchestra played at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night, it's obvious that the band - which will keep working every Monday night at the club (Seventh Avenue South at 11th Street) - is in no danger of fading away.

LEAD: Johnnie Ray, a singer whose emotionally uninhibited hit recordings in the early 1950's anticipated the rock-and-roll era, died of liver failure on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 63 years old.

LEAD: As this year's statewide election campaign in New York begins behind the scenes, Gov. Mario M. LEAD: A Democratic candidate for governor has apologized for trying to make a campaign issue out of a murder case in which the defendant is black.
LEAD: The widespread use of wool for winter clothing gave way in the last decade to new synthetic materials. But within the last year, a new generation of wool products has brought on a fresh look.

LEAD: Two people died and five were wounded today in another day of artillery and rocket duels in East Beirut as the Palestine Liberation Organization offered to mediate in the conflict between rival Christian forces, its past enemies.

LEAD: The Gashouse Gang Q. During the 1930's, the St. Louis Cardinals were referred to as The Gashouse Gang. How did they acquire the nickname? A. There is more than one version of where the term for the scrappy Cardinal teams of the mid-30's came from, but the common thread is that it originated in New York City sometime in 1934 and that it mirrored the ragtag crowd of thugs, rowdies and misfits from the Gashouse District on the East Side of Manhattan, the area around 14th Street in which large gas tanks were housed.

LEAD: There may be no surer test of the sturdiness of a vintage Broadway musical than to be subjected to the kind of spare revival that the American Jewish Theater has given to the 1970 Jerry Bock-Sheldon Harnick show, ''The Rothschilds.''
LEAD: * American Healthcare Management Inc., Dallas, which operates hospitals, appointed Robert M. Dubbs vice president, general counsel and secretary.
LEAD: Nathan Magill, a retired textile manufacturer, died of kidney failure on Saturday at Hackensack Medical Center in New Jersey. He would have celebrated his 90th birthday yesterday.

LEAD: The East German Social Democrats, who are expected to get the most votes in the elections to Parliament on March 18, ended their first congress today by choosing a candidate for Prime Minister and presenting a timetable without a deadline for German reunification.

LEAD: Lynn Nesbit, a literary agent, is selling Tom Wolfe's next book around the world. Publishers in Europe have paid well in excess of $1 million for it. Yet, Ms. Nesbit said: ''It's not a book yet. It's not even an outline. In fact it's hardly even an idea.''

LEAD: As environmental investigators pressed their search for the source of a mysterious illness afflicting toll officers on the Triborough Bridge, union officials complained yesterday about what they called management insensitivity to the health hazards of their jobs.

LEAD: The latest attempt to break the 26-year-old stalemate on Cyprus reaches a critical stage at talks opening here on Monday between the leaders of Greek- and Turkish-speaking Cypriots, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

LEAD: Jill Wender, the daughter of Mrs. Jerry Wender of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Mr. Wender, was married yesterday to Richard Spitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Spitz of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Efraim Wolf officiated at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.
LEAD: Divers recovered the body today of the last of seven people who were killed when members of a youth group and four people trying to rescue them fell through thin ice into a lake.

LEAD: Behind the seemingly sudden collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. were months of missteps and pressures from outside forces that were fully understood by the firm's executives only as Drexel was drawing its last breaths.
LEAD: Upward pressure on interest rates in Japan and West Germany is expected to continue to influence the domestic credit rate structure this week and in the near future.
LEAD: At a time when many publishing houses are complaining about declining revenues and even losses, W. W. Norton & Company is not only profitable, but also independent.

LEAD: Malcolm Forbes, chairman and editor in chief of Forbes Magazine and a flamboyant multimillionaire whose enthusiastic pursuits included yachting, motorcycling and ballooning, died Saturday of a heart attack in his sleep at his home in Far Hills, N.J. He was 70 years old.
LEAD: A performance by the Manhattan Marimba Quartet and the Women of the Calabash will open a New Riffs series at 8 P.M. on March 6 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

LEAD: A well-known pop singer has been thrown into jail, accused of having evaded more than $400,000 in taxes. LEAD: The public has got the idea that Congress is self-perpetuating, and a companion idea that limiting members' terms of service would set things right. Both ideas are wrong, and so is a proposed constitutional amendment to limit terms to 12 years.

LEAD: Gerald G. Conway, who was news director of WOR Radio when he retired in 1976 after 30 years with the station, died of leukemia on Thursday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 76 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: The Federal Census Bureau this year is delivering on a promise it made seven years ago: to give America a computerized map of itself, a gargantuan file of geographic data knitting together every street, stream and political boundary.

LEAD: The Jamaican-English poet Linton Kwesi Johnson knows the reggae beat intimately, as both inspiration and accompaniment.

LEAD: HOCKEY HARTFORD (NHL) - Recalled Al Tuer, defenseman, from Binghamton of the American Hockey League. Sent Terry Yake, center, to Binghamton.

LEAD: Young pro-independence militants are exercising increasing influence in the Vale of Kashmir, cutting the support for traditional pro-Indian groups and leaving mainstream politicians isolated and silent.

LEAD: At the street shrines where people died at Christmastime to overthrow the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu, heaped with evergreen boughs symbolizing eternal life and pale yellow votive candles, there are impromptu gatherings each day to argue politics.
LEAD: Nelson Mandela urged his followers today to bring an immediate halt to the factional warfare that has swept Natal's black townships and taken more than 2,500 lives in the last five years.

LEAD: Protesters shouting anti-Government and anti-United States slogans tried to stone an American diplomat's residence today in Kwangju and clashed with the police in four other cities, according to Korean news reports and witnesses.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late Friday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid at 7.68 percent, while the six-month issue was bid at 7.69 percent.

LEAD: Seventy people, including three rabbis, were arrested outside the Soviet Mission in Manhattan yesterday after they blocked traffic during a protest to urge direct flights to Israel from the Soviet Union.
LEAD: Peace is losing; freedom is winning.
LEAD: Michael Smith, who has averaged 3.6 points so far this season, scored 24 points and sparked a late rally as the Boston Celtics beat the Denver Nuggets, 115-107, today.

LEAD: Washington architecture aficionados were relieved when PRESIDENT BUSH reappointed J. CARTER BROWN to the Commission of Fine Arts, a panel that oversees preservation of the capital's plan and the historic district of Georgetown. Mr. Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art, will serve his fifth term on the panel.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Sarah Smith's father was an alcoholic who abused her verbally and physically. Her first husband did, too. Somehow, she hoped her second husband would be different. He was. He was worse.

LEAD: Under intense international scrutiny, this war-battered country voted today in the first free and broadly contested elections in its history. There were few reports of violence and strong signs of an overwhelming voter turnout.

LEAD: Declaring that ''sweeping, fundamental changes'' must be made in education, the nation's governors committed themselves today to work with the White House on a 10-year program of reforming primary and secondary schools.
LEAD: A senior lawyer at the State Department has been appointed general counsel to the Central Intelligence Agency.

LEAD: THE maker of the controversial Ping Eye2 iron has refused a proposal by the PGA Tour to allow a three-person panel of antitrust arbitrators to decide whether the tour can ban golf clubs with U-shaped grooves from its competitions. The refusal by Karsten Solheim, the president and founder of Karsten Manufacturing Corporation, emphasized the club maker's desire to take his lawsuit against the tour before a jury in Federal court.

LEAD: In the last year, GORDON PARKS has written a ballet, has won two awards, has had his 1969 film, ''The Learning Tree,'' selected for the National Film Registry of the Library of Congress and has a major retrospective of his photographs touring Europe. He is talking with the Soviets about making a movie there and is writing his 14th book.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Several Federal lawsuits have been filed against Perrier Group of America Inc., contending that the company knowingly sold bottled spring water that was contaminated with benzene.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Ending two days of talks, President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany declared today that there was no reason for anyone to fear the economic, political or military power of a united Germany.
LEAD: With 6.6 seconds remaining in overtime today, the ball slipped out of Purvis Short's hands, and a chance for victory slipped away from the Nets.

LEAD: The Government has decided not to try a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam charged with perjury in the Jamaica Tourist Board affair, the advertising agency said Friday. The case against Steven M. McKenna will be referred to the United States Pre-Trial Services Agency, Y.&R. said, and will be resolved under the Federal agency's pre-trial diversion program.

LEAD: HE is there every day, almost lost among the young players who file in and out of the Yankees' minor league complex at Tampa, Fla. Like everyone else, he does his work, dreams a little dream of pitching in the big leagues, then goes home. But it is different for Brit Burns. He has been there before.
LEAD: President Bush said today that if the Sandinistas win the Nicaraguan elections the United States will move to improve relations, provided that the elections are judged free and fair.

LEAD: The Bush Administration said Friday that it would not retaliate against the 12-nation European Community and South Korea over trade barriers imposed against United States telecommunications companies.

LEAD: A MOMENT came to mind of Maurice Cheeks on a basketball court nearly seven years ago. It wasn't in a game. It was after a practice session prior to the 1983 playoffs, the playoffs that his team then, the Philadelphia 76ers, would conclude as world champions.

LEAD: Now that he has publicly challenged himself to become the first player ever to win a regular PGA Tour event and a Senior event in the same year, Jack Nicklaus has spent the last month preparing his game with an intensity he hasn't shown in several years.
LEAD: A hospital here plans to close its doors to emergency cases, saying it was losing money treating poor victims of gang violence from Los Angeles.

LEAD: The Communist establishment suffered a double blow today as protesters across the country thronged the streets in a defiant call for a share of power while one republic, Lithuania, voted to end Communist rule.

LEAD: Beginning with its title, ABC's ''Daughter of the Streets,'' tonight at 9, has all the earmarks of standard prime-time exploitation, including plenty of sex, sudden eruptions of violence and a comforting finale. After 15 minutes, the vast majority of viewers could fill in the rest. This one, though, is better than most, primarily because it's loaded with estimable talent.

LEAD: An Eastern Air Lines ticket folder signed by MOTHER TERESA with the words ''God bless you'' added fetched $80 Saturday evening at an auction to benefit Miami-Dade Community College business students. LEAD: Missouri and Kansas have worn each other out playing tag with the No. 1 national ranking this season while their Big Eight rival Oklahoma, panned by some as a poor imitation of previous Sooner teams, has been the odd man out.
LEAD: There are many bad omens for the Democrats in President Bush's soaring approval ratings, but one of the most troublesome may be Mr. Bush's unusual popularity among blacks.
LEAD: The East German Social Democrats, favorites in the March 18 elections, presented a detailed plan for reunification as they ended their Congress.

LEAD: GOLF Couples Wins Los Angeles Open: Fred Couples lost the lead with his only bogey of the round on the ninth hole, then took charge with three birdies down the stretch to win the Los Angeles Open yesterday. Couples, winning for the first time since 1987, shot a final-round two-under-par 69 at Riviera Country Club, good for an 18-under-par 266 and a three-shot edge over Gil Morgan.(AP) United States Rallies to Win: Don Bies set the pace with a three-under-par 69 as the United States rallied from a slow start yesterday to win its third consecutive Chrysler Cup.

LEAD: Political horse sense dictates an obvious strategy for the Democrats in an election year: fall in behind Senator Pat Moynihan's proposal for a rollback in the Social Security payroll tax of more than $60 billion over two years.

LEAD: In a country-by-country report made public today, the Population Crisis Committee estimates that the world population can be stabilized in the 21st century only if countries make birth control universally available by 2000 at a cost of about $10.5 billion a year.
LEAD: Gov. James G. Martin has decided against seeking any elective office after his term ends in 1992, saying he wanted to preclude criticism that he was positioning himself for future campaigns.

LEAD: There is a lot of big talk in the sandstone halls of the State Capitol these days, and most of it is coming from the Democrats. Driven by the politics of reapportionment, they maintain that this will be the year they capture control of the State Senate for only the second time in the last half century.

LEAD: Given the new freedom of Soviet artists to indulge the soul's delight, the latest theater company here has decided to risk all by combining the separate agonies of Chekhov and Soviet free enterprise.

LEAD: Chanticleer's evening of a cappella music at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday seemed more than anything an act of mourning. All the component parts were constant in this otherwise far-flung program - sorrow, fear, resignation, hope. These 12 male singers from San Francisco began with a Gregorian setting of the medieval hymn ''Ave Maris Stella,'' went on to Josquin's ''Missa Ave Maris Stella'' and then to a young Gyorgy Ligeti's versions of Central European folk songs.

LEAD: The Forbes family said yesterday that Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., 42 years old, would assume his father's position as chief executive and editor in chief of Forbes magazine.

LEAD: A mixed jeer and cheer went up from the smoking section of United Airlines Flight 133 from Boston to Los Angeles Saturday night when a flight attendant announced that a new law would ban smoking on all domestic flights under six hours starting today. ''So tonight's it, smokers,'' she said.

LEAD: Despite the lifting of martial law in the capital last month, the Chinese authorities appear to have intensified their efforts to keep foreign journalists under surveillance and limit their unofficial contacts with Chinese, Beijing-based correspondents and some Chinese say.

LEAD: For more than a year, Hilary Foretich, the focus of a bitter custody battle in Washington, D.C., lived with her mother's parents here in a few cramped motel rooms, revealing her identity only to the family doctor.

LEAD: Former President Sandro Pertini, whose open manner and common touch made him one of Italy's most beloved leaders, died in his sleep Saturday night at his apartment by the Trevi Fountain. LEAD: NOW in its 13th year, the World Fishing and Outdoor Exposition, at Rockland Community College in Suffern, N.Y., has become, for many winter-weary anglers, an eagerly awaited harbinger of spring nearly as salubrious to the spirit as the April 1 opening of the trout season.

LEAD: SEVERAL times a week, I walk out the kitchen door, snap on my cross-country skis, and take off over an overgrown pasture to the edge of our property. A glorious system of trails awaits. These trails snake through the trees, cross frozen brooks and streams, climb steep hills and arc boldly through open fields.

LEAD: CALL it a safety-minded humanitarian gesture or a clever marketing ploy, but a leading manufacturer has stopped producing traditional baseballs for the youth market, issued a recall for those in circulation and called for other manufacturers to follow suit. LEAD: EXERCISE routines at home have come a long way since the early radio days when young listeners were urged to march around the breakfast table. Adults are marching now, but the voices they hear come from the well-toned bodies they see on television or videotapes.
LEAD: A Federal Court of Appeals today upheld the conviction of a demonstrator who burned an American flag, but the court did not rule on the constitutionality of a new law outlawing flag burning.

LEAD: The Annual Dancers' Emergency Fund Benefit at the New York City Ballet on Sunday night had the same packed house and intense atmosphere observed in recent seasons. Now in its sixth year, this special program has become a major, if curious, event, one of the most eagerly awaited in the entire dance season.

LEAD: At the end of ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' three young people of 1957, all with dreams of theatrical or literary glory, stand on a roof in New York City to spot Sputnik, a symbol of their high hopes, as it streaks across a starry sky. Nine years after its failure on Broadway, ''Merrily'' continues to follow its own alluring, elusive trajectory through the musical theater.

LEAD: AT least a dozen major insurers and health-care chains are bidding to provide the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with an innovative insurance program that will be the nation's largest experiment in managed health care. LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil and gas continued to decline last week, falling by 21, to 897, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. Mr. Kerridge said the rig count generally declines in the first quarter and is expected to bottom out in March or April.

LEAD: When Sandinista leaders discovered on Sunday evening that they were losing their country's first free and broadly contested national elections, they made no attempt to keep power or dispute the results, former President Jimmy Carter said today.

LEAD: The New Jersey Supreme Court examined today the range of penalties in the state's drunken-driving statutes to determine if they are serious enough to entitle defendants to jury trials.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Advocates of children's television are poised to open an offensive in Congress next month against the network deregulation put in place by President Reagan. They hope to reverse a trend - the shrinking time given to children's programs and the growing time given to commercials beamed at children. After a decade of defeat, they are optimistic about their chances of victory.
LEAD: The Audi Southern Ocean Racing Conference, the annual yacht-racing series in Florida, stands to be revitalized this winter by the return of the prestigious 50-Foot Class.
LEAD: He began as a bad guy, but RICHARD WIDMARK was a Hollywood hero when he received the D. W. Griffith Career Achievement Award for his 40 years in films.
LEAD: The founder of the Crazy Eddie Inc. electronics chain failed to appear today before a Federal judge to answer demands that he return $52 million to the United States.
LEAD: Benjamin F. Schwartz, a prosecutor with the Navy, died of heart failure on Sunday. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: A fledgling science that creates software whose behavior mimics that of living creatures is beginning to provide scientists with a new class of software tools with significant commercial potential.
LEAD: Israel and Poland resumed full diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break. Poland was the third Warsaw Pact country to renew relations with Israel in the last six months.

LEAD: The French Government announced today that it would subsidize the cost of using a pill that induces abortion, known as RU 486, after 34,000 abortions were carried out free of charge with the method in the last 21 months.

LEAD: The Honda Motor Company plans to export a United States-made Accord station wagon to Europe, Honda's chief executive, Tadashi Kume, said. Honda will begin making the Accord wagon at its assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, later this year for the 1991 model year. Honda's Marysville plant now makes the Civic and Accord models.

LEAD: It has been five months since Hurricane Hugo tore into this hilly enclave of 8,000 people off Puerto Rico's northeast coast, but the physical and psychic scars of the ordeal are still painfully apparent.
LEAD: Danny Hurley's burden lines two walls of the Jersey City National Guard Armory.

LEAD: President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras insisted yesterday that the victory of the opposition in Nicaragua's election Sunday means that Nicaraguan rebels based in his country must leave as soon as possible.

LEAD: State education officials hastily decided today to scrap outdated questions about Eastern Europe on a sixth-grade social studies test instead of asking pupils, as test administrators had planned, to pretend that the cold war was still being waged.

LEAD: Major league baseball's stodgy owners are advised to note what's happening in minor-league Birmingham, Ala. The Japanese are coming. Suntory International, the American subsidiary of the largest privately owned company in Japan, is buying the Birmingham Barons, the hottest team in the Southern League.

LEAD: Following his recent rebuke by the House Ethics Committee for making sexual advances to a Peace Corps worker, Representative Gus Savage, an Illinois Democrat, took to the House floor to denounce his three colleagues who had pressed the ethics charges. He said that one, Barney Frank of Massachusetts, ''has admitted keeping and prostituting a homosexual.

LEAD: Despite a choppy stock market in February, investors resumed their purchases of stock mutual funds at a rapid rate, fund managers said yesterday. Investors had moved out of such funds in January for the first time in seven months.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: FOOD manufacturers seem to have a penchant for taking nutritious foods and processing them to the point where they are no longer wholesome. Potatoes are a good example. In its purest form, a medium 5-ounce potato provides only 155 calories and is virtually free of fat and sodium. Potatoes are also good sources of complex carbohydrates, fiber and vitamin B6, and excellent sources of vitamin

LEAD: How much of Dmitri Shostakovich resides in ''Rothschild's Violin'' is something we shall never really know or perhaps need to. The one-act opera after Chekhov's story was left incomplete by Shostakovich's pupil Benjamin Fleischmann before he marched off to die in defense of Leningrad during 1941. The Juilliard Opera Center made ''Rothschild's Violin'' part of its double bill at the school on Friday night, joining it with Kurt Weill's hybrid stage work of 1933, ''The Seven Deadly Sins.
LEAD: * Autodesk Inc., Sausalito, Calif., a design software company, named Carolyn Aver chief financial officer. She replaces Donald W. Lohin, who is leaving the company.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 President-elect Violeta Chamorro has begun preliminary talks with the defeated Sandinista Government on the first democratic transfer of power in Nicaraguan history. The talks were called positive. Page A1

LEAD: In an unprecedented move, an American university and a South African university are starting a joint program aimed at training black, Indian and mixed-race South Africans for business management posts in the racially divided nation.

LEAD: A long-secret document outlining concessions that the two main Protestant parties in Northern Ireland are willing to make to break a political impasse in the British province was disclosed today in an Irish newspaper.
LEAD: The United States trade deficit increased slightly in the fourth quarter of 1989 but narrowed to $113.2 billion for all of last year, its lowest level since 1984, the Government reported today.

LEAD: The United Brands Company announced it would change its name to Chiquita Brands International Inc., effective March 20. The change is intended to increase the Cincinnati-based company's recognition, but will not alter its business strategy, said Keith E. Lindner, president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: A memorial service for Drew Middleton, former foreign correspondent and military correspondent of The New York Times, will be held on Tuesday at 11 A.M. at the Century Club, at 7 West 43d Street. Speakers will include Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Clifton Daniel and John Chancellor. Mr. Middleton died at his Manhattan apartment on Jan.

LEAD: Under fierce prodding from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Supreme Soviet gave initial approval today to his proposal to secure greater executive powers through the institution of a popularly elected presidency.

LEAD: A group of Roman Catholics from Chicago is seeking 100,000 signatures on an appeal for major changes in the Catholic Church. They would include the ordination of women and married people to the priesthood, widespread consultation with believers in developing church teaching about sexuality and the participation of priests and lay people in the selection of bishops.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An article in Science Times on Feb. 20 about a new class of materials that respond to light by rearranging the electric charges in their microscopic structures misstated an affiliation of Dr. Jack Feinberg. He is at the University of Southern California.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Anchorage today indicted the Exxon Corporation and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts stemming from the Alaskan oil spill, after negotiations between the Justice Department and the company on a settlement of the case broke down. .
LEAD: ALONG with requests for water or more rolls, patrons at the lobby restaurant in the Hyatt Orlando hotel here often ask for something more: a rabbi.

LEAD: The city fathers of Pasadena, Calif., sent up their police helicopter last Thursday night. Its task was to ticket some helicopters engaged by the state to spray the dreaded Mediterranean fruit fly. The bust was observed, of course, by a fleet of television helicopters. It's hard not to wonder if the fight between the fly and its foes hasn't lost touch with the ground.

LEAD: ''Other Dances,'' presented by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, is Jerome Robbins at his most sophisticated. An extended pas de deux set to Chopin piano pieces, the ballet has the music's teasing folk accents but is essentially a dance of stylized abandon and cool passion, founded in the classical ballet technique, for two playful and dreaming lovers.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a rise of almost 9.2 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-February.

LEAD: For their "courageous and selfless actions during the Armenian earthquake relief effort," the Soviet Ambassador, YURIY V. DUBININ, gave his nation's Personal Courage award yesterday to some of the Americans who helped during the Armenian earthquake in 1988

LEAD: At the National Governors' Association dinner here on Monday, the Rev. Jesse Jackson worked the crowd and chatted with other guests about his decision not to run for mayor of Washington. He talked about concentrating on winning statehood for the District of Columbia and improving the moral tenor of the scarred capital.

LEAD: Several electronics companies are discussing the formation of a venture to develop and produce display screens for use in laptop computers, military gear and television sets, an official involved in the venture said today.

LEAD: After five postponements over is scheduled tomorrow in Los Angeles to consider testimony against Chuck DeBus, a track coach who has been accused by several athletes of advocating and managing their use of performance-enhancing drugs.
LEAD: Raging seas, whipped up by a storm that has killed 51 people in Europe, surged through a shattered sea wall and swamped homes in this coastal village today.

LEAD: Folklore and music and the classical ballet might seem to be odd artistic partners. The program, called ''Folksteps,'' consisted of works set to scores drawn from folk music.

LEAD: MIDWINTER rain fell in a contemplative pitter-patter on the stucco hacienda tucked in the hills. A calico cat sat rigid as a sphinx on the back stoop of the ranch, glaring at the heavy wooden door. But a guest standing inside saw only miles of vineyards, parched from a dry season, turning their pruned tips toward the sky.

LEAD: The Atlantic storm that has killed at least 53 people in northern Europe has reached the Mediterranean, turning small blazes on this island into major brush fires. In Nancy, in eastern France, a motorist died when he was blown off an icy road late Tuesday. Fifty-three deaths have been reported since the storm struck Monday: 17 in Britain, 12 in West Germany, 3 in East Germany, 11 in France, 5 in Belgium, 2 in Switzerland and 1 each in Ireland, Italy and the Netherlands.

LEAD: Beginning this weekend, three New York City institutions pay homage to Prague, the Czechoslovak capital that during the first half of this century turns out to have been no less an incubator of modern art than Paris or Moscow or Vienna. Whether it was testing out the waters of new technologies, like film, or giving a distinctively Czechoslovak twist to movements in painting, photography and sculpture like Cubism and Surrealism, Prague turns out to have been a city where modernism was embraced with a remarkable combination of passion and panache.

LEAD: Her coach, Don MacLeod, describes Vicky Sunohara as the Wayne Gretzky of women's hockey. And who's to doubt him?

LEAD: Peter Planyavsky took time from his vast musical responsibilities as cathedral organist at St. Stephen's in his native city of Vienna to play a recital at Holy Trinity Church on Sunday afternoon. At the age of 43, Mr. Planyavsky finds himself overseeing a network of performances in Vienna that numbers over a thousand a year.

LEAD: In his first public comments since his Government's election defeat on Sunday, the hard-line Sandinista who heads Nicaragua's large security apparatus and secret police has indicated that he will be willing to step down when the opposition takes power on April 25.

LEAD: Despite increases in the level of new orders and exports, the manufacturing sector of the nation's economy remained in decline in February for the 10th consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday. But the decline was at a slower rate than in previous months.

LEAD: Even hardened followers of the nightly news may be shaken by ''Madness in Mozambique,'' which takes up most of tonight's edition of ''20/20.'' Tom Jarriel's report, at 10 P.M. on ABC, focuses on the youngest victims of a brutal, decadelong civil war in the poorest of the African states. It tells of boys as young as 8 years old turned into killers, of 10-year-old girls raped repeatedly, of children forced to witness or even participate in the murder of their parents.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 499 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.9 billion, to $388.79 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 153 institutional funds fell by $1.15 billion, to $91.54 billion. The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds dropped by $151.5 million, to $132.40 billion.

LEAD: Nautilus Sports-Medical Industries Inc., which makes Nautilus exercise equipment, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. In documents filed in Roanoke, Va., the company listed $38.6 million in liabilities and $27.3 million in assets. The company was moved here in 1987 after it was purchased by Ward International Corp., owned by Dallas investor Travis Ward.

LEAD: Norman Blackburn, a writer and producer who worked in film, radio and television and whose movie credits included the Marx Brothers' ''Day at the Races'' and the ''Our Gang'' comedies, died on Feb. 21 after complications from hip surgery. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: A laser scientist aims an icy-blue beam at his assistant, who accidentally explodes. As if that didn't make life difficult enough, the laser man -a Chinese-American named Arthur Weiss - also has to contend with a Jewish mother convinced she has a Chinese soul, a hoodlum brother-in-law involved with a prostitute, a girlfriend who would rather meditate and describe his previous incarnations than have sex, and a Shanghai-born police detective who sums up the lethal experiment with this version of Confucian wisdom: ''Too much education can be hazardous to your health.
LEAD: Dave Brazil, a veteran assistant coach, was promoted to defensive coordinator yesterday by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Washington-based MCI's complaint involves changes in a contract to redesign and provide voice, data and video telecommunications networks, a project that could total $25 billion over 10 years.

LEAD: The remaining senior editor at Pantheon Books resigned yesterday, following the departures of the four other senior editors in protest over the removal of Andre Schiffrin as managing director.

LEAD: The National Football League yesterday added two wild-card teams to its playoff format and in the process helped swell television revenue to an expected $30 million a team each year, an increase of $13 million a team.
LEAD: ADVERTISING creative people may leave their hearts in San Francisco, but many seem to be taking their resumes and portfolios out of town.
LEAD: Fabia Drake, an actress whose career spanned 77 years with credits from the Shakespearean stage to television mini-series, died on Wednesday at her home. She was 86 years old.

LEAD: A suspect in a street fight was shot in the mouth by the police last night when he pulled a knife on two officers who had chased and cornered him on the roof of a building at 515 West 169th Street in Harlem, the police said. The suspect, who was not identified, was said to be between 25 and 30 years old.

LEAD: Many people were outraged that Michael Moore's documentary, ''Roger & Me,'' was shut out in the Academy Award nominations. I can't understand why. The film mocks American culture brilliantly, but forfeits any claim to distinction by manipulating its audience to believe that General Motors abandoned Flint, Mich., in the pursuit of profits.

LEAD: Eliot Feld has tried something different from his recent choreography in ''Mother Nature,'' a little faux-naif allegory that had its premiere Wednesday night at a gala benefit for the Feld Ballets NY.

LEAD: Some celebrations are hard won. Not long ago the National Orchestral Association had cause to wonder whether it would even reach its 60th anniversary this year, let alone feel like celebrating. Founded in 1930 to offer advanced training to aspiring orchestral musicians, the association determined a few years ago that, with music schools increasingly providing this training themselves, it had to some extent outlived its usefulness and needed to redirect its resources if it hoped to continue making a genuine contribution to American musical life.
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had reached a new labor agreement with the union representing 2,100 hourly workers at its plant in Hermosillo, Mexico.

LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, the first Government regulator called before Congress to discuss the bankruptcy of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, said today that the authorities would almost certainly refuse to rescue even the largest securities firms from the brink of collapse.

LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Spanish Government signed an agreement to invest $1 billion in the next 12 years to build a high-technology industrial complex in the northern region of Asturias. Spain has agreed to put up $300 million for the complex, which is to employ 1,000 people in the hard-pressed region by 2001.

''I understand your pain,'' the gray-haired psychiatrist called Granny Ruth says in a kind and comforting voice to the patient on her couch -the mutant severed half of a Siamese twin, a creature resembling a giant Mr. Potato Head with gangly arms and blue eyes. ''But ripping the faces off people may not be in your best interest,'' she croons. ''Basket Case 2'' continues the story of Belial, who was once a growth sticking out from under his normal-looking brother's arm and is now a violence-prone individual carried around by his twin in a wicker basket. As cheap horror spoofs go, this one isn't all bad. Granny Ruth, known to the world as Dr. Freak, has taken the twins into her menage of misfits, which includes a man with 27 noses, a creature with a frog's head, even a woman with the figure of a tree stump who turns out to be a perfect match for Belial. These creatures actually look cheery, not fearsome.
