Nearly every dress, shirt, pair of shorts and pants is meant to look, feel and act like fun, designed with play in mind. For girls, dress silhouettes are simple and pretty, not fussy, with empire or basque waistlines.

LEAD: Evelyn F. Abelson of Greenwich, Conn., has announced April wedding plans for her daughter Joanne Sue Abelson and Christopher Andrew Goelz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Goelz of Half Moon Bay, Calif. The prospective bride also is a daughter of the late Lawrence Abelson.
LEAD: An answer in the Q & A column on Feb. 18 misstated the dates of Ash Wednesday this year and next. It fell last week, on Feb. 28, and in 1991 will be on Feb. 13.
LEAD: Time for reader-speak.

LEAD: When she was a stockbroker, Eve J. Alfille used paper clips to bring her jewelry designs to life. The first pins she created in 1972 were made of something equally functional: transformer parts.

LEAD: ENVIRONMENTALISTS and county officials have often been at odds. At the moment they agree on one thing: the county's quality of life is increasingly at risk, and no one is minding the environmental store.
LEAD: For five days last month, Tenzin Gyatso, a Buddhist monk who is the Dalai Lama of Tibet, was the guest of Vaclav Havel, a playwright who is the President of Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: John F. Burns is undoubtedly correct in maintaining that United States policy has been affected adversely by the standards of reporting in the Afghan conflict (''Afghans: Now They Blame America,'' Feb. 4). But it is hardly because of ''selective reporting'' by journalists in the field. It is, rather, the dismal failure on the part of the

LEAD: Ann Frances Hunt, a daughter of Mrs. William E. Hunt of Albany and the late Mr. Hunt, and Dennis Patrick Leddy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo P. Leddy of Spring Lake, N.J., plan to marry in April. Miss Hunt is a graduate of McGill University; Mr. Leddy of Ursinus College. Both are institutional sales traders at securities brokerage houses in New York, she at Muriel Siebert & Company and he at Morgan Stanley & Company.

LEAD: IN 1922 a botanist named Godfrey Sykes happened upon a bizarre- looking tree in the Sonoran desert, which stretches from Baja California nearly to the eastern border of Arizona. It resembled a 30-foot-tall upside-down green carrot with tiny, tiny branches. ''Ho, ho, a boojum,'' Mr. Sykes said when he saw the unusual plant.

LEAD: FIRE & ICE The Greenhouse Effect, Ozone Depletion, and Nuclear Winter. By David E. Fisher. 232 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95. THE NEXT ONE HUNDRED YEARS Shaping the Fate of Our Living Earth. By Jonathan Weiner. 312 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.
LEAD: PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS By Vladimir Pozner. 324 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $19.95.

LEAD: About 300 demonstrators, led by the Rev. Al Sharpton and several other black leaders, marched through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday to protest the prosecution's handling of the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins last summer.

LEAD: Kathy Shaskan's article, ''Postpartum Syndrome: A Patient's View'' (Opinion page, Feb. 11), rang a discordant bell with me. In the 1940's, I had four babies in seven years and was quite familiar with the subsequent depression of which the article speaks.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Indira Desai and Patrick Ian Christie were married yesterday at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Robert Hundley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Krishna Desai of Sarasota, Fla. The bridegroom is a son of George Christie of Orleans, Mass., and Pat Goodwin of Middlebury,

LEAD: Paul Azinger went from the spectacular to the unsteady, while Fred Couples kept a steady level of phlegmatic proficiency as the two young stars remained tied for the lead going into the final round of the Doral Ryder Open.

LEAD: Traveling the 120 miles from London to Devon in March is to make the leap from winter to spring. Thanks to the warm waters of the Gulf Stream, England's southwest peninsula begins to bloom weeks before the rest of the country has emerged from gray dampness and night frosts. Wherever you go in Devon, the ocean is not far away, and its influence makes winter a gentle affair with minimal frost, sea mists and lots of rain.

LEAD: Soon after the London opening of ''Le Train Bleu'' during the 1924 season of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, a writer in one of the glossy weeklies complained, ''It is as difficult to get a seat for 'The Blue Train' as it is to get a seat for the thing itself during the height of the Riviera rush.

LEAD: A HUMBLE gourd can assume many guises in Africa. Calabashes, hard-skinned members of the squash family, have been transformed into fearsome masks, musical instruments and ceremonial vessels in many parts of the continent.

LEAD: The White City, as this ancient urban center has been named for most of its existence, looks a bit grayer to visitors returning after a few years, a result, residents say, of neglect and a decade of economic crisis.

LEAD: Plausibly, 1990 can be the year in which America cleans up the way it pays for politics - if two adversaries can be conquered in coming days. The first is Republicans inside the Senate who seem determined, once again, to torpedo all serious reform. The other is Democrats outside the Senate who seem determined to kill the one reform that would do the most good.

LEAD: Rutgers University administrators have backed away from several aspects of a policy affecting fraternity pledging at predominantly black fraternities and sororities. But the most controversial dispute is yet to be resolved.

LEAD: Packages of lavosh are appearing in more and more stores. Lavosh is not the crispy cracker-like bread that has become so popular, but the soft variety that comes folded in half and then tucked in on both sides. There are two sheets to a package.

LEAD: Rod Strickland for Mo Cheeks is more than simple arithmetic. It is an equation that takes into account stability, chemistry, leadership and unselfishness - all the things that Cheeks has in abundance and the Knicks need. Al Bianchi made the right move. The Knicks are not a player away from title contention.

LEAD: IT was a reporter's curiosity that brought me to the site. I wanted to see what it was like after the fact, when the confusion had ceased and the cries of pain were etched forever in the deep recesses of suppressed memories.

LEAD: SEARCHING for inspiration does not take them to old photographs by Cecil Beaton or exquisitely poised models in fashion magazines. When children contemplate a new haircut, they flip on ''Yo! MTV Raps,'' the music video show on cable television. There, they see the Fade, the Slope, the Gumby, the Fence, the Bowl, the Spike - haircuts with sharp, strong style worn by singers named Def Jef, Bobby Brown, Queen Latifah and the New Kids on the

LEAD: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off. I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals. I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss.

LEAD: This recent trade is just another in a continued series of bad moves - Gerald Henderson, Jawann Oldham, Kiki Vandeweghe, the loss of Sidney Green, the waiving of Pete Myers - by people who haven't the vision, talent or patience for building a championship team. The only reason this team is competitive is Patrick Ewing.

LEAD: A listing of travel arrangements and hotel rates for Trinidad on Feb. 11 with an article about carnival misstated the availability of flights from New York to the island's capital, Port of Spain. There is indeed direct service - with stops but without a change of aircraft - on BWIA and Pan Am.

LEAD: In choosing a tour guide to crime and corruption in New Orleans, you want to know where the authors will send you for a good time. Julie Smith will stroll you through the Garden District, in NEW ORLEANS MOURNING (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $17.95), and treat you to a muffuletta at the Napoleon House.

LEAD: The Army's standard combat weapon, the M-16, in use since the Vietnam War, is still considered the finest extant assault rifle. Nonetheless, since 1982, when six weapons manufacturers were asked to develop new technologies, the Army has been seeking to improve on it. Four companies have produced prototypes - including the Steyr-Mannlicher from Austria (above) - that are now being tested at Fort Benning, Ga., and at Aberdeen Proving Ground,

LEAD: At 2 A.M. today, Ilya I. Zaslavsky, political kingpin, was on the phone with his pollster. A last-minute survey of the Oktobr district of Moscow showed the tide running against the Communist establishment and in favor of Mr. Zaslavsky's slate in Sunday's local elections.

LEAD: The southern coast of Albania is sometimes referred to as the Ionian Riviera. In this case the term is not ambiguous. There are no high-rise developments here, no casinos, no jet airports or trailer parks. Polychrome limestone cliffs loom above the sparkling emerald water, grown with cedar, pine and myrtle.
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Essey of San Francisco have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Tina Beth Essey, and Trygve Mikkelsen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kjell Mikkelsen of Oslo.

LEAD: More than half of the states are battling serious budget problems as they approach the final months of the fiscal year, and eight Eastern states are striving to avoid deficits that could disrupt statewide and local programs.

LEAD: In fairy tales, love songs and most Hollywood movies, any boy-meets- girl story takes the long way around to proving the predictable; the neat trajectory of conventional romance always shows that Cinderella and the Prince, tomato and tomahto, Tracy and Hepburn were right for each other all along. But in real life, who hasn't been an idiot in love, defying the odds to find the wrong person at the least convenient time to create an emotional mess?
LEAD: Dog Barking at Milton

LEAD: Mathias B. Freese has penned an eloquent plea for a grade school Kulturkampf in ''Teachers Have No Chance to Give Their Best'' (Long Island Opinion, Jan. 21), and one which I heartily endorse. I was one of Mr. Freese's advanced 10th-grade English students five years ago, and I consider myself an antecedent to what he cites as a ''general diminishment in students'' over time.

LEAD: I am pleased that Walter McCarthy brought up the topic of social skills for the retarded. Interestingly, it is an area that does receive a great deal of emphasis in schools and agencies, while being an area that the public does not hear much about.

LEAD: It was with great interest that I read ''What the Retarded Need: Social Skills.'' Yes, concern, imagination and time are desperately needed attributes for our developmentally disabled population. With these attributes, Theater for the Learning Disabled was established by three professional people for 15 adults.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: PASTA VIOLA, a newcomer in Stony Brook, sounds like yet another strutter in Long Island's never-ending parade of Italian restaurants. But take a second look; it is not the same old tarantella. There isn't a Bolognese, Alfredo or carbonara in sight. Insted, fasten your seatbelts for the likes of violet linguine, an amalgam of pasta, sauteed red cabbage, prosciutto and olive oil splashed with balsamic vinegar.

LEAD: An explosion in the basement of a house in Cresskill, N.J., where the authorities found weapons and ammunition, killed an 83-year-old woman yesterday and injured her grandson and another family member.

LEAD: For This Week: Finish pruning grapes. Lime lawns. Indoors start seed of vegetables and annuals that will be planted outdoors in May when the weather settles. Save fireplace wood ashes for use in the garden. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS Pressure-Treated Lumber
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: To the Editor If your section had less concern for corporations and more for their stockholders, ''Butlers and Crystal as Well as a View'' (Feb. 4) would have appeared on page 1 of The Times, and not on page 29 of your section. More important, the story would not have been about the ''bosses' '' uniformed butlers, crystal decanters, peeled oranges, Acapulco retreats and other ''perks,'' but about their corruption.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A BRIDGE OF CHILDHOOD: Truman Capote's Southern Years. By Marianne M. Moates. (Holt, $19.95.) ''He was a kook,'' declares Marianne M. Moates in her prologue to ''A Bridge of Childhood.'' ''He was a squeaky-voiced homosexual who drank too much.'' A rather crotchety view, but typical of the unreverential squint taken at Truman Capote in this homespun reminiscence.

LEAD: THE Texan in the Stetson went by horse-drawn buggy and the grave matron from Japan by Arab steed, and, with many others, they rode in a gaggle to ancient Petra through the defile called the Sik.

LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and President Bush ended two days of talks today, and Mr. Kaifu said he had pledged to take serious action to ease trade tensions between the two countries. As part of that effort, Mr. Kaifu said he would try to improve the quality of life in Japan.

LEAD: There's Joan Collins's Spectacular. And let's not forget Elizabeth Taylor's Passion, Cher's Uninhibited, Undeniable by Billy Dee Williams, Only by Julio Iglesias and those named Paloma, Deneuve, Cassini and Misha, named for you know who. Now, in the upper reaches of Madison Avenue, you can have your very own fragrance created for you and you alone and identified not with your name but - how tony can you get?

LEAD: Having talked about inexpensive loudspeakers last week, it now seems fair to allot equal time to costly ones. It is also fair to point out at the start that such speakers aren't for average listeners. They are meant for passionate devotees of high-fidelity, unsparing in the effort to narrow the persistent gap between music (the real thing) and its electronic replica.
LEAD: LESTER D. MORAN, who left his job as vice president of Bloomingdale's Dallas store last year, put the tax laws to work for him to help get the cash flow needed to start his own company.

LEAD: With midterms approaching this week, 25 male and 12 female Swarthmore College undergraduates took a break from their books last Sunday to take part in the annual McCabe Mile - an 18-lap race amid the bookshelves in the McCabe Library basement.

LEAD: Commack $190,000 25 Daisy Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old split level; den, fireplace, sun porch, pool, deck; taxes $3,100. Mineola $255,000 198 Linden Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 65-year-old colonial; den, fireplace, attic, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IF ''King Lear'' is unplayable - oft times, it has been so declared - then what seems like a recent inundation of stage and screen Lears may have a common cause. That is to prove how Shakespeare's ''very foolish, fond old man'' who is ''every inch a king'' can be played any which way, and the play can happen anytime, anyplace or in limbo.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended Feb. 17 MANHATTAN Chelsea $800,000 110 West 15th Street 4-family, 5-story town house; dining room, 2 1/2 baths in primary duplex; 1 bath in others; 2 bedrooms, fireplace in each; 20- by 83-ft. lot; taxes $13,518 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia)

LEAD: To the Editor: I was surprised but happy to learn that trekkers have discovered Oyacachi (''Adventuring in the Cloud Forests of Ecuador,'' by Joan K. Peters, Travel, Nov. 5). As a Peace Corps volunteer, I walked to Oyacachi twice after the earthquake - which was in March 1987, rather than in 1985 as the article stated - to inspect their newly built potable water system.

LEAD: Carol Ann Walsh, an associate vice president of Prudential-Bache Securities in New York, and Louis Mead Treadwell 2d, the chairman of the Siberia-Alaska Trading Company in Anchorage, are planning a June wedding.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: NO two analysts agree on the percentages or the dollars. Nor do they agree on what defines an office building or what constitutes midtown Manhattan. They don't even agree on whether empty space is ''vacant'' or ''available,'' or whether it can be measured accurately in the first place.

LEAD: Will the dollar continue the small rally it started last week against the West German mark and other European currencies? The West German Bundesbank signaled its concern about the rally of almost three pfennigs by selling dollars in Frankfurt Friday. (See Friday closings for New York at right.) If it is really worried, it will do the same thing again this week.
LEAD: A review of ''Loving Letters From Ogden Nash'' on Feb. 11 referred erroneously to the poet's widow, Frances Leonard Nash, recipient of many of the letters. She remains alive, in Maryland.
LEAD: ON a small, colorful rug in the center of the classroom, 7-month-old Allison Stumper lay on her back, drinking juice from her bottle.

LEAD: I have for many years been fascinated by Romania, and in particular by Bucharest. It is a purely literary fascination. It began when I read Olivia Manning's ''Balkan Trilogy,'' from whose pages there rose a seedy glamour, a whiff of alluring decadence that was irresistible. Gradually it attained the status of a disreputable Mecca, something between Anthony Hope's Ruritania and Malcolm Bradbury's Slaka.

LEAD: Barcelona is a city that has been brushed aside by history - and has learned how to take advantage of that neglect. In the 13th century, Catalan culture flourished from Valencia to Nice; if events had taken a different turn, Barcelona might have become the natural center of a country about the size of Portugal.
LEAD: MOST people have never heard of the alternative minimum tax or they choose to ignore it.
LEAD: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW once noted that there are two tragedies in life: One is to lose your heart's desire, the other is to gain it.

LEAD: Se-tenants stand together. These are groups of different stamps, perforated and printed on one sheet. They are usually collected in blocks or strips without separating them. Hobbyists in the United States will be most familiar with the sheets of the 50 state flags (1976), the 50 state birds and flowers (1982) and the 50 stamps picturing wildlife (1987).
LEAD: Forget hot pants. Save the cutoffs for the beach. Shorts have taken on a soigne new image.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Restoration work on the Old Dutch Church in North Tarrytown, N.Y., which is immortalized in Washington Irving's ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,'' has started and will continue throughout the year. The first phase is a study of the repairs necessary in the wooden belfry and roof, parts of which have been damaged by dry rot and insects.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Deirdre Marie Catherine Sheehan and Douglass Alexander Ewald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Philip Ewald of Greenwich, Conn., have been made known by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Conrad P. Sheehan of Rye, N.Y.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: VOYAGES By Doris Buchanan Smith. 170 pp. New York: Viking. $11.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

LEAD: It's a bleak day in Manhattan as I'm writing this, and I can't help wondering why I'm here and not on some gorgeous tropical island. In fact, I wonder why I've never been on a gorgeous tropical island. My favorite Broadway number is still ''Bali Ha'i,'' from ''South Pacific,'' with its romantic longing for lush, waterlapped surroundings, and its seductive refrain, ''Come to me, come to me.
LEAD: A picture caption on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today misattributes a revival of ''The Sound of Music.'' It is being presented by the New York City Opera, not the City Center.

LEAD: To help as many as 1,000 of their employees buy affordable homes, four New Jersey companies have joined a state agency there to underwrite mortgages in what may be the first such program in the country. Dubbed HOPE, or Home Ownership for Performing Employees, the companies guarantee up to 20 percent of a home loan for selected employees, while the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency underwrites the entire amount.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore David Eisler of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Catherine Lea Eisler and Scott D. Ackerson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Dee Ackerson of Hilliard, Ohio.

LEAD: Perils to New York's Water New York has smoothly provided some of the country's finest water for decades. Facing growing pollution and shortages, the city hopes to tap the Hudson despite upstate objections. The Magazine, section 6. 16 G.I.'s Hurt in Panama A bombing at a downtown discotheque wounded 16 American servicemen and 11 Panamanians, the Southern Command said.

LEAD: Astapovo. It is a tiny railroad station in western Russia, unmarked in any atlas I have seen. There, in the stationmaster's humble little shack beside the tracks, a small iron bedstead was placed in the living room with, beside it, a bedside table with a lamp, a candle, matches and the sick man's notebook.
LEAD: The Balsa Ball Park
LEAD: BEATRIX POTTER'S LETTERS Edited by Judy Taylor. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: Frederick Warne/Viking. $29.95.

LEAD: I have fished for bonefish on the virgin flats of Christmas Island. I have stalked them in the shadows of the orchid-bedecked ruins of Mayan temples in the Yucatan. Biscayne Bay in Florida is not nearly so remote but is equally pretty, its waters the prettiest light blue I have ever seen. And the fish are really big.
LEAD: HENRY IN LOVE By Marian Thurm. 265 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: President Bush, describinghimself as a longtime supporter of the United Negro College Fund, used his best-known term for private charity in praising the gift of $50 million by Walter H. Annenberg to the consortium of private black colleges.
LEAD: In 1979 I saw an aerial photograph of the Mayan pyramid at Coba. The pyramid itself was invisible because trees and vines had grown over it. There was only a green hump in the green jungle.

LEAD: Princeton became the first team to qualify for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament by capturing its second consecutive Ivy League basketball title with a 73-47 victory over Columbia tonight.
LEAD: Matt Muehlbach had 29 points and the Arizona defense stifled Oregon State's Gary Payton as the Wildcats beat the Beavers, 87-60, today to gain a share of the regular-season Pacific-10 title.

LEAD: Though Elizabeth Swados had wanted to write a musical based on the story of Jonah as long ago as 1972 - ''because I was so keen on what the inside of a whale would sound like'' - it wasn't until she came across Robert Nathan's short, poetic 1925 novel, ''Jonah,'' that she saw how to do it. The novel, she said, ''made Jonah such a prophet for the 80's and 90's, so narcissistic, full of complaints, apathetic, unwilling to do anything for anyone because there wasn't enough in it for him.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Maps That Try to Hide Their Age'' (Practical Traveler, Jan. 14) represents hard work in your effort to assist the public in purchasing up-to-date maps. Concerning maps produced by General Drafting, however, we would like to amplify on the A20 code on our map of Baltimore mentioned in the colunn.

LEAD: April wedding plans have been announced for Joan Feigenbaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Feigenbaum of Valley Stream, L.I., and Jeffrey J. Nussbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Nussbaum of New Hyde Park, Queens, and West Palm Beach, Fla.

LEAD: Rosita Brailovsky, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Brailovsky of Westfield, N.J., was married there last evening at Temple Emanu-el to Dr. Steven Fine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Fine of Mountainside, N.J. Rabbi Marc Disick officiated. Mrs. Fine, 27 years old, graduated from Cornell University and received a master's degree in counseling psychology in January from Harvard University.
LEAD: THE 50 million Americans who will pay someone to prepare their income tax returns this year face an important choice: what kind of service to use.
LEAD: A Macintosh program that costs less than $100 may offer the least painful way to complete a 1989 tax return - short of getting someone else to do it.

LEAD: St. Mary's College has been offering higher education in lower Maryland for 150 years. For the last 19, it has also presented a series of spring and summer festivals covering poetry, drama, art and music.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. von Glahn of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Anne von Glahn to Eric Christian Hussar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hussar of Lancaster, Pa. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE divorce courts on Long Island are not spilling over with Donald and Ivana Trumps, but the highly publicized marital split will probably create more demand for prenuptial agreements, Long Island lawyers say.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''It's impossible to be all things to all people,'' said Eric S. McCready, speaking of his 15 years as a museum director, first at the Elvehjem Museum of Art of the University of Wisconsin, then at the Archer M. Huntington Art Gallery of the University of Texas at Austin. ''The demands generally by boards are so complex that very few people are capable or willing to meet them - to be a scholar, a fund raiser, a diplomat, an entertainer, an after-dinner speaker, a budget officer and a personnel officer - and all of that for the glory, for being able to say that you run a museum.

LEAD: Every weekday morning for the last five weeks Joseph J. Hazelwood has walked across the iced street from the Captain Cook Hotel to a small room in Alaska Superior Court where he has heard himself alternately described as a reckless mariner and a hero.

LEAD: ONCE she won an Oscar. Now her agent hangs up on her. Once she was the victim of the distortions of an unauthorized biographer who snooped around outside her beach house in Malibu. Now she has hired a live-in journalist to record her story - honestly.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Q. My house was built in 1926, and the original banisters and newel posts had many coats of paint on them that I stripped off. I found that the wood had been stained a dark color that I could not remove with alcohol, bleach and other chemicals. I applied two coats of a pigmented shellac sealer, then two coats of acrylic latex and two coats of semi-gloss.

LEAD: The shooting of a retired navy officer in the northern city of San Sebastian was the latest act of violence in a week that began with an offer from Justice Minister Jose Luis Corcuera to the Basque separatist group E.T.A. to exchange generous treatment for a six-month truce.

LEAD: June wedding plans for Stacey Gillis and Jeffrey Andrew Weber have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Robert Gillis of Lake Wylie, S.C., and Mrs. Stanley Grey of Atlanta. Mr. Weber is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Weber of New York.

LEAD: Dr. Lynn Chinitz, a resident in radiology, and Dr. Steven Gruenstein, a senior fellow in hematology-oncology, both at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, were married last evening at the Puck Building in Manhattan. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Chinitz of Queens.

LEAD: Tanzanian politics involve a good deal of self-analysis and what some would consider interminable debate. Although this is a one-party state, politicians here like to say, at least the party's laundry is washed in public.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of a producer's schedule change, an article on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the musical ''Jonah'' gives an incorrect opening date. ''Jonah,'' now in previews at the Public Theater, will not open on Tuesday; a new date will be announced.
LEAD: The Knicks gave up too much youth, talent and most of all, potential for a player who, however classy and dependable, has his best years behind him. ALAN C. MILLER Vienna, Va.

LEAD: For the first time, West Virginia University last week chose a woman as its buckskin-clad mascot for men's athletic events. The new Mountaineer, 22-year-old Natalie Tennant, said winning the honor was more a matter of showing school spirit than of overcoming a sex barrier.

LEAD: FRANCIS MARION, AN American general in the Revolutionary War, bedeviled the British with his surprise attacks from the marshy areas of South Carolina. The short, sickly-looking fellow was among our earliest partisan fighters, pioneering guerrilla tactics against regular troops in skirmishes at Tearcoat Swamp and Halfway Swamp.

LEAD: CINZANO'S in Fairfield is a year-old restaurant that sends mixed signals to first-time visitors. Outside the entrance are handsome, terra cotta pots, but to enter the restaurant, you have to pass through a mundane bar. Once inside the restaurant proper, you are greeted by a stylish, semiformal decor of tapestry-backed banquettes and chairs, rose-colored carpeting, wood paneling and a back wall covered with an oil painting of a pastoral Italian scene, the front a wall of greenhouse-style glass windows.

LEAD: When a freshman business major, Barry Abrams, registered for a class called ''Law in Society'' last semester, he had no idea he would be standing in front of 600 students playing the role of an Oxford-educated gorilla who got drunk one Labor Day and chomped off his neighbor's leg.
LEAD: About 7,500 hotel workers went on strike today after contract negotiations collapsed, threatening to disrupt the state's $6-billion-a-year tourism industry.

LEAD: Last Sunday night, sometime after 10:30 P.M., I put an end to my seventh straight day of work. I left behind the stress of my office to confront another set of pressures -finding transportation home on the coldest day of the year.

LEAD: Seventy dog teams and mushers set out today in the Iditarod Trail sled-dog race, a 1,160-mile, two-week chase that will take them through snow, ice and punishing cold winds before they reach Nome.

LEAD: ANDY ROONEY, the crabby curmudgeon of CBS News, is back tonight on ''60 Minutes,'' two months before the end of a three-month suspension. Portrayed at first as a compromise - CBS News responds to complaints about offensive remarks without banishing the offender forever - the suspension and its abrupt end ultimately had more to do with internal politics than with the issue of sensitivity versus censorship.
LEAD: Not so long ago, there was mostly Health-Tex and Danskin, and style was an afterthought. But for baby-boomer parents nowadays, style is thought of long before they get to the store.

LEAD: Senate 1. Armenian Issue: Vote to cut off debate on a proposed resolution to commemorate the mass death of Armenian civilians during World War I at the hands of the Ottoman Turks. Failed, with 48 votes in favor and 51 opposed (60 votes were needed), February 27. 2. Peace Dividend: Vote on a Democratic sponsored non-binding resolution expressing the sense of the Senate that any savings from anticipated reductions in military spending be used to: (1) balance the Federal budget without using the Social
LEAD: Ruth Cummings Mead and Jeffrey Pierce Barker were married yesterday at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. John M. Allin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on page 3 of the Travel section today refers incorrectly to the fare that qualifies passengers for Economy Select seating on British Airways DC-10 flights to Gatwick Airport near London from Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The midweek $1,102 round-trip fare does not require advance purchase.

LEAD: A work in desperation. That's what the writer/director James L. Brooks (''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''Terms of Endearment'') once called ''The Tracey Ullman Show.'' He was in a position to know, being co-creator of the series and one of the executive producers. Fortunately, with Fox Broadcasting itching to set up a fourth network, the show was allowed to lurch on.

LEAD: AFTER years of watching in dismay as star Soviet athletes defected to the United States and other Western nations, Soviet athletic authorities seem to have turned the emigration tide. Dale Mulholland, a 25-year old American Soccer League player who spent last season with the Orlando Lions, said he had signed a contract to become the first American to play with Locomotiv Moscow, one of 22 professional teams in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Mrs. Byron Cleveland Herbert of Edenton, N.C., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Ethel Walker Smith Bush and Malcolm Percy McAllister, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hoitt McAllister of Greenwich, Conn.
LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is considering a modified American proposal for starting peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, his office said this morning.
LEAD: The Rangers do not go in much for moderation. This season they have won in streaks and lost at length. Tonight, in a fashion that was both painful and familiar, they crashed.
LEAD: As Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu headed for California to meet with President Bush last week, Japan-bashing was on the rise in the financial markets.

LEAD: The police killed a protester today in the old downtown area of Srinagar after 25 people came out of their homes in defiance of a curfew, witnesses said. The police and airport officials said India sent hundreds of reinforcements to the Kashmir Valley after troops fired on Muslim protesters this week.

LEAD: Never has so much been written about a place of which nobody knows a thing. When religious Victorians put about that the hereafter was not a place but a state of being, the sublime Cardinal Newman opined that the idea of place was inherent in that of the afterlife.

LEAD: Maurice Cheeks is a great playmaker and leader as well as a class act. But he does not fill the Knicks' needs, which are a shooting guard and a solid scoring forward. LEAD: THE WORDS ''FAMILY SUPPER'' CARRY with them an almost unutterable nostalgia, images and emotions of the past wrapped in the glow of better values. The vision is fueled by Norman Rockwell paintings and television commercials for turkeys, long-distance telephone companies and insurance agencies. The props are large linen napkins, grandparents, paneled dining rooms and vast tables loaded with roasted birds, homemade breads, jams and pickles and a ravishment of pies, cakes and cookies.

The players - Erika Nickrenz, a pianist; Adela Pena, a violinist, and Sara Sant'Ambrogio, a cellist - are accomplished musicians with interpretive instincts that are solid and well matched.

LEAD: As a writer working on a guide to pregnancy, I am familiar with the dangers posed by alcohol. Yet, I take issue with the way in which Elisabeth Rosenthal uncritically quotes Dr. Claire D. Coles. Dr. Coles seems to regard even the slightest aberration in behavior as a likely symptom of the effect. The fact that a month-old baby ''should be calm'' but isn't is used as evidence that the infant is suffering from the effects of prenatal substance abuse.

LEAD: VIRGIL THOMSON used to say that when you have company, you serve a roast. Perhaps this seems a little old-fashioned in these days of swordfish steaks and composed salads, but few things so firmly state that the meal is a special occasion.

LEAD: AMONG the 3,282 candidates running for the Moscow City Council in elections Sunday, Yuri A. Prokofiev may be the one with the most to lose. Since November he has been the Communist Party chief of Moscow, and by most accounts his party's control of the Soviet capital is in some jeopardy.

LEAD: On the surface, the Feb. 11 article on the expansion of international flights at Newark Airport was nothing but good news - so good that it almost seemed like a self-congratulatory press release from the Port Authority. LEAD: An irony surrounds the bevy of tax-preparation computer programs on the market these days: Despite countless hours spent by program writers to distinguish their products from the competition, the programs for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers remain essentially alike. As a result, a consumer would be wise to pick a program based on how easy it is to use, whether it offers adequate on-screen help and whether it can generate a finished tax return on the printer the consumer owns.

LEAD: Your article was informative and, at times, chilling in its implications. However, I do not feel this subject can be thoroughly addressed without presenting the significant issue of male alcoholism and its effect on the fetus. NAOMI HOROWITZ Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

LEAD: IN his moment of defeat after the election last week, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua gave a concession speech. Then he went to the house of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, almost like a neighbor in distress coming to seek solace. ''Come in, my little father, because I love you,'' the handsome woman was quoted as telling the man she had just defeated in the race for president.

LEAD: Walter McCarthy's article on social skills for the retarded as the key to advancement from sheltered workshop to successful supported employment in the public sector was a well considered one, raising the questions we need to ask about how retarded children and young adults gain these skills. The relationship with the job trainer, a coach who is eventually faded out as the retarded young adult becomes more able to do his/her job, is vital in training both the employee and the supervisor.

LEAD: The No. 2 official in the Palestine Liberation Organization says in an article to be published on Sunday that Palestinians welcome the idea of a confederation with Jordan but only after the establishment of an independent Palestinian homeland.

LEAD: Antonia Coello Novello was confirmed as Surgeon General by the Senate on Thursday. A 45-year-old pediatrician and expert on AIDS in children, she is the first female and the first Hispanic Surgeon General. She has been deputy director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, one of the National Institutes of Health.

LEAD: As in many other things, New Yorkers are in a class by themselves when it comes to ''The Sound of Music.'' Architects played the same game, and a fair amount of the time managed to overextend themselves just as much, piling up significant levels of esthetic debt as they struggled to capture the combination of flamboyance and dignity that characterized the architecture of the 20's.

LEAD: The family of the deposed Panamanian military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, arrived today in Havana after being granted safe passage by the Panamanian Government, a Mexican news agency reported. The agency said General Noriega's wife, three daughters and grandson would travel to the Dominican Republic, where they have been granted asylum and where the general's son-in-law is a citizen.

LEAD: When Joe Roth walks from the 20th Century Fox commissary to his office in the executive building a few hundred yards away, he is the master of nearly everything his eye can see. But he ambles down the street instead of bestriding the Fox lot like a mogul.

LEAD: ''A CHORUS LINE,'' the hit musical that is to close this month after a record-breaking Broadway run of 15 years, in some ways is the ideal New York story, both in its own success and in the story it tells. In it, 17 dancers try out for jobs in a show and, although almost all are destined to be losers, their up-and-down careers represent the mood of eternal hope that keeps attracting out-of-towners to New York.
LEAD: Barbara Jayne Kerker and Marc Adam Honig, who expect to receive medical degrees in May from Johns Hopkins University, plan to marry in June.

LEAD: On the hill above the old city of Ohrid, in southern Yugoslavia, is an overgrown park, half reclaimed by forest and crowned by the monumental, ruined fortress of Tsar Samuil, who during the 10th century created a Macedonian empire extending from the Danube to the Adriatic. The park is full of ruins: crumbling walls, rusted swing sets, the roofless Sveti Pantelejmon, which, like so many Yugoslav churches, served as a mosque for much of its life.
LEAD: JOHN TURNER leaned back on a row of wooden bleachers in the Mabee Center at Phillips University and wiped the perspiration from his forehead.

LEAD: The six members of an international expedition arrived at a Soviet base on Antarctica's eastern coast today, completing a seven-month, 3,800-mile ski and dogsled journey that organizers called the longest unmechanized crossing of the frozen continent.
LEAD: NEW YORK area cooperatives are beginning to ease their traditional restrictions on the rights of shareholders to rent their apartments to outsiders.

LEAD: Jad Fair and Kramer, who brought a six-piece band to Wetlands on Monday night, are kindred souls on rock's scruffy fringes. Mr. Fair, who has led the band Half Japanese since the late 1970's, is one of rock's last professional amateurs; he writes blunt, seemingly artless lyrics, sings them in a nasal whine and scratches out scraggly notes and chords from his guitar.

LEAD: A certain talented writer who, like myself, came here from Eastern Europe complained to me recently that totalitarianism has ruined him twice: first, by imprisoning him and forcing him to emigrate; second, by falling apart just when the writer had completed an 800-page novel on the very subject of totalitarianism.

LEAD: I feel that Roger Keizerstein in his article ''Teen-Agers and the Trap of Affluence'' (Jan. 21) misses the point of what is really missing in their affluent lives. It is this very protection from life in the outside world that creates for them an empty nonworld. Even more to their detriment is the fact that they've never been told that the end of homelessness, the reversal of environmental decay, the elimination of animal exploitation, all rest within their hands.

LEAD: Mrs. Charles F. Fogarty of Darien, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter Theresa Ellen Fogarty to Troy Edwin Stavens, the son of Mrs. Edwin H. Stavens of Hatton, N.D., and the late Mr. Stavens. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Al Bianchi's Kiki Vandeweghe fixation cost the Knicks the 1989 first-round draft choice and Sidney Green. His ego cost the team Rick Pitino, a great motivating coach who always had the team playing at top intensity. Now Bianchi's trade of Strickland's future for Cheeks' past has cost the Knicks the 1988 first-round draft pick and any hope for meaningful improvement next season.

LEAD: About halfway through his first set at the West End Gate on Thursday night, Claude (Fiddler) Williams fiddled away at a solo cadenza as an introduction to the tune ''Laura.'' Soaring through chords and tossing off complicated, jumping rhythms, he eventually wound his way to the first notes of the melody.

LEAD: EVERY few years, The Gryphon appears in Old Lyme. Its full title is The Gryphon: A Literary Review, and it is filled with the work of local writers. LEAD: MY JOB WAS TO open beer bottles and load guns. I hadn't volunteered for the tasks, and like any draftee I was intimidated. I did as I was told, hoping for survival, and soon the back seat of the old Ford was littered with bent bottle caps and spent shell casings.

LEAD: Bowling may be the only sport where the participants do not have to break a sweat. And this sport is a perfect way to spend a few hours on a nasty winter day. It can appeal to the intensely competitive or mere fun lovers; adults or children; small groups or large.

LEAD: The price of the traffic violation that brought Zsa Zsa Gabor to court last year keeps going up. LEAD: Mutual fund expenses are rising. But are investors getting their money's worth? In most cases, the answer is no. LEAD: AFTER the bad old days of the 1970's, when bankruptcy seemed near and boom unimaginable, New York City was ordered to untangle its books and submit them to newly appointed fiscal monitors. The city was also forced to draw up budgets for four years at a clip and to update its spending plans four times a year, so it could not, as one official put it last week, hide its head in the sand for more than three months at a time.

LEAD: I went back to Greer Spring one day a few months ago. Greer Spring is, arguably, one of the prettiest spots in the Ozarks, and I hadn't been there for several years. The ticks and chiggers and poison ivy that make summer woodland visits in that part of the country so itchy were gone, and the day was such a bright-blue sunny one it demanded a walk in some beautiful spot.

LEAD: Erich Rupprecht delineates exactly the sort of savvy that's needed to compete against younger opponents (About Men: ''What Do You Call an Aging Hoopster?'' Feb. 4). For me (age 44), the moment of ''wisdom'' came 10 or so years ago, when a windmilling, spread-eagled, college-age defender was left gasping when I threw a perfect bounce-pass between his legs to a teammate (older than I), cutting to a basket: two points for us and a Newtonian epiphany for me.

LEAD: The soot-belching city bus is headed for extinction as a result of stringent Federal emissions standards due to go into effect next year. LEAD: These are days of confirmation that the American economic system remains the model for those yearning to be rich. The nation is borrowing billions to cover expenses and to build high-tech toys like the stealth bomber, the theory goes, while everything from vocational education to computer-chip factories slides into obsolescence.

LEAD: IN economy class, the squeeze is on. You are being packed in more snugly. Instead of a seat that occupied 34 inches or even 36 along the aisle four years ago, you will probably now get a seat that takes up only 31 inches.

LEAD: Jean-Baptiste Greuze (1725-1805) is the great whipping boy of 18th-century French art. This is the Greuze beloved by the 19th century, the Greuze of the 4th Marquess of Hertford, who paid staggering sums for these ''fancy heads.

LEAD: WHILE stuck in traffic on Tucson's south side recently, I noticed something that had previously escaped me. It was a painting of a woman asleep on a pillow, in a friendly desert landscape, against a backdrop of waterfalls, canyonland and bluffs. The artistry was confident, but no one would confuse it with museum-quality.
LEAD: WHEN Vladimir Dukelsky came to America in 1921, the classically trained Russian composer began writing popular songs, and soon thereafter he met George Gershwin.
LEAD: Using Your Own Car Abroad

LEAD: When Internal Revenue Service agents set out to separate the Newhouse clan from $609 million seven years ago, they should have known to pack a lunch. Lawyers for S.I. Newhouse Jr. and his brother, Donald, walked out of Federal Tax Court in Washington last week with a victory in one of the biggest tax disputes in I.R.S.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: On a Sunday some months ago, my wife, Lynne, and I were driving west on U.S. 14 from Brookings, S.D. We had spent the night there, after a visit to the South Dakota Art Museum, with its exceptional collection of paintings by the South Dakota artist Harvey Dunn. At De Smet we stopped for a tank of gas, and I studied the map.
LEAD: By tonight, the Nets had suffered through enough hardships this week, both on and off the court. So they took out their frustration on the Atlanta Hawks.

LEAD: The east and west coast branches of the Writers Guild of America reached an agreement with CBS Friday on a three-year contract that will run through 1992. The contract covers 325 network television and radio employees in New York and Washington and employees at CBS-owned stations in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.

LEAD: In these contentious times, we hear a great deal about the single-issue voter, the citizen for whom nothing in the political spectrum matters except a candidate's stand on taxes or the burning of the flag. A parallel phenomenon, I have found, is the single-issue reader, whose urge to correspond is set off only by mention of, say, Maria Callas or Glenn Gould or original instruments.
LEAD: I got my first, and worst, tax headache of the year choosing a program to prepare the return.

LEAD: ''People do not expect to see much glass at the Winter Antiques Show,'' said Arlene Palmer, a glass specialist from Yarmouth, Me., who visited the show at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, in late January.

LEAD: If collectors go merely by a catalogue description, an unusual coin could be overlooked. Its description, coin 2362, in the catalogue of Pontero and Associates for its mid-March sale is mild: Philip II, 359-336 B.C., Tetradrachm. Laureate head of Zeus right; reverse, naked youth on horseback, right.

LEAD: The trade was a terrible one. True, Strickland was bad for the team's morale. But the Knicks should have gotten much more for him than a player who has at most a year or two left. It was a trade you might make if you had a real shot at the championship, but the Knicks don't belong on the same court as the Lakers.

LEAD: Machine tool makers are part of the nation's industrial bedrock. Manufacturers rely on them for equipment to forge, cut, grind, drill, bend, trim and stamp the blocks and sheets of metal that become cars, airplanes and appliances.

LEAD: HOW to become part of a neighborhood? Buy a house with a garden. Not a garden that's handed over to other people to care for - that destroys the whole purpose. It's all right to have somebody cut the lawn and clip the hedge but the garden itself - the dirty earthy part, the part that gets under your nails and ruins your manicure - must be your baby.

LEAD: It is true, of course, that anyone who wants to reach the top ranks of the game must have an independent mind and not passively take for granted whatever is promulgated by the authorities. Nevertheless, if one is to diverge from the pronouncement of a great player, a very searching analysis is a must.

LEAD: Ellen Joy Gottmann and Mark Cooper Kulik plan to marry in May. Ms. Gottmann, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Gottmann of Ramsey, N.J. Her fiance, 25, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Kulik of Ramsey.

LEAD: IT IS RAINING ON THE ASHOKAN RESERVOIR. The rain ruffles the surface of the water, and a gray mist slinks off the Catskill Mountains. Several months from now, this rain will emerge, 90 miles to the south, through innumerable New York City faucets and washing machines and fire hydrants. The trip, made by billions of gallons of water every month, will be uneventful.

LEAD: THE GENIUS OF JACOPO BELLINI The Complete Paintings and Drawings. By Colin Eisler. Illustrated. 560 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $195. GIOVANNI BELLINI By Rona Goffen. Illustrated. 347 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $60.

LEAD: As the day for balloting drew near, Vitaly P. Khlystov, an assembler at Mechanical Factory No. 2 and an unpaid organizer of one the plant's workshop-level Communist Party cells, was not breaking a sweat nor even breathing particularly hard in efforts to promote the party's candidates.
LEAD: ''LAUGHTER through tears is my favorite emotion,'' says Truvy, the owner of the most successful beauty shop in Chinquapin, La.

LEAD: The engagement of Celia Ann Vlasin to James Benjamin Martin, a son of Mrs. John McK. Martin of Wilmington, Del., and the late Mr. Martin, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Vlasin of East Lansing, Mich. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''WITH the right agricultural management, Syria could become another California.'' This was the view of a Dutch agronomist with whom I shared a taxi on my arrival at Damascus Airport. On my departure a week later, I wondered whether the same might be true of Syrian tourism one day. If you tend to think of Syria along with Iran, Libya and Lebanon as places no reasonable American would visit, it is also true that no Americans have been taken hostage in Syria, that it has diplomatic relations with the United States and that, while the State

LEAD: STARTING this month, public libraries around the state will be offering free book-discussion series in the largest such project ever organized in Connecticut. The project, Connecticut Reading Connections, supported by a Federal grant, will bring 240 individual programs to 60 communities.
LEAD: For freelance artists and writers, whose yearly expenses and income are often unpredictable and irregular, staying on top of personal finances is essential for saving on taxes.
LEAD: This department recently listed a handful of players who have achieved the feat of winning a national title at the first attempt.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Eisenberg of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy B. Eisenberg to Dr. Marc G. Brandriss, a son of Perla Brandriss of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Rabbi Joseph Brandriss. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Dr. Laurie Joan Polis, a dermatologist, and Dr. Richard Marc Wind, an obstetrician and gynecologist, both in New York, are planning an April wedding. The announcement was made by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Polis of Williston Park, L.I. Dr. Wind is a son of Samuel Wind of New York and the late Margot Wertheimer

LEAD: Armonk, N.Y. $376,000 2 North Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, c/a, deck, 2-car garage, 1.2 acres; taxes $4,191. Chappaqua, N.Y. $324,000 74 Orchard Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 68-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, sun porch, front porch, deck, 0.85 acre; taxes $5,129.

LEAD: The failure of Gen. Michel Aoun to crush his militia opponents in the Christian sector after five weeks of fierce battles is likely to force him to step down and turn power over to President Elias Hrawi, according to news reports published today and Arab diplomats.
LEAD: The harsh realities of world-class gymnastics became painfully clear to Brandy Johnson today. One, it is not a sport for the unhealthy. Two, a younger athlete can pop up anywhere, anytime.

LEAD: Covenant House is, of course, no bucolic Boys Town, but somehow New York had come to view the juvenile shelter's founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, as a bit like the tough-but-wholesome priests of 1930's Hollywood. There he was, fighting at various times City Hall, landlords, criminals and the odds to save ''these good kids,'' the young runaways and throwaways of Times Square.
LEAD: President Bush's nominee for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job holds nearly $20,000 worth of stock in a company that does business in South Africa.

LEAD: The average person's notion of food in Los Angeles is that it's supermodern, trendy and eclectic. Like all cliches, this is largely true. There's a place on Melrose that serves Tex-Mex dim sum, and a favorite kind of sushi, with avocado, is called California maki. L.A., with its vista west to the Orient, its rich stew of immigrants, its diverse cultures, encourages strange mixtures and makes everything its own, while at the same time preserving individual flavors.

LEAD: For the vast majority of Americans, the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986 has meant slightly lower taxes and an easier time figuring them out. But for some people, most of them well-to-do, the new law has meant much higher taxes and a nightmare of unfathomable rules and regulations.

LEAD: THE overwhelming election victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and her opposition coalition in Nicaragua has done more than merely stun pollsters, pundits and the ruling Sandinistas. Taken in tandem with the United States invasion of Panama, Mrs. Chamorro's triumph last week may signal the possibility of a significant change in the politics of Central America and in

LEAD: THE SURPRISE OF BURNING, by Michael Doane. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A war photographer and his mother, an aspiring singer with a heroin problem, find that both are instinctively drawn to history's great disasters. Michael Doane ''throws together pivotal events and archetypal characters from our nation's history to create a dazzling Jasper Johns-like construction,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times in 1988.

LEAD: A waterfront park proposed for the West Side of Manhattan may cost as much as $331 million - about $70 million more than is now pledged to the project, a consultant told a panel overseeing the plans for the park.

LEAD: Bernie, the grandpa, is slowly dying but will survive the play. Bessie, the grandma, is quickly cooking and fussing and will survive grandpa. Neal, the grandson, a modern young man, and you know what that adds up to, has decided to immerse himself in the life of his grandparents and even to get grandpa the bar mitzvah ceremony he missed out on when he turned 13.

LEAD: Genesia Perlmutter and Steven Romain Kamen were married last evening at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Ely Emanuel Pilchik, the bride's stepfather, officiated with Rabbi Barry H. Greene and Cantor Norman Summers.
LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan and President Bush concluded two days of talks, and Mr. Kaifu said he had pledged to take serious action to ease trade tensions.

LEAD: A bipartisan group of four House leaders has moved to restore several health benefits for older Americans that were included in the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act that Congress repealed last year.

LEAD: Regina E. Napoli and Bruce S. Borden were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Smithtown, L.I., by the Rev. Paul Walsh. Mrs. Borden, 28 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Napoli of Hauppauge, L.I. Her husband, 30, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Borden of Cape Elizabeth, Me.
LEAD: There's little mystery to successful investing. No matter what the investments, the key, most financial advisers and accountants agree, is careful planning.

LEAD: When Ronnie Masango fled South Africa as a radical teen-ager, he thought he would get six months' military training with the African National Congress in the Angolan bush and return with a rifle to help overthrow the white-minority Government.

LEAD: The familiar won out over the new on a program by the Ohio Ballet on Friday night at the Whitney Museum of American Art at the Equitable Center. The company, founded in 1976 and based in Akron, is a troupe of disciplined, well-trained young dancers who sailed easily through George Balanchine's ''Concerto Barocco,'' which is fast becoming a staple of the national ballet repertory.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Ehrlich of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Ann Ehrlich to David J. Rimmer, the son of Phyllis Rimmer of Bay Terrace, Queens, and the late Murray Rimmer. A May wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: NOWHERE in the world do kites occupy as important a place in national life as they do in Japan. The Japanese both welcome in the new year and celebrate Boys' Day on May 5 by flying kites. Local kite festivals that involve dramatic airborne battles are also a feature of many communities in the spring and summer months.
