LEAD: THE New Orchestra of Westchester does not resume its subscription concerts for two more weeks, but the ensemble is leading up to them with four special programs under the umbrella ''Spring Festival: Made in the U.S.A.''

LEAD: Elizabeth Wilson grew up in Worcester, Mass., far from the worlds of Far Eastern folk art and fashion. But she became enthralled with Oriental textiles while a graduate student in Chinese art history at Columbia University. In 1975, when her husband, Marc, became curator of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., Ms.

LEAD: I enjoy an occasional glass of wine (''When a Pregnant Woman Drinks,'' by Elisabeth Rosenthal, Feb. 4). My husband, who is a physician, and I have no children yet. However, when and if I ever become pregnant, my normally mild-mannered husband has informed me that he will not tolerate any alcohol consumption by me during my pregnancy, and for several months thereafter if I choose to breast-feed.
LEAD: Charles Shackleford is described by one of his former North Carolina State teammates as a mystery man.

LEAD: The Caere Corporation, which two years ago created the first optical character-recognition system for personal computers, is preparing to introduce a $10,995 computer that is said to recognize printed words at a rate of 2,500 a minute and convert them to electronic form with a high level of accuracy.
LEAD: One of the St. Louis goals came after the referee accidentally blocked an Islander clearing pass.
LEAD: Foreign Minister Gyula Horn said in an interview published today that he expected to reach an agreement on the total withdrawal of Soviet troops from Hungary when he visits Moscow next week.

LEAD: An article in The Long Island Weekly last Sunday described the investigation of a car-bombing on Feb. 15 that killed a Suffolk County narcotics detective. It reported that investigators' focus had shifted from the detective's undercover work to his private life.

LEAD: Dynasty Hao is a restaurant that has recently opened in Tokyo. Its interior has been designed to resemble a bare-beamed SoHo loft, and its sound system speaks riffy American jazz. The food, however, is spicy Taiwanese: pork dumplings, sauteed pumpkin with garlic, minced chicken in lettuce. The restaurant is the second of this name to be opened in Tokyo by Kiddieland, an upscale Japanese toy store.

LEAD: DESPITE its usefulness, the router is a mysterious power tool to many amateurs, perhaps because its name does not describe its function. A better name might be electric chisel, for a chisel is the hand tool whose operations the router duplicates most closely.

LEAD: Karen comes back from Florida, talking about Key West. She hit the Overseas Highway, and 42 bridges later she was on Duval Street buying a palm frond hat. She checked into a guesthouse called Big Ruby's, stuffed herself with conch fritters and got wasted away in Margaritaville. There was music everywhere, blues and jazz and calypso, and what they call Conchtown.

LEAD: To the Editor: The Marriott's Leisurelife program offers 50 percent off rack rates for people 62 and over, according to your article ''Getting Breaks on Hotel Rates'' (Practical Traveler, Dec. 24). I called the Marriott in Boca Raton, Fla., twice to book and was told the rate was $124 and no further discount would be allowed.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has decided to levy sanctions against Maryland's men's basketball program, but is not quite ready to release the information, an official of the agency was quoted as saying. ''I'm working out some kind of schedule with the institution,'' David Berst, the N.C.A.A.

LEAD: Composites combine the properties of two or more materials to accomplish tasks beyond the capabilities of homogeneous substances. An early example was the addition of straw to bricks to resist breakage. Currently, carbon-reinforced plastics produce lighter, stiffer golf clubs and tennis rackets, and designers are looking at exotic metal-ceramic combinations for high-performance aerospace applications.

LEAD: Howell $159,900 20 Deer Hollow Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; c/a, family room, 2-car garage, patio; taxes $2,653. Livingston $185,000 20 Claremont Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 34-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $2,814.

LEAD: When Melvin Van Peebles first came to Hollywood 34 years ago to break into movies, he was offered work as an elevator operator. Last month he was honored at the Sundance United States Film Festival as a pioneering black film maker. When Wendell Harris Jr. first came to Hollywood with hopes of working as an actor in 1976, he couldn't get past ''the secretary to the secretary'' to see an agent.

LEAD: The meshing of West and East Germany - one a sleek, postwar capitalist engine and the other a shattered, inefficient state-run rowboat with high unemployment - is expected to be a formidable task. While the two halves may some day become a seamless and vibrant economy, the transition is expected to be rough, and unsettling for interest rates around the globe.

LEAD: HIGH on a hill overlooking Bonn from across the Rhine stands Silesia House, an elegant and meticulously restored old mansion where German families expelled from their homeland during World War II gather to maintain old ties, to explore their heritage, to wax nostalgic - and to nurture a bitterness.
LEAD: THE TRAVELS OF MENDES PINTO By Fernao Mendes Pinto. Edited and translated by Rebecca D. Catz. Illustrated. 663 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $49.95.

LEAD: RETIREMENT can be the time to enjoy the fruits of a life's labor, or it can be a time of penny-pinching uncertainty. To be sure it is the first, an understanding of the role tax laws play, both in saving for retirement and during retirement, is essential.
LEAD: Scott Steidl, a composer from Minneapolis who studied with David Diamond and Elliott Carter at the Juilliard School, presented a program of his music at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening.
LEAD: Rape, sometimes called broccoli di rape, began to make its way out of the Italian grocery store and into the supermarket four or five years ago.

LEAD: Not long ago, all a defecting Soviet intelligence officer might want from America was protection, a modest living and a chance to die in bed. Now, for Victor I. Sheymov, at least, it is interviews, press conferences and, yes, book deals. Mr. Sheymov surfaced last week in Washington and let the world know that 10 years ago he had defected straight from the inner sanctum of the K.G.B.

LEAD: There is another country, aside from Japan, where the bond market has fallen sharply and sent interest rates to startingly high levels. But in that country - West Germany - the impact has not been nearly as devastating.

LEAD: Terri Newman Wed to Steven Bleiberg Terri Lynn Newman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan A. Newman of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Steven David Bleiberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Bleiberg of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Daniel Allen officiated.

LEAD: THERE is no mistaking it, not from the distance of the interstate highway that whisks past it and not up close, where it rises unevenly, looking somehow as if it were slipping irreparably into its foundation. And while it is both a little odd to the eye and seemingly out of place here, there is no reason to believe that it won't soon be the home of big league baseball.
LEAD: American soldier has died of wounds suffered in a grenade attack on a discotheque, and 13 American servicemen remain hospitalized, the United States military said today.

LEAD: A former owner of a local fruit juice company was sentenced last week to two years in prison for selling orange juice adulterated with ingredients not listed on container labels. United States District Judge
LEAD: WHEN I was growing up, two of the most charming characters in my neighborhood were an owl that smoked cigars and a lunatic bear.

LEAD: After months of seeking to reduce its 68 percent stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton, the American Express Company siad it would, instead, buy all the outstanding shares of the investment bank. Weekend talks about selling Shearson to Sanford I. Weill, a Wall Street exectuvie, fell through. Business Day, page D1.

LEAD: For anyone who is terminally ill, with 18 months or less to live, Rob T. Worley Sr., of Albuquerque, N.M., has an offer: Assign a life insurance policy to his company, Living Benefits Inc., and get up to 80 percent of the policy's value, now.

LEAD: The news from Ethiopia could hardly be grimmer. In a bitter reprise of the famine of 1984-85, millions face starvation as stores from a meager harvest are exhausted. Again, Western relief agencies must deal with a truculent Marxist tyranny led by President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The difference this time is that Mr.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As they sit in a Nassau County courtroom here, listening to hour after hour of grim testimony about the murder of 13-year-old Kelly Ann Tinyes, the jurors in the case often turn to stare at the defendant, Robert Golub.

LEAD: TONYA and Greg Grant grew up near basketball courts. They had a backboard in their backyard, and their grandmother lived next to the courts on Walnut Street in Trenton. This was a good thing. It meant there was always some family member around to calm things down.
LEAD: As they did 25 years ago, civil rights marchers gathered today under a cloudless sky and slowly walked onto the Edmund Pettus Bridge.

LEAD: The Exxon Valdez oil spill was arguably the worst environmental disaster in U.S. history, so it's reasonable to expect those responsible to be called to account, clean up the mess and pay damages. The Justice Department chose to pursue those ends through a plea bargain with Exxon. The collapse of that bargain has almost certainly served the larger cause of justice.
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins told reporters that he had visited yesterday with the family of David Cotto, the 20-year-old Brooklyn man who died on Thursday when he was struck by nine police bullets.
LEAD: Deception By Philip Roth 208 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
LEAD: IRONY was presumably not what George F. Will intended when he came up with a title for his new book, which examines the intricacies of major league baseball.

LEAD: JUST six months after stunning Wall Street with its first-ever quarterly loss, Sun Microsystems Inc. has put its corporate house back in order, analysts say. Results improved dramatically in the quarter ended Dec. 31 at Sun, the leading maker of work stations, which are powerful desktop computers previously used for scientific and engineering work but now being employed for financial services and other applications.

LEAD: Samuel Perlman, a businessman and philanthropist, died of cardiac arrest on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old. Mr. Perlman, a Brooklyn native, was a graduate of St. John's University and the New York Law School. He served in the Army in World War II and with the American military government in Germany after the war.

LEAD: The American Express Company, which had struggled to separate itself from Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., found that doing so was not easy. Now, realizing that its prestige and reputation are inextricably bound up in Shearson's fortunes, it has decided to buy the entire brokerage firm.
LEAD: M. Steffy Browne, professor emeritus of economics at Brooklyn College, died of heart failure Friday at New York Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Jesse Sligh, an assistant district attorney, pondered the information the police officer had just given him about an arrest the night before. The suspect had kicked his pregnant wife during a domestic dispute.

LEAD: Diego Trujillo, an immigrant from Colombia who is a legal resident of the United States, and his companion of 13 years were thrilled last month when a Federal immigration policy was changed to try to keep alien families together.

LEAD: The Advertising column on Friday, about an exodus of creative people from San Francisco agencies, misidentified the Los Angeles agency that has employed Dan Mountain, a copywriter. It is Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, not Chiat/Day.

LEAD: AS Jim Calhoun sat in his office last week, his basketball team was little more than 24 hours away from gaining a share of first place in the final regular-season standing for the first time in the University of Connecticut's often depressing history as a member of the Big East Conference.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: If Ms. was the magazine that defined feminism, can the new Ms. magazine, scheduled to appear in June, be described as post-feminist?

LEAD: By noon today, when the morning shift had finished tending the dairy cows on the state farm in this small village, nearly all the eligible voters had cast their ballots at the polling station. Only 14 holdouts remained, mostly those who were still out doing their chores.
LEAD: As was expected for months, the Justice Department has sued the Virginia Military Institute in an effort to end the exclusion of women from the 1,300-student academy.

LEAD: FACING a severe cash squeeze, the trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos - who often suffer from fatal diseases - has begun to offer settlements of up to 40 percent in cash and the rest in non-marketable, long-term notes.

LEAD: Fred Rogers, the host of ''Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood,'' took the pictures of children from his wallet and displayed them, as any proud parent would do. But the photos were not of his children; they were of children who had visited his ''Neighborhood.'' Mr. Rogers simply loves children.
LEAD: The British Broadcasting Corporation has announced plans to expand its news programs in the United States and Eastern Europe.

LEAD: One of the peculiar complaints of the Japanese - presumably repeated by Prime Minister Kaifu to President Bush at the Rancho Mirage summit meeting - is that Americans don't save enough. We are accused of spending too much on Japanese cars and other imports, thus increasing our trade deficit through no fault but our own.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Friday about the Penrod Drilling Corporation misstated the extent of the company's ownership of offshore drilling rigs. Penrod owns 39 modern drilling rigs, not 39 percent of the world's total.

LEAD: THEY are at once loyal alumni, avid boosters and potential saboteurs: dedicated fans whose very eagerness to help old Siwash U. get a leg up on Rival State can cost Siwash the chance to sign a valued prospect or keep an established star.

LEAD: Amid a merger that will cost hundreds of millions of dollars and shuffle thousands of jobs, a storm of community anger has broken out over the determination of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center to move 42 of its maternity beds downtown.
LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu returned to Japan on Sunday from his meeting with President Bush in California to face what politicians and commentators agreed was a severe test of his leadership.

LEAD: More than any other foreign institution, the World Bank has had enormous impact on China's economic transformation of the last decade. It was not just a large lending institution but a bank of ideas.

LEAD: Despite campaign promises to ''send all the weapons to the bottom of the sea,'' President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will only gradually reduce Nicaragua's military, and she has backed away from plans to abolish the army entirely, her advisers say.
LEAD: A mine exploded today while soldiers were exploring a tunnel supposedly dug under the border by North Korea, killing a sentry dog but causing no other casualties, officials said.

LEAD: Two and a half years, 124 witnesses and 800 exhibits later, prosecutors are ready to seek convictions once again in the McMartin preschool molestation case, this time with a different judge and jury and only one defendant.

LEAD: The National, the new sports newspaper, has gotten off to a fast start by using discounted introductory rates to lure national advertisers like A.T.&T., Philip Morris and Nike, media analysts say. The tabloid claims a daily circulation of 200,000.
LEAD: Alma Nicoll Baker, an interior designer, died of ovarian cancer yesterday at Memorial Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fordham will have to wait one more day to leave the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference behind. The Rams, who join the Colonial League next season after a decade in the M.A.A.C., have a chance to leave the league they helped found with their second conference championship.
LEAD: TO ski and to study. That may seem like a prospect too perfect to be true for many high school students looking forward to college. But every year it is attained by thousands of young athletes.

LEAD: A less-than-impressive season in Italy may have motivated Danny Ferry, the former Duke all-American, to leave Il Messaggero Roma and sign with the Cleveland Cavaliers, Italy's largest sports daily has reported.
LEAD: HAVE you ever wondered why skiing is so difficult to learn? After all, gravity pulls you down the hill. All you really need to learn is to turn.

LEAD: * Boeing Co., Seattle, announced the retirements of Malcolm T. Stamper as vice chairman and Harold W. Haynes as executive vice president and chief financial officer. Boeing promoted Dean D. Thornton to the position of executive vice president; he will continue as president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group.

LEAD: Voters in the Slavic heartland of the Soviet Union went to the polls today in an exercise of limited democracy that pitted an array of grass-roots challengers against the vast Communist Party patronage network.

LEAD: There was, in a very real and sad sense, no reason for the Rangers to wait for yesterday morning's diagnoses. Over the years in such instances, the team has assumed the worst and rarely been wrong.

LEAD: The pianist Abbey Simon is to give a free piano recital on March 20 at 8 P.M. at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street. The event is part of the Faculty Recital Series at the school, where Mr. Simon has been a faculty member since 1977. On the program are Beethoven's Sonata No. 31 in A flat, Schumann's Fantasia in C and Liszt's ''Grandes Etudes de Paganini.

LEAD: Several hundred South African political prisoners have begun a hunger strike to force President F. W. de Klerk to release them under a general amnesty that could strengthen the negotiating position of the African National Congress.

LEAD: Thailand's armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, announced today in Bangkok that he would resign his post this month. It is widely expected that he will join the faltering Government as deputy prime minister.

LEAD: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday New-Car Sales Feb. Tuesday Factory Orders Jan. Wednesday Consumer Credit Jan. Productivity 4th Qtr. Thursday None Friday Unemployment
LEAD: The object looked suspicious. So Patrolman Ernest Silagyi pulled over to talk with the man carrying it down Mount Lucas Road in Princeton, N.J., yesterday morning.

LEAD: Leading members of the governing Likud party spoke out strongly today against a modified American proposal for peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. The rumblings of dissent came as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met with his three top Cabinet officials to discuss the plan, which the Israeli leader has reportedly leaned closer to accepting in recent days.

LEAD: The University of Maryland will be banned from postseason play this year and in 1991 under National Collegiate Athletic Association sanctions against the men's basketball program, a published report said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Television entertainment is often accused, justifiably, of being on a collision course with reality, and images of teen-agers are a particularly good case in point. Most daily headlines about young people are not encouraging as they follow crises ranging from education failures to drug abuse. Last week it was announced that New York City was doubling its staff of lawyers assigned to prosecute juveniles, because of an enormous surge in Family

LEAD: THE sun is setting behind the tennis courts and a clan of hump-backed raccoons assembles like spectators in the palm trees as Jennifer Capriati, the teen-ager voted most likely to take No. 1 away from Steffi Graf, attempts to wind down from her day.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The hurricane-force winds that have ripped Western Europe three times in the last six weeks, killing more than 140 people and costing perhaps a billion dollars in damage, marked the return of a weather phenomenon that had not often been seen in the last two decades.
LEAD: An article on Feb. 19 about regulation of doctors in Massachusetts misstated two provisions of state law.

LEAD: American Airlines Flight 40 from Los Angeles to New York suddenly lost cabin pressure and the pilots put it into a steep dive yesterday, dropping 25,000 feet in several minutes. No one was injured, an airline official said, but passengers on board said they thought they were going to crash.

LEAD: It's a new decade, and today at the Doral Ryder Open Greg Norman played sensational golf to answer those who spent the 1980's labeling him the golfer who has done less with more than anyone else in the game's history.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Friday about the bankruptcy proceedings of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. misidentified a creditor of one of the firm's subsidiaries. The creditor is the central bank of Portugal, not Puerto Rico.
LEAD: The day after he denied any involvement with point-shaving at North Carolina State, Charles Shackleford returned to practice with the Nets and tried to regain a sense of normality in his life.
LEAD: The space shuttle Atlantis landed here this morning, ending a secret military mission of four and a half days for its five astronauts.
LEAD: The residents of this city pride themselves on cordiality. But overnight, a pack of barking sea lions have emerged in San Francisco Bay, sometimes sorely testing the city's hospitality.

LEAD: ''Nobody knew about us. Now people come, and they say we are the most polluted town in the world.'' - Dr. Alexandru Balin of the occuptional health clinic at the metals factory in Copsa Mica, Romania. [A9:4.]

LEAD: Maybe the negotiators in the baseball labor dispute will meet today, after a weeklong recess, and maybe they won't. The only thing known for certain is that they will talk by telephone to discuss whether or not they want to meet.

LEAD: N.B.A. Bulls 118, Celtics 114: The league's free-throw leader, Larry Bird, missed a foul shot with 11.6 seconds left and a 3-pointer with 3 seconds left yesterday as Chicago extended its winning streak to eight games, its longest since 1980-81. (AP) Pistons 111, Pacers 105: Detroit, playing at home, held Indiana scoreless for 3:26 down the stretch for the Pistons' 18th victory in 19 games.

LEAD: NADIA COMANECI revisited the scene of her greatest triumph when she returned to Montreal last week. The former gymnast toured Olympic Stadium, where as a 14-year-old she scored seven perfect 10's and won three gold medals in 1976.

LEAD: For the last decade, this town has been known throughout Nicaragua as ''the cradle of the insurrection,'' in honor of the singular role that it played in helping the Sandinista Front overthrow Anastasio Somoza Debayle. But when Masaya residents voted last Sunday, they cast aside their reputation as Sandinista loyalists and voted for Violeta Barrios de
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., Dr. Kara Fae Sheinart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sheinart of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Joseph Alpert, a son of Meryl Alpert of Kew Gardens, Queens, and the late Louis Alpert. Rabbi David Moseson officiated.
LEAD: A Philippine general and 13 others were killed today when Government troops clashed with supporters of a provincial Governor who took over a hotel in Tuguegarao, 250 miles north of Manila.
LEAD: The urban school system here and the suburban district in nearby Millburn are separated by only six miles. Academically, socially and economically, they are worlds apart.
LEAD: A senior Iranian envoy discussed efforts to free Western hostages held in Lebanon when he met today with Syria's Foreign Minister, a Syrian said.
LEAD: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum might sell art from its permanent collection to help pay for its recent acquisition of more than 200 contemporary works from Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo.

LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.23 percent last week, down from 10.31 percent in the previous week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.48 percent last week, up from 8.44 percent the week before.
LEAD: Bela Karolyi gets so carried away whenever he talks about the great female gymnasts he has coached that it's easy to factor in a certain degree of skepticism as he gushes over his latest model.
LEAD: Nelson Mandela was enthusiastically greeted here today as an African nationalist hero by hundreds of South African exiles and thousands of Zimbabweans.

LEAD: The Nobel prizes were created by ALFRED NOBEL, the inventor of dynamite. Nitro Nobel Company, the Swedish company he founded, also awards a gold medal in the inventor's name, to a scientist who has discovered new ways to blow things up.

LEAD: Joseph Giarratano has spent most of the last 10 years in his cell in Mecklenburg Correctional Facility here, in the undeviating and claustrophobic universe of death row. But more than any of the nation's 2,500 other condemned inmates, his name has traveled beyond the prison walls.

LEAD: Dorothy James Roberts, a writer best known for her retelling of ancient Arthurian, Irish and Icelandic myths in historical romances, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. She was 96 and lived in Palo Alto.

LEAD: I resigned from the Israeli Government because I fear that its present political initiatives, even if founded in a sincere attempt to achieve peace, reward the Palestinians for their terrorism and increase the risks of war.

LEAD: In a move intended to bring products to market faster, the Upjohn Company is forming a unit, Upjohn Laboratories, that will integrate research and medical-affairs divisions into a single global operation. Dr. Jerry R. Mitchell will be its president.
LEAD: Someone will have to win the Kentucky Derby on May 5, but making an early selection is getting harder with each passing round of prep races.
LEAD: Susan G. Akst and Archie Granot were married yesterday in Mount Kisco, N.Y., at the home of the bride's sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Jay H. Schecter, by Rabbi Benjamin Blech.

LEAD: Fuzzy signals about the domestic economy and rising foreign interest rates are likely to create a standoff and keep interest rates in the United States in a narrow trading range - as long as the dollar remains strong, many analysts say.

LEAD: In a move that analysts say should calm jittery shareholders, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the troubled advertising and communications giant, confirmed today that it had arranged enough bank financing to see it through its current difficulties.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: King Rice scored 20 points to lead five players in double figures as North Carolina spoiled Duke's hopes for a share of first place in the Atlantic Coast Conference with an 87-75 victory over the Blue Devils today.
LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to bills, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and concluding with an auction of one-year bills on Thursday.
LEAD: Southern Tier Women's Services, one of two abortion clinics in Broome County, believes it has perfected the art of keeping unruly anti-abortion protesters off its premises.

LEAD: John M. Poindexter, the Navy admiral who said he made the decision to divert profits from the Iran arms sales to the Nicaraguan rebels, goes on trial Monday as the last of the original Iran-contra defendants to face charges.

LEAD: The Soviet Ambassador, YURI V. DUBININ, is giving a musicale at his embassy tonight,where the president of Oberlin College, S. FREDERICK STARR, plans to tell guests about the American Soviet Youth Orchestra.

LEAD: One-Team Famers Q. Jim Palmer, who will be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame this summer with Joe Morgan, spent his entire major league career pitching for the Baltimore Orioles. Among those members of the Hall admitted principally for their contributions as players, how many others also played for only one team in their major league careers?

LEAD: One day nine years ago, a 29-year-old firefighter from Yocona, Miss., named Larry Brown decided to become a writer. He sat down at his wife's portable electric typewriter and began seven months of work on a novel about a killer bear running amok in Yellowstone National Park.

LEAD: After a 20-month investigation, the British Government has decided not to bring any charges in connection with the 1985 takeover by the Fayed family of House of Fraser P.L.C., which owns Harrods, the renowned London department store.
LEAD: Three months ago, Ann Richards seemed headed for victory in this year's gubernatorial race in Texas - a handsome, witty woman apparently destined for stardom in the national Democratic Party.

LEAD: Security forces reportedly sealed off a city near Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, today after clashes with demonstrators. Officials said at least one soldier had been killed, but a protester reported many dead.
LEAD: Republicans are joyful that Jesse Jackson has chosen to become the black Stassen.
LEAD: A bicycle trailer for carting children is designed to fold for storage.
LEAD: The American publishing industry is in turmoil. Some leading publishers have been forced out; employees have been laid off, and companies are feeling more pressure to focus on profits.

LEAD: In an era in which the cold war is ending, the Germanys are moving toward reunification and the South African Government has legalized the major black opposition, is it possible to resolve trade disputes with Japan?

LEAD: The guards that Coach Chuck Granby of Andrew Jackson High School calls his ''two Teddies'' proved more than enough yesterday to eliminate Hillcrest from the second round of the Public Schools Athletic League tournament at Queensborough Community College.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday about an interview with Karl Otto Pohl, president of West Germany's central bank, mistranslated a comment on the possible rate at which East German marks will be converted to West German marks under a unification of the two economies. The quotation should have read, ''The better the rate is for the savers, the worse it will be for debtors,'' not creditors.
LEAD: Two Democratic committee leaders in the House of Representatives have angered some colleagues by engaging in independent negotiations with the White House on a hotly disputed child care bill.
LEAD: Some relatively simple changes in teaching methods can produce significant gains in learning for college students, according to a study made public yesterday by Harvard University.

LEAD: GENERATIONS of country-and-western singers have equated freeways with freedom, so it is unsurprising that this city ringed and spliced by highways should have become the center of the loosest and least formulaic automobile advertising done today.

LEAD: Managua to Keep Army President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has backed away from plans to abolish the Nicaraguan Army and will reduce its size gradually, her advisers say. Page A3. A Star Descending in Texas The gubernatorial campaign of Ann Richards, the State Treasurer, has stumbled on a question about whether she ever used illegal drugs.

LEAD: Although Eastern Airlines is beginning to attract more passengers and is likely to get an infusion of cash soon from its parent, the Texas Air Corporation, it still faces large hurdles in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy protection as a profitable regional carrier.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A basketball had just vanished, after a triumphant heave through the noise and into the largest crowd to see a game on a college campus. A net was disappearing at one end of the Carrier Dome, strand by strand, as the Orangemen of Syracuse University took turns sitting on one another's shoulders and the crowd of 33,015 kept its volume turned up.

LEAD: Motorola Inc. will introduce computer work stations today that company officials say will offer better performance and lower pricing than the systems introduced last month by the International Business Machines Corporation.

LEAD: One of the most prestigious positions in bridge journalism has a new occupant: Albert Dormer of London has succeeded Jeremy Flint, who died last November, as columnist for The Times of London, one of the world's most famous newspapers.

LEAD: International A3-9 Soviet people in the heartland voted in an election that raised the hopes of pro-democracy groups that they could oust the Communist rulers of Moscow, Leningrad and other large cities. Page A1

LEAD: Eastern Airlines' striking machinists marked the one-year anniversary of their walkout with demonstrations yesterday at more than half a dozen large airports. Officials on both sides said there was no end in sight to the labor dispute.
LEAD: A 27-year-old man who said he was robbed by drug dealers discovered the next day - to his surprise - that he had been shot in the stomach, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: General Assembly SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE ON OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR CONFERENCE ON ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT - 3 P.M.

LEAD: D. Herbert Lipson, the owner of Manhattan,inc., has been getting a lot of calls lately from admirers - and not just from people praising the magazine's splashy behind-the-scenes business articles. Some callers want to buy the magazine.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 4, 1990: MONDAY Albertsons Inc Harnischfeger Davis Wtr & Wste Inds Inc Rykoff Sexton Inc TUESDAY Alaska Air Group Inc Premier Indl Corp Premark Intl Inc WEDNESDAY Browning Ferris Inds Inc Neiman-Marcus Group Inc Chemical Wste Mgmt Inc Stanhome Inc Corroon & Black Corp Starrett L S Co Dillard Dept Stores Inc Tis Mtg Invt Co General Dynamics USF&G Corp Handleman Co Del Wolverine World Wide Inc Helmerich & Payne Inc

LEAD: With daring and precision, two armed men in masks walked off one recent night with more than 200 valuable statuettes, vases and other objects that had been found in the remains here of the ancient Roman city of Herculaneum.
LEAD: The headline of an obituary on Saturday about Scott Jarvis, an actor and singer, misstated his age. He was 48 years old.

LEAD: A decorated counterintelligence specialist for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Miami lost his security clearance and was suspended as a result of a nearly three-year investigation that has involved allegations of espionage for Cuba, Government officials and friends of the agent say.

LEAD: COMPANIES American Express will buy Shearson's outstanding shares, after trying for months to find an outside investor so that it could reduce its 68 percent stake. Talks with Primerica nearly produced an agreement but broke down over financial issues, said Sanford I. Weill of Primerica, who built Shearson into a powerhouse and then sold it to American Express.

LEAD: Still another premiere by Eliot Feld? The fourth this season is ''Charmed Lives,'' whose charm, indeed, lies in the choreographer's gentler treatment of pure movement compared with the mathematical hard edge of some of his recent pieces.
LEAD: So violent is the Bronx neighborhood where Homer Goodwin died that rumors of his brutal murder were accepted as gospel.

LEAD: According to the Supreme Court's peculiar reasoning last week, the Fourth Amendment does not protect a foreigner from a warrantless search by Americans of his home in his native country, and the use of seized evidence at his trial in this country. This 6-to-3 decision is to jurisprudence what gunboats are to diplomacy.

LEAD: State Senator Abraham Bernstein, a Bronx Democrat who served almost 30 years in the Legislature and whose district stretched from Riverdale to Co-op City, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: Andy Rooney, suspended from the CBS News program ''60 Minutes'' last month over remarks attributed to him that offended blacks and homosexuals, returned to the program last night, not with an outright apology, but with the kind of commentary he is known for: provocative questions sprinkled with personal observations.
LEAD: Gerard Blitz, founder of the Club Mediterranee empire of vacation villages billed as an ''antidote to civilization,'' has died, company officials said today. He was 78 years old.
LEAD: The candidate had been well smeared by broadsides stuffed at the last minute into the mailboxes of the tenement warrens of Communism in the dawn of Election Day in Byelorussia.
LEAD: The 78th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases collected a total of $4,372,283, surpassing last year's record by more than $332,000.

LEAD: A company that recently expanded to become the largest supplier of concrete in the New York metropolitan area is under Federal investigation for possible financial irregularities and ties to organized crime, according to lawyers, officials and others familiar with the inquiry.
LEAD: In an abrupt about-face, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would buy all the publicly held shares of its brokerage firm, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
LEAD: Thousands of people cheered and danced in the streets with soldiers today after military officers overthrew the Government of Ciskei, the nominally independent South African homeland.

LEAD: Frank X. Graves Jr., the longtime Mayor of Paterson, N.J., and also a State Senator for many years, died after a heart attack yesterday morning at his home in the Lakeview section of the city. He was 66 years old.
LEAD: HIS English is limited, so Sergei Beloglazov teaches with body language. And what better sport could there be for that than wrestling?
LEAD: The Devils made a number of mental mistakes against the Capitals this afternoon and took another step backward only two days after they had crawled forward in the Patrick Division race.

LEAD: Hank Gathers of Loyola Marymount University, one of the leading scorers in National Collegiate Athletic Association history, died tonight after collapsing on the court during Loyola Marymount's game against Portland. He was 23 years old.

LEAD: The number of jobs in American health care is soaring at a rate three times faster than the growth of the population, troubling experts concerned about the sharp rise in the nation's medical costs. Thirty-seven of every 1,000 Americans worked in health care last year, compared with about 28 for every 1,000 just 10 years earlier.

LEAD: The fans at North Carolina State's Reynolds Coliseum wore yellow V-shaped ribbons to express their support for Jim Valvano today, and they greeted the embattled basketball coach with a standing ovation.

LEAD: Lacrosse, a spring sport now played at 203 colleges, will be different this season. Subtle rules changes aimed at a swifter tempo will mean less dawdling around with the ball, and one defensive specialist, waving a long stick, has been struck out.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: From time immemorial, the Papago Indians have lived in the harsh desert here, roaming back and forth across what is today the United States-Mexico border. But after fending off conquistadors, miners, ranchers, armies and other Indian tribes, the Papago now confront perhaps the most dangerous threat to their existence: the international drug trade.

LEAD: Lisa Steinberg and Lee Snow were married yesterday at Nanou, a Manhattan restaurant. Rabbis Kenneth Hain and Irwin Isaacson officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Steinberg of Brooklyn. Her husband is a son of Frances Snow of Brooklyn and the late Mel Snow.

LEAD: If Hollywood press agents had X-ray vision, they would all be trying to pierce the white polyester curtain in Gilbert Cates's office on Sunset Boulevard. The curtain hides a bulletin board plastered with salmon and white index cards, each with a movie star's name on it. The stars are candidates to present one or another of the Oscars at the 62d annual Academy Awards presentations on television in three weeks.

LEAD: For about 15 miles around, every growing thing in this once-gentle valley looks as if it has been dipped in ink. Trees and bushes are black; the grass is stained. The houses and streets look like the inside of a chimney. Even the sheep on the hillsides are a dingy gray.
LEAD: There is one big optimist in this country of great economic changes and political tensions. His name is Ante Markovic, and he happens to be the Prime Minister.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the Federal Census Bureau had omitted a 21-story apartment building on the Lower East Side, along with other buildings and blocks, from a list of the sites in New York City that it intends to canvass in this year's census.

LEAD: Leslie Winship 2d, a former vice president of Dartmouth College, died of a heart attack Friday at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. He was 68 years old and lived in Hanover.

LEAD: As he was giving a speech yesterday morning in Washington, LEE ATWATER, chairman of the Republican National Committee, collapsed. He was taken to George Washington Hospital, where he was to spend the night. A hospital spokesman said a series of tests were inconclusive.

LEAD: Leo Melamed, whose leadership transformed the Chicago Mercantile Exchange from a sleepy backwater where mostly agricultural products were traded into a leading arena for the management of interest-rate and currency risks, announced today that he would relinquish his exchange duties at the end of the year.
LEAD: A suspect in the killings of two New York City women surrendered to F.B.I. agents after being coaxed down from a rooftop where he frantically dared them to shoot him, the authorities said.

LEAD: Though ''Woyzeck'' was written in the 1830's, it is a seminal play of the 20th century, the first to articulate the alienation of modern man driven to madness by forces far beyond his control. In a sequence of cumulative scenes, Buchner's play - based on a true story - follows the downward path of a barber who murders his mistress and suffers tragic consequences.

LEAD: The Cesar awards, the French equivalent of the Oscars, this year went mostly to ''Too Beautiful for You.'' LEAD: PEOPLE who own microwave ovens are often asked by friends, ''Do you use that thing much?'' Notice they do not even use the term ''cook.'' The answers will vary depending on how the owner uses the oven. Some use it for everything because they like the coolness and easy cleanup as much as the speed, while others make only certain foods that are quicker or better when made in the microwave oven, including vegetables and fish.

LEAD: AFTER a 30-day legal battle and lobbying effort, the United States Department of Agriculture has reversed itself and will permit Bart Ehman, a chicken rancher in Sebastopol, Calif., to use the label ''Rocky the Range Chicken'' on the birds he has been raising and selling in the western United States for five years.

LEAD: The First Boston Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Michael J. Kugler as a managing director and head of its government securities business. LEAD: ''I'm angry that I don't have my drug,'' the pregnant woman said last week. ''I miss my drug.''

LEAD: Dr. Edgar Raymond Lorch, an author and a leader in the development of modern mathematics theory, died on Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Soviet Parliament voted yesterday to allow citizens to own the ''means of production'' and create small-scale factories, making fundamental changes in the Soviet economic system as described by the nation's Constitution. LEAD: If Supreme Court opinions were paintings, art critics would have trouble defining the Supreme Court style. Sometimes the Court paints with broad strokes, splashing color across the canvas as boldly as any Abstract Expressionist. Sometimes it draws delicately, the results as fragile and fine as a Persian miniature, precise as Pointillism, or filled with Renaissance shadings of light and shadow.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said that it would raise prices 3 percent for many of its computers, 4 to 5 percent for selected printers and 10 percent for services and many of its software products. ''The Handmaid's Tale'' is that rare totalitarian fantasy in which the tyrants plant tulips and wear pearls. The United States, now renamed Gilead, has become a male-controlled police state dedicated to the oppression of women, yet there are very few men in either Margaret Atwood's novel or Volker Schlondorff's film version. The men are either roaming the corridors of power, fighting as soldiers called Angels, or (if they are nonwhite) relegated to far-flung colonies in badly polluted parts of the world. So for the most part, it is only the women we see. Women called Aunts, dressed in high heels and loose, demure brown outfits that would have been just right for office jobs in the days when women were still allowed to hold them, are now in charge of teaching moral pieties and laying down the law. Women called Wives wear an overpowering shade of blue and preside over large houses in the suburbs. Women called Marthas, in gray-green maids' uniforms, keep these houses running smoothly. Women called Handmaids dress in red and have been robbed of all rights, reduced to only two basic functions: breeding babies (because pollution has rendered most other women barren) and buying groceries.

LEAD: For two decades, the composer La Monte Young has been presenting grandiose, mystic concerts in which musicians groan away for hours accompanying a dense electronic drone, sitting in a dark, hieratic visual environment. These events, which have been fairly infrequent in recent years, are called Dream Houses, and the collection of musicians - who over the years have included some of the brightest lights of ''downtown'' experimental music - is called the Theater of Eternal Music.

LEAD: ANYONE who wants an antique bed or bed frame knows the predicament. LEAD: Virgil M. Rogers, a former dean of education at Syracuse University who had served as a local school superintendent in three states died Saturday at the Birchwood Care Center in Syracuse, N.Y. He was 92 years old and lived in Syracuse.

LEAD: Bruce Sutter, who achieved 300 saves in a 12-season career as a reliever and was one of the first pitchers to have success with the split-finger fastball, has returned to the St. Louis Cardinals as a minor league pitching instructor.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in extremely lethargic trading yesterday, as dealers watched developments in the foreign exchange markets and waited for the release tomorrow morning of February employment data.

LEAD: Gene therapy for human disease took a leap from the theoretical realms of the laboratory toward the real world of practicing medicine today. A National Institutes of Health panel approved a proposal to treat children with a severe genetic disease by inserting new genes into their blood cells.

LEAD: In another sign that the Government is easing its tough austerity policy, one of China's biggest banks said today that it would provide more than $500 million in new loans to troubled enterprises in China's principal industrial regions.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: Mexico announced plans today to sell off the nation's two leading steel companies, including its third-largest state-owned enterprise, as part of a sweeping privatization program.

LEAD: Congressional investigators are expected to announce today that they will seek immunity for a former top aide to Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Reagan Administration's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, in exchange for what the investigators say will be some of the most damaging testimony to date about Mr.

LEAD: The Knicks came to Philadelphia tonight to protect the Atlantic Division lead they had held since Nov. 18, when the National Basketball Association season was only 15 days old. But by the time the game at the Spectrum was one period old, it was obvious that they were not only going to relinquish the lead to the 76ers, but they were also going to be embarrassed.

LEAD: As the Soviet Union's barriers crumble, so certainly in time will one of the last remaining musical enclaves of idiosyncratic style. The Soviet school has prospered perhaps by its isolation; and in the process, it has more or less ignored contemporary trends toward lighter, finer musical phrasing and attention to historical accuracy.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has demanded that Lithuania pay compensation equivalent to $33 billion if the republic goes ahead with plans to secede from the Soviet Union, Lithuanian officials said today.

LEAD: Troy Muilenburg scored 14 points and Northern Iowa sank crucial free throws down the stretch tonight as the Panthers beat Wisconsin-Green Bay, 53-45, in the championship game of the Association of Mid-Continent Universities tournament.

LEAD: ''It's hip to be square,'' went the refrain of a rock tune popular a couple of years ago. Could there be better evidence of that than Fred Rogers, star of the Public Broadcasting System's longest-running show, ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood''?

LEAD: After years of efforts to recruit more minority students, law schools are beginning to make progress, with 22 percent more minority students enrolled in the current school year than three years ago, the American Bar Association reports.
LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday upheld a Federal policy barring family planning aid to private foreign organizations that perform abortions.

LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran denied today that any direct negotiations had been held with the United States on the fate of Western hostages in Lebanon. But he said in a news conference that American messages on the hostages had reached Teheran through Westerners and other intermediaries.
LEAD: The state Attorney General's office and a private lawyer will help North Carolina State negotiate a contract settlement with Coach Jim Valvano, officials said Wednesday.

LEAD: For the first time in more than 400 years, the Catholic Church is preparing to issue a comprehensive summary of its beliefs aimed at governing church teaching throughout the world, an effort that has provoked a sharp dispute among church scholars.

LEAD: State budget negotiations took a novel turn today when leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate said that they would ignore the spending plan Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed in January. Instead, the leaders said, they will work from last year's budget and increase spending only where they think it is essential.
LEAD: His Beatitude Archbishop Shnork Kaloustian, the Patriarch of the Armenians in Turkey, died Tuesday at Nork Hospital in Yerevan, Soviet Armenia. He was 76 years old and lived in Istanbul.
LEAD: * Counihan, Bridgewater & Associates has merged with Louden, Kaplan & Elegant to form Counihan, Bridgewater, Elegant Inc., with offices at 747 Third Ave. in Manhattan.

LEAD: Arthur Fletcher, the newly appointed chairman of the Federal Civil Rights Commission, today underwent his second triple-bypass heart operation in less than six months. Mr. Fletcher, 65 years old, entered George Washington University Hospital on Monday after doctors concluded that previous bypass surgery ''didn't take,'' said Barbara Brooks, a commission spokeswoman.
LEAD: A forensic expert from a genetic testing laboratory said today that bloodstains found at the scene of Kelly Ann Tinyes's slaying had identical DNA ''fingerprints'' to the blood of Robert Golub.

LEAD: More than 100,000 gallons of home heating oil spilled into the Arthur Kill on Tuesday after two mysterious explosions ripped apart a barge that had just taken on 4.2 million gallons of oil, Coast Guard officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Nobody will accuse liberals of having led the political debate during the past decade or so. Indeed, many liberals themselves acknowledge, a bit ruefully, that the ideas that made a difference in the 1970's and 80's came more often than not from conservatives. But a small group of liberal writers and professors, many with national reputations, are starting a new journal, hoping it will become the focal point of a renewal.

LEAD: The multiple oil spills that have sullied the waters in and near the Arthur Kill in recent months threaten to reverse the progress that has been made in restoring wildlife to the narrow waterway separating New Jersey and Staten Island, environmentalists said yesterday.

LEAD: Francis X. Smith, a top New York City judge jailed for perjury in a corruption scandal, was released from jail last month after having served two months of his one-year sentence. He said yesterday that his short time behind bars had reinforced opinions he had held as a judge.

LEAD: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday showing the 1989 population of bald eagles described the National Wildlife Federation's midwinter eagle survey incompletely and omitted or misstated figures for some states. The survey includes migratory Canadian eagles and does not reflect the status of the nesting population of the lower 48 states; not all states are covered in the survey.

LEAD: Joe Sewell, the sharp-eyed batter who struck out only 114 times in a 14-year major league career, died on Tuesday at his home in Mobile, Ala. Mr. Sewell, who was elected to the Hall of Fame by the veterans committee in 1977, was 91 years old and lived with his son, Dr. James W. Sewell.

Buddy (Arye Gross) is the middle brother, the peacemaker, the one who wears Bermuda shorts and loves a girl named Tammy.

LEAD: Erotic passion run amok is one of the hardest things to portray on the stage without its seeming either tinnily melodramatic or unintentionally funny. If the Intar Stage 2's production of Ana Maria Simo's heavy-breathing drama, ''Going to New England,'' has moments that seem both shrill and silly, her play still deserves credit for trying to go below the surface of soap opera histrionics to get at the primal emotions that erupt when sexual feelings go out of control.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: STEPHEN POTTER, the author of ''Gamesmanship'' and ''One-Upmanship,'' said an economist has two basic ploys. The first, labeled Economic Approach A, is to cloak the obvious in ''a little wild incomprehensibility.'' Thus, Mr. Potter's model economist, named Regil, would tell listeners that if they wanted to influence ''the general liquidity situation of banks and public,'' they had better not forget that the central bank's ''discretionary action on the cash basis took the shape of dealings in Treasury bills, the market rate of discount on which could and did fluctuate.

LEAD: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said today that the military had been purged of mutinous soldiers, but the renegade general who led a violent coup attempt said from hiding that he would keep fighting.

LEAD: A number of new faces have worked their way into the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Faust.'' Judging from Wednesday evening's performance, they have not mitigated its problems, and as is so often the case in cast-change situations at the Met, stagecraft has been loosened and ensemble blurred.

LEAD: The French are fond of wearing and bestowing medals, and last night in New York they awarded the medal of Chevalier des Arts et Lettres to three New Yorkers: the artists ELLSWORTH KELLY and FRANK STELLA, and the chief dance critic of The New York Times, ANNA KISSELGOFF.

LEAD: The USX Corporation, the giant steel and energy company, said yesterday that it had agreed to allow shareholders to vote on a proposal by the investor Carl C. Icahn to incorporate the steel business and spin off at least 80 percent of the company.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins, keeping a political promise, said yesterday that he would let the New York City Fire Department reopen Engine Company 41 in the South Bronx, a firehouse that Mayor Edward I. Koch closed last year, after a long, bitter fight, to save money.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said its 1989 profits would generate $166 million in profit-sharing payments, or about $1,025 for each employee, roughly one-third of last year's amount and the lowest payout since 1984.

LEAD: THE soliloquy is at least as old as Shakespeare, but it was not until the late 18th century that Johann Christian Brandes, a German actor and playwright, invented the monodrama. A short solo entertainment often accompanied by a chorus, it was used to lengthen an otherwise brief evening of theater.

LEAD: The Supreme Court has shed all pretense of neutral justice on the matter of Federal court relief for state prisoners, especially those on death row. Not content with rejecting most death penalty appeals, a five-justice majority is now doing all it can to close the Federal courts even to inmates with meritorious legal claims.

LEAD: THIS November, Staten Island voters are supposed to go to the polls to decide whether their borough should takes steps to secede from the rest of New York City. The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, does not want the vote to take place. Nor does the Mayor of New York City, David N.

LEAD: Does it make sense to tax Iowa farmers so that suburban commuters can take the train into Philadelphia? No, says Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner in the Administration's long-awaited transportation policy statement: Transportation facilities produce local benefits. Let local governments pay more for their upkeep.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James Bonbright Ketcham of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Bruce Ketcham to Thomas Mark Donahue, the son of Beatrice Donahue of Barre, Vt., and Bare Foot Bay, Fla., and the late Howard Donahue. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Laura S. Hill and Lyle G. Clark 3d, financial executives in New York, were married yesterday at the Marriott River Center in San Antonio by the Rev. Nell Linebarger, a United Methodist minister and an aunt of the bride. The bride, a daughter of Mrs. Crawford Reeder and Edward Hill, both of San Antonio, will keep her name.

LEAD: An article on Feb. 25 about Princeton Entrepreneurial Resources, a consulting concern that matches companies with executives temporarily, misstated the percentage of its clients who are early retirees, 50 years old and over. It is 18 percent, not 80.

LEAD: One of the more curious objects at the Museum of Modern Art in New York sits on a long table in the fifth-floor office of Kirk Varnedoe. It's a square white mat populated by what seem to be high-tech chessmen, or futuristic warriors in a space-age board game. They are, actually, foam-core replicas of the museum's Brancusi sculptures, and they are giving Varnedoe, the museum's new director of painting and sculpture, a tough fight.
LEAD: DON'T TELL THE GROWN-UPS Subversive Children's Literature. By Alison Lurie. 229 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

LEAD: James Barbagallo's thoughtful and elegant choice of music for his Alice Tully Hall piano recital on Thursday night pretty much reflected the thoughtfulness and elegance with which it was addressed. Mr. Barbagallo played four Debussy pieces -including one of the neglected masterpieces of the keyboard literature, ''Hommage a Rameau'' - Schumann's Second Sonata, ''Masks'' by Robert Muczynsky and three pieces by Chopin.

LEAD: In French, the word ''Vitrine'' conjures up the imaginary and unattainable world that exists behind glass in shop windows and showcases. And each year, the glass of the now-famous gallery-long vitrine in the costume exhibitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art must be cleaned of fingerprints several times a week, as the crowds press in for a closer look at the magical array of small decorative accessories that have become the heart of the shows.

LEAD: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Clean Air Act: Vote to amend the Clean Air Act to strike a provision that removes the existing authority of the Environmental Protection Agency and the states from regulating radioactive emissions at Nuclear Regulatory Commission centers, by making the commission the sole regulator.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Don King, the boxing promoter, has been hit with a violation citation by the Landmarks Preservation Commission because he changed the facade of a town house he owns at 32 East 69th Street without obtaining a permit as required by law. The five-story building, which is used as the headquarters of Don King Productions, is within the boundaries of the East Side Historic

LEAD: The clergyman whose defiance helped start the rebellion that toppled Romania's Communist dictatorship in December says he believes that centrist forces can retain enough strength in elections on May 20 to maintain momentum toward democracy.

LEAD: In Boris Spassky's contract for the Linares International Tournament, which began Feb. 18 in Spain, one clause read that he must, ''not make any compromises before move 40.'' The tournament sponsor, Luis Rentero, did not want the former world champion to show up in body but not in spirit, aiming for quick draws, as he so often does.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Bernard of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Pamela Jill Bernard to Dr. Richard Scott Shames and of their daughter Jacqueline Lee Bernard to Mark Scott Rosenbaum.

LEAD: The engagement of Robin Dunn Smith to Charles Howard Swanberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund R. Swanberg of New Canaan, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Smith of Hamden, Conn. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Holding the coach or athletic director responsible for the current state of big-time college basketball or football is like placing the blame for typhoid fever on Typhoid Mary.
LEAD: HAPPY TALK Confessions of a TV Newsman. By Fred Graham. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Lois Touhey of Albany has announced the engagement of her daughter Amy Conklin to James Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Rose of Locust Valley, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $5.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington, the other in Hollywood. 2 6 WEB OF DREAMS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) The origin of a curse that has haunted a family of orphans in five previous novels.

LEAD: SOONER or later, anyone whose work involves issues related to AIDS could encounter the militant tactics of the group called Act-Up. For some scientists and Federal officials, it happened last August at a public meeting of the Food and Drug Administration in Washington.

LEAD: Aaron Bisno arrived at Washington University here having heard of women's issues, but never thinking about how they might relate to him. Three-and-a-half years later, he is a founder and leader of a campus group working to help men see the connection he eventually discovered.
LEAD: The Department of Energy says it will propose procedures to protect nuclear weapons workers who complain about health or safety violations from retaliation by their employers.
LEAD: A man convicted in a murder that was cited by the group claiming responsibility for two deadly mail bombs was sentenced Friday to die in the electric chair.
LEAD: Marilyn Jane Abraham and Alexander MacGregor 3d were married yesterday at their home in Mahopac, N.Y., by the Rev. Ann Tyndal, a Unitarian minister.

LEAD: The ''All About'' column on Feb. 25, discussing modems, misidentified a company listed among those dominant in that market. It is Multi-Tech Systems Inc. of Mounds View, Minn., not the Acer America Corporation. The article also referred incorrectly to the Telebit Corporation. It was one of the first makers of cellular telephone modems, not the first.

LEAD: A PROPOSAL to build a new public library in Seaford has divided this South Shore community, but the issue may be resolved Wednesday, when Seaford residents will vote on a $4 million bond issue to finance construction of the building.

LEAD: Christina Ann Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Johnson of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to Eelco Dewitt Swaak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reyer Swaak of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Robin Capoor officiated at the Unitarian Fellowship in Morristown, N.J.

LEAD: IT was hardly the opening gun in Communism's going-out-of-business sale, but Soviet citizens have just been awarded the right to own the ''means of production,'' decades after the revolution forsook the notion of private property.

LEAD: ''All's well that ends well,'' said Mike Wallace, without attribution. Andy Rooney was back on ''60 Minutes'' and everybody at CBS was happy about it, especially those who had suspended him. Not only that: Mr. Rooney expressed gratitude to the groups that sought to have him punished; it had been a learning experience.

LEAD: Elizabeth Streb is one of several choreographers who during the past two decades have based dances upon athletic or gymnastic movement. Whereas some of them make gymnastics seem witty or fantastic, Ms. Streb emphasizes effort for its own sake. At their best, her works resemble vigorous games. At their worst, they are displays of stress and strain.

LEAD: Jeanne McWilliams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. McWilliams of Dallas, was married yesterday at the Burden mansion in New York to John Michael Blasberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Blasberg Jr. of Boston. Judge Harold Silverman of the New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony. Donelle Aileen Howser was the maid of honor and John Keenan

LEAD: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on Feb. 25 included an outdated entry under the heading ''Restricted Fare.'' The $298 round-trip fare offered by T.W.A. between New York and Paris expired on Feb. 15.

LEAD: Given the somewhat shaky condition of the state of matrimony these days, one wonders at times how serious the recent marriage of food and wine really is. As someone once said about a prominent wedding: ''Too bad. It ended a beautiful relationship.''

LEAD: Collaboration makes a partnership work, and the best collaborations often bring together people with complementary talents. Such is the secret of Esti/Frederica's success. The New York jewelry company is run by Esti Scharf, while the jewelry is designed and sold by Frederica Zwiebel.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Take a jacket made of fake lamb's fur, line it with polka-dot dress silk, and what have you got? An imaginative and versatile piece of clothing that has suddenly captured imaginations on both sides of the Atlantic. The jacket, designed by Dolce & Gabbana in Milan, Italy, is reversible, so it can look like a fur (actually a pile fabric that resembles caracul) with polka-dot cuffs, or a polka-dot jacket with fur cuffs and collar.

LEAD: The attitude about gossip these days reminds me of an attitude people had about sex 20 years ago. It was called the sexual revolution, and it was as tiresome as can be. It ignored any possibility that people had copulated in Edsels, or that bonafide grandparents had in the past-and perhaps in the present - chased one another around the kitchen in their underwear.

LEAD: Yienan Song offered an imaginative and strangely soothing evening of dance in ''Daughters and Sons From Atlantis'' on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church (Claremont Avenue and 120th Street), where her Ancient of Days Dance Theater performs the piece through tonight.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. W. Loeber Landau of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna Ellen Landau to John Louis Hardiman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Hardiman of Bridgeport, Conn. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Glenn Rifkin is features editor of Computerworld, a weekly trade newspaper, and co-author of ''The Ultimate Entrepreneur.''

LEAD: It was Rap Day at John Dewey High School last week, and most of the workshops focused on sex and drugs. But in room 343, it was standing room only as students, teachers and professionals discussed the really hot topic of the times - the rights of illegal immigrant children.

LEAD: Six students were arrested last week at the University of California at Irvine in a demonstration protesting Chancellor Jack W. Peltason's refusal to permit gay and lesbian couples to live in family dormitories. The demonstrators blocked an entrance to the administration building.

LEAD: Just two days after the United States Golf Association had declared golf shoes worn by John Huston in the PGA Tour Honda Classic to be illegal, the maker of the shoes, the Weight-Rite Golf Corporation of Tampa, Fla., plans to seek judicial relief.

LEAD: Mike Tomczak, the Chicago Bears quarterback from Ohio State, has started an endowment to pay for a grant-in-aid for an Ohio State quarterback. He will contribute $100,000 over the next five years to provide the fund a $7,500 annual scholarship. . . . Dale Ellis of the Seattle SuperSonics, who suffered three broken ribs in an automobile accident on Jan.

LEAD: A picture caption on Feb. 25 misidentified a building in East Berlin. It was the Museum of German History, not the German State Opera House. The caption also referred imprecisely to the tower in the background. It is more commonly known as the Fernsehturm (television tower); the tower known as the Funkturm (radio tower) is in West Berlin.

LEAD: Electric utilities have flourished in the United States during the last half-century by virtue of being monopolies. But those monopolies are giving way to a new order as a growing number of small, independent power producers, and now joint ventures with the utilities themselves, enter the industry.

LEAD: This is the other shoe dropping. Two weeks ago, we talked here about the Infiniti Q45 sedan, Nissan's $38,000 would-be resident of the lux-lux neighborhood. But there is also a second Infiniti, very different and considerably less expensive, albeit equally high-falutin.
LEAD: Classy Irene, unbeaten in five races, heads a field of nine 3-year-old fillies Sunday in the $50,000-added Magnolia Stakes at Oaklawn Park.
LEAD: FEZZIWIGS

LEAD: ''My garden will never make me famous/ I'm a horticultural ignoramus,'' wrote Ogden Nash, but he did not know about the South Garden at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. For this garden was designed by two people who know relatively little about horticulture, the artist Jennifer Bartlett and the architect Alexander

LEAD: So far this week, a 13-year-old ponytailed phenomenon with a pink-handled racquet and a redoubtable backbone has ignored her homework and shredded her opponents. School is being held in abeyance as Jennifer Capriati, already a millionaire and evidently a genius, at least on the tennis court, continues to write her own history.

LEAD: Standing shoulder to shoulder, their eyes shaded by Mountie hats, they looked like extras from a Nelson Eddy movie. But these young men were models, costumed for winter by Valentino, one of Italy's reigning fashion designers. And their cinematically scarlet jackets, lumberjack shirts and Hudson Bay blanket coats were not destined for the wilds but for some of the most exclusive men's shops in cities on several continents.

LEAD: What will be one of the few housing developments in Westchester County adjacent to a nine-hole golf course is being built in the Village of Pleasantville. Named the Country Club at Pleasantville, the project will contain 72 two-story town house units in a cluster of 15 buildings. The units, the first of which is due to be finished late this summer, will have either two or three bedrooms and range from 2,400 to 3,400 square feet.

LEAD: A chart last Sunday under the headline ''National Output'' gave an incorrect value for the gross national products of several countries. The numbers represented trillions of dollars, not billions.
LEAD: Rossini at the Pierre

LEAD: Some video manufacturers hesitate to bring technically advanced and correspondingly costly products to the United States. Market research tells them that - unlike in Japan, Germany, Switzerland and Scandinavia, where there is widespread interest in technology - only 4 to 5 percent of American video buyers appreciate advanced engineering enough to pay a higher price.

LEAD: The Manhattan Marimba Quartet and Women of the Calabash opened a series called New Riffs at Town Hall on Tuesday night. The idea of combining the two groups seemed odd. The Marimba Quartet performs written works in the European classical tradition, dryly. The Women of the Calabash celebrates the African diaspora with songs and percussion, sentimentally.
LEAD: While the cold war may be over, we in Washington are locked in a campaign- spending arms race.
LEAD: The informative article ''Enrollment Slips at Many Private Schools'' focused almost exclusively on the marketing-related efforts to deal with this problem.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: SOVIET WOMEN Walking the Tightrope. By Francine du Plessix Gray. 213 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

LEAD: Top-quality corporate bonds were among the first casualties of the takeover craze that defined the Drexel era on Wall Street. With each new debt-laden deal, another set of corporate investors awoke to find that their bonds, blue-chip assets the night before, were suddenly on their way to the junk heap.
LEAD: SUFFOLK Community College has a classroom shortage. So much space is needed for remedial courses that the standard college departments are being squeezed into fewer rooms.

LEAD: Federal law now allows the Government to seize drug barons' wealth - mansions, yachts, sports cars - and give a share to local cops who may have helped with the prosecution. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh calls that ''poetic justice.'' There is good reason to worry about distorted justice as well.

LEAD: A committee set up at Simon's Rock of Bard College has exonerated three professors accused by students of sexual harassment. The committee, comprising two students, two faculty members and one administrator, recommended unanimously that no disciplinary action be taken against the professors.

LEAD: The engagement of Betsey Trent Winsor to John Hartley Watlington Jr., a son of Mrs. Watlington of Mangrove Bay, Bermuda, and the late Mr. Watlington, has been made known by her parents, Gayle Winsor of Asheville, N.C., and Fred Winsor of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: I have to wonder why you would print an article by someone whose paranoia seems to have gotten the best of her - and her family, too.

LEAD: WANDERING through duty-free shops to try on sleek Ebel watches, inhale seductive fragrances or admire the frosted curves of Lalique crystal has become as much a part of the itinerary for many travelers as lolling on pristine beaches or visiting landmark museums and temples.

LEAD: Many people think that laissez-faire capitalism will be a workable model for the redevelopment of the socialist economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Western advisers have consistently pushed for the creation of markets, free pricing and currency systems and an economy built on private enterprises.

LEAD: At a time when the intentions of the contras are crucial to Nicaragua's newly elected government, the Bush Administration finds it has less and less sway over the rebel force that Washington created and sustained for nearly a decade, Administration officials say.

LEAD: In the 1950's heyday of the ''Baroque revival'' - how dim and distant that sounds, in this age of the early-music movement - the marketplace was flooded with integral ''i's'' and ''ini's.'' The long-playing record had just taken over the record business, and multidisk boxed sets proliferated of the complete concerti grossi of Vivaldi, Corelli, Albinoni, Galuppi, Torelli, Locatelli, Manfredini, Geminiani, Tartini and Boccherini.

LEAD: The value of paper money is just a chimera unless you can convince someone of its worth. Today our conviction in the value of United States dollars is so high so that we accept them without a second thought although the bills are only redeemable in other bills or coins made of nearly worthless alloy.
LEAD: A Queens woman was found stabbed to death in her bed Friday afternoon, and detectives later charged her 19-year-old nephew with killing her, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Jacqueline Diane Ryan, a manager of customer service and marketing at Citibank in Long Island City, Queens, was married last evening to Michael Gordon Zapson, the vice president of the City Council of Long Beach, L.I., at the Metropolitan restaurant in Glen Cove, L.I. Judge Jerome B. Fleischman of Long Beach City

LEAD: A panel of prominent West Coast artists defended their freedom of creativity and denounced censorship at a Congressional hearing this week at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, and they urged continued Federal support without restrictions for the National Endowment for the Arts.

LEAD: Why is baseball so consistently unable to reach collective bargaining agreements without a work stoppage? Since 1972, a strike or a lockout has occurred each time the old contract expired. The record of conflict stems partly from the need for the union to break down the system of paternalism and impediments to freedom in the players' labor market.

LEAD: The business executive couldn't believe his eyes. His golfing partner had gone off in search of a lost ball and when he followed unexpectedly, there was the man he believed he knew pretty well surreptitiously nudging along the ball with the toe of his shoe.

LEAD: MORE than a decade after computer networks have become well traveled highways for data, deals, ideas and information, lawmakers and computer users are still trying to define the rules of the road.

LEAD: Callaway Anne Ludington, a business reporter, and Michael Paul Zuccarello, a sports columnist, both in St. Louis, plan to marry in September. Miss Ludington is the daughter of Gail C. Ludington of Boston and William F. Ludington of Stamford, Conn. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis C. Zuccarello of Poughkeepsie, N
LEAD: A knot of solemn boys is gathered in front of a table draped with the red flag of Albania on which rests the framed color photograph of a young man.
