LEAD: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW described Hedda Gabler, the title character in Henrik Ibsen's play, as a woman with no ethical ideals, only romantic ones. He said that she had imagination and an intense appetite for beauty, but no conscience, no convictions.
LEAD: A letter tells us: ''I went to a local audio store and asked about the . . . loudspeaker you wrote about. The dealer said, 'Never heard of it.' Then he tried to sell me something else.''

LEAD: Field of Dreams 1989. MCA. No suggested retail price. Laser disk. $34.98. 1 hour. 46 minutes. Closed Captioned. PG. An Iowa farmer named Ray Kinsella (Kevin Costner), his wife (Amy Madigan) and a prize-winning 60's author and political activist (James Earl Jones) are the prime movers in this fantasy about the creation of a baseball field in a cornfield so that Shoeless Joe Jackson and other mythic greats can come back to life to play.
LEAD: The principals in baseball's labor dispute remained quiet yesterday but not inactive.

LEAD: A November wedding is planned by Katherine deLancey Joyce and Hugh Kilpatrick Webster, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Raymond Joyce Jr. of Washington, have announced. Mr. Webster is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Drury Webster of Bethesda, Md.

LEAD: In the heart of the sleepy village in ''The Starry Night'' is a Dutch church that van Gogh transposed to the south of France. Its interior is black, its steeple as protective and forbidding as a lance. Although the steeple is a lightning rod for the wave of light flowing across the pre-dawn sky, the church is untouched by the sea of energy and light bolting and spiraling through the cosmic night.
LEAD: The United State Postal Service, in a rush of marketing enthusiasm, has announced new issues for the next few months that include two popular themes: movie stars and sports heroes.

LEAD: Would you have changed your Superbowl bet if you had learned that Joe Montana wasn't going to start for the San Francisco '49ers? Would the German Army have amassed forces at the Normandy beaches had it known that Gen. George Patton was commanding the invasion? Would you like to know that Peter Lynch, the superstar manager in charge of Fidelity's Magellan Fund, was moving to Fund

LEAD: Basketball DePaul 64, Notre Dame 59: David Booth scored his team's first 14 points in leading DePaul to victory yesterday in Rosemont, Ill., as the two Midwest independent rivals battled for a possible at-large berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament.(AP) Michigan 127, Iowa 96: Michigan, playing in Ann Arbor, set a scoring record for Crisler Arena.

LEAD: I have taken over a basement room in which someone who lived here before had left a Ping-Pong table. It is now my sewing room. The table is just the right height for me, and I can spread out the fabric on its expanse of dark green when I cut out things. It's quiet there. I listen to the radio and work away, and a flat piece of cloth takes on shape as I work, grows breast-shaped curves and hips, gathers itself into a waistband, to which I have added an inch because I am fatter than I wish

LEAD: The first of a new generation of yachts that will compete for the America's Cup is being launched this month in Europe. American efforts, stalled, with no plans yet to start construction for a 1992 cup event.

LEAD: A Soviet satirist, Mikhail Zhvanetsky, is a keen observer of life in his country and the United States. Following are excerpts from an essay he wrote for Literaturnaya Gazeta. It was reprinted in the February issue of Literary Gazette, an English-language version of the Soviet newspaper.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Among the GTE Academic all-America men's basketball players named Friday were Alex Kessler of the University of Georgia and Philip Hutcheson of David Lipscomb College, both repeat first-team selections in the university and college divisions.

LEAD: Syracuse was ranked No. 1 in the nation in January when Villanova defeated the Orangemen at the Carrier Dome. The Wildcats snapped the Orangemen's winning streak at six games in February in Philadelphia.

LEAD: THERE is a story, possibly apocryphal, of the novice cook who put a chicken in the oven to roast. After about 20 minutes, a revolting stench began to fill the kitchen. It turned out that this newcomer to the culinary arts did not know enough to remove the package of innards tucked inside the bird.
LEAD: TAKING SHELTER By Jessica Anderson. 232 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: SINCE F. W. de Klerk became President of South Africa six months ago, he has taken bold steps to turn away from the dead end of apartheid. While he has been most visible in laying the groundwork for negotiations with the country's black majority, he has also been working in the mine field of white politics.

LEAD: For This Week: It is early to plant if the soil is too heavy to dig and rake. Keep off the lawn if it is wet and soggy; allow the soil to dry thoroughly before using spreaders. Turn seedlings growing indoors near window sills so they do not bend toward the light. If seedlings are growing under lights do not forget to use half-rate, water-soluble fertilizer weekly.
LEAD: Maya Angelou was no stranger to the 700 people who listened to her speech at Centenary College of Louisiana here last week.

LEAD: FOR the last five or six years local planning boards in the New York metropolitan area have been too busy wrangling with builders, worrying about the voters and wrestling with a host of new state environmental protection laws to think through a coherent new vision of the future of their communities.

LEAD: IT has been one of the most reviled buildings in the city's history, denounced as an eyesore and officially slated for demolition for three-quarters of a century until it was declared a landmark in 1984.

LEAD: ''WE were young and strong and we knew we were going to live forever,'' recalls one of the Tuskegee Airmen. Looking back with pride and bravado, but not in anger, three legendary and yet unsung heroes recall their wartime glory - and how it was suppressed.

LEAD: Uproar in Jerusalem The American assertion that Jerusalem's eastern, Arab sector should be treated the same as the West Bank has brought a wave of condemnation from Israelis, including the city's Mayor. Page 3. Romanian Voice of Hope A clergyman who helped spark the Romanian revolt in December says he is optimistic that centrists can overcome ''the apparatus men'' left over from Communist rule.

LEAD: A number of sweeping decisions by state courts are forcing legislatures to develop new systems for financing public schools in an attempt to remedy the disparities between rich and poor school districts.

LEAD: IN a crack-plagued Bronx neighborhood, public school students wear uniforms proudly. At a Bedford-Stuyvesant high school ringed by poverty, students know to leave their gold jewelry and the removable gold jackets for their teeth at home. And in a handful of New York City high schools, students routinely submit to metal-detector searches for weapons.
LEAD: 'THE Great American Backstage Musical'' begins in 1939 and ends in 1945 in Johnny's Bar, where having a fancy drink means putting olives in your beer.

LEAD: While most American universities are making control of on-campus drinking the concern of administrators, Haverford College has ratified a policy that puts responsible drinking in students' hands.

LEAD: The final days of 1989 brought with them the end of the Communist era. The system that had proclaimed itself the future of the world was buried in the ashes of burning Romanian towns. No doubt there will still be police and military relapses, no doubt various epigones of Communism will still tantalize with their baubles and sow dissension with their calumnies.

LEAD: One problem with long-term, fixed-rate mortgages is that most homeowners sell their houses long before their loans are repaid. This, in turn, forces them to pay higher interest rates for the first years than with an adjustable-rate mortgage. But if they have a short-term, adjustable-rate loan and decide not to move after all they usually must pay several thousand dollars in refinancing costs when obtaining a new mortgage, and sometimes face major increases in interest rates as well.

LEAD: LIFE was tough last week in Michael Rossi's sociology class at Hastings-on-Hudson High School. Kevin Gannon and Ruchi Khurana discovered their son, Peter, had a hole in his heart and would need major surgery. Bronwyn Fisher and Matt Bucko found their infant daughter, Jessica, dead of ''SIDS.''

LEAD: John Fletcher, Clarkson's star goalie, made one mistake tonight that gave Colgate a score and ultimately a 5-3 victory over the Golden Knights in an ECAC Hockey tournament semifinal game at Boston Garden.

LEAD: HACIENDA DON EMILIO in downtown Stamford has so much space, with several tiered dining areas (divided into smoking and non-smoking sections) and so many tables and staff, that it smacks of an upscale, slicker version of a mass-feed chain.

LEAD: A newborn boy was discovered yesterday morning only an inch from the blade of a garbage compactor when the caretaker of a Brooklyn housing project heard the infant's cries over the whine of the machine, the police said.
LEAD: Three young children, including a brother and sister, were killed last night in an apartment fire in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, police and fire officials reported.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Madden of Ross, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lynne Marie Madden to Paul Harrington McDonough, a son of William J. McDonough of Chicago and Joyce Harrington Thompson of Brooklyn. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: A fire Friday morning destroyed the sprawling lakeside house where Jim Bakker, the former television evangelist, once lived. Officials searched the ruins, but no one was found, and the police said neighbors had told them no one had been there recently.
LEAD: Willy Brandt took the East Germany election campaign onto Polish soil today to assure Poland that most Germans do not question its right to live in areas that were German until 1945.

LEAD: It doesn't take long for the 17,000 people in the audience at Kansas City's Kemper Auditorium, mostly blond teen-age girls heavy on the mousse, to go haywire. LEAD: The words are familiar: ''I didn't get up one morning and say, ''I think I'll become a drug addict,' the way someone decides to be a fireman or a doctor. No one wants to become an addict. But once I got sucked up into the drug habit, I didn't know how to stop. I didn't know where to go for help.''

LEAD: LIKE many other Americans, I have had an interest in world affairs, but never as much as now, after having spent three weeks as a student in a Moscow high school.

LEAD: For the Rangers, the game did not exactly add momentum to their march to first place. The point in the standing produced by their 2-2 draw today with the Minnesota North Stars, though, did provide another step in the right direction.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York said today that personal attacks on Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri for criticizing President Bush's policy toward Eastern Europe were part of a Republican pattern of evading major issues.

LEAD: In response to Robert Figlerski's essay, ''Encouraging a Healthy Life Style,'' R. S. McCord recommends ''eliminating the medical fringe.'' This response is simplistic and naive. The health care system in this country is both complex and complicated.
LEAD: NOTES OF A HANGING JUDGE Essays and Reviews, 1979-1989. By Stanley Crouch. 275 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

LEAD: Q. The ceiling of our unheated basement is insulated with fiberglass that has an R-13 rating. These fiberglass batts have a vapor barrier that faces the heated first floor above the basement. The fiberglass now fills most of the space between the joists, but we want to add more insulation to this ceiling.
LEAD: THE last few years have witnessed a rise in the number of developments offering buyers the opportunity to acquire plots on which they can create their dream houses in compatible settings.
LEAD: ''LOVE AFFAIR'' isn't strong enough; the automobile is part of the American identity. And more and more it looks like the Mr. Hyde part.

LEAD: The Defense Minister, Adm. Theodor Hoffmann, conceded on Friday that ''signs of dissolution'' existed in the military, but said an overwhelming majority of his forces were carrying out their duties responsibly, particularly those linked to East Germany's obligations under the Warsaw Pact.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Gustin Jr. of Wellesley, Mass., have announced the engagement of his daughter, Lisa J. Gustin, to Peter Day Fitzsimmons, a son of Thomas H. Fitzsimmons of Mansfield, Conn., and the late Virginia Day Fitzsimmons. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: Rich Gedman, the Boston catcher who has forgotten how to hit, suffered the maximum 20 percent pay cut this year, his salary plummeting from $1.15 million to $920,000. Life wasn't always so cruel to Gedman. In 1988, he batted .231 and drove in 39 runs and got a raise, from $980,000 to $1.15 million.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Vincent Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Page Pendleton Vincent to Thomas Duncanson Walker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Walker of Barrington, R.I., and Stratton, Vt. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: With their week-old strike against Greyhound Bus Lines showing that it may be a long and bitter struggle, officials of the Amalgamated Transit Union insist that more than 7,000 union employees will be rehired no matter how the strike ends.
LEAD: NOT BY FACT ALONE Essays on the Writing and Reading of History. By John Clive. 334 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.
LEAD: THE THINGS THEY CARRIED By Tim O'Brien. 273 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Thousands of ethnic Tamils who cooperated with Indian peacekeeping forces in Sri Lanka since 1987 are fleeing to India in boats, fearing violence when New Delhi's troops leave the island at the end of this month.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: ''La Commedia e Finita - The comedy is over'': The final words of Leoncavallo's tragic opera ''I Pagliacci'' were the ones Sir Rudolf Bing chose on April 22, 1972, to ring down the curtain on his lordly and controversial 22-year tenure as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera. A drama was indeed ending, but it was hardly the last that awaited Sir Rudolf, who could not have anticipated the quintessentially operatic tangle of tragedy and farce that lay ahead.

LEAD: President Bush and many officials in his Administration say they are deeply disappointed by the failure of the Chinese Government to relax its repressive rule in response to numerous conciliatory gestures by Mr. Bush.
LEAD: A BLUE FIRE Selected Writings. By James Hillman. Edited by Thomas Moore with the author. 323 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

LEAD: IN a single day of balloting last month, Nicaraguan voters tore the heart out of the Sandinista Government: its claim to represent the will of the Nicaraguan people. The transformation was nothing Sandinista leaders had imagined last year when, to repair their international image, they accepted calls to hold free, closely supervised elections.
LEAD: AT THE GATES OF THE ANIMAL KINGDOM By Amy Hempel. 137 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

LEAD: It is down, down, down for the British pound, which has fallen more than nine cents, to $1.6160, in the last two weeks. The Bank of England was in the foreign exchange market Friday buying the sagging sterling, which until several weeks ago had been one of the surprise strong currencies of the year.

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has warned that it will discipline any employee found to have disclosed information about the suspension of an agent in a case said to involve allegations of spying for Cuba.

LEAD: It seems to me that Barbara S. Cain's article ''Older Children and Divorce'' (Feb. 18) does not add anything new to that tired subject. We all know that everyone suffers in a divorce. However, everyone suffers growing up. The young people mentioned in your article might have had different problems in nondivorcing families, but problems they would have had.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: COMPANIES The Great American Express Cut-Rate Buyback Finally, the American Express Company has found a way to come out ahead at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. But it's at the expense of Shearson shareholders. In 1987, American Express sold the public a minority interest in Shearson at $34 a share.
LEAD: A fraternity at the State University of New York at Binghamton that was suspended last April after a rape investigation is fighting the suspension in court.

LEAD: Robert E. Coker, the project superintendent at the paper plant expansion in this tiny town just outside Savannah, thinks Sheryl T. Hamlett is a terrific carpenter's helper. She works hard, takes classes on her own time and never balks at working late or weekends. She is, he said, ''one of the best workers we've got.

LEAD: After reading the two articles on housing in your Feb. 18 edition [''Housing Forum Presses Its Effort at Local Level'' and ''Union Housing Offer Attracts No Takers''] , I felt compelled to write in with my thoughts on that familiar Westchester oxymoron - ''affordable housing.''

LEAD: For Americans everywhere, the news from abroad in recent months has been both dazzling and disorienting.

LEAD: A relay of troopers from two states rushed a heart to a 13-year-old transplant patient Friday after fog forced doctors to land at an airport 50 miles away. Three doctors flying the heart from Tulsa, Okla., to Detroit had to land in Toledo, Ohio.

LEAD: Peter Sellars has been named the artistic adviser to the Boston Opera Theater, a company that is planning to begin operations in December 1991.

LEAD: It is early morning, Jan. 25, 1989, and the caravan - my ''60 Minutes'' camera crew and assorted hangers-on - is waiting at the Majestic Hotel in Ho Chi Minh City. Huang Mai Huong, my guide-interpreter, is looking very smug. ''Miss Mai,'' as I call her, has been wedding shopping in Ho Chi Minh City, which to someone from Hanoi is the equivalent of Hong Kong or Bangkok.

LEAD: THERE is a tendency among some thoughtful Germans to lament this winter's developments as a noble revolution gone tawdry. It is as if the purity of that night four months ago when Germans laughed and danced at the newly opened Berlin wall has been defiled by politics, commercialism, nationalism and intrigue.
LEAD: Tea and toast are usually all I can take for breakfast in the comfort of home, when what I really want is an excuse to put off going to work.

LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke signaled the start of a new era of cooperation with the Board of Legislators last week in a sharply detailed State of the County address that recommended major changes in Westchester's tax collection and spending procedures.
LEAD: The beaver, the official mammal of New York, is flourishing so well that it is considered a nuisance in some parts of the state.

Wilson. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop and the Rev. Sydney A. Woodd- Cahousac performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE effort to save Long Island Sound demands more aggressive action by state and Federal environmental agencies as well as a commitment by industries to obey clean-water laws, says a study by the Connecticut Public Interest Research Group. LEAD: My heart goes out to the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. Taken over in a leveraged buyout; junk bonds sinking; publicly blasted into dropping its plan to make a pitch to sell its products to blacks. Nobody seems willing to walk a few steps, much less a mile, for a Camel.

LEAD: The pompous new head of a British intelligence service sends a top deskman to make a tour of various installations and pep them up. This is against all rules. Top deskmen are not supposed to be in the field. They know too much, and if they are captured and tortured, operatives may die and services may be compromised.
LEAD: CINNABAR A Novel of China. By Robert B. Oxnam. 322 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/ St. Martin's Press. $18.95.

LEAD: THE BEST OF ABBIE HOFFMAN. Edited by Daniel Simon with Abbie Hoffman. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $21.95.) At the Chicago conspiracy trial 20 years ago, the judge gently scolded Tom Hayden: ''Fellows as smart as you could do awfully well under [the American] system.'' Those words would have been lost on Abbie Hoffman, who remained, in his actions and, as this book shows, in his writings, incorrigibly and imaginatively subversive to the end.

LEAD: Some theatrical spaces enhance choreography. Others serve as purely neutral containers for it. Still others seem absolutely hostile to any form of dancing that might take place in them. One space of the last type is surely the Great Hall at Cooper Union, where on Thursday night Patricia Cremins and Wyoming, her New York-based company, presented ''Landing With and Without the Map.

LEAD: The National Football League completed its television package for its international venture yesterday, agreeing to a four-year contract with the USA cable network, which guarantees that all World League of American Football games involving United States teams will be shown in the United States.

LEAD: During the eight years of the bitter Iran-Iraq War, no place was harder hit than Basra, Iraq's chief port and second-largest city, which, owing to casualties and citizens fleeing the siege, saw its population, once more than a million, diminish by half. LEAD: In ''The Graduate,'' Dustin Hoffman's character, Ben, is given a single word of career advice by a friend of his parents: Plastics. Presumably Ben ignored the suggestion, but by the time the film was made, in 1967, the Italian-born guitarist and instrument-maker Mario Maccaferri had proved the value of that advice, having made his fortune manufacturing plastic ukeleles, hangers, clothespins and tape cassettes.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Saturday night is the peak of the weekend - the high point of our precious time off (''Saturday Night,'' by Susan Orlean, Feb. 11). It's no wonder we embrace it as our most celebrated evening of the week.

LEAD: FENCING, says a student of the sport, combines cunning and speed with ''cloaked aggressiveness.'' Like chess, swordplay requires a strategy: like tennis or boxing, it demands both physical prowess and mental agility.

LEAD: Striking teachers in West Virginia's 55 counties began voting today on whether to go back to the classroom on Monday in return for a promise by Gov. Gaston Caperton to resume talks over a pay increase and not to discipline strikers.

LEAD: White House Suspicions may have begun to percolate when someone noticed that the number supposedly left by the President of Iran had a Cleveland area code or some such. But what the heck, President Bush has often said he would talk to ''anyone, anytime'' about freeing American hostages in the Middle East.
